text:
Overview

Program Description

Electric utilities worldwide consistently report that power quality (PQ) is a fundamental component of three key utility business performance metrics: grid system performance, utility economic performance, and customer satisfaction. A resurgence of interest in electric power quality performance is being driven by the need to increase the economic performance of existing infrastructure, reduce the cost of grid operations and repairs, manage and respond to increasing grid complexity, and retain existing and attract new load with excellent PQ performance and related customer support.

Research Value

With this program, members will have access to research results that can help them in the following ways:

  • Expert analysis tools will improve methods for estimating future grid PQ harmonics, flicker, and other PQ phenomena on modern utility systems in the context of changing grid configurations and load behaviors.

  • Through EPRI’s lab testing, new PQ-enabled, grid-connected devices can be assessed and improved to provide actionable PQ data.

  • Based on EPRI laboratory testing, an updated library of end-use and distributed energy resources (DER) models could be created that would allow assessment of the PQ impact of different and changing load configurations.

  • Benchmarking of system performance can be improved through development of updated benchmarking methods based on more robust PQ severity metrics and experience from recent and previous EPRI studies.

  • The development of methods such as innovative data visualization techniques, data validation techniques, and open-source data management and visualization platforms can help modern utilities get the maximum value from grid data streams.

  • PQ data can be integrated with other data sources to monitor the health of grid-connected equipment and, where possible, to detect incipient issues before failure or undue impact on grid performance. EPRI’s proven expertise can be leveraged in the development of methodologies for identifying key signature characteristics in PQ data and waveform recognition techniques to identify problems before they become catastrophes.

  • Highly cost-effective prevention of PQ compatibility issues will be facilitated through the development of key industry standards to increase compatibility between electric power and customer loads, principally through active support of the International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC), International Council on Large Electric Systems (CIGRE), and the Institute for Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) standards committees.

  • Utility PQ teams are directly supported by access to more than 900 EPRI-authored PQ technical documents and other resources via the MyPQ.epri.com website, and by expert advice on specific PQ-related problems from more than 60 EPRI PQ experts via the EPRI PQ Hotline. Lessons learned from support for the problems and questions raised are incorporated back into EPRI's PQ body of knowledge to be used to improve grid level power quality on a national basis.  

The Power Quality research program offers fundamental insights on electrical grid power quality and compatibility to improve the value of electricity service for society.

Approach

The Power Quality research program places a very high priority on funder input, prioritization, and collaboration, with active funders providing guidance on research priorities. EPRI research in power quality will yield a variety of expertise, software, analysis tools, and knowledge that will be beneficial to program members. This information will be offered in several forms and is expected to include the following:

  • Software tools for analysis of T&D PQ phenomena and tools that enable scenario analysis of future PQ levels based on changing grid configurations, operational practices, and changing connected load and DER.

  • PQ data validation and visualization tools that maximize the value of data stores while reducing the cost of using and maintaining them.

  • Laboratory assessment of the PQ contribution and compatibility of DER, including renewables, energy storage, and smart inverters.

  • Laboratory and field assessment of PQ mitigation technologies and end-use device sensitivity to common PQ phenomena.

Accomplishments

The Power Quality program has delivered valuable research over the years that has helped its members, the industry, and society:

  • EPRI created the best-in-class PQ Investigator software integrating $2M in end-use device testing and facility investigation results and expertise, allowing funders to conduct expert-level facility assessments.

  • EPRI created the first of its kind Grid-IQ software platform for estimating future PQ performance levels based on changing loads, grid configurations, and operational practices, including an open-source-based grid model database to allow quick and low-cost analysis. Most prominent among these tools are the Harmonic Evaluation Module (HEM) and Flicker Evaluation Module (FEM), tools which allow analysis of current conditions and modeling of future conditions based on changes in grid configurations and end-use loads.

  • EPRI's laboratory testing of many end-use technologies has enabled the development of a detailed load model library for new and changing loads such as compact fluorescent lamps (CFLs), light-emitting diode (LED) traffic lights, hybrid electric vehicle chargers, and rooftop photovoltaics (PVs).

  • EPRI created the PQ Dashboard, a low-cost, easy-to-deploy open source platform for visualization of PQ and other data and integration with other data resources including Geographic Information System (GIS) information.

  • Many of EPRI’s past research developments have been implemented over time into PQView®, a multi-component software system for building and analyzing databases of power quality and energy measurements that is jointly owned by EPRI and Electrotek Concepts.

  • The Power Quality Online Resource Center, deployed on MyPQ.epri.com, is a member-focused website featuring more than 900 EPRI-authored PQ case studies, technology briefs, and other authoritative documents available from no other source.

Key Activities

In the coming year, this research program expects to accomplish these objectives:

  • Develop readily deployable data analysis modules for near-time assessment using PQ data of the health and detection of incipient failure for common grid-connected equipment.

  • Migrate the Harmonics Evaluation Module to an Open Source platform.

  • Develop enhancements to the Flicker Evaluation Module, including more advanced models of flicker-producing loads and enhanced reporting features, and migrate the application to an iPad-compatible app.

  • Make improvements to the PQ Dashboard environment, including advanced data visualization and data validation capabilities.

  • Perform laboratory testing for accuracy, precision, and usability of the PQ monitoring capabilities of non-PQ devices.

  • Evaluate the PQ sensitivities and contribution of new advanced manufacturing technologies as well as new DER technology such as Smart Inverters.

  • Assess the PQ contribution, integration, and management challenges of DER, including rooftop PV, energy storage, and smart inverters.

  • Enhance search capability for the MyPQ.epri.com website, including additional technical resources for the PQ Online Resource Center comprising more than 900 documents.

Estimated 2017 Program Funding
$2.5M
Program Manager
William Howe, 720-565-6888, bhowe@epri.com

Last Updated
  • PS1A: Improving PQ in Transmission and Distribution
    05-May-2016

    This project set focuses on PQ issues and opportunities for transmission and distribution networks. Power quality is a key electric grid performance metric and through improved understanding of PQ performance, this project set seeks to maximize the value of grid investments by helping to manage the inevitable consequences of increasing grid complexity. PS1A develops and supports unique tools for improving PQ management and analysis, including the Harmonics Evaluation Module and the Flicker Evaluation Module. Both of these tools enable unique scenario-analysis capabilities that not only help in understanding today’s PQ challenges, but also help to prevent future PQ issues through expert analysis. In addition, PS1A seeks to leverage PQ expertise by employing advance data analysis techniques to monitor the health and performance of grid-connected assets and to detect problems using PQ data streams before they become costly failures.

    Among this project set’s key attributes:

    • Estimates future harmonics, flicker, and other PQ phenomena using a growing library of advanced grid and load models.

    • Supports deployment of advanced algorithms to detect incipient grid performance issues using PQ data.

    • Applies to any utility that operates T&D infrastructure anywhere in the world, and is especially timely for any utility actively pursuing smart-, micro-, and integrated-grid technologies.

    The Key Research Questions are:

    • How can power quality (PQ) levels, such as harmonics, be modeled for the transmission and distribution system in the context of changing grid configurations, end-use loads, distributed energy resources, and microgrids? How can responsibility be assigned to different customers for harmonic distortion on a particular feeder?

    • What techniques can be applied to model and evaluate, and ultimately anticipate and mitigate voltage flicker, thereby enabling utilities to improve the quality of delivered electric service to customers?

    • What analysis tools can be developed to identify potential PQ-related performance issues or equipment failures before interruptions occur to maintain or increase reliability?

    • P1.001: PQ Issues and Solutions for Transmission and Distribution
      15-Jun-2016

      This project develops expert tools for detailed and efficient scenario analysis of grid harmonics and other PQ phenomena based on grid configurations, operational practices, and integration of new or changing complex loads and distributed energy resources (DER). The ability to allocate harmonics responsibility to different point sources is an important new feature. This project also develops and executes techniques for estimating future grid harmonics and other PQ levels through the application of grid models based on changing grid configurations and end-use loads.

      Key research questions being addressed by this project include: How can power quality (PQ) levels, such as harmonics and voltage flicker be modeled for the transmission and distribution system in the context of changing grid configurations, end-use loads, distributed energy resources, and microgrids? How can responsibility be assigned to different customers for harmonic distortion on a particular feeder? How can a utility quickly determine present and future compliance with harmonic and voltage flicker standards and, through scenario analysis, identify issues and best methods for prevention/mitigation in advance?

    • P1.002: Advanced PQ Analytics and Applications for Transmission and Distribution
      15-Jun-2016

      Harmonics at the transmission and distribution levels are of concern with increasing grid complexity, expansion of renewables, and connection of increasingly electronic loads. Modern electric utilities need sophisticated tools and strategies to allow guided analytics – tools that provide for analysis, guidelines, and solutions to common and new harmonics issues.

      Key research questions being addressed by this project include: How can new loads be integrated with good certainty that harmonics levels will not be exceeded? What impact will new renewables have on grid harmonics levels? What techniques can be applied to model and evaluate and ultimately anticipate and mitigate harmonics, thereby enabling utilities to improve the quality of delivered electric service to customers?

    • P1.003: Support and Development of PQ Analysis Tools
      15-Jun-2016

      This project will continue the development of tools and techniques for using PQ data, and especially waveform data, to identify performance issues or incipient equipment failure before expensive interruptions occur and emergency repairs are required. The project will emphasize automated approaches for data analysis and notification of identified issues.

      Key research questions being addressed by this project include: How can utilities better use PQ data resources for detecting incipient failure of grid-connected equipment? What analysis tools can be developed to identify potential PQ-related performance issues or equipment failures before interruptions occur to maintain or increase reliability?

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • PS1B: Integrating PQ Monitoring and Intelligent Applications to Maximize System Performance
    05-May-2016

    This project set focuses on techniques and resources for gathering, processing, and reporting many types of data and, in particular, power quality (PQ) data. Improved acquisition, storage, analysis, and visualization of PQ data are very highly leveraged activities that can provide benefits greatly exceeding cost.

    • Application and analysis of PQ and other data resources is perhaps the fastest and lowest-cost way to enhance value for proven grid operations and analysis.

    • Understanding new and evolving PQ data sources (such as relays, switches, and smart meters) is essential for the modern electric utility

    • Utilities are faced with a “data tsunami” that this project set is working to anticipate and manage through data integration, validation, and visualization tools. 

    Key research questions for this project set are:

    • How can power quality data be quickly and efficiently integrated and visualized to inform utility decision-making to support the operation of transmission and distribution systems?

    • How can utilities quickly and efficiently acquire, store, and validate the accuracy and precision of PQ data? What methods can enable the most value from new and existing data management processes?

    • How can PQ data be most effectively and efficiently acquired and visualized so that utilities have a granular few of power quality from the entire grid?

    • P1.004: Open PQ Dashboard 2017
      15-Jun-2016

      In this project, EPRI will expand the ability to visualize PQ data through further development of the PQ Dashboard data visualization platform, enabling low-cost, open source deployment of visualized data to a variety of audiences.

      Key research questions being addressed by this project include: How can power quality data be quickly and efficiently integrated and visualized to inform utility decision-making to support the operation of transmission and distribution systems? How can utilities extend the value of their investment in PQ monitoring and data acquisition by making selected PQ data visualizations available to management, key accounts, and selected end-use customers?

    • P1.005:PQMark-Alpha, Cloud-Based PQ Benchmarking
      15-Jun-2016

      This research focuses on increasing the value of PQ monitoring systems and the data gathered thereby through the development of advanced data validation algorithms and data quality management. Once created, these algorithms will be deployed using the PQ Dashboard platform for application by funders.

      Key research questions being addressed by this project include: How can utilities know that the gigabytes of data that they have acquired and stored—at considerable expense—are valid and of high quality? How can utilities quickly and efficiently acquire, store, and validate the accuracy and precision of PQ data? What methods can enable the most value from new and existing data management processes?

    • P1.006: Monitoring System Development and Management
      15-Jun-2016

      This project researches new, advanced features and capabilities for data acquisition systems and sensors, with a particular focus on validating the integrity of PQ measurements and data provided by nontraditional sources such as relays, switches, and other grid-connected devices.

      Key research questions being addressed by this project include: How can utilities have confidence in PQ data from nontraditional sources, such as relays, switches, and even smart meters? How can existing PQ data sources be assessed and future PQ data sources be specified so as to optimize accuracy, precision, and overall value? How can utilities be enabled to undertake these investigations themselves, rather than relying only on expensive outside resources?

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • PS1C: Achieving Cost-Effective PQ Compatibility Between the Electrical System and Loads
    18-May-2016

    This project set helps EPRI members achieve electrical compatibility between the power system and edge-of-grid equipment including end-use customers. Power quality mitigation solutions significantly reduce electrical disturbances at the transmission, distribution, and end-use levels by integrating advanced energy storage technologies with power electronics. This work comprises detailed examination and understanding of the PQ implications of distributed energy resources (DER) and microgrids, as well as other edge-of-grid innovations. This project set is also creating a library of end-use and DER models, which may allow assessment of the PQ impact of different and changing load configurations.

    Key research questions for this project set are as follows:

    • How can utilities understand, influence, and anticipate the sensitivity of new, changing, and emerging loads to common PQ phenomena? What will be the impact on grid PQ of new loads?

    • Can the power quality impacts of emerging end-use loads and DER and microgrids be modeled and evaluated under a variety of load configurations to predict future grid power quality conditions? How can utilities best prepare for the inevitable compatibility and operational issues that will emerge from an increasingly complex grid?

    • How can utilities develop a thorough understanding of the PQ benefits and vulnerabilities of advanced grid applications?

    • P1.007: System Compatibility Research
      15-Jun-2016

      This project seeks to expand our understanding of the sensitivity of new end-use loads to common PQ phenomena and the impact on edge-of-grid PQ caused by new and changing loads, with a particular focus on new advanced manufacturing devices and systems.

      Key research questions being addressed by this project include the following: How can utilities understand edge-of-grid PQ and how this serves and is influenced by new loads? How can utilities understand, influence, and anticipate the sensitivity of new, changing, and emerging loads to common PQ phenomena? What will be the impact on grid PQ of new loads?

    • P1.008: Impact Assessment and Modeling of Grid-Connected Loads and Power Supplies
      15-Jun-2016

      The project seeks to improve our understanding of both the PQ benefits and vulnerabilities of DER, microgrids, and other edge-of-grid innovations. It also seeks to advance capabilities for recognizing and resolving new PQ issues resulting from DER, microgrid, and similar innovations.

      Key research questions being addressed by this project include: How can utilities anticipate the PQ impact of rooftop photovoltaics (PV), hybrid electric vehicle (HEV) chargers, energy storage, and other edge-of-grid distributed energy resources (DER) and microgrids? Can the power quality impacts of emerging end-use loads and DER be modeled and evaluated under a variety of load configurations to predict future grid power quality conditions? How can utilities best prepare for the inevitable compatibility and operational issues that will emerge from an increasingly complex grid?

    • P1.009: Facility Load Integration for System Compatibility
      15-Jun-2016

      This project will evaluate both the potential PQ benefits and vulnerabilities of key enabling edge-of-grid technologies for advanced grid applications such as microgrids, with particular focus on smart inverters, microgrid controllers, hybrid electriv vehicle (HEV) chargers, and other emerging technologies .

      Key research questions being addressed by this project include the following: How can utilities maximize the PQ benefits of DER and microgrid innovations while minimizing and quickly solving negative impacts? How can utilities develop a thorough understanding of the PQ benefits and vulnerabilities of advanced grid applications?

Overview

Program Description

Electricity is the only widely available and domestically produced form of energy for transportation that addresses the simultaneous needs for fuel diversity, energy security, reduced greenhouse gas emissions, and improved air quality. The transition of transportation energy from petroleum to electricity represents a paradigm shift for electric utilities to the role of fuel provider for vehicles. It also represents a significant opportunity for electric utilities.

To help advance the use of electricity as a transportation fuel, the EPRI Electric Transportation program conducts research and development on electric vehicle and infrastructure technologies, analyzes the economic and environmental impacts of electric transportation, and supports industry and utility programs to build public awareness of as well as foundational work supporting electric transportation in the public interest. 

The early market for electric vehicles (EVs) has been characterized by modest but steadily increasing sales, high vehicle reliability and customer satisfaction, and a rapid evolution of both vehicle and charging technologies. Compared to the first mass-produced EVs, new vehicle models can charge at faster rates and travel with greater range per charge. A variety of EV models ranging from sedans to bucket trucks are seeing increased usage in fleet applications. In addition, public charging infrastructure to support EVs is expanding, with the installation of thousands of public and workplace charging stations. A fast-charging network is also beginning to emerge, using direct current (DC) electricity at levels of 50 kW to 120 kW to charge EVs in as little as 20 minutes. In addition, automotive manufacturers have developed the first production charging systems that enable EVs to potentially interact with the grid. By the end of Mayl 2016, total U.S. EV sales exceeded 400,000 vehicles and more than 20 EV models were available from 11 manufacturers, including five of the six largest U.S. automotive manufacturers. Another 33 EV models are scheduled to be launched by the end of 2019.

 

Nearly all major automakers are reaching out to the utility industry to help develop and standardize EV charging infrastructure and to help educate their mutual customer. The customer, meanwhile, is also looking to the utility for guidance as an impartial trusted energy advisor. Residential, commercial, and industrial customers –, fleet managers, employers, retail stores, developers, local governments, and others – are seeking guidance on the design, location, and installation of charging infrastructure. Utilities need to understand the system impacts and customer requirements associated with plug-in vehicles, and prepare their grid to support the rollout and adoption of EVs. This program helps utilities address these challenges.  

Business customers are also looking to utilities for help in quantifying the value of incorporating EVs into their vehicle fleets in both on-road and non-road operations to offset high fuel costs, improve operating efficiencies, meet environmental requirements, and enhance customer satisfaction. This program equips utilities to conduct such evaluations.

Research Value

For more than a decade, the EPRI Electric Transportation program has played a leading role in the advancement of EV technologies that are at the forefront of automotive industry development efforts. EPRI also serves as a focal point of collaboration between the automotive and utility industries for the development of infrastructure standards, vehicle demonstration programs, and advanced infrastructure technologies. EPRI’s commercial and industrial electric transportation efforts have demonstrated the cost-effective use of battery electric vehicles in numerous commercial and industrial applications, and serve as the technical foundation for successful, customer-focused utility commercial and industrial electric transportation market expansion programs.

Approach

EPRI research in electric transportation yields data and knowledge beneficial to members of the program. This information is delivered in a number of forms and is expected to include the following:

  • Facilitated collaboration between the utility industry and the major automotive manufacturers, EV infrastructure equipment suppliers, infrastructure operators, and public agencies.
  • Analysis of the grid impacts of EV charging to utility systems.
  • Utility-specific analyses on potential EV market size, load shape and requirements, customer expectations, infrastructure requirements, and other material required to support internal utility EV readiness or mainstreaming programs.
  • Testing and evaluation of EVs and EV charging equipment; data collection and analysis of real-world EV operation in utility fleet and other applications.
  • Formation of major vehicle and infrastructure demonstration initiatives to collect and analyze real-world operating data on the latest vehicle and infrastructure technologies.
  • Development of advanced charging technologies that enable integration of EVs into the utility smart grid.
  • Enhancement of commercial and industrial electric transportation applications and markets through field demonstration and technology development and assessment.
  • Validation of the economic and environmental benefits (including greenhouse gas emissions) of EVs to the utility, utility customers, and their communities.

  • General
    • Gave quarterly Electric Transportation program and EV market updates
    • Published quarterly Electric Transportation newsletters
    • Formalized and published Electric Transportation hotline summaries
    • Wrote quick response summaries for important Electric Transportation news

  • EV Technology and Market Development

    • Created easy-to-read consumers’ guide to EV charging infrastructure
    • Researched status of EV battery technology and wrote update
    • Actively participated in Department of Energy’s multi-industry EV workgroups
    • Served as utility member of Department of Energy multi-industry cradle-to-grave emissions study
  • Commercial and Industrial Electric Transportation
    • Held public bus and truck infrastructure and charging meeting (three annual meetings)
    • Provided input and leadership into bus and truck charging standards for the good of the public
    • Released easy-to-read guide to commercial and industrial electric vehicles
    • Wrote 10 one-page fact sheets on commercial and industrial technologies
    • Provided technical assessment of electric transport refrigeration units (eTRU)
    • Wrote overview of marine technology and did two case studies
  • Electric Transportation Systems, Infrastructure, and Readiness
    • Held public Infrastructure Working Council (IWC) meetings (three annual meetings) with summary report
    • Monitored status and market entry of EV charging infrastructure and networks
    • Shared data and tables for EPRI-NRDC “Environmental Assessment of a Full Transportation Electrification Portfolio”
    • Provided input and leadership into low and high power AC and DC charging standards for the good of the public
    • Created on-demand GIS mapping of charging infrastructure and calculated projections for charging infrastructure
  • Advanced Electric Transportation Infrastructure
    • Created “hotspotter” tool that allows utilities to model impact of EV adoption on distribution circuits up to the transformer
    • Conducted advanced infrastructure testing of a vehicle-to-home (V2H) device
    • Prioritized and developed key smart charging use cases with utility and automotive OEMs
    • Wrote technical report on state of vehicle-to-grid (V2G)
  • Supplemental Projects
    • Together with the National Resources Defense Council (NRDC), performed a detailed environmental assessment including greenhouse gases and air quality of a full electric transportation portfolio
    • Developed and managed a nationwide medium- and heavy-duty plug-in truck and van demonstration consisting of 296 vehicles at 62 companies in 26 states and provinces
    • Co-wrote with EEI  four case studies on utility EV programs
    • Developed open vehicle-grid-integration platform together with seven automakers and six utilities to create foundation for standards-based geographic smart charging

  • PS18X: Market Intelligence
    02-Jun-2016

    This project set provides the fundamental market intelligence, standards support, and impartial educational tools necessary to bring the benefits of electrification to the transportation industry. 

    • P18.040: EV Market Information and Education
      15-Jun-2016

      An understanding of how the electric transportation industry is evolving is crucial for the public to efficiently adopt new technologies as they emerge.  This same understanding provides a basis for utilities to adapt their systems and operations to successfully integrate these evolving technologies as they are adopted.   

    • P18.041: Public Education and Support
      15-Jun-2016

      As the electric transportation industry evolves, conveying impartial, complete information on emerging and commercially available products is crucial to wide adoption.  This project seeks to provide public, business, utility and regulatory bodies with information on market trends and advances. 

    • P18.042: EV Industry Standards Leadership, Support and Collaboration
      15-Jun-2016

      A strong set of standards that are accepted by industry stakeholders creates the “plug and play” environment necessary for wide adoption of electric transportation technologies.  This research seeks to understand and advance those factors that produce the that environment.   

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • PS18Y: Technical Research & Development
    02-Jun-2016

    This project set concentrates on research related to short and long-term EV charging and infrastructure technology, integration of EVs and EV charging with the grid, commercial and industrial electric transportation, data collection and analysis of EV performance and driver behavior, commercial and industrial electric transportation, as well as the deep scientific understanding of the environmental impacts of EVs and related analysis.  All are needed to help provide information for utilities to make decisions in their support the EV market.

    • P18.044: EV Charging and Infrastructure Technology
      15-Jun-2016

      An understanding of how EV charging is evolving and how charging technologies effect electric utility grid operation is necessary to quickly and efficiently support adoption of electric transportation.  This project seeks to develop that understanding.

    • P18.045: EV Grid Integration
      15-Jun-2016

      The adoption of electric transportation has the potential to create reliability and safety issues for the electric utility grid which undermine the utility’s ability to provide safe and reliable electricity.  Managing how and when EVs charge helps mitigate these potential issues.  This project seeks to advance development of technologies and systems that enable that management.

    • P18.046: Commercial and Industrial Electric Transportation, Data Collection, and Analysis
      15-Jun-2016

      C&I transportation electrification is advancing but how that is happening and how electric transportation technologies are used and, more importantly charged, is not well understood.  This project seeks to understand how businesses use electric transportation

    • P18.047: Environmental Impacts and Analysis
      15-Jun-2016

      Even as electric transportation adoption is advancing, questions still remain as to the overall environmental impacts and benefits of these technologies.  This project seeks to understand those impacts and benefits   

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • PS18Z: Utility Strategic Support
    13-Jun-2016

    Utility specific electric transportation programs, provide basic information and support necessary to bring the benefits of electrification to the transportation industry. Building from the results of the other two project sets, this project set incorporates key learnings into a collection of customizable tools, data collection, and impartial analysis which enable utilities to determine the need for and develop implementable transportation programs.  The elements provided through this research are key components for decisions and development of utility-specific electric transportation strategy and provide the basis for development of related tactics that, when implemented, may advance and accelerate the adoption of electric transportation technologies and the realization of its subsequent benefits. 

    • P18.043: Localized Utility EV Infrastructure, Grid Impact, Environmental and Market Research, Analysis, and Support
      15-Jun-2016

      As electric vehicles and electric commercial and industrial transportation becomes more prevalent, an understanding of what support is necessary to advance adoption as well as potential impacts to existing grid infrastructure is necessary to bring the benefits of electrification to the transportation industry.  This project seeks to identify how support and impacts vary across utility service territories and advance understanding of effective techniques.

Overview

Program Description

Transmission companies face challenges such as improving safety and reliability, as well as reducing operations and maintenance (O&M) costs. They are also seeking ways to increase transmission capacity without making large capital investments. Reducing capital expenditures for new and refurbished equipment is also another priority.

This program is designed to address the research needs of transmission asset owners and operators. The program offers a portfolio of tools and information focused on components (e.g., conductors, insulators, compression connectors, and composite structures) and issues (e.g., lightning and grounding, live working, transmission capacity, and methods to assess the condition of overhead lines). The program delivers a blend of short-term tools such as software, reference guides, and field guides, together with longer-term research such as component-aging tests and the development of sensors for monitoring the performance of line components.

Research Value

The research results provided by the collection of projects intends to provide members with knowledge that can help with the following:

  • Management of aging transmission line components;
  • Inspection and assessment tools and techniques;
  • Lightning performance and grounding reliability;
  • Efficiency of transmission line design;
  • Working techniques, tools and procedures;
  • Methods to get more capacity out of existing overhead lines;
  • Approaches to selecting, applying, inspecting, and assessing insulators; and
  • Knowledge on emerging transmission line sensing and inspection technologies.
Approach

The EPRI research results are delivered in ways that can easily be applied to increase reliability of the system while managing costs to help keep electricity affordable. Many results can be applied immediately while other research may yield benefits over a longer time frame.  This approach is expected to offer members both short- and long-term value.

Accomplishments

The Overhead Transmission program has delivered valuable information that has helped its members and the industry in numerous ways. Some examples include:

 

  • Asset registry and data model for transmission line surge arresters and insulator. To support asset management efforts.
  • Transmission Line Workstation-Generation 2, Version 4.0. (3002007685) A software tool to examine lightning performance, audible noise, corona, ozone, and radio noise generation, as well as the electric and magnetic fields of transmission lines.
  • The Conductor Corrosion Inspection Tool, a non-contact tool to assess the condition of conductors with steel cores and steel wires.
  • Guidelines for inspecting compression connectors provides information on different technologies, their limitations and how best to apply them.
  • Insulator Reference Book (3002005685)
  • Overhead line design guide (3002005663)
  • Identifying critical defects in polymer insulators prior to energized work
Key Activities
  • Approach to advanced overhead line design
  • Asset Management Analytics;

 

Short-term research examples include:

  • Industry-wide failure databases;
  • Reference books, guidelines and field guides;
  • Online training software to help workers identify levels of component deterioration and take timely corrective action.
  • New and emerging inspection technology evaluation;
  • Methods and tools for maintenance and lifetime extensions of transmission components.

 

Medium- to long-term research examples include:

  • Component aging models;
  • Evaluation of advanced coatings for insulators and conductors;
  • Corrosion probe for sub-grade corrosion;
  • Transmission structure design guide (1024138);
  • Forecasted transmission line ratings methodologies;
  • Selection, application and maintenance of composite structures; and
  • Accelerated tests of polymer insulators.

  • P35.001: Inspection and Assessment
    02-Jun-2016

    Utilities need to understand the condition of their overhead transmission lines to effectively manage and maintain them at their designed level of performance and safety. Inspection and assessment research is needed to understand the current condition of transmission assets, extend the life of those assets while keeping the aging infrastructure performance at levels that meet safety and reliability expectations of the public.

    As assets age beyond their design margin, the ability to inspect and assess their condition becomes vital. New and emerging inspection and sensing technologies are essential to meet this challenge. As new technologies appear on the market there is a need for utilities to be aware of what they are, how they are applied and how they perform.

    In addition, new inspection and maintenance management practices and tools may be based not only on the application of advanced technologies, such as robotics and sensors but also on advancements in the understanding of how line equipment and components age and degrade.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P35.002: Conductor, Shield Wire and Hardware Corrosion Management
    02-Jun-2016

    The driving questions in fleet management of transmission lines are, how do we locate areas with a high probability of failure, what is the most cost effective approach in quantifying the present condition and how do we manage that risk.

    Atmospheric corrosion may lead to failure of conductors, shield wires, hardware, and components that result in momentary or even sustained outages. Airborne salts, acid rain, and time of wetness are the primary environmental factors controlling atmospheric corrosion severity. The effectiveness of protective systems, such as galvanized coatings, are strongly dependent upon the degradation rate of that coating and its time of service.

    Utilities need to understand the present condition of their conductors, shield wires and hardware, where these severely aged components are located, what caused the degradation, how future designs may avoid premature aging and how to forecast the replacement schedule.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P35.003: Structure and Sub-Grade Corrosion Management
    02-Jun-2016

    A federally funded study has estimated that the power generation and delivery sectors experience $5 to $10 billion of corrosion damage each year. These costs consist of property damage, penalties, loss of revenue and in some cases public or personnel safety. This project intends to manage that risk by identifying corrosion issues, characterize corrosion types, and develop appropriate corrosion management solutions.

    Utilities need to understand the present condition of their foundations, grillage, anchors and poles, the cause of degradation, how to mitigate or design around the damage and how to forecast for maintenance and replacement schedules.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P35.004: Compression Connector Management
    02-Jun-2016

    Predicting the remaining life of splice and dead-end compression connectors is a major challenge. Compression connector failures may increase with higher demand for heavier loading operations. Due to the limitations of existing inspection techniques, isolating the components early enough to avoid failure is challenging.

    Technologies currently used to inspect compression connectors are not always reliable and repeatable, and application methods and threshold levels for these technologies are not well defined. This project intends to assess the performance of existing compression connection inspection technologies, develop application guidelines for inspection, and work to identify and evaluate new inspection technologies.

    Furthermore, this project intends to provide information and tools, to improve field training and connector installation, as well as making inspection, assessment and management of compression connectors easier, these tools include:

    •  Guidelines on proper installation of compression connectors;
    •  Analysis of improved methods for inspection and assessment;
    •  Tools for remediation of high risk compression connectors;
    •  A population assessment approach for compression connectors; and,
    •  Failure database and analysis
    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P35.005: Management of Composite Structures
    02-Jun-2016

    The use of composite structures (including poles and cross arms) is being considered as an alternative to traditional steel and wood structures. Despite continuing refinements in material composition and manufacturing techniques, composite products have a fairly short history of service as crossarms and poles in electric utility service.

    There is a need to fully understand the material attributes, as well as failure and degradation modes, particularly at high voltages. This learning is supported by identifying the initiation mechanisms leading to the degradation and failure modes of the material, and the aging rates of that material. The learnings enable understanding of design, application and future maintenance requirements and an estimate of the service life.

    This project intends to address a range of concerns on composite structures including the selection and application of these structures with the objective of helping members increase their confidence in applying, inspecting and assessing these technologies.

     

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P35.006: Lightning Performance and Grounding of Transmission Lines
    02-Jun-2016

    Lightning is the leading cause of outages and service interruptions on transmission lines. Finding the most effective measures to improve the lighting performance of lines is not always straight forward. There are a number of options to consider, such as shielding, grounding, insulation, and line surge arresters to determine cost effectiveness. Some options may also impact other design aspects of the line. For example, transmission line grounding influences both the lightning performance and public/worker safety of transmission lines.

    This project seeks to develop advanced engineering and maintenance tools to understand lightning and grounding performance, and evaluate effectiveness of grounds and grounding designs using traditional and new materials.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P35.007: Line Design Tools and Practices for Construction and Maintenance
    02-Jun-2016

    To meet increasing power demand and reliability requirements, electric utilities need to build new or refurbish existing transmission lines. The lines need to be reliable and have the lowest life-cycle cost that includes not only the capital cost but also the operation and maintenance costs of the lines.

    In order to achieve this tools are required by overhead line designers to make informed decisions in selecting the most optimal design for either new construction or upgrading lines. Tools may include research results, techniques, equations, methodologies, practices, guides and software.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P35.008: Line Hardening and Emerging Designs
    02-Jun-2016

    The continued impacts from big storm events, fueled in part by increasing variability in weather patterns due to climate change, place a clear emphasis on the need for increased resiliency in power systems. Not only do overhead lines need to be structurally resilient, but utilities need the ability to respond quickly and effectively, to restore damage following extreme weather events.  Both of these needs are addressed in the following initiatives:

    Firstly, recent overhead line failures from extreme weather events such as hurricanes, tornadoes, wind and ice storms have raised the question of how existing designs can be improved to provide more resilient designs that have a higher probability of surviving these events. The deterministic method applying safety factors to the strength of line components has been the traditional approach in designing overhead lines. The probability of failures of a line is difficult to assess using this approach, and improvements to the design are not effective. The probability-based design is evolving and allows for easier identification of structures and components for hardening to improve the overall reliability of an overhead transmission line.

    Secondly, isolated overhead line failures can still occur due to exceedance of design conditions under extreme events or material degradation. Under these circumstances, an effective restoration scheme is required.  The scheme shall include a) systems with appropriate materials, adaptable over a range of voltages, to allow restoration of power quickly until a permanent replacement is available, b) a well-defined, coordinated strategy to effectively integrate disciplines participating in the restoration effort and c) ongoing emergency preparedness training to increase restoration speed and effectiveness.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P35.010: Live Working: Research, Techniques and Procedures
    02-Jun-2016

    Higher transmission loads compel utilities to keep transmission lines in service every day making line outages for maintenance more difficult to obtain. Transmission owners are applying live-line working techniques as standard practice to perform required maintenance. Live-line work on energized lines must be performed safely.

    Work on de-energized lines, when it is possible, still face hazards that include step-touch-transfer and induced voltages. These hazards in de-energized work must also be recognized and mitigated. New techniques, tools, procedures and technical analyzes are needed to:

    • Communicate and safely apply minimum approach distances for different types of live working methods and energized environments.
    • Respond to changes in Regulatory rules and /or Industry guidelines that impact live work and worker safety in a way that can support utility decision making with technically sound and justified analyzes.
    • Develop new tools and techniques to enable live line maintenance on energized and de-energized lines.
    • Design of structures to facilitate safe, efficient, and economic execution of live work.
    • Application of emerging technologies (e.g. robotics, UAV’s) to improve live work safety and work task efficiency.
    • Energized rescue of workers.
    • Training of crews to promote safety during both energized and de-energized work, including situations such as construction in the vicinity of energized lines.
    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P35.011: Polymer and Composite Overhead Transmission Insulators
    02-Jun-2016

    Polymer insulator components offer advantages such as contamination performance, light weight, and vandal resistance. In order to achieve the expected design life, utilities need to understand their design and material characteristics to properly select, procure and apply polymer insulator components

    The performance of a polymer component on an overhead transmission line is affected by its design, the material chemistry and application. Research is needed to understand how the different designs and materials perform under in-service stresses and how the application can be designed to minimize the stresses that shorten the lifetime of the polymer component.

    This research focuses on:

    • Selection

    • Application

    • Inspection

    • Population assessment

    • Helping increase member knowledge and reliability in using these components.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P35.012: Porcelain / Glass Insulator Integrity Assessment
    02-Jun-2016

    Currently, millions of porcelain and glass insulators are approaching or have exceeded the end of their intended service life. With increasing age utilities are seeking end of life metrics in order to prioritize maintenance and replacement programs. Utilities need industry wide information about the performance of insulators and how to identify them so they can effectively perform the maintenance.

    In addition to age related degradation, recent shifts in manufacturing locations, market expansion, and new emerging manufacturing plants have introduced uncertainties in the performance of new porcelain and glass insulators. These changes have introduced a need to evaluate traditional tests and develop new tests to ensure the insulators perform as expected.

    Understanding the insulator designs, markings, and known issues is accomplished by

    • tracking the industry changes in a vintage guide

    • tracking industry failures and understanding the factors influencing population end of life

    • developing tests that may

      • help identify end of life criteria

      • supplement standard tests to assess performance

      • improve population assessment.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P35.013: Overhead Line Ratings and Increased Power Flow
    02-Jun-2016

    The demand for electric power over transmission circuits is increasing at a faster rate than transmission assets were originally built for. This trend is pushing the capacity of many existing transmission circuits to their design limits. Additionally, much of the grid has already aged beyond its original design specifications. These issues are affecting the grid causing an increasing number of bottlenecks, and other congestion and reliability problems.

    The power industry recognizes that there is a need to identify and develop methods and tools for increasing and optimizing the power throughput of existing assets. Relative to these issues, there are recent mandated regulatory requirements on the establishment of transmission circuit ratings, and utilities need to have tools to establish line ratings in a scientifically rigorous manner. New tools and procedures are needed to:

    • improve transmission circuit reliability and safety

    • increase and optimize power flow through overhead lines and entire transmission circuits

    • optimize energy transactions through rating forecasts

    • ride out emergency situations safely and reliably

    • avoid unnecessary system outages

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P35.014: High Temperature of Overhead Lines
    02-Jun-2016

    Transmission asset owners may increase the power transfer capacity of its transmission lines by increasing the current flow in a transmission which raises the conductor operating temperature. The effects of an elevated conductor temperature may result in reduced conductor ground clearance, loss of conductor strength, and damage to connectors and other overhead line components. In addition to these mechanical effects the elevated temperatures may impact the line corona performance. Inaccurate corona and thermal models may produce values that exceed the utility’s design limits.

    This may include the following:

    • Understand premature failures of conductors and conductor accessories due to thermal cycling from high- temperature operations. Conductor accessories include conductor splices and dead-ends, dampers, spacer dampers, and all hardware attached to the conductor of an overhead line.

    • Determine the performance of connector mitigation devices

    • Understand the high-temperature effects on corona, thermal, and other models used in evaluating electrical effects, heat-transfer capability, and other performance indicators of an overhead line.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P35.015: Qualification, Selection and Maintenance of Advanced Conductors
    02-Jun-2016

    Recently developed high-temperature conductors (also known as advanced conductors, high-temperature low-sag conductors, or simply HTLS conductors) offer the advantages of higher current capacity, lower conductor sag, and lower line losses than conventional ACSR (aluminum conductor steel-reinforced) conductors. Knowledge on the long-term performance of HTLS conductors is limited, particularly for newly developed products. In addition, there is a need for information on the selection, procurement, application and maintenance of HTLS conductors.  This project intends to address a range of concerns and give transmission owners and operator confidence in applying this technology.  This includes:

    • Determining the applicability of conventional conductor maintenance tools and procedures for HTLS application

    • Documenting utility design and installation experience

    • Developing test protocols that may be applied to predict the long term performance advanced conductors.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P35.017: Asset Management Analytics for Overhead Transmission Lines
    02-Jun-2016

    Aging equipment fleets, more stringent operating requirements, financial constraints and retiring expertise make managing transmission line assets challenging. Many electric utilities are considering or already have moved toward implementing asset management concepts and decision-making procedures based on minimizing equipment life-cycle costs and risks. However, the data, analytical tools and models required for power delivery equipment risk assessment and management are not well established.

    This project intends to support utilities in their asset management decision making through its complete life cycle including acquisition, operation, inspection, maintenance and disposal. Asset management analytics supports intelligent fleet management to improve performance, control costs, extend overhead transmission line asset life and maintain reliability.

    Fleet management decision support analytics and methodologies require new knowledge, tools and methodologies to accomplish these steps and help with the implementation of a successful risk based equipment asset management program. Required are:

    • Data models and database structures to assemble historical and future line performance data

    • Methodologies and tools for analyzing and extracting information from industry-wide databases

    • Metrics to better quantify equipment performance

    • Condition assessment approaches and tools

    • Analytics for projecting future performance

    • A generic framework for incorporating condition indices, operational requirements, and business rules into a risk-based assessment and mitigation methodology

    • Transmission line asset management guidelines

    Key research areas are categorized in the following way:

    • Asset Characterization and Performance Information

    • Asset Health Algorithms

    • Asset Management Program Decision Support

    • Technology Transfer

Overview

Program Description

Underground transmission systems consist of extruded and laminar dielectric cables and accessories. While a significant portion of the installed cable base is laminar dielectric cables, the trend has shifted towards installing more cables using extruded dielectric technologies.

The research results of the EPRI Underground Transmission Program support utilities to resolve challenges in design, construction, installation, operations, and maintenance of both extruded and laminar dielectric cable systems. Cross-cutting research addresses issues such as design calculations, static and dynamic cable ratings, and inspection technologies. Research specific to extruded dielectric cables focuses on cable thermo-mechanical performance and advanced sensing and monitoring. Research specific to laminar dielectric cables focuses on cable and system diagnostics and buried steel pipe corrosion. One project is designed to focus on technology transfer and knowledge capture for transmission cable engineers of utilities installing or considering underground transmission lines. The project includes EPRI Green Book update, Increased Power Flow Guide Book update, industry engagement, and member technical supports in various formats. The project on Cable Systems Asset Management Analytics is to address issues in implementing asset management concepts and decision-making procedures.

Research Value

With the knowledge acquired through this research program, transmission cable users will have access to information and products that can help

  • acquire strategic intelligence on emerging technologies

  • increase engineering staff efficiency and expertise in underground transmission

  • improve efficiency and quality in underground transmission system design

  • lower underground transmission installation and operating costs

  • develop tools and methods to design and operate the system with increased power flow

  • gain more accurate and timely knowledge about asset condition and life expectancy

  • improve transmission system reliability and safety and reduce environmental impact

Approach

EPRI research in underground transmission will yield a variety of technical knowledge to benefit transmission cable users. The information will be provided in a number of forms, including:

  • Experimental and analytical results

  • Advanced tools and equipment

  • Technological demonstrations

  • Software packages

  • Reference books

  • Practical manuals

  • Conferences, meetings, and web casts

  • Educational workshops

Accomplishments

Through decades of research and development, this EPRI Underground Transmission Program has delivered considerable values to the cable industry in a number of ways. Recent examples include:

  • EPRI Underground Transmission Systems Reference Book (Green Book) (3002006025)

  • Underground Transmission Workstation (UTW) software tools (3002006012)

  • EPRI Increased Power Flow Guidebook (3002005707)

  • Life-cycle Cost Guide for Underground Transmission Systems and Application Examples (3002006010)

  • Underground Transmission Cable System Construction and Installation Practices Manual (3002006011)

  • Update of Technology Review of Extra High Voltage (EHV) Extruded Dielectric Cable Systems, 220 kV to 500 kV (3002006014)

  • EPRI Dissolved Gas Analysis Guide for High Voltage Cables and Transformers (3002006019)

  • Underground Transmission System Protection (3002003467)

  • Guide and Verification Practices for High-Quality Installation of Transmission Cable Accessories (3002000877)

  • Experimental Verification of Thermo-Mechanical Models for Cross-Linked Polyethylene Cable in Pipes and Ducts: Interim Report on First Cable Test (3002000865)

  • Electrical Safety Practices in Underground Transmission Systems (1024176)

  • Underground Cable Fault Location Reference and Application Guide (1023060)

  • Corrosion of Buried Steel Pipes Used with Transmission Pipe-type Cable Systems (1019987)

  • Pressurization Procedures for High-Pressure Fluid-Filled and High-Pressure Gas-Filled Cable Systems (1015930)

  • EMF Management User’s Guide for Underground Transmission Systems (3002007657)

  • Reducing Cost of Constructing Underground Transmission Line

  • Cable Accessory Long-term Performance

  • Thermo-mechanical Design and Performance

  • Advanced Sensors and Monitoring Techniques

  • P36.001: Design, Construction, Ratings, and Operation and Maintenance of UT Systems
    02-Jun-2016

    Cost-effective and reliable underground cable systems depend on sound engineering practices for design, construction, operations, and maintenance. This research project develops technologies, software tools, guides, and technical basis for best practices to assist in accomplishing safe, reliable, and efficient underground transmission systems for both extruded and laminar dielectric cables. This project addresses specific research needs, including cable accessory long-term performance and failure root cause, methods and tools to determine cable circuit ratings, framework for evaluating transmission line options, advanced designs and innovative techniques to reduce construction and installation cost, and safe and effective cable circuit inspection techniques. By addressing these issues, the cable industry is better equipped with knowledge, methods, and tools to execute required tasks throughout the life cycle of the cable systems.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P36.002: Extruded Dielectric Cable Systems
    02-Jun-2016

    Utilities increasingly rely on extruded dielectric cable systems to meet growing demands for new underground transmission lines. A challenge facing the utility planners, engineers, and operators is to provide assurance that extruded dielectric cable systems will perform and last at least as well as the proven laminar dielectric cable systems. This project addresses several key research issues impacting such assurance, including:

    • Improving engineering-based design and installation procedures to accommodate electrical, mechanical, and thermal requirements

    • Improving specification, design, operation, maintenance, and monitoring of cable bonding and grounding systems

    • Developing effective inspection and monitoring methods for cable system condition assessment

    • Achieving better understanding of aging and failure mechanisms of cable systems.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P36.003: Laminar Dielectric Cable Systems
    02-Jun-2016

    Laminar dielectric cable systems consist of high-pressure fluid-filled (HPFF), high-pressure gas-filled (HPGF), and self-contained fluid-filled (SCFF) cable systems. About 80% of the installed underground transmission infrastructure in North America is laminar dielectric cables. These cables in general have provided long lasting service to the utilities, surpassing their design life specifications. However, the growing age of many of these assets may be a cause for concern. Replacement costs for laminar dielectric cable systems are high. The consequences of electrical failures or cable system fluid leaks are significant. Research is needed to

    • Improve understanding of cable and steel pipe failure mechanisms

    • Develop and demonstrate advanced inspection, diagnostic, and monitoring techniques

    • Provide guidance and develop strategies for effective operations, maintenance, and replacement.

This project provides educational resources and technical supports to current and future cable users. The participants will be better equipped with transferred technologies, captured knowledge, and educational materials and will execute more reliable and cost-effective transmission cable systems.

Overview

Program Description

This program helps substation owners enhance safety, reliability, equipment life, and performance, as well as maximize the return on asset investments and prioritize their resources. It offers a portfolio of tools and technologies such as risk based asset and fleet management decision support analytics and transformer monitoring. The program also provides training materials and resources to improve equipment life management such as failure databases and aging models.

Research Value

This research and development (R&D) program addresses asset-specific performance and industry issues. Collectively, the goal is to develop tools, techniques, and methodologies to help a utility improve substation equipment inspection, assessment, maintenance, and risk-based asset management. The information provided through the collection of projects in this program will provide members with knowledge that can help them:

  • Develop risk based fleet management programs;

  • Extend equipment life with maintenance guidelines;

  • Reduce maintenance costs via condition-based maintenance;

  • Improve sulfur hexafluoride (SF6) management;

  • Increase the understanding of vulnerability of substation equipment to specific physical and intentional electromagnetic attacks;

  • Implement predictive maintenance practices for reduced outages;

  • Reduce failures of critical assets; and

  • Reduce switching errors, increase worker safety, and prevent outages.

Approach

The research applies the EPRI created knowledge of the fundamental aging and degradation process of materials, components and systems, in order to define inspection and monitoring approaches, maintenance activities and mitigation options. Research results will be transferred to members in scientific reports, reference guides, easy to use operational and procedural guidelines, and workshops. Specific research activities include:

  • Development of equipment aging assessment tools - failure modes, degradation mechanisms and diagnostics;

  • Development of asset management analytics - decision support analytics and methodologies;

  • Assessment of effectiveness of various diagnostic tools;

  • Development of asset management and maintenance guidelines;

  • Reference books, guidelines, videos, field guides and technology transfer workshops;

  • Industry-wide equipment performance databases, and

  • Collaborative environments for sharing lessons learned and best practices.

Accomplishments

In the past, the Substations program has delivered many highly valuable reports, guides and tools that have helped its members increase the reliability and control the cost of electric power delivery. Some examples include:

  • Reference Guides: Comprehensive collection of reference information that provides the technical basis to design and execute comprehensive maintenance, condition assessment and life extension programs for substation equipment as well as safely perform switching and other operations. These reference guides include – Power Transformers Book, Substations Life Extension Guidelines, Switching Safety & Reliability, Fault Current Management (1023060) and Increase Power Flow Guidebook (3002005707).

  • Pocket Field Guides: Step-by-step instructions to increase quality and consistency of daily activities. A set of six pocket field guides are presently available. They include: Substation Infrared Monitoring, Circuit Breaker Lubrication, Circuit Breaker Pump and Compressor Maintenance, Transformer Root Cause Analysis and Failure Investigation, Smart Ground Meter and Preventing Switching Errors.

  • Power Transformer Expert System (PTX) for Condition Assessment: Power transformers are vital components of the power delivery system and their operation impacts a utility’s economic and reliability performance. Hence, accurately and efficiently assessing transformer condition is important for asset and risk management. EPRI has developed expert fleet assessment methodologies for power transformers using readily available data. The automated tool emulates the thought processes of industry experts and provides individual unit and complete fleet assessments and suggested actions.

  • Circuit Breaker Fleet Management Software: A suite of applications (3002007835) that utilities can apply and adapt to their own needs – maintenance triggering, replacement or maintenance ranking. The application uses readily available data and analytics that enable trigger driven condition and risk based maintenance or replacement. A spreadsheet-based approach provides utilities with a framework for circuit breaker asset management with default values that a utility expert can adjust and readily apply.

  • SF6 Complete Library, Version 2.0: The SF6 Computer-Based Training Modules, Version 2.0, is a set of four CDs for computer-based training on SF6 safety, handling, and analysis that includes the impact of SF6 on the environment.

  • Industry-wide Substation Equipment Performance and Failure Database—Data, Model and Results: This comprehensive product (3002007828) provides a populated data set of close to 50,000 in service power transformers and more than 3000 failures; analysis tools and techniques for investigating both industry-wide and utility fleet-specific transformer performance; statistical analysis results of select hazard rates; tools for relating utility performance with industry-wide data – segmented by application, family, make and model; and data models to assist utilities with data gathering and retention.

  • Switching Safety and Reliability Conference: The annual conference is attended by managers, supervisors, and operations personnel to exchange experiences about switching procedures contributing to improved safety and reliability practices through improved switching.

 

 

Key Activities

In the coming year, the Substations program expects to accomplish these objectives:

  • New research focusing on contamination of external insulation

  • Asset Management Analytics

  • New versions of Industry-wide Transformer Database, Analytical Tools and Results Library (3002007831)

  • New version of the Industry-wide Database for Circuit Breakers (3002005988)

  • New modules and analytical capabilities to Transformer and Circuit Breaker Fleet Management Software

  • Methodologies for developing spares strategies and associated analytical tools for substation equipment

  • Asset management approach to the management of legacy relays and integration of the next generation

    This project develops new tools and knowledge to help substation owners anticipate and prevent failures in transformers, extend transformer life, develop and retain key subject matter expertise and specify new diagnostic equipment with confidence.   • P37.102: Circuit Breaker Life Management
    02-Jun-2016

    The life cycle performance of a circuit breaker is determined by the performance and condition of its materials and components. Together, they drive the requirements for maintenance and refurbishment or replacement. There is very little quantifiable data on breaker material and sub-system performance available to make well-informed conclusions and design cost-effective condition-based maintenance programs. To bridge these gaps, proposed research may develop the information, and develop tools, techniques and methodologies, for high voltage circuit breaker life management. The methods developed may be adapted so that they can be applied to medium voltage (13.8 kV to 69 kV) breakers.

    Through a multi-year research effort, it is anticipated that the development may result in:

    • Maintenance guidelines

    • Innovative techniques for condition-based maintenance

    • Equipment aging assessment tools - failure modes, degradation mechanisms and diagnostics

    • Diagnostic effectiveness assessments

    • Reference books, guidelines, videos, field guides and technology transfer workshops

    • Collaborative environments for sharing lessons learned and best practices

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P37.103: Protection and Control
    02-Jun-2016

    Utilities face the challenge of managing the performance and reliability of multi-generation relaying technologies accompanied by tighter regulations. Many disruptions have relay misoperations as the root cause.  Specific issues include:

    • Incorrect relay settings, design errors, and as-left personnel errors remain as the leading factors causing protection system misoperations.   
    • Tighter regulations on protection settings with increasing coordination needs make the traditional configuration management processes and approaches less appropriate
    • The absence of a sound technical bases challenges utilities in determining useful life spans, maintenance intervals and replacement strategies for aging electro-mechanical relay fleets and short-life-span microprocessor relay fleets.
    • Fast-evolving protection and control technologies create new opportunities, as well as challenges, for utilities to reduce complexity and cost, enable condition based maintenance, improve safety, and enhance storm hardening and system resilience.  

    Required are:

    • Guidelines for settings and configuration management
    • Maintenance basis
    • Guidance on emerging technologies
    • Protection and control asset management analytics

  • P37.104: Substation Ground Grid Research
    02-Jun-2016

    A substation ground grid is an essential component of the substation and must provide the following functions to preserve system integrity and eliminate risk:

    • Provide step and touch potential protection for any personnel who may be in the substation
    • Minimize hazards to the public, such as step and touch potentials near or around the perimeter of the substation
    • Provide adequate grounding for substation equipment and control room electronics by minimizing ground potential rises in the substation during faults, lightning strikes and normal/abnormal switching operations.

    Substation ground grids must be designed to ensure that even the most severe faults and transient voltage rises will not harm staff or damage equipment within the substation and will not create hazards for the public outside the substation fence. Faults or transient voltage rises in substations may result in electrical stresses on the ground grid system and other substation equipment, and may be categorized as follows:

    • Stresses during power system faults or lightning strikes
    • Stresses during switching operations
    • Stresses that are the expansive and persistent forces of corrosion and weather.
    • Stresses due to freezing and soil expansion may break the connection of individual elements.
    • Soil corrosion, which is worse for low resistivity soil, constantly degrades the grounding electrodes and conductors. Galvanic corrosion resulting from dissimilar metals may accelerate this process.

    This corrosion may cause the failure of individual grounding elements or the deterioration of the entire grounding system.  It may cause an interruption in the grounding system continuity, introducing high resistances across bonds, inadequate step and touch potential protection and ground potential rises that can damage equipment.

    Required are –

    • Inspection and assessment approaches to locate and assess ground grid corrosion

    • Guidance on corrosion rates

    • Guidance on how to mitigate underlying degradation

    • Guidance to select materials for designs that are compatible with environment

  • P37.105: Disconnect Switches, Arresters and Ratings
    02-Jun-2016

    Air break disconnect switches are critical assets for utilities and are key to the operability of a substation. The age of disconnect switches and the fact that they may be operated infrequently, coupled with cost reduction strategies have brought to the forefront the need to minimize maintenance expenditures. Organizational goals of minimum maintenance, high reliability, and extended life cycle can cause conflicting results. The maintenance of high voltage disconnect and grounding switches has characteristically been based on in-service time and number of operations. This approach works well during the early life of the switch, but current concerns which include aging equipment, limited maintenance resources, the requirement for increased emergency ratings, restricted maintenance outages, and the demand for high reliability have maintenance and asset managers exploring maintenance improvements and alternative replacement strategies. EPRI R&D is helping utilities reduce maintenance costs and uncertainties, and maximize disconnect switch reliability through the application of new technology, and improved disconnect switch life-cycle management through the following:

    • Identification of the most problematic disconnect and grounding switch designs
    • The exploration and testing of minimal disassembly refurbishment methods for disconnect switches
    • Investigation of a next generation of disconnect switch including drop in replacement disconnect switch designs
    • Simplified disconnect live part replacements
    • Simplified operating mechanisms and linkages
    • Examination of disconnect switch application and ratings

    Additionally, the power industry recognizes that there is a need to identify and develop methods and tools for increasing and optimizing the power throughput of existing assets in a scientifically rigorous manner including:

    • Effective tools for performing rating calculations and studies
    • Improved thermal models for transmission substation components
    • Improved rating processes and best practices information
    • Effective technology transfer
