Program Name: Pressurized Water Reactor Steam Generator Management (SGMP)
text:
Overview

Road Maps

EPRI has developed the following roadmaps to guide research in key technical areas. These roadmaps provide a communication tool for determining what success looks like, identifying research tasks necessary to meet goals, and clarifying roles for all stakeholders.

  • Steam Generator Foreign Object Management - 1.70MB PDF
  • Steam Generator Degradation Prediction and Mitigation - 1.89MB PDF
  • Steam Generator Tube Integrity Assessment - 2.07MB PDF
Program Description

Many factors affect materials degradation in steam generators, including water chemistry, inspection limitations, material performance issues, and the presence of foreign objects. Greater understanding of these factors and their integrated impacts will lead to more effective tools for predicting degradation and more effective inspection and mitigation techniques for identifying and addressing degradation.

The Electric Power Research Institute’s (EPRI’s) Steam Generator Management Program (SGMP) conducts research to inform decisions regarding the safe, reliable, and economic operation of steam generators in pressurized water reactor plants. Research activities target identification and mitigation of various forms of steam generator degradation, foreign object assessments, optimized operation of replacement steam generators, water chemistry, in-service inspections, and tube integrity.

Research Value

Steam generator tubes are an integral part of the reactor coolant pressure boundary and have a number of important safety functions.

  1. Maintain the primary system’s pressure and inventory

  2. Act as a heat transfer surface between the primary and secondary systems such that residual heat can be removed from the primary system

  3. Isolate the radioactive fission products in the primary coolant from the secondary system

  4. Help the plant meet containment objectives of preventing uncontrolled fission product release under conditions resulting from core damage severe accidents

The Steam Generator Management Program supports greater consistency in managing steam generator issues across the nuclear fleet. The program develops guidance for existing issues such as degradation in steam generators with original Alloy 600 MA tubes, as well as emerging issues such as managing degradation in steam generators with the more corrosion-resistant Alloy 600 TT, Alloy 690 TT, and Alloy 800 tubes. Program participants gain access to the following:

  • Strategic roadmaps outlining research gaps associated with key issues—such as foreign object management, tube integrity assessment, and steam generator life management—and the collaborative actions needed to address these gaps.

  • Guideline documents that reduce the potential for steam generator tube ruptures and forced leakage outages, which can cost an estimated $5 to $20 million per event.

  • Better tools for integrity assessments, informing decisions regarding examinations, which can cost an estimated $1 to $2 million per plant.

  • Performance information on steam generator examination techniques that can be used to optimize inspections, increasing the probability of detection of existing tube degradation mechanisms.

  • Chemistry controls that can delay the onset of corrosion and mitigate steam generator fouling.

  • A database of worldwide steam generator information related to degradation, used to inform decisions on steam generator operation and maintenance.

Approach

The Steam Generator Management Program uses an integrated approach for managing steam generator materials degradation in pressurized water reactors. The program develops guidance through improved understanding of how multiple variables impact steam generator operation and maintenance, including thermal hydraulics, water chemistry, tubing materials, inspection techniques, and tube-plugging/repair criteria.

The Steam Generator Management Program closely collaborates with other EPRI programs, including the PWR Materials Reliability Program, the Nondestructive Evaluation (NDE) Program, and the Chemistry Program, to ensure appropriate technologies and technical guidance are effectively integrated into research activities.

There are both base and supplemental components of the Steam Generator Management Program. The base portion encompasses NDE research and development, water chemistry, materials performance/thermal hydraulics, and the Steam Generator Degradation Database (SGDD).

  • Nondestructive Evaluation: Develops tools such as software algorithms, improved inspection techniques, and database libraries to enhance the accuracy and efficiency of steam generator inspections. Improved flaw detection and flaw-sizing accuracy capabilities, for example, can better inform decisions regarding operating intervals between inspections.

  • Water Chemistry: Develops guidelines, chemistry technologies, and predictive models to minimize steam generator tube corrosion and fouling, and to optimize chemistry for safe, reliable, and long-term steam generator operation. Advanced technology developments are incorporated into application sourcebooks to inform water chemistry control actions, including the use of improved amines, dispersants, molar ratio control, and intergranular stress corrosion cracking inhibition.

  • Materials Performance and Thermal Hydraulics: Conducts experiments and develops computational simulations that more accurately estimate foreign object movements and tube wear rates from steam generator foreign objects. This research area also develops prediction tools and on-line measurement techniques to manage issues resulting from buildup on tube support plates. Finally, corrosion studies are conducted that can help determine the effect of various steam generator environments on tube degradation rates.

  • SGDD: Maintains a web-based database of steam generator information that contributes to the safe and reliable operation of steam generators by providing data to inform decisions regarding inspection scope, tube repair activities, and the effectiveness of steam generator corrective actions, such as chemical cleaning.

Research focus areas containing multiple common projects are used to document the strategic objectives for each focused area of research. The Steam Generator Management Program has five research focus areas: Understanding Wear Mechanisms in Steam Generator Tubing, Managing Chemistry and Fouling Issues, Managing Corrosion Mechanisms Affecting Steam Generator Tubing, Developing and Employing Nondestructive Examination Improvements, and Development of State-of-the-Art Software for Analyzing Steam Generator Flow Conditions. To resolve complex issues that may stretch across multiple focus areas or involve multiple external stakeholders, the Steam Generator Management Program has developed targeted roadmaps on foreign object management, tube integrity assessment, steam generator life management, and aging management of the steam generator channel head assembly. Additional roadmaps will be developed as conditions warrant.

The supplemental portion of the Steam Generator Management Program provides mechanisms for responding to emerging issues and for developing effective monitoring and assessment programs.

  • Supplemental Research and Emerging Issues: This project enables EPRI to conduct research to address emerging technical, operational, and regulatory issues not anticipated in annual research planning. This project also facilitates research in specific areas that may not be of interest to the broader base of program participants. Such research could include additional capabilities for software products and review of newly developed chemical additives.

  • Structural Integrity Assessment and Nondestructive Evaluation Field Support: This project develops products to ensure steam generator tube integrity through thorough inspections, condition monitoring, and operational assessments. Cornerstone products include the Steam Generator Examination Guidelines and its qualification program, the Steam Generator Integrity Assessment Guidelines, the Steam Generator Primary-to-Secondary Leakage Guidelines, and the Steam Generator In-Situ Pressure Test Guidelines.

Accomplishments

The Steam Generator Management Program supports nuclear power industry efforts to minimize the potential for steam generator tube ruptures, forced leakage outages, and other steam generator integrity issues. Accomplishments include both technology development and technical support, spanning more cost-effective nondestructive evaluation techniques for steam generators to technical input into regulatory issues.

  • Updated the MULTEQ software to include cobalt species, lead and nickel titanate, new copper and nickel species, and the revision of various iron and copper species based on new information in the literature. The precipitation reactions that previously included redox reactions were revised to separate the redox and precipitation reactions. This allows a clearer delineation of the redox and no redox modes when running the ChemWorksTM Tools. This software calculates the chemistry environment, equilibrium speciation, precipitation and volatilization of species at temperatures from 150 to 350 degrees Celsius.  SGMP collaborates with Chemistry and Fuel Reliability Programs for continued development of this software.

  • Released the Steam Generator Deposit Removal Strategies Sourcebook, which provides detailed descriptions of mechanical and chemical removal technologies and industry experience.  This sourcebook assists nuclear plants in selecting appropriate deposit removal processes for steam generators.

  • Updated a report on field experience with dispersants to control iron transport and steam generator fouling. Published with the EPRI Chemistry Program, this update provides additional field experience with application of dispersants, including online applications as well as shutdown and hybrid applications to achieve better control of deposits in steam generators.

  • Developed generic elements to assist nuclear plant owners in assessing the susceptibility of their steam generator designs to U-bend fatigue. This approach can be used for all susceptible steam generators.  

  • Revised the Steam Generator Management Program Administrative Procedures in 2015 to incorporate operating experience.  This document provides guidance for compliance with NEI 03-08.

  • Revised the Steam Generator Degradation Specific Flaw Handbook to reflect operating experience and add material properties for Alloy 690TT tubing. This handbook contains equations for calculating structural limits for all known steam generator tube degradation.

  • Developed a process to streamline site validation of bobbin and rotating probe inspection techniques. The process evaluates the eddy current inspection system as a whole when determining equivalence, rather than assessing each essential variable separately.

Key Activities

The Steam Generator Management Program research and development for 2017 will focus on continued development of thermal-hydraulic analysis software; advanced inspection methods, root causes of steam generator degradation, dispersant application, and guideline revisions. Specific efforts include:

  • Continue support of the SGDD.

  • Continue support of the Qualified Data Analyst package which will include the initial addition of array probe data and the Site Specific Performance Demonstration) program, which are essential elements for qualifying and training personnel on steam generator exam guidelines.

  • Maintain the Examination Technique Specification Sheets which define essential variables for equipment, techniques, and data analysis for steam generator examinations.

  • Release Version 1.0 of Triton, a next-generation steam generator thermal-hydraulics code.

  • Enhance the eddy current Automated Analysis Performance Demonstration Database (AAPDD) by increasing the range and quantity of eddy current data available for performance tests.

  • Continue development of advanced software algorithms for automated eddy current data analysis for detection of steam generator degradation and foreign objects.

  • Participate in research studies on two retired steam generators with Alloy 600TT tubes.

  • Publish revisions to the Steam Generator Integrity Assessment Guidelines, Steam Generator In Situ Pressure Test Guidelines, and Pressurized Water Reactor Steam Generator Examination Guidelines.

  • Develop a technical basis for guidance and procedures related to automated analysis of steam generator eddy current data, including a single integrated process. 

  • Release a report on laboratory testing of inhibitors for lead stress corrosion cracking (PbSCC).

  • Release a report on field experience of testing alternatives to hydrazine for use on the secondary side to control dissolved oxygen.

Selected reports and products may be prepared in whole or in part in accordance with the EPRI Quality Program Manual that fulfills the requirements of 10CFR50 Appendix B and 10CFR21. The QA status of reports and products will be marked and identified.

Program Manager
Helen Cothron, (865) 7734033, hcothron@epri.com

Program Name: Boiling Water Reactor Vessel and Internals Program (BWRVIP)
text:
Overview

Road Maps

EPRI has developed the following roadmaps to guide research in key technical areas. These roadmaps provide a communication tool for determining what success looks like, identifying research tasks necessary to meet goals, and clarifying roles for all stakeholders.

  • Management of Jet Pump Flow-Induced Vibration - 1.26MB PDF
  • Mitigation of Boiling Water Reactor Materials Degradation - 1.69MB PDF
Program Description

As boiling water reactors (BWRs) age, various types of materials degradation mechanisms can challenge the reliable operation of the BWR primary system. Stress corrosion cracking, for example, first appeared in recirculation piping in the early 1960s and was then shortly thereafter discovered in reactor pressure vessel internal components. Materials performance issues across the nuclear fleet were dealt with on a case-by-case basis, focusing on site-specific components, systems, and materials management philosophies. This near-term, reactive approach resulted in costly unplanned outages and expensive weld-by-weld mitigation and repair methods that lacked a comprehensive fundamental understanding of the degradation and how to effectively deal with it. A longer-term, strategic approach to materials aging management helps ensure that safe and reliable functionality is maintained throughout the life of BWR plants.

The Boiling Water Reactor Vessel and Internals Project (BWRVIP) provides an integrated and proactive approach for managing materials-related degradation issues in reactor coolant system components in boiling water reactors. The program develops reliable and cost-effective detection, inspection, mitigation, and repair guidance to address the safety-significant facets of operation resulting from materials degradation issues.

Research Value

The BWRVIP addresses materials integrity issues related to the BWR reactor pressure vessel and internals. Research results lead to proven solutions for managing materials degradation, optimized inspection scopes, improved understanding of structural integrity during operation, reduced personnel radiation exposure, and improved models to better characterize the degradation of internals components that can be used by BWR utilities.

Program participants gain access to the following:

  • Strategic roadmaps outlining research gaps associated with key issues—such as jet pump flow-induced vibration, intergranular stress corrosion cracking (IGSCC), irradiation assisted stress corrosion cracking (IASCC), and mitigation of internals degradation—and other activities needed to address these gaps

  • The technical bases documents for guidance that improves plant reliability

  • Cost-effective techniques to mitigate stress corrosion cracking of reactor internal components

  • Options and design criteria for replacing or repairing reactor components

  • Optimized internals inspection guidelines and solutions to BWR technical issues

  • Global BWR industry operating experience

  • Technical insights for inspection options that can help reduce outage critical path times, address new degradation phenomena, and provide data to inform regulatory decisions

Approach

The BWRVIP Program takes an integrated approach to degradation management encompassing assessment, repair, mitigation, and inspection. Continuous learning from research and development (R&D) using state-of-the-art materials testing and analysis tools improves understanding of materials aging mechanisms. This knowledge is used to develop the technical basis of guidelines for inspection and assessment of materials-related issues associated with the BWR reactor vessel and internals. BWRVIP activities lead to innovative, efficient ways to manage degradation without compromising safety. Operational experience and inspection techniques are evaluated to identify best practices that can be deployed to enhance boiling water reactor reliability and alert stakeholders to new or unexpected issues.

The BWRVIP works closely with other Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) materials related programs, including the Materials Reliability Program (MRP), Nondestructive Evaluation (NDE), Primary Systems Corrosion Research (PSCR), Chemistry, and Fuel Reliability Program (FRP) to ensure appropriate technologies and technical guidance are effectively integrated into BWRVIP research activities.

The program focuses on improving the understanding of materials performance in areas such as fracture toughness and crack growth of stainless steel exposed to high fluence levels as well as the weldability of irradiated materials for repair. Because these factors impact materials aging on all reactor types, enhanced understanding of their interactions and their impact on materials performance are essential. Research results are provided in the form of guidelines that help ensure prompt detection of material degradation; technical reports to support materials performance assessments; and cost-effective tools that identify and enable degradation management over the life of the plant.

The BWRVIP program encompasses research related to assessment, inspection, repair, and mitigation.

  • Assessment: Develop inspection and evaluation guidelines that provide the scope for what needs to be inspected and a methodology for evaluating or repairing any indications.

  • Inspection: Develop advanced nondestructive evaluation techniques to improve detection of indications in internal components.

  • Repair: Develop technically based repair criteria for degraded components and compile information needed to safely plan and implement repairs.

  • Mitigation: Provide guidance for implementing effective chemistry-based countermeasures for stress corrosion cracking of reactor internal components.

The program also manages the Integrated Surveillance Program (ISP) for the U.S. BWR fleet, which monitors changes in reactor pressure vessel materials properties due to neutron irradiation.

The BWRVIP uses the Materials Degradation Matrix (MDM) tool along with the BWR Issue Management Tables (BWRVIP-167, Rev. 3) to identify damage mechanisms and the associated knowledge gaps needed to resolve technical issues. Tasks that are developed to address the issues are grouped into Research Focus Areas (RFAs) to help communicate the annual work plans. The BWRVIP has 12 RFAs:

  • Reactor Pressure Vessel

  • Thermal and Irradiation Effects on Stainless Steel Reactor Internals

  • Management of Jet Pump Flow-Induced Vibration

  • Mitigation of BWR Material Degradation

  • BWR Irradiated Materials Welding

  • Management of High Strength Alloys

  • BWR-Related Corrosion Research

  • BWR Inspection & NDE Technology

  • Guideline Management

  • Fatigue Management

  • Steam Dryer Management

  • Alloy 182 / 600 Management

 

To resolve complex issues that may stretch across multiple focus areas or involve multiple external stakeholders, roadmaps have been developed in BWRVIP addressing jet pump flow-induced vibration, intergranular stress corrosion cracking (IGSCC) and irradiation assisted stress corrosion cracking (IASCC), and mitigation of internals degradation. The BWRVIP also collaborates on roadmaps in other EPRI programs that have implications relevant to BWRs, including roadmaps on the welding of irradiated materials and irradiated materials testing.

Nuclear plant owners can participate separately in a project aimed at maintaining and improving the BWR Vessel and Internals Application (BWRVIA) software code, which performs radiolysis analysis and electrochemical corrosion potential calculations for boiling water reactors. Continued maintenance of this code ensures that the latest industry operating experience is reflected in BWR radiolysis analysis.

Accomplishments

BWRVIP research informs the assessment and implementation of effective approaches for managing materials degradation issues in reactor internal components. Research results provide nuclear plants with the information necessary to maintain safe operation and make cost-effective decisions for managing degradation of BWR vessel and internal components.

  • Received safety evaluation for Optimized Core Spray Inspection and Evaluation Guidance based on operational experience and technical data.

  • Published a report that provides updated load terms, definitions and combinations for flaw evaluation and repair design criteria of reactor pressure vessel internal components to support utility implementation of the BWRVIP guidance.  This resolved issues associated with GE-Hitachi Safety Communications regarding postulated recirculation line break and annulus pressurization loads for BWR internals.

  • Developed a methodology that can be used to assess the technical viability of a requirement to examine core plate bolting.

  • Published Revision 19 of the examination guidelines for reactor pressure vessels and internals.

  • Evaluated irradiated BWR internals to advance the understanding of the relationship between fracture toughness and neutron fluence in highly irradiated stainless steel materials.

  • Developed data on crack growth of irradiated austenitic stainless steels in support of a methodology to evaluate the operability of internal components in BWRs to end-of-life fluence levels. Data will be used to extend crack growth models to higher neutron doses associated with longer term service.

  • Conducted metallurgical evaluations of off-axis indications removed from a utility’s core shroud. This information will be used to develop and improve the technical bases for managing this type of cracking.

  • Demonstrated online noble metal chemical addition as a mitigation technique for stress corrosion cracking. Field tests indicate that the technique is effective in reducing electrochemical corrosion potentials and has no adverse plant impacts. Because the application is performed during operation, 60 critical path hours can be saved versus the classic noble metal application.

  • Continued to support remote visual round robin testing being performed jointly by the industry and NRC Research.

  • Received safety evaluation on technical basis for screening irradiation and thermal embrittlement in cast austenitic stainless steel materials.

  • Developed a nondestructive method for measuring noble metal loading on plant surfaces.

  • Reviewed the adequacy of BWRVIP aging management programs for second license renewal (60-80 yrs).

  • Developed an integrated surveillance plan to monitor materials behavior for longer time periods and support effective aging management through second license renewal.

Key Activities

BWRVIP research and development for 2017 will continue to focus on the technical gaps defined in the BWR Issue Management Tables (BWRVIP-167 Rev. 3). Highest-priority gaps include the impacts of fluence on the material properties of BWR materials, flow-induced vibration in jet pumps, and mitigation of intergranular and irradiated assisted stress corrosion cracking. Specific efforts will include the following:

  • IASCC research and inspection guidance

  • Environmental effects on fatigue properties and fatigue crack growth curves for BWRs

  • Crack growth testing, fracture toughness evaluations, and metallurgical examinations of highly irradiated materials

  • In-plant electrochemical potential measurements to demonstrate mitigation effectiveness of on-line noble metal chemical addition

  • Quantification of the effect of chemistry transients on stress corrosion cracking of low-alloy reactor pressure vessel steels and updated associated guidance

  • Evaluation and publication of results from remote visual round robin testing

  • Extension of the BWR Integrated Surveillance Program from 60 years to 80 years

  • Development of technical basis on BWRVIP materials aging to inform decisions regarding second license renewal in the United States and license extension outside the United States.

 

Selected reports and products may be prepared in whole or in part in accordance with the EPRI Quality Program Manual that fulfills the requirements of 10CFR50 Appendix B and 10CFR21. The QA status of reports and products will be marked and identified.

Program Manager
Andrew McGehee, 704-595-2615, amcgehee@epri.com

Program Name: Pressurized Water Reactor Materials Reliability Program (MRP)
text:
Overview

Road Maps

EPRI has developed the following roadmaps to guide research in key technical areas. These roadmaps provide a communication tool for determining what success looks like, identifying research tasks necessary to meet goals, and clarifying roles for all stakeholders.

  • Ensuring Reactor Pressure Vessel Integrity Through Eighty Years of Operation - 2.12MB PDF
  • PWR Reactor Internals Aging Management - 0.20MB PDF
  • Fatigue Management in Boiling and Pressurized Water Reactor Coolant Systems - 0.15MB PDF
  • Pipe Rupture Probability Re-Assessment (XLPR) - 1.77MB PDF
  • Primary Water Stress Corrosion Cracking Characterization of Alloy 690 and Weld Metals - 0.29MB PDF
  • Stress Corrosion Cracking of Stainless Steel in PWR Environment - 0.21MB PDF
  • Nickel-Based Alloy Aging Management - 1.74MB PDF
Program Description

Materials aging effects must be managed effectively to ensure safe and reliable functionality is maintained throughout the life of the plant. Stress corrosion cracking and other degradation mechanisms in reactor coolant system components have resulted in forced and extended outages, increased inspection requirements, and component repairs and replacements. A better understanding of crack initiation and propagation processes and environmental corrosion in reactor coolant system components can help in developing reliable predictive models and cost-effective mitigation technologies.

The Materials Reliability Program conducts research to identify and resolve existing and potential issues impacting materials in pressurized water reactor (PWR) primary systems. Research activities inform operational and maintenance decisions for existing plants, design choices for new reactors, and regulatory actions pertaining to materials aging and degradation mechanisms. These activities are coordinated among PWR owners and operators to ensure the plants are proactively addressing materials degradation and aging.

Research Value

The primary systems are critical to the safe operation of PWR nuclear plants. The Materials Reliability Program assesses technical and regulatory issues regarding materials degradation in PWRs and pursues cost-effective inspection, evaluation, and mitigation approaches for assessing and addressing degradation. These activities provide tools that plants can use to maintain safe operation and avoid unnecessary outages. Program participants gain access to the following:

  • Strategic roadmaps outlining research gaps associated with key issues—such as PWR reactor internals aging management and reactor pressure vessel integrity through extended operation—and the collaborative actions needed to address these gaps

  • Detailed inspection and evaluation guidelines for susceptible areas of the reactor coolant system in pressurized water reactors

  • Technical bases to inform decisions regarding the extended operation of PWRs

  • Mitigation, repair, and replacement methodologies for aging degradation mechanisms

  • Technical analyses and technological options for evaluating and managing in-service degradation to respond to regulatory concerns

  • Guidance and tools for fatigue-specific materials management in existing plants and design guidance for new plants to address environmentally assisted fatigue

Approach

The Materials Reliability Program takes an integrated approach to degradation management in PWRs, encompassing assessment, mitigation, testing, inspection, and technical analysis. Through improved inspection techniques, new results from materials research and development, and plant operating experiences, best practices can be deployed to make cost-effective decisions. The program closely collaborates with other Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) programs, including BWR Vessel and Internals Project (BWRVIP), Steam Generator Management Program (SGMP), Primary Systems Corrosion Research (PSCR), Weld Repair and Technology Center (WRTC), Nondestructive Evaluation (NDE), Advanced Nuclear Technology (ANT), and Chemistry, as well as industry entities such as the PWR Owners Group, to ensure the research is coordinated and the guidance is consistent and effectively integrated.

There are both base and supplemental components to the Materials Reliability Program. The base portion largely focuses on reactor vessel integrity, fatigue management, and irradiated materials testing.

  • Reactor Pressure Vessel Integrity: To maintain safe, reliable operation within established limits, the structural integrity of the pressure vessel must be demonstrated under a series of normal operational conditions. Accurate methodologies are needed to analyze vessel integrity for neutron attenuation through the vessel wall, evaluate the effect of irradiation on the vessel and nozzles, and develop models for predicting fracture toughness as vessels operate longer.

  • Fatigue Management: The prospect of life extension underscores the need for accurate characterization of the effects of high-temperature coolant on component fatigue life, including design rules and inspection requirements. In addition, although guidance to address high-cycle thermal fatigue degradation in coolant system components due to cyclic stratification exists, the guidance needs to be evaluated to ensure it adequately addresses all reactor coolant system components.

  • Irradiated Materials Testing: Reactor internal components in PWRs may be affected by age-related degradation effects, including general material effects and irradiation-induced effects. Data collected through irradiated materials testing can support PWR reactor internals management through extended operation. Long-term irradiation effects are characterized by testing materials removed from retired plants or by conducting irradiation and post-irradiation testing of PWR materials at test reactors.

The supplemental portion of the Materials Reliability Program largely targets research needs related to nickel-base alloy aging management, pipe rupture probability, and reactor internals aging management.

  • Nickel-Base Alloy Aging Management: This project develops pragmatic technical guidance for inspecting, mitigating, and managing nickel-base alloys in PWRs to ensure safe operation and a low probability of safety-significant leakage. By reviewing the latest field results and comparing them to original assumptions in the technical basis for the guidelines, the Materials Reliability Program can identify best practices for managing nickel-base alloy issues.

  • Pipe Rupture Probability Reassessment: Through a collaborative effort between EPRI and the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission, the Materials Reliability Program is re-evaluating the analytical basis upon which the leak-before-break principle was developed for coolant system piping in PWRs. The program is responsible for several tasks related to the new calculation, including dissimilar metal weld residual stress measurements, mapping the extremely low probability of rupture (xLPR) calculation, and implementing the xLPR calculation plans.

  • Reactor Internals Aging Management: The Materials Reliability Program develops inspection and evaluation guidelines for PWR vessel internals to support the implementation and execution of effective aging management programs. These guidelines are developed and updated by integrating information and insights from the irradiated materials behavior database, functionality analysis results, inspection methods, flaw evaluation methods, plant design information, and plant operation data and experience.

Research focus areas containing multiple common projects are used as an approach to document the strategic objectives for each focused area of research. The Program’s 10 research focus areas are: Reactor Vessel Internals Assessment, Modeling & Inspection; Reactor Vessel Internals Irradiated Materials Testing; Alloy 600/690 Management, Mitigation and Inspection; Reliability of CASS Pressure Boundary Components; Pipe Rupture Probability Assessment; Stainless Steel Degradation Mechanism Studies; Fatigue Management (Thermal and Vibration); Replacement Materials Testing (Alloy 690/52/152); Reactor Pressure Integrity; and Environmentally Assisted Fatigue.

Accomplishments

EPRI’s Materials Reliability Program supports efforts to assess and implement countermeasures for degradation mechanisms impacting materials in PWR primary systems. Program research provides utilities and regulatory agencies with the information necessary to make technically sound and cost-effective decisions for managing degradation.

  • Developed generic safety- and reliability-driven strategies for materials management for nickel-base alloy components, reactor internals, reactor pressure vessels, and piping degradation due to thermal and environmental fatigue.

  • Published the Technical Basis for Reexamination Interval Extension for Alloy 690 PWR Reactor Vessel Top Head Penetration Nozzles (MRP-375), a technical analysis that uses laboratory and plant operating data to evaluate opportunities for optimizing the inspection interval for A690 reactor pressure vessel head penetration nozzles. Nuclear plants may be able to use this analysis to extend the current 10-year inspection interval to 20 years.

  • Published the Evaluation of the Reactor Vessel Beltline Shell Forgings of Operating U.S. PWRs for Quasi-Laminar Indications (MRP-367) and the Damage-Based Modeling and Analysis of Reactor Vessels with Numerous Base Metal Quasi-Laminar Indications (MRP-388). In 2012, quasi-laminar indications were discovered in the beltline ring forgings of two Belgian PWRs during ultrasonic inspection (UT). These reports assess the implications of that discovery for reactor pressure vessels (RPV) using either probabilistic fracture mechanics or a novel technique for RPV integrity. In the United States, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) cited MRP-367 in its justification for not requiring special vessel inspections at U.S. PWRs.

  • Reviewed recent thermal fatigue operating experience, identified gaps in the existing guidelines, and published an Interim Guidance Letter to manage the gaps. The Interim Guidance identified eight “Needed” requirements and two “Good Practice” recommendations that, when implemented, will help nuclear plants prevent cracks from exceeding Code allowable limits and prevent forced outages.

  • Published the Pressurized Water Reactor Internals Inspection and Evaluation Guidelines (MRP-227, Revision 1) and the Inspection Standard for Pressurized Water Reactor Internals - 2015 Update (MRP-228, Rev. 2). MRP-227, Revision 1 clarifies component identifications, rationalizes primary and expansion component relationships, incorporates operating experience and lessons learned over the past five years, and incorporates 2014 interim guidance for control rod guide assembly card inspections. MRP-228, Revision 2 is the inspection standard providing information on how to perform the inspections recommended in MRP-227, Revision 1. 

  • Published the Assessment of the Use of NUREG-0800 Branch Technical Position 5-3 Estimation Methods for Initial Fracture Toughness Properties of Reactor Pressure Vessel Steels (MRP-401, BWRVIP-287). 10CFR50, Appendix G requires that reactor pressure vessel integrity assessment use fracture toughness reference temperature, RTNDT. Approximately 46 PWR vessels were fabricated before the ASME Code began requiring the tests to determine Initial RTNDT. NUREG-0800 Branch Technical Position (BTP) 5-3 provides regulatory guidance for estimating RTNDT from other available test data, permitting compliance with Appendix G. In early 2014, some of the BTP 5-3 guidelines were identified as potentially non-conservative. MRP conducted a joint project with BWRVIP to assess the impact of these potentially non-conservative methods on vessel failure risk. Probabilistic fracture mechanics analyses showed a negligible increase in risk through 60 years of operation with continued use of the existing BTP 5-3 guidance.

  • Completed Revision 11 of the Inspection Data Survey Report, which compiles inspection data on the total number of components, the number inspected, the inspection methods, and results for inspections required per program guidelines. This report provides a high-level overview of susceptible component conditions in the PWR fleet, helps measure progress on industry initiatives, and helps assess aging risks.

Key Activities

The Materials Reliability Program research and development activities for 2017 will focus on aging management of reactor pressure vessels, reactor internals, piping, and nickel-base alloy components. The program will also develop data needed to revise materials management guidelines by conducting projects related to irradiated materials testing and nickel-base replacement alloys. Key efforts will include:

  • Resolve emergent issues in reactor pressure vessel integrity

  • Update thermal fatigue management guidance (including the 2015 interim guidance) and perform R&D in this area to refine and strengthen this management program

  • Support regulatory review of reactor internals aging management guidance (MRP-227, Revision 1) for license renewal and develop technical bases for updating this guidance for second license renewal (MRP-227, Revision 2) by testing irradiated materials, compiling materials data, modeling materials behavior, analyzing assessment approaches, and identifying viable inspection methods

  • Use software to calculate extremely low probability of rupture for nickel-base alloy dissimilar metal welds to inform the techncial discussion needed to resolve the leak before break issue

  • Assess Alloy 690/52/152 resistance to primary water stress corrosion cracking (includes crack growth rates and initiation testing);

  • Conduct research to examine how environmentally assisted fatigue can be addressed in both current and new plants in a consistent, practical manner that meets nuclear industry safety objectives.

Selected reports and products may be prepared in whole or in part in accordance with the EPRI Quality Program Manual that fulfills the requirements of 10CFR50 Appendix B and 10CFR21. The QA status of reports and products will be marked and identified.

Overview

Road Maps

EPRI has developed the following roadmaps to guide research in key technical areas. These roadmaps provide a communication tool for determining what success looks like, identifying research tasks necessary to meet goals, and clarifying roles for all stakeholders.

  • Welding of Irradiated Materials For PWR And BWR Internals - 2.64MB PDF
  • Alloy 52 Nickel-Base Filler Metal Weldability Solution - 0.25MB PDF
  • Characterizing and Controlling Weld Residual Stress - 0.27MB PDF
  • Powder Metallurgy-Hot Isostatic Pressing for Reactor Pressure Vessel Internals and Pressure Retaining Applications - 2.40MB PDF
  • Spent Fuel Pool and Transfer Canal Liner Degradation Management - 1.52MB PDF
Program Description

High-quality repair/replacement methodologies, mitigation processes, and dependable welding solutions are critical to safe nuclear plant operation. The safety significance of component repairs and replacements emphasizes the need for a high degree of confidence in the integrity of joining processes and implementation techniques. The use of new technologies and process procedures can lead to extended plant life, higher productivity rates, and improved material properties, contributing to cost savings in maintenance, fabrication, and repair activities while maintaining a commitment to quality and safety.

The Welding & Repair Technology Center (WRTC) develops and tests advanced materials, joining, and repair technologies for nuclear plant applications, supporting the implementation of safe, effective welding and repair technologies and procedures in the field. The program also supports interactions with code and regulatory entities, providing technical input to inform the development and modification of new and existing code requirements, and new technologies.

Research Value

Research results from the WRTC help nuclear power plants deploy safe, effective, less costly repairs using novel welding techniques and apply existing techniques to new applications. Research results are also used to inform interactions with regulators regarding code requirements and applicability. Program participants gain access to the following:

  • Repair options for key components, supplemented by application guidelines, procedures, and training

  • Information exchange forums for sharing operating experience, nuclear weld program issues, and emerging issues

  • Research focus areas and strategic roadmaps outlining research gaps associated with key issues—such as advanced nickel-base filler metals, welding of irradiated materials in boiling and pressurized water reactors, and advanced welding processes—and the collaborative actions needed to address these technology gaps

  • Proven repair, replacement and fabrication techniques and technologies that can improve material performance, enable safe component life extension, increase plant availability, and reduce repair costs

  • Benchmarking information from nuclear plant welding programs, repair and replacement programs, and industry practices

  • Advanced welding technologies and techniques that can improve welding residual stress profiles, inspectability, weldability, and productivity; such techniques can reduce base metal interactions and may be necessary to provide repair solutions for irradiated materials and high-chromium nickel-base filler metals, and improve material properties

  • Materials, welding, and repair experts across the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) and peers in the nuclear industry

  • Support during implementation of plant repair activities involving material interactions, weld process control, and code requirements

Approach

The Welding & Repair Technology Center combines extensive laboratory capabilities with detailed familiarity with industry and regulatory needs to investigate and evaluate welding, fabrication, and repair techniques. EPRI can replicate welding field conditions such as techniques, materials, joining processes, and equipment to create realistic welding environments in the laboratory. Through participation in industry code and technical committees, the program also ensures that the research results inform technical bases for code requirements.

To address strategic objectives established for WRTC, EPRI has developed 11 research focus areas to plan, coordinate, and execute needed research:

  • Nickel-Base Filler Metal Weldability and New Alloy Development

  • Irradiated Materials Welding Solutions

  • Identify, Research, Develop, and Mature Advanced Welding Processes

  • Optimize Joining, Fabrication, and Repair Processes

  • Small Bore Piping Asset

  • Transfer & Promote Fabrication & Joining Technologies into Codes, Standards, & Regulations

  • Buried Pipe Asset Management / Repair Solutions

  • Repair Solutions for Structures: Containment, Fuel Pool Asset Management, Spent Fuel Storage

  • Tactical Implementation of Repair Methods

  • Document & Evaluate Operating Experience for Welding & Repair Programs

  • Thermal Spray Coatings and Hardfacing Applications

In addition, roadmaps have been developed for certain issues that require cross-industry collaboration among multiple entities. Current roadmaps include: Welding of Irradiated Materials for Reactor Internals; Weldability Assessment of Alloy 52/52M Weld Metals; Advanced Welding Process Development in the Nuclear Power Industry; Incorporation of Fabrication, Repair, and Joining Technologies in Nuclear Codes and Standards; and Advanced Welding Development to Support Repairs of Spent Fuel Pools and Spent Fuel Storage Containers.

Regular engagement with code organizations and other technical bodies helps inform the implementation of new repair methods, welding procedures, and weld materials within acceptable safety limits. WRTC regularly interfaces with the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) and other code and regulatory bodies to share research and technical results that can help inform decisions and regulations regarding a wide range of component repairs.

Accomplishments

EPRI’s Welding & Repair Technology Center supports nuclear power industry efforts to develop and apply welding and repair techniques that enhance safety, inform regulatory issues, reduce maintenance costs, and improve productivity.

  • Supported development of the technical bases for new code cases on post-weld examination hold times, temper bead welding, and use of dissimilar metal weld overlays for stress corrosion cracking mitigation.

  • Provided annual update to the Repair Welding Handbook and ASME Code activities, which assists nuclear power plants in choosing appropriate repair techniques and complying with regulatory and code processes.

  • Demonstrated the feasibility of in-vessel underwater repairs of critical components, eliminating the need to drain the reactor vessel. Areas that have been addressed include weldability of irradiated materials, seal welding capabilities, temper bead welding, and hot cracking susceptibility.

  • Provided guidance for fabrication and welding with high-chromium nickel base materials to support implementation of repair procedures utilizing these alloys, and to understand and ultimately reduce typical welding-related defects, such as ductility dip cracking, hot cracking, and general weldability issues.

  • Evaluated Alloy-52-type materials and derivatives to support alloy selection and grading (screening) to distinguish heat-to-heat variations in weldability.

  • Developed guidance for overlay applications based on lessons learned, best practices, and weld studies to support current technology. Also supported development of new and higher production welding processes such as gas-metal arc welding.

  • Evaluated new repair techniques for non-metallic repairs for spent fuel pools, buried piping, and high-density polyethylene piping, which is gaining traction as an alternative to steel in low-energy applications.

Key Activities

Welding & Repair Technology Center research and development for 2017 will focus on addressing technology gaps related to safe repair and fabrication technologies, benchmarking, training, and code implementation. Specific efforts include:

  • Establish welding criteria for repair and mitigation of irradiated material used in nuclear reactor internals; validate the criteria using hot cell facility.

  • Develop training and workshops to support technology transfer and knowledge capture for early career staff and engineers new to utility repair and replacement programs. These knowledge transfer tools (including computer based training and regional classes) will address topics such as operational leakage, code applications, socket welding, welding fundamentals, welding programs and advanced welding processes.

  • Provide benchmarking and compile best practices to support development and implementation of effective welding programs, health assessments and repair and replacement (R&R) programs.

  • Identify repair/mitigation options that address buried piping issues, fuel pool leakage, spent fuel containers, and components susceptible to stress corrosion cracking.

  • Conduct technical analyses to evaluate advanced welding processes and applications that could be used for component replacement, mitigation, and repair, thereby supporting code compliance and utilization of new welding processes.

  • Provide technical support for implementing new technologies, including application guides for advanced welding methods that can improve inspection, welding residual stress profile, weldability and productivity.

Selected reports and products may be prepared in whole or in part in accordance with the EPRI Quality Program Manual that fulfills the requirements of 10CFR50 Appendix B and 10CFR21. The QA status of reports and products will be marked and identified.

    Research results from the WRTC help nuclear power plants deploy safe, effective, less costly repairs using novel welding techniques and apply existing techniques to new applications. Research results are also used to inform interactions with regulators regarding code requirements and applicability. Program participants gain access to the following:

    • Repair options for key components, supplemented by application guidelines, procedures, and training

    • Information exchange forums for sharing operating experience, nuclear weld program issues, and emerging issues

    • Research focus areas and strategic roadmaps outlining research gaps associated with key issues—such as advanced nickel-base filler metals, welding of irradiated materials in boiling and pressurized water reactors, and advanced welding processes—and the collaborative actions needed to address these technology gaps

    • Proven repair, replacement and fabrication techniques and technologies that can improve material performance, enable safe component life extension, increase plant availability, and reduce repair costs

    • Benchmarking information from nuclear plant welding programs, repair and replacement programs, and industry practices

    • Advanced welding technologies and techniques that can improve welding residual stress profiles, inspectability, weldability, and productivity; such techniques can reduce base metal interactions and may be necessary to provide repair solutions for irradiated materials and high-chromium nickel-base filler metals, and improve material properties

    • Materials, welding, and repair experts across the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) and peers in the nuclear industry

    • Support during implementation of plant repair activities involving material interactions, weld process control, and code requirements

    • RFA 1 WRTC Nickel-Base Filler Metal Weldability Solutions: Alloy 52 Weldability and New Alloy Development
      25-Jan-2017

      Presently, two distinct resolution approaches are being pursued under this research area. The first is optimization of Alloy 52 weldability and strategic development of solutions for specific problems associated with Alloy 52 weldability. The approach addressed in this Research Focus Area addresses improved mapping of Alloy 52 and development of tools that provide for improved results associated with Alloy 52 weldability. This solution approach is described in Roadmap NUC_MAT­08­R1. The second approach involves development of an alternate weld filler metal that retains adequate margins to PWSCC, but also resolves weldability problems. This   approach is described in Roadmap NUC_MAT­09­R1.

      Design Applicability:  Applicability is judged to be high for PWRs, VVERs, and CANDUs where Alloy 52 is being used. Solutions developed can be applied to both operating and advanced reactors. Applicability to operating BWRs is low due to the limited use of Alloy 52 in the BWR fleet to date. Applicability to advanced BWRs is also judged to be low since current design plans include modified Alloy 82 and not Alloy 52.

    • RFA 10 WRTC Document & Evaluate Operating Experience for Welding & Repair Programs
      25-Jan-2017

      This Research Focus Area addresses trending and tracking of industry performance, development/maintenance of guideline documents and technology transfer. Training, information exchange and operating experience topics are included in this focus area.

      Design Applicability:  

      Applicability is focused on resolution of issues for operating systems, although there is some applicability for advanced reactor designs (new plants).

    • RFA 4 WRTC Optimize Joining, Fabrication, and Repair Processes (including Residual Stress Optimization)
      25-Jan-2017

      This Research Focus Area addresses the opportunity to optimize and improve established welding processes and procedures, and to optimize residual stresses through surface conditioning and other techniques.

      Design Applicability: There is a broad applicability to both BWRs and PWRs. Applicability is highest for those components having significant susceptibility to SCC and / or IASCC. The greatest opportunities will be related to high-temperature, high alloy systems (e.g. NSSS systems), where optimization of welding processes and improved understanding of residual stresses (and the related influence on degradation) is of significant importance.

      For advanced designs, there is an opportunity to resolve many SCC concerns through application of welding / joining processes that do not induce significant residual stresses in the weld and HAZ regions. As a result, the applicability of this work, if expanded to address new construction, could be significant.

    • RFA 7 WRTC Buried Pipe Asset Management / Repair Solutions
      25-Jan-2017

      Buried piping can have significant degradation and in some instances the repair and replacement of these systems and components are difficult and costly to the utility. This RFA investigates repair technologies that can increase operable life of buried piping, reduce welded repair durations, and research new materials such as non-metallic repairs.

      Design Applicability:  From a welding & repair technology perspective, buried piping issues are independent of plant design type and are instead primarily dependent on the nature of the buried pipe and associated design and installation details. As such, this Research Focus Area is generically applicable to both BWRs and PWRs.

    • RFA 8 WRTC Repair Solutions for Structures: Containment and Fuel Pool Asset Management
      25-Jan-2017

      This Research Focus Area address the need for development of repair solutions for critical nuclear structures, with the current focus being placed on containment and spent fuel pool (SFP) structures. OE indicates that degradation of containment liners does occur and is being identified with greater frequency as plants age. Leakage of SFP liners, most likely due to SCC occurring at liner welds, is an ongoing industry problem. This focus area will also include issues related to Dry Cask Storage Systems (DCSS) and Chloride Induced SCC (CISCC) repair by FSW and other processes.

       

      Design Applicability:

      Applicability includes BWRs and PWRs. SFP repair solutions are independent of design type.

      The repair needs and associated solution technologies will be different for BWR and PWR containment structures. Repair technologies developed will need to address several design configurations. SFP and containment repair technologies may eventually be applicable for advanced reactor designs (new plants), but are not near-term concerns.

      Dry Casks Storage Systems are available in a variety of designs and provided by different vendors, however, the repair and mitigation options will be applicable to all designs.

    • RFA 9 WRTC Tactical Implementation of Repair Methods
      25-Jan-2017

      This Research Focus Area addresses implementation of specific repair solutions, primarily in the form of guidance for implementation. This Research Focus Area represents one of the ways WRTC transfers information from research into practical use for members.

      Design Applicability:

      Applicability is focused on resolution of issues for operating BWRs and PWRs. There is relatively less applicability for advanced reactor designs (new plants).

Overview

Road Maps

EPRI has developed the following roadmaps to guide research in key technical areas. These roadmaps provide a communication tool for determining what success looks like, identifying research tasks necessary to meet goals, and clarifying roles for all stakeholders.

  • Mitigation of Fuel Failures Caused By Foreign Material - 0.32MB PDF
  • Loss of Coolant Accident (LOCA) Regulation - 0.28MB PDF
  • Silicon Carbide Composite BWR Channel Development - 0.26MB PDF
  • Development of Accident Tolerant Fuel Using Molybdenum Alloy Cladding - 0.27MB PDF
Program Description

Fuel failures and other fuel-related issues can have significant operational impacts on nuclear power plants. Failures, for example, can cost tens of millions of dollars per event to cover replacement power and the costs of a fuel reload if the unit has to shut down to replace the leaking assembly. While the industry has made substantial progress in reducing the frequency of fuel failures, sustaining this success will require continued attention to technical gaps impacting fuel reliability. There are also opportunities to enhance the performance of nuclear fuel under accident conditions through more robust materials.

The Fuel Reliability Program (FRP) drives improvements in nuclear fuel performance and reliability based on issues encountered at operating plants around the world. Research addresses multiple aspects of fuel performance and reliability, including fuel failure root-cause resolution, fuel/water chemistry interactions, operational margins through end of life, and improved safety margins during accident conditions. The new knowledge is then applied to update fuel reliability guidance and tutorial handbooks, to develop new and enhance existing software products, and to provide technical feedback for new fuel designs. The program also engages nuclear regulatory agencies to provide technical input informing fuel-related regulations.

Research Value

About $45-$50 billion of nuclear fuel is operating in commercial reactors worldwide. Optimizing use of this fuel while ensuring its safe operation is paramount to reliable and cost-effective nuclear plant operation. Fuel Reliability Program participants gain access to the following:

  • A strategic matrix that identifies gaps and coordinates technical efforts among utilities, EPRI, and other stakeholders. The matrix is integral to identifying strategic focus areas where research is needed.

  • Technical guidance to improve fuel reliability and reduce economic risks associated with fuel failures, which have cost the U.S. nuclear industry more than $300 million over the past decade and the global nuclear industry 2–3 times that amount.

  • New nondestructive evaluation (NDE) techniques that allow some fuel examinations that have historically been performed at costly off-site hot cell facilities to be performed on-site in the spent fuel pool.

  • Global operating experience with all types of nuclear fuel assemblies and reactor types to inform decision-making.

  • State-of-the-art software tools to analyze fuel rod thermo-mechanical performance and assess crud and corrosion risk under a range of operating conditions, helping nuclear plants safely manage a variety of margins.

  • Technical studies to inform regulations impacting nuclear fuel.

  • Assessment of breakthrough fuel concepts that could provide additional response time before damage and fission product release occurs in accident scenarios.

Approach

The Fuel Reliability Program develops knowledge, guidance, and tools to maximize the reliability of nuclear fuel and core components. The program also participates in international research efforts to improve fundamental understanding of in-reactor behavior of fuel, cladding, control materials, and other core components.

There are both base and supplemental components to the Fuel Reliability Program. The base program focuses on fuel-related issues that generally apply to two or more nuclear steam supply system designs. Projects commonly focus on fuel performance and reliability by quantifying fuel operational margins and identifying fuel failure mechanisms through poolside and hot cell examinations. Projects are often cost-shared with fuel vendors to ensure information is factored into subsequent fuel designs, thereby driving improvements in fuel reliability. An important strategic focus area relates to advancing nondestructive poolside techniques to quantify fuel performance margins, locate failed fuel rods, and identify the cause of failure, as well as measure distortion of fuel assemblies, components and BWR channel boxes. An industry-wide fuel reliability database, which compiles data on failure root causes, fuel reliability statistics, and good operating practices, is also maintained through the base program.

A separate research effort is evaluating breakthrough fuel technologies. Several technology options are available that offer potential benefits in terms of higher melting temperatures and reduced hydrogen generation during severe accidents. Along with the U.S. Department of Energy, OECD’s Nuclear Energy Agency, nuclear fuel vendors, universities, and other research organizations, EPRI is evaluating and developing promising concepts to overcome potential barriers to commercialization, such as ease of fabrication.

The supplemental portion of the Fuel Reliability Program addresses technical issues with regulatory implications and technical issues confronting corrosion and crud control in both boiling and pressurized water reactors. EPRI informs regulatory issues by participating in experimental programs and performing independent analyses to better understand various accident criteria. Areas of focus include the applicability of existing reactivity-initiated accident (RIA) and loss-of-coolant-accident (LOCA) criteria to high- and intermediate-burnup fuel.

With respect to corrosion and crud control, EPRI research helps improve the understanding of and the links between fuel operation, water chemistry, crud, and fuel reliability in both PWRs and BWRs. The research combines fuel surveillance programs and laboratory and mechanistic studies to develop various guidelines and improve predictive capabilities. Plant demonstrations verify that new technologies and changes in chemistry regimes or core operating strategies do not adversely affect fuel performance.

The program has developed 16 research focus areas to coordinate what R&D is performed and how that R&D is executed:

  • Development of Nondestructive Examination (NDE) Techniques     

  • Fuel Cycle Optimization   

  • PWR Cladding Corrosion Issues

  • Loss of Coolant Accidents (LOCA)

  • Fuel Integrity Monitoring & Causal Analysis

  • Breakthrough Fuel Technologies

  • PWR Crud Issues

  • Reactivity Initiated Accidents (RIA)

  • Hydrogen Impact on Zirconium Materials

  • BWR Cladding Corrosion Issues

  • PWR Fuel Assembly Structural Component Issues

  • BWR Channel Distortion Mitigation

  • Sustained Fuel Reliability Performance

  • BWR Crud Issues

  • BWR Control Blade Integrity

  • BWR Fuel Assembly Structural Component Issues

Participants can access targeted research activities available through separately funded projects:

  • Falcon User Group: a forum for contributing experience and lessons learned with the Falcon fuel performance software code.

  • Nuclear Fuel Industry Research Program: a global collaboration of utilities, fuel vendors, and research entities, led by EPRI, focused on generic, long-term issues and opportunities to ensure safe and reliable use of core materials and components.

Accomplishments

EPRI’s Fuel Reliability Program distills global experience with nuclear fuel into actionable guidance and insights that drive measurable improvements in fuel reliability.

  • Interim reactivity insertion accident (RIA) criteria have been proposed based on evaluations that combined experimental data from a variety of sources with transient fuel rod analysis calculations. Key to the results were the effects of burnup on BWR and PWR fuel rod failures. New data from novel modified burst tests on different cladding materials prompted new formulation of pellet cladding mechanical interaction (PCMI) failure curves for PWRs and BWRs.

  • Critical attributes for fuel fabrication oversight have been documented to supplement the Program’s Fuel Design Evaluation Handbook (FDEH). The FDEH provides technical oversight guidance for nuclear fuel and core component fabrication/manufacturing, while contributing to mitigation of defects and performance issues in boiling and pressurized water reactors (BWRs and PWRs).

  • The Falcon Fuel Rod Performance Code has been updated. This software combines steady-state and transient thermal/mechanical finite element (FE) to analyze light water reactor fuel behavior. The modeling approach employed by Falcon can analyze both normal operation and accident conditions for fuel rod average burn-up levels approaching 80 gigawatt days per metric ton of uranium (GWd/tU).

  • Development of a best-estimate model that is used to predict bounding BWR channel bow performance. The model assists in the evaluation of channel bow-induced channel-control blade interference risk for an existing or planned core configuration—thereby assisting the utility and core designer in mitigating that risk.

  • Developed a new nuclear fuel fragmentation testing technique that allows direct observation of the fragmentation process. Experiments using the new technique are easy and economical to perform, making it feasible to conduct a large number of tests for the same cost. Test results have been shown to be similar to those that were seen in traditional integral tests.

  • Conducted a confirmatory fuel surveillance campaign at Peach Bottom 3 following the first application of early hydrogen water chemistry injection in the United States. Surveillance results provided the basis to assess the impact of early hydrogen injection on fuel performance for BWRs that wish to apply this technology for intergranular stress corrosion cracking (IGSCC) mitigation.

  • Conducted a fuel surveillance campaign at Comanche Peak to determine the effects of reactor coolant elevated pH and lithium on fuel cladding corrosion performance. The Fuel Reliability Program sponsored an earlier demonstration of these effects at Comanche Peak, but this surveillance campaign bridged a knowledge gap after these units had raised fuel duty and integrated-lithium exposure.

  • Performed numerous laboratory and hot cell testing and qualification projects to support the application of Frequency-Scanning Eddy Current Technique (F-SECT) to nondestructive measurements of corrosion, metal thickness, and absorbed hydrogen in zirconium-based fuel assembly structural components. These projects serve as the bases for transferring this technology to the commercial light water reactor industry.

Key Activities

Fuel Reliability Program research and development (R&D) for 2017 will focus on a number of remaining fuel reliability gaps, including the continuing threat of foreign materials, the effects of new water chemistry regimes on fuel reliability, development of non-destructive examination equipment, and fuel reliability training. Specific efforts will include the following:

  • Revision of the Fuel Failure and Monitoring Handbook. Last revised in 2010, the update will include fuel failure data from the last 10 years; correlation of cycle radiochemistry data with post irradiation examination (PIE) data; and identification of trends that will assist with diagnosis of tight fuel failures.

  • Execute projects that support a new research focus area: Fuel Cycle Optimization. These activities will (1) identify those issues that currently prevent the implementation of more efficient core designs; and (2) address identified constraints through base-level research.

  • Perform fuel failure and operational issue investigations for events with industry-wide implications.

  • Perform hot cell investigations to improve the understanding of BWR fuel cladding hydrogen pickup to support operational and regulatory issues.

  • Perform poolside investigations of the impact of operating with combined elevated lithium and zinc coolant chemistries in PWRs.

  • Assess key contributors to cracking behavior of Alloy 718 components of PWR assembly components, and develop optimized thermo-mechanical treatments and alloy chemistry to mitigate cracking.

  • Develop nondestructive examination equipment to measure PWR assembly distortion, BWR channel distortion, and hydrogen pick-up by fuel assembly components in BWRs and PWRs.

  • Improve existing PWR risk assessment tools to avoid crud-induced power shift and crud-induced corrosion including incorporation of an explicit model for zinc behavior.

  • Develop a test standard and evaluate cladding degradation under long-term cooling conditions after a LOCA transient.

  • Refine risk assessment tool for BWRs to better understand interactions between water chemistry, cladding, and fuel duty.

  • Develop alternative fuel cladding and BWR channel materials that provide operators more time to mitigate core damage under severe accident conditions.

Selected reports and products may be prepared in whole or in part in accordance with the EPRI Quality Program Manual that fulfills the requirements of 10CFR50 Appendix B and 10CFR21. The QA status of reports and products will be marked and identified.

  • FALCON Maintenance
    23-May-2016

    Falcon helps answer questions on how light water reactor (LWR) fuel rods behave when the unit is operated under various conditions. The software tool provides best estimate values of critical parameters such as local cladding hoop stress/stain and rod internal gas pressure/composition, which are essential in making comparisons with design, accident and operational limits. 

    Falcon predicts fuel pellet and cladding material states and geometric conditions as they evolve, enabling predictions to be made regarding LWR fuel rod behavior when subjected to an upset loading situation that may lead to fuel rod cladding failures.
