Program Name: Used Fuel and High-Level Waste Management Program
text:
Overview

Road Maps

EPRI has developed the following roadmaps to guide research in key technical areas. These roadmaps provide a communication tool for determining what success looks like, identifying research tasks necessary to meet goals, and clarifying roles for all stakeholders.

  • Used Fuel Extended Storage - 1.92MB PDF
  • High Burn-Up Fuel Transportation - 0.31MB PDF
  • Used Fuel Storage, Transportation, and Disposal Criticality Control - 1.62MB PDF
Program Description

Nuclear power's long-term viability depends on continued safe, cost-effective management of used fuel and high-level waste (HLW). An integrated solution encompassing long-term interim storage, transportation, and permanent geologic disposal is achievable, but requires significant research and technology development.

The Used Fuel and High-Level Waste Management program examines a range of complex scientific and technical issues affecting used fuel and HLW management, including used fuel long-term storage, used fuel transportation, and geologic disposal. Research related to these issues informs regulatory, industry, and national decisions on waste management; supports safe on-site handling and long-term storage of used fuel; establishes the technical bases for transportation of high-burnup used fuel; and provides insight into technical advances required to develop an integrated waste management solution.

Research Value

Better understanding of the options available for managing the technical, economic, environmental, and institutional aspects of used fuel and high-level waste management is needed to inform decision making. The Electric Power Research Institute's (EPRI’s) Used Fuel and High-Level Waste Management program conducts research to characterize the various technical risks and risk mitigation options related to used fuel storage, transportation, and disposal. Program participants gain access to the following:

  • Strategic roadmaps outlining research gaps associated with key issues—such as high-burnup fuel transportation, used fuel criticality and burnup credit management in storage and transportation, and extended used fuel storage—and the collaborative actions needed to address these gaps

  • Technical analyses and guidance to support safe storage of low-burnup and high-burnup used fuel and high-level waste over extended periods

  • Technical evaluations of alternative geologic repository systems

  • Technical basis to resolve generic used fuel storage and transportation issues impacting plant operability, license renewal, decommissioning, and the ability to move fuel off-site

  • Development of more realistic methodologies for estimating criticality in spent fuel pools and dry storage, during transportation, and for permanent disposal

  • Assessment of the long-term performance of neutron poison materials, and a database of the properties of neutron absorber materials

  • Improved understanding of used fuel storage pools in accident conditions to inform nuclear plant design and operational decisions.

Approach

The Used Fuel and High-Level Waste Management program develops knowledge, guidance, and tools to reduce the risks and maximize the technical options for safe, cost-effective handling, storage, transportation, and disposal. The program incorporates global experience with fuel handling and fuel reprocessing, and collaborates with global entities on cross-cutting research addressing extended used fuel storage, and supporting elements.

Base research activities address the following research focus areas:

  • Aging Management of Dry Fuel Storage System Components: Given the lack of options for ultimate disposition of used nuclear fuel in many countries, multi-decade storage in dry storage systems may be required. Thus, aging management of storage system components subject to degradation is a critical research area. Important storage system components subject to aging degradation include the concrete overpacks used in canister based systems and seals in bolted metal cask designs. However, the thin-walled stainless steel canisters used in canister based systems have received the most attention globally due to the perceived potential for development of chloride-induced stress corrosion cracks over time. As a consequence, recent efforts in this research focus area have focused on development of the technical basis for aging management of stainless steel canisters. Parallel work is underway to develop non-destructive examination techniques – and associated delivery systems – to allow early detection of incipient cracks in the canisters before they threaten confinement integrity.

  • Criticality Control during Used Fuel Storage and Transport: Control of nuclear criticality is a primary safety concern during used fuel storage. Ensuring safety is addressed by controlling the configuration of the used fuel, the use of neutron absorbing materials, or both. As both reactors and dry storage systems extend their operations beyond initial licensed periods, continued performance of neutron absorbers needs to be assured. Work in this research focus area includes testing to evaluate the long-term performance of neutron absorbing materials; development of alternative neutron absorbing materials; improvement of computational models used to determine criticality safety margins; experimentally derived benchmarks for assessing the bias and uncertainty of computational models; and development of in-situ and ex-situ test methods for evaluating the performance of neutron absorbing materials.

  • Used Fuel Cladding Performance during Extended Storage and Transportation: Irradiation of fuel cladding material (primarily zirconium-based alloys) leads to changes in the mechanical properties of the materials. Further changes may occur during periods of extended storage, such as changes in material strength and ductility. It is important to understand the mechanisms driving the changes, the environmental parameters controlling their occurrence, and the timeframes at which changes may occur. Most importantly, it is critical to identify and understand those changes that could affect the performance of the cladding alloys during storage and subsequent transportation. For example, hydride reorientation in high-burnup fuel (>45 GWd/MTU) can degrade the ductile behavior of the cladding when fuel assemblies are subjected to normal or transient pinch loads.

  • Technical Basis for Disposition of Used Nuclear Fuel: While most countries have committed to deep geological disposal of used nuclear fuel, no facility exists today. Some countries are evaluating long-term centralized interim storage of spent fuel until a national used fuel disposal policy is established and suitable disposal facilities are sited, designed and constructed. Research can inform the technical basis for disposal and/or long-term management plans, including: risk assessments for proposed disposal or long-term storage facilities; technical input to environmental impact assessments; input on technical issues related to fuel reprocessing; and technical input to risk assessments associated with transportation of fuel for permanent disposal or long-term storage at centralized interim storage facilities.

Through a separate supplemental project, nuclear plant owners can contribute to the continued development, maintenance, and sharing of lessons learned for the Cask Loader software program. Cask Loader provides analyses to support the safe, economic movement of used fuel from wet to dry storage with reduced documentation errors.

Accomplishments

EPRI’s Used Fuel and High-Level Waste Management program provides specialized technical analysis to support the safe, economical management of used fuel and high-level waste (storage, transportation, and disposal) and to inform decisions regarding the viability of various nuclear fuel cycles.

  • Assessed the economic and radiation impacts associated with accelerated transfer of used fuel to dry storage. The study determined that an industry-wide requirement to move used nuclear fuel into dry storage after five years of cooling would result in a net present value cost increase of $3.5 to $3.9 billion compared to current practice. The study also determined the U.S. industry-wide reduction in spent fuel assembly inventory, decay heat, and Cs-137 inventory would be in the range of 67 to 78%, 23 to 32%, and 43 to 53%, respectively.

  • Completed the development of pressurized water reactor (PWR) spent fuel pool criticality reactivity decrement benchmarks and additional sensitivity studies using operational data from pressurized water reactors. This results of this research are under review by the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) and the International Atomic Energy Agency, with endorsement expected in 2016. The research will inform a pending Regulatory Guide on determination of burnup credit.

  • Initiated the Accelerated Boral Corrosion test program, a five-year program that aims to understand the performance and potential degradation issues with Boral over extended time (>95 years).

  • Completed a broad chloride-induced stress corrosion cracking (CISCC) “susceptibility assessment” to prioritize which in-service canisters should be inspected for signs of pitting or cracking earlier than others. This work will be incorporated in the aging management strategy for stainless steel canisters used in dry cask storage systems.

  • Completed harvesting of Boral neutron absorber panels from the retired Zion nuclear power plant. These panels will be evaluated for degradation in neutron absorber performance as part of ongoing research on aging management of neutron absorber materials.

  • Demonstrated prototype robotic delivery systems being developed to deploy nondestructive evaluation (NDE), temperature monitoring and radiation detection equipment for inspection of stainless steel canisters in dry cask storage systems. Demonstrations of the equipment at additional vendor and plant sites will continue through 2017 as equipment design is finalized.

  • Continued collection of data on high burnup advanced cladding properties to support short- and long-term used fuel storage followed by transportation.

  • For the high-burnup demonstration project, completed shipment of sister rods to the test facility; completed design of special penetrations through the TN-32 cask lid to obtain temperature data and gas samples; and completed preparation of documents needed to license the research cask.

Key Activities

Used Fuel and High-Level Waste Management program research and development for 2017 will focus on generic used fuel storage and transportation issues. Specific efforts include:

  • Develop technical basis to inform licensing decisions regarding high-burnup used fuel transportation systems.

  • Obtain additional data on high-burnup, advanced nuclear fuel claddings to support used fuel storage, transportation, and disposal.

  • Complete external review of the EPRI PWR reactivity decrement uncertainty model by the NRC and the International Atomic Energy Agency. The reactivity decrement benchmarks and associated sensitivity studies provide the technical bases for assessing the uncertainty in the estimation of the spent fuel pool criticality (k-eff).

  • Analyze Boral samples from accelerated corrosion tests that simulate performance over more than 19 years. Compare third-year accelerated test results to the existing EPRI Boral coupon database, which contains coupon data from the past 25 years. Continue testing remaining coupons for the next two years to gain better understanding of long-term (>95 years) performance and degradation issues. This will provide information to determine how long Boral will last in spent fuel pools prior to there being enough degradation to cause loss of neutron absorber (boron) material.

  • Continue Zion comparative analysis project of three independent measurement and analysis methods to gain a better understanding of performance and potential degradation issues: complete analysis of existing spent fuel pool coupons and compare to previous coupon analysis results; complete analysis of the results of in situ measurements using BADGER after fuel offload from the pool; and complete destructive analysis of sections cut from existing panels.

  • Complete the development of the aging management guidance for welded stainless steel dry storage canisters; and continue development of prototype NDE systems capable of detecting stress-corrosion cracks on the canister surfaces.

  • Demonstrate robotic NDE and monitoring equipment delivery systems at additional plant and vendor sites. This effort will culminate in the use of the completed system to perform an in-service cask inspection on a loaded cask.

  • For the high-burnup demonstration project, complete the fabrication work to modify the TN-32 cask; support NRC review of the License Amendment Request (and supporting Design and Licensing Basis Document); and initiate pre-storage characterization of the sister rods.

Selected reports and products may be prepared in whole or in part in accordance with the EPRI Quality Program Manual that fulfills the requirements of 10CFR50 Appendix B and 10CFR21. The quality assurance status of reports and products will be marked and identified.

Program Description

Plant owners must be responsive to the changes that can occur in materials and components integral to plant operations. By understanding these material changes in advance of failure, plants can avoid unsafe operational conditions and minimize mitigation and maintenance costs. Nondestructive evaluation (NDE) is an effective tool for assessing component condition, and depends on correct deployment of qualified technologies, inspection personnel, and procedures.

Power plant owners use NDE to inform engineering analysis and strategic decisions on whether to continue to operate a component, or to plan and execute mitigation, repair, or replacement. The NDE Program identifies and develops technologies to quickly, accurately, and cost-effectively examine and characterize nuclear components, and also serves as a focal point for demonstration and qualification. The NDE Program’s research frequently comprises the technical basis used to inform ASME Code or regulatory actions related to pre-service and in-service examinations. 

A population of proficient, informed technicians delivering robustly qualified NDE technologies and procedures is essential to the safe, reliable long-term operation of the nuclear fleet.

Research Value

Research results from the NDE Program support deployment of examination and structural health monitoring technologies to the nuclear power industry to minimize unplanned maintenance and maximize plant safety. Tools for risk-informing the examination scope help power plant owners make decisions regarding the need for examinations in terms of their contribution to plant safety. These activities provide for higher plant availability and safety, lower operating costs, and lower radiation exposure to workers. NDE Program participants gain access to the following:

  • NDE technologies, nuclear-specific NDE training, codes and standards support and regulatory compliance support that can shorten plant outages and avoid costs associated with repairs and replacement power.

  • NDE diagnostic capabilities useful during extended plant operation, informing regulatory consideration of life extensions.

  • Technical support to address various inspection issues and challenges: inspection and evaluation guidelines issued through the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) and industry materials analysis programs; independent expert evaluation of the results of difficult examinations, or of unexpected indication resolution needs; first-of-a-kind inspections; examination oversight that can lead to improved pre-service and in-service inspections and NDE related decisions; and apparent cause or root cause analysis of NDE events.

  • Demonstration and qualification processes for NDE personnel, procedures, and equipment in accordance with American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) Section XI, Appendix VIII, and expert assistance in complying with other qualification regimes used globally by industry.

  • The means of a strengthened NDE workforce through human performance analytics, focused advanced multi-media training, and skills inventory maintenance and assessment methods.

The NDE Program significantly contributes to public benefit by ensuring that qualified and advanced examination technologies are available for use by industry to assess material degradation and component integrity. The NDE information is vital to engineering analysis of system and component operability and integrity. As plants age, the information provided by the effective delivery of NDE is integral to successful asset management and operations.

Approach

The NDE Program develops and demonstrates cost-effective and reliable examination methods and analysis programs that can be integral to structural and lifetime evaluations of power plant components and systems. NDE results contribute to more accurate characterization of nuclear component condition and help inform decisions on whether to mitigate, repair, or replace a component, or to continue its operation.

A wide range of NDE technologies are evaluated: ultrasonic methods including conventional techniques, phased array technologies, full matrix capture, and guided waves; visual methods including visible light, infrared, hyperspectral, microwave, and terahertz imaging; electromagnetic methods including conventional eddy current examination for flaw detection, nonlinear methods for material properties assessment, and larger-scale methods for rapid assessment of large material volumes; advanced radiographic methods; and modeling and simulation capabilities to help assess and optimize the capabilities of all these technologies. Various materials, components, and systems are investigated, including the primary pressure boundary, buried pipe, cast stainless steel, concrete civil structures, and spent fuel pools. Research results are primarily delivered as technical reports or guideline documents that are used by nuclear plants and inspection vendors to develop safe, effective inspection strategies.

Research focus areas containing multiple common projects are used as an approach to document the strategic objectives for each focused area of research. The Program’s 10 research focus areas are: Workforce Proficiency; Improving NDE Reliability; Performance Demonstration; Cast Stainless Steel; Materials Degradation and Characterization; Strategic Long-Term; Underground Piping and Tanks; NDE Efficiency; Concrete; and Fuels and Dry Storage. 

To resolve complex NDE issues that may stretch across multiple focus areas or involve multiple external stakeholders, roadmaps have been developed in five areas: concrete, remote visual inspection technology, NDE of cast stainless steel, modeling and simulation, and NDE reliability.

Technology transfer is achieved largely through evaluation and application support of NDE technologies in field-deployable products. NDE reliability is supported through projects targeted at maintaining compliance with industry NDE requirements, evaluating the ways examiners can use low-cost sensor platforms and wearable technologies to do their jobs reliably, and improving plant owners’ ability to fulfill their responsibility for effective NDE oversight.

Accomplishments

EPRI’s NDE Program addresses material- and inspection-related issues through innovative NDE technologies, technical guidance, and qualification support.

  • Performed an exploratory study on vision-based algorithms to size cracks in different materials (3002007205)

  • Advanced remote visual testing (VT) image analysis technologies (3002007814)

  • Created an “Industry Best Practices” document in support of delivering reliable NDE (3002007329)

  • Developed structural models to determine the integrity of concrete structures (3002007777)

  • Created an Issue Management Table (IMT) for concrete-related issues (3002007779)

  • Updated a guideline for conducting ultrasonic examinations of dissimilar metal welds (3002007786)

  • Codified risk-informing requirements for pipe support inspection (3002007787)

  • Simplified a number of procedures to support improved NDE reliability:

    • EPRI NDE Procedure:  EPRI-WOL-PA-1  (3002008323)

    • EPRI NDE Procedure:  EPRI-DMW-PA-1  (3002008325)

    • EPRI NDE Procedure:  EPRI-PIPE-MPA-1 & EPRI-PIPE-TWS-MPA-1  (3002008328)

    • EPRI NDE Procedure:  Procedure for Single-Side Ultrasonic Examinations for Stainless Steel Piping: Encoded Ultrasonics (3002007780)

  • Revised EPRI’s streamlined risk-informed in-service inspection (RI-ISI) methodology, which provides a more cost-effective and easier-to-implement approach than traditional RI-ISI approaches. (3002003029)

  • Characterized several permanently mounted ultrasonic sensors for use in structural health monitoring. The research identified new possibilities for in situ data collection. (3002003031)

Key Activities

The NDE Program's research and development activities for 2017 will address a number of issues where effective and reliable NDE is essential. Specific efforts will include:

  • Analyze industry best practices and lessons learned to identify NDE implementation cost reduction opportunities

  • Develop and evaluate applications for NDE modeling and simulation to streamline NDE technique development and qualification activities

  • Investigate advanced NDE technologies for above- and below-ground piping applications

  • Benchmark structural models and NDE capabilities for concrete infrastructure applications

  • Evaluate and develop NDE technologies for spent fuel pools, dry casks, tanks, and containment liners

  • Maintain NDE qualification programs to support safe plant operation and compliance with regulatory requirements and industry commitments

  • Evaluate further opportunities for developing and deploying risk-informed in-service inspection, repair and replacement strategies

  • Exploit robotics and advanced sensors for deployment of NDE technologies and structural health monitoring

  • Develop capability to deliver encoded NDE examination technologies without robotics

  • Continue to study human performance improvement opportunities in NDE and apply results to NDE reliability

  • Identify and develop advanced sensors that can be used in all aspects of NDE

  • Develop a suite of tools for NDE and aging management of large concrete infrastructure

  • Develop automated analysis of imaged data for increased reliability and cost reductions

Selected NDE program activities, reports and products may be prepared in whole or in part in accordance with the EPRI Quality Program Manual that fulfills the requirements of 10CFR50 Appendix B and 10CFR21. The QA status of reports and products will be marked and identified. Additional NDE program activities may be conducted in accordance with 10CFR50 Appendix B and 10CFR21 at the discretion of the Nondestructive Evaluation Center, member utilities or EPRI, when such action is deemed appropriate.

Program Description

The Nuclear Maintenance Applications Center (NMAC) provides guidance for maintaining high equipment reliability through the application of technically sound maintenance and engineering strategies. To this end, maintenance practices must be continuously reviewed and updated based on industry operating experience and emerging issues. NMAC conducts research to identify maintenance and engineering advances with the potential to produce substantial plant performance improvements while maintaining or enhancing safety and reliability. 

NMAC also develops maintenance guides and coordinates worldwide technology transfer to drive improvements in nuclear maintenance activities, with a focus on mechanical maintenance and engineering. The program’s technical guides, user groups, and workshops reflect best practices and engineering judgment gathered from nuclear plant experience, providing actionable maintenance activities that lead to improved safety, lower costs, and higher reliability.

Research Value

The reliability of plant systems and components are critical to the continued safe operation of nuclear plants. NMAC develops guidelines and technical reports that provide technically sound maintenance strategies and practices, enabling nuclear plants to improve equipment reliability and reduce operations and maintenance costs. The information produced by the Nuclear Maintenance Application Center can be used to ensure safe and reliable operation of nuclear power plants for the benefit of the people that work at the plant and the general public at large.

NMAC participants gain access to the following: 

  • Strategic roadmaps outlining research gaps confronting key issues, such as advanced preventive maintenance, and the collaborative actions needed to address these gaps 
  • More than 400 maintenance guides for nuclear equipment and systems, which provide source documents for improved procedures and training packages
  • Assistance and identification of failure-related root causes through access to EPRI research, expertise, and operating experience from other program participants
  • A broad range of maintenance solutions with reduced implementation risks due to collaboration with subject matter experts around the world
  • Templates for establishing preventive maintenance practices and intervals for key components and systems, including portable emergency equipment 
Approach

NMAC conducts research that supports maintenance and engineering improvements at nuclear plants. Long-term research focuses on new methods and approaches that enable sustained improvements to plant equipment, processes, and practices. Near-term research focuses on maintenance methods and guidance that can help reduce operations and maintenance costs and improve equipment reliability. 

NMAC research focuses on developing maintenance program improvements that can increase equipment reliability and plant performance and on developing and implementing new processes and technologies that can close the gaps between current issues and available solutions. 

  • Equipment Issues and Maintenance Guides: Maintenance strategies, fully informed by operating experience and technology advances, can improve equipment reliability, lower operating costs, and increase overall plant reliability. This program area identifies and addresses important maintenance and equipment issues by conducting user group meetings each year and compiling data from nuclear plants, vendors, and other industry sources. The maintenance guides aggregate relevant diagnostic and mitigating technical advice for addressing key maintenance issues, providing details on problem identification, troubleshooting, preventive and predictive maintenance, and maintenance tasks.
  • Operations and Maintenance Procedures: Bringing essential information to the point of decision-making can drive safe and reliable plant and fleet performance. Access to equipment information and personnel knowledgeable in operations and maintenance practices can provide useful perspective and input. EPRI expertise is applied to plant operations and maintenance concerns through direct phone and email interaction, plant visits, assistance with selected plant assessments, and failure analysis reviews when emergent issues arise. EPRI staff also use this expertise to develop reports and guidelines that address new or improved methods and processes to enhance nuclear plant performance. 

Research focus areas containing multiple common projects have been developed to document and guide research activities. NMAC’s six research focus areas are: Component Guidance, Innovative Technology, Maintenance & Engineering Practices, Predictive Maintenance, and Preventive Maintenance.

Accomplishments

The Nuclear Maintenance Applications Center distills global operations and maintenance experience into actionable guidance for nuclear plant systems and components. Lessons learned from nuclear plants around the world are incorporated into industry and vendor specific technical guidance. 

  • Developed preventive maintenance templates for portable emergency equipment. 
  • Revised the Horizontal Pump Guide to include interactive graphics that enhance technology transfer and support best practice implementation by new and next-generation engineers and maintenance staff.
  • Upgraded the Preventive Maintenance Basis Database software to define optimum replacement and refurbishment times, and to support preventive maintenance optimization through refurbishment/replacement considerations as well as a user-friendly “Vulnerability Tool’” to assess changes in PM strategies and identify which failure modes may change with PM changes.
  • Completed initial development of a seal for water-circulating pumps in nuclear power plants that could control leakage by adjusting its shape while in use, potentially reducing plant shutdowns and maintenance costs. A patent on this new seal technology is pending in the United States.
  • Revised guidance for creating an effective leak management program in response to an increase in plant shutdowns and down-powers caused by leaks.
Key Activities

NMAC research and development for 2017 will focus on updates to key equipment maintenance guides and focused attention on emerging industry maintenance issues. Specific efforts will include the following: 

  • In the Maintenance and Engineering Practices focus area, continue efforts supporting the implementation of mobile work management, guidance for air-operated valves, and guidance for main steam isolation valves.
  • In the Preventive Maintenance Strategies focus area, update the Preventive Maintenance Basis Database software to facilitate interactions with other information sources and publish a comprehensive maintenance strategy guideline.
  • Within the Knowledge Transfer focus area, develop an interactive maintenance guide for “Pump Specialist,” update the guidance for valve packing, and revise the Terry Turbine Application to add additional components.
  • Continue development of innovative technologies, such as implementation of wireless work management within the power block.

Selected reports and products may be prepared in whole or in part in accordance with the EPRI Quality Program Manual that fulfills the requirements of 10CFR50 Appendix B and 10CFR21. The QA status of reports and products will be marked and identified.

  • NMAC Base
    • Monitoring Valve Seat Leakage
      09-Feb-2017

      Secondary Cycle Isolation Valves in power plants provide the barrier between the regenerative thermal cycle of the feedwater/extraction steam/heater drain systems and the ultimate heat sink.  When energy in the form of steam leaks from the secondary cycle to the heat sink the efficiency of the power generation cycle is reduced.  This reduction in efficiency can result in the loss of electric megawatts. The standard method for monitoring for leakage is to have personnel on inspection rounds measure the temperature differential across these isolation valves.  This inspection program can be manpower intensive.

      Technology exists that can potentially provide monitoring on a continual basis for a minimal cost.  This technology would use piezoelectric sensors connected to RFIDs to monitor for leakage across the valves. The output from these RFIDs could then be queried either by personnel on a set inspection path, or at a monitoring station.  This project will determine the most effective sensor/RFID configurations, the sensitivity of the sensors, and the process to use for monitoring the valves.

To support nuclear power plants in their efforts to more effectively optimize equipment maintenance strategies based on both reliability and cost considerations, value-based maintenance tools are needed. EPRI is well positioned to support the development and implementation of such tools.

Program Description

The Plant Engineering Program at EPRI performs research to inform decisions related to the continued safe, reliable, and cost-effective operation of nuclear power plants. Research activities address key equipment issues and the effectiveness of plant engineering programs.  Active and ongoing research includes but is not limited to: component aging and mitigation (flow-accelerated corrosion, electric cables, buried piping, cathodic protection, nuclear grade coatings, electric relays), system reliability (offsite power, emergency power, single point vulnerabilities), plant performance (heat exchangers, transformers, service water system, plant thermal performance), and other engineering and operational support areas (procurement engineering, seismic qualification, workforce and skills development).

The program also supports technology transfer through technical assistance programs, users groups, interest groups, and training.

Research Value

Research results from the Plant Engineering Program provide engineering-based guidance that enables nuclear plants to improve equipment reliability, potentially contributing to improved plant safety and performance and reduced operations and maintenance costs. Participants gain access to the following:

  • Research results and guidance delivered through written reports, forms, and templates for topics such as:

    • Condition assessments

    • Reliability program creation and implementation

    • Commercial grade dedications

    • Service life assessments and extensions

    • Long-term planning and asset optimization

    • Diagnostic techniques

    • Mitigation options

    • Repair and replacement techniques

    • Skills and knowledge development 

  • Application of research results through software programs:

    • Risk ranking inspection and mitigation techniques such as CHECWORKS and BPWORKS

    • Integrated Life Cycle Management (ILCM)

    • Computer-based training modules 

  • Collaboration meetings and training, on topics such as:

    • Circuit breakers

    • Relays

    • Transformer & switchyard

    • Condition-based maintenance

    • Flow-accelerated corrosion

    • Cathodic protection

    • Heat exchanger performance

    • Buried pipe

    • Large motors

    • Flow-accelerated corrosion

Approach

The Plant Engineering Program has established research focus areas that correspond to critical components, processes, engineering programs, and workforce skills and knowledge in a nuclear power plant. Research projects are developed and executed to address current and future issues within these focus areas. The issues are identified by EPRI with input from member advisors and other stakeholders.

The current focus areas within the Plant Engineering Program are:

  • AC Power Reliability

  • Emergency Power Reliability

  • Active Electrical Component Reliability

  • Passive Electrical Component Reliability

  • Procurement Engineering

  • Flow-Accelerated Corrosion and Mechanical Erosion in Plant Piping and Components

  • Plant Heat Rate Enhancement Methods

  • Ultimate Heat Sink and Cooling Water System Performance

  • Heat Exchanger Structural Integrity and Performance

  • Plant Coating Degradation and Impacts

  • Buried and Underground Piping and Tanks Degradation Mitigation Strategies

  • Non-Metallic Material Degradation research

Roadmaps are often developed to plan, coordinate, and execute needed research among multiple entities. These roadmaps guide Plant Engineering research and help communicate ongoing strategies in addressing these key issues.  For example, the cable aging roadmap is used to coordinate the research gaps and the collaborative actions needed to address these gaps.  Additional roadmaps will be developed as conditions warrant. 

Through separately funded projects, participants can gain access to additional resources. The Standardized Task Evaluation Program provides tools that can be used to ensure that the workforce is competent to reliably perform tasks associated with operating and maintaining industry facilities.

Accomplishments

Plant Engineering Program accomplishments are best indicated by the use and usefulness of the products, as reflected through the amount of downloads and through direct feedback and technology transfer awards from field application. Statistics and products of note are as follows:

  • Over 10,000 Plant Engineering product downloads in 2015

  • 47 new products created in 2015 including

    • Assessed geometry factors in the CHECWORKSTM software and released an updated version of CHECWORKSTM software to improve prediction of flow accelerated corrosion rates and to enable better selection of inspection locations.

    • On-line Comprehensive Condenser Resource for simple reference to condenser information.

    • Updated electrical cable aging management guidance document that provides a framework for developing and implementing cable aging management programs.

  • Technology Transfer Awards and Success Stories

    • Reducing O&M cost through relay service life extensions

    • Optimized maintenance using single point vulnerability process guide

    • Collaborative benchmarking to prevent counterfeit and fraudulent items

    • Application of standardized task evaluations for worker qualification

    • Development and implementation of long-term asset management strategies

    • Development and demonstration of open-phase detection system

  • Revised the Equipment Reliability Matrix tool, which simplifies the identification and downloading of EPRI products pertaining to specific equipment reliability-related needs.

Key Activities

Plant Engineering Program research and development for 2017 will focus on aging management programs, procurement and material quality improvements, life-cycle planning guidance, secondary plant and buried piping corrosion phenomena, equipment reliability, and training/qualification. Specific efforts will include the following:

  • Complete HDPE (high-density polyethylene) materials research supporting efforts to facilitate implementation of HDPE in safety-related code-required applications.

  • Develop a more effective method for assessing the effectiveness of cathodic protection at a nuclear power plant.

  • Develop comprehensive tools for heat exchanger management, including a tube plugging guide, leak troubleshooting guide, and a feedwater heater resource that compiles relevant EPRI products into a simple on-line information source.

  • Evaluate technical approaches for monitoring the health of large transformers insulator coatings; improved monitoring would support enhanced offsite power reliability.

  • Develop a web-based version of the Integrated Life-Cycle Management software program to enable greater use in informing capital asset decisions at nuclear plants.

  • Develop a generic service life assessment process.

  • Continued to develop and assess electrical cable aging management strategies, research accelerated cable aging methodologies, explore qualification of various cable types for use in submerged environments, and explore effects of simultaneous heat and radiation on electrical cable aging.

  • Continue development of long-term planning products for identifying replacement needs associated with major plant components.

  • Provide clear product quality strategies to address substandard, counterfeit, and fraudulent materials issues; inform revisions to regulations governing commercial grade dedication processes; and inform procurement specification and in-process vendor inspection strategies.

  • Continue projects to understand and address electrical relay aging issues involving both protective and control relays, and expand this component aging effort to other electrical subcomponents.

Selected reports and products may be prepared in whole or in part in accordance with the EPRI Quality Program Manual that fulfills the requirements of 10CFR50 Appendix B and 10CFR21. The QA status of reports and products will be marked and identified.

Overview

Road Maps

EPRI has developed the following roadmaps to guide research in key technical areas. These roadmaps provide a communication tool for determining what success looks like, identifying research tasks necessary to meet goals, and clarifying roles for all stakeholders.

  • Digital Instrumentation and Control Implementation (New/Existing Plants) - 2.20MB PDF
Program Description

Instrumentation and control (I&C) systems impact nuclear power plant reliability, efficiency, and operations and maintenance costs. As equipment ages, I&C-related challenges are increasing. However, as I&C and information technology advances, the opportunities to use I&C to improve plant performance will increase.

The Instrumentation and Control Program develops and transfers advanced I&C and information technologies. These technologies, and the underlying technical knowledge, enable existing and new nuclear plants to tap into functionality and capabilities important in maintaining safe operation, while managing I&C obsolescence and achieving higher levels of equipment reliability and plant productivity.

Research Value

Research results from the Instrumentation and Control Program enable nuclear plants to apply I&C systems in an effective manner that supports safe, reliable plant operation. Advanced I&C research provides the technology and knowledge bases so plant owners can make informed system- and component-level decisions, comply with applicable requirements, and achieve cost savings. Program participants gain access to the following:

  • Strategic roadmaps outlining research gaps associated with key issues – such as digital I&C implementation – and the collaborative actions needed to address these gaps

  • Guidance in setting up automated asset- and equipment-monitoring systems that will improve overall plant reliability

  • Improved decision-making tools such as control room human factors guidelines, improved information access and visualization, and visualization-enhanced approaches for tacit knowledge capture and training

  • Technical bases for the generic resolution of technical issues for new and operating plants, such as risk-informed defense-in-depth and diversity assessment guidance; cyber security guidance for critical digital assets; and guidelines for electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) testing and digital upgrades

  • Evaluations of new technologies in nuclear applications, such as field programmable gate arrays (FPGA) controllers, “smart” sensors, and wireless communications

  • Training, operating experience, and lessons learned on replacement projects that will enable plants to avoid costly mishaps and electromagnetic interference events and to implement plant strategies to cost-effectively manage I&C obsolescence

  • Life-cycle management and maintenance guidelines for existing I&C systems and components such as radiation monitoring systems

  • New robust sensor designs providing information that can be used for early detection of degradation, for more robust characterization of equipment health, and for decisions related to plant safety, reliability, and cost-effective operation

Approach

The Instrumentation and Control Program is designed around three main research initiatives:

  1. Use advanced I&C to improve overall plant health and productivity: Existing plant I&C equipment and functionality do not accommodate up-to-date features and techniques that can reduce costs and enhance reliability and productivity. Expanded capabilities can streamline many plant tasks and procedures to reduce operations and maintenance costs while improving reliability and extending component lifetimes. This research area pursues advanced technologies, such as remote monitoring, wireless communication, early prognosis, and data visualization that can inform maintenance tasks and intervals, on-line equipment condition assessment, self-testing and diagnostics, and access to plant data.

  2. Develop technologies and technical approaches that reduce the risk of implementing replacement I&C systems: As the nuclear industry transitions from analog to digital technology, there are several I&C-related issues for which the available technical solutions are unclear, incomplete, or evolving. Examples include failure analysis, software common cause failure prevention, cyber security, defense-in-depth and diversity, various design considerations for control rooms, and the impact of new technologies such as field programmable gate arrays. This research area develops the technical bases to support the deployment and licensing of I&C and human system interface (HSI) replacement systems; develops guidelines for implementing new I&C, information, and HSI technologies in nuclear applications; and documents operating experience and lessons learned.

  3. Improve reliability of existing systems and components: I&C systems such as sensors, printed circuit cards and radiation monitoring systems must be reliable to avoid unplanned plant trips and down-powers. This research area develops generic technical bases for effective maintenance and life-cycle management of I&C systems and components already installed in the plant. Such technical research is required to maintain and improve the reliability of existing I&C systems and equipment. Key research products include maintenance templates for I&C components to reduce failures and inappropriate maintenance activities.

To address strategic objectives established for each of its programs, EPRI has developed roadmaps to plan, coordinate, and execute needed research among multiple entities. For the Instrumentation and Control Program, a roadmap has been developed to address technical barriers related to digital I&C implementation.

Accomplishments

EPRI’s Instrumentation and Control Program has provided much of the fundamental basis supporting digital implementation in the nuclear industry and in identifying and overcoming many of the barriers to implementing newer technology. The program also has provided the fundamental basis for implementing reliability and productivity improvements.

  • Developed and released the Plant Health Monitoring software suite, including the Asset Fault Signature database and Diagnostic Advisor. This product culminates many years of joint work with EPRI's Long-Term Operations Program and the EPRI Generation sector.

  • Issued guidance for the implementation of wireless networks in nuclear power plants, with emphasis on the use of wireless sensors for asset condition monitoring. Guidance includes real-life experiences from industry and addresses concerns such as cyber security and electromagnetic and radio frequency interference.

  • Developed comprehensive design guides and training modules for digital upgrades that enable plants to transition their processes and personnel to this new technology

  • Developed technical guidelines for using field programmable gate arrays (FPGAs) in nuclear safety-related applications.

  • Developed technical methods for preventing and mitigating digital I&C common cause failure in nuclear plants.

  • Developed multiple cyber security products related to technical assessments of installed equipment and design and procurement for new equipment to ensure that cyber security controls are effectively and efficiently applied.

  • Developed human factors engineering (HFE) guidance for control room and digital (HSI) design and modification covering planning, specification, design, licensing, implementation, training, operation, and maintenance.

  • Developed technical content for circuit card reliability programs, including instructions to increase the reliability and operating life of existing circuit cards and components, and guidelines for the proper handling of printed circuit cards and their components.

  • Updated preventive maintenance basis templates for I&C components in the Preventive Maintenance Basis Database.

  • Developed an Obsolescence Management Guide for radiation monitoring systems.

  • Designed and tested new sensors such as a prototype solid-state containment hydrogen sensor with much faster calibration times than existing technology and a fiber-optic Bragg sensor for measuring fluid pressures in nuclear power plants that is more robust than current technology.

  • Designed and built a prototype aerial drone, the Severe Accident Mobile Investigator (SAMI), which can provide operators remote visual and sensing abilities during nuclear accidents.

Key Activities

Instrumentation and Control Program research and development for 2017 will focus on plant productivity, new I&C system implementation, and I&C equipment reliability. Specific efforts will include:

  • Develop the technical basis and software requirements to use data from sensors and monitoring to inform maintenance tasks and intervals.

  • Integrate new concepts in failure analysis and systems engineering into digital design guides and training products.

  • Develop technical assessments for application of cyber security controls to commonly used plant equipment & systems.

  • Develop, in conjunction with the U.S. Department of Energy, new programming and hardware for robust and simple control systems that are less susceptible to design flaws and cyber security attacks.

  • Improve maintenance strategies and tasks for digital equipment.

Overview

Program Description

Risk and safety assessments provide information that enables nuclear plant owners to make technically sound decisions about plant design and operating and maintenance practices. These decisions contribute to safer and more cost-effective plant operation. The approaches for these assessments are also used to inform online maintenance, surveillance interval extensions, flexible allowed outage times, and risk-informed performance-based fire protection. Further refinement and extension of methods for risk analysis and applications are necessary to ensure that their use supports decisions reflecting industry operating experience and improved understanding of plant response; that they can be employed efficiently and practically; and that they make appropriate use of state-of-the-art computational advances.

The Risk and Safety Management Program develops risk assessment methods, the guidance to facilitate use of these methods, and tools to make their use more practical and efficient to enhance the safe and economic operation of existing and future nuclear power plants. These tools include software developed by the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) to perform detailed risk analyses necessary to achieve these objectives most effectively.

Research Value

Risk-informed, performance-based approaches yield benefits for nuclear plant owners, regulators, and the public. Use of these approaches allows both the plant owner and the regulator to focus on issues truly important in protecting the health and safety of the public. The plant owner can also use such approaches to achieve more flexible plant operation and to reduce costs. Risk assessment has improved many aspects of plant safety and performance through broader use of risk-informed initiatives, plant and equipment reliability improvements, and better insights gained from advances in probabilistic risk assessment (PRA) techniques.

Risk and Safety Management Program participants gain access to the following:

  • Strategic roadmaps outlining research gaps associated with key issues—such as risk analysis of fire, seismic events, and other external hazards—and the collaborative actions needed to address these gaps
  • Research results and technical input that are valuable for utilities operating in a risk-informed, performance-based regulatory environment, including the Significance Determination Process, the Mitigating Systems Performance Index, and globally through periodic safety cases and license renewal
  • Tools and methods that can be used to increase plant safety and reduce plant and resource requirements
  • A robust, plant-specific framework that supports effective regulatory interactions
Approach

Base research in the Risk and Safety Management Program develops improved methods and tools for conducting probabilistic risk assessments (PRAs). Methods are improved by collecting and evaluating data and experience from risk practitioners who apply PRAs in a risk-informed framework. Tools are improved through applied research in numerical and logic modeling techniques and analysis of data for events such as loss of offsite power. Further advances in methods and tools are aimed more explicitly at addressing the risks associated with external hazards, such as earthquakes, external flooding, and high wind loads.

Base research also supports stakeholder engagement to advance risk-informed methods within the regulatory context, through meetings, risk-informed discussion forums, and EPRI research activities. For example, this research area develops technical insights into the treatment of low-power and shutdown conditions, supports participation in the development of global standards, and assembles guidance on methods and issues for configuration risk management. Finally, through base research, EPRI supports continued development and refinement of its Education of Risk Professionals curriculum, which provides a structured approach for developing the new generation of risk practitioners.

Consistent with the other programs at EPRI, the Risk and Safety Management Program has implemented a process to ensure that strategic objectives are addressed through clearly identified research focus areas. Further, EPRI has developed roadmaps to plan, coordinate, and execute research of strategic importance among multiple entities. For the Risk and Safety Management Program, roadmaps have been developed to address the technical barriers confronting the performance of PRAs for fire and seismic events and for other external hazards (such as flooding and high winds). Additional roadmaps focus activities on low-power and shutdown conditions, and the development of the next generation of software tools.

Beginning in 2017, the following projects will be included in the Risk and Safety Management Base Program:

  • Integrated Risk Technology Users Group. Through the activities of this Users Group, EPRI continues to enhance software tools for constructing and evaluating PRA models. The Users Group provides a forum for users to share experiences and best practices.
  • Modular Accident Analysis Program (MAAP) User Group. The MAAP Users Group supports further development of the MAAP code for conducting severe-accident analyses, and also provides user training and technical support.
  • GOTHIC Advisory Group. Similarly, the GOTHIC Advisory Group is the venue for continued support of improvement to the GOTHIC code for thermal-hydraulic analysis of containments and a wide range of other types of compartments.
  • HRA Calculator User Group. The HRA Calculator User Group promotes consistency in the evaluation of human reliability for PRAs, with a focus on the HRA Calculator as the tool to facilitate that consistency of practice. The User Group also provides a forum for sharing practices and supporting further evolution of HRA methods.
  • Seismic Qualification Utility Group (SQUG). The SQUG focuses on examining earthquake experience to gain further understanding of the seismic ruggedness of equipment needed for nuclear power plants, and addresses other issues associated with seismic qualification, such as guidance for and training in performing seismic walkdowns.
Accomplishments

EPRI’s Risk and Safety Management Program supports the development and implementation of risk-informed approaches that can be used in making operational, maintenance, and regulatory decisions impacting nuclear power plants. This has been demonstrated through projects in which EPRI:

  • Conducted a comprehensive research review examining how severe accidents in nuclear power plants evolve. The resulting series of reports and the supporting research provide a major contribution to informing regulatory decisions, form the basis for analyzing accident risks for the new generation of reactors, and will help ensure the safety of currently operating nuclear plants over their lifetimes. In conjunction with detailed analyses using the MAAP code, this research also provides insights into measures (including filtered containment vents) that might be effective in reducing the potential for serious releases after an accident.
  • Completed extensive testing of components potentially susceptible to high-frequency ground motions, and developed guidance for applying the results to focus on only those few components with actual susceptibilities.
  • Enhanced the MAAP5 code for performing severe-accident analysis, addressing insights from the Fukushima accident and other recent developments.
  • Performed detailed technical analysis of the Fukushima accident to gain insight into the course of events.
  • Continued to develop the next generation of risk professionals (more than 200 graduates of the educational program to date).
  • Deployed new computer-based training modules that address elements of PRA technology and use (including in support of risk-informed regulatory interactions), suitable for management and the end users of risk information.
  • Improved methods for developing Fire Probabilistic Risk Assessments in support of risk-informed regulation, including transition to National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) 805. In particular, compiled a new database that will be the foundation for ignition frequencies and other important elements of fire PRAs going forward.
  • Released the first version of the Phoenix platform, an advanced software tool used in risk management to support risk-informed applications, including the implementation of flexible technical specifications.
  • Produced detailed guidance for conducting human reliability analysis in support of fire PRA, and developed analogous guidance for use in seismic PRAs.
  • Assembled guidance that can be used to perform seismic evaluations and perform seismic walkdowns in response to regulatory or other actions following the Fukushima accident.
  • Developed an update to the guidance for addressing post-earthquake restart of nuclear power plants.
  • Completed a framework for conducting PRAs for spent fuel pools in BWRs and PWRs, and applied the framework at pilot plants.
  • Produced guidance and pilot demonstrations for assessment of particular types of external flood hazards.
  • Assembled the state of technology regarding risk assessment for high winds.
Key Activities

Risk and Safety Management Program research and development for 2017 will focus on further enhancing risk-assessment methods and continuing the socialization of risk technology with both regulatory and industry personnel. Specific efforts will include:

  • Further enhancement to methods for assessing the risk of fires, including better methods and guidance for modeling fire growth and propagation and for assessing the risks associated with fires that necessitate evacuating the main control room.
  • Significant improvements to the methods for performing elements of seismic PRAs, with an emphasis on fragility assessment.
  • Development of new consensus methods for evaluating external flooding and further development of such methods for high winds hazards.
  • Continued development of the next generation of risk professionals through the Education of Risk Professionals course.

  • Continued detailed evaluations of the Fukushima accident to capture insights and to improve modeling capabilities.

Adequate preparation for these challenges requires a recognition that our understanding of the hazards – and indeed the nature of the some of the hazards themselves – may evolve over time. Tracking information pertaining to external hazards on a continual or periodic basis can help ensure that hazards are more fully taken into account to maintain the safe operation of nuclear power plants.

Overview

Road Maps

EPRI has developed the following roadmaps to guide research in key technical areas. These roadmaps provide a communication tool for determining what success looks like, identifying research tasks necessary to meet goals, and clarifying roles for all stakeholders.

  • Environmentally-Assisted Fatigue - 1.72MB PDF
Program Description

New nuclear power plants must overcome a number of economic, technical, and regulatory challenges prior to successful licensing, construction, startup, and operation. Some of the key challenges are uncertainty and risk in cost and schedule for deployment, ensuring successful startup and initial operations, maximizing potential operational life with manageable operations and maintenance costs, and incorporating modern technologies into plants from a design and regulatory perspective. Many of these challenges can be addressed through application of focused Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) technical products and tools that minimize deployment risks.

The EPRI Advanced Nuclear Technology (ANT) Program conducts research and development (R&D) through EPRI’s collaborative model to evaluate and address issues regarding the near-term deployment of advanced light water reactors around the world.

The primary R&D focus is on light water reactor designs, technologies, and projects that can have an impact in time to support plants just starting up, those currently under construction, and those planned for deployment in the next dozen years. This includes the current Gen III, Gen III+, and light water small modular reactor (SMR) designs.

An increasing focus for the ANT Program is Gen IV designs and non-light water SMRs. Efforts are focused on engaging stakeholders from industry, government and academia, and on conducting R&D to inform development and deployment decisions regarding these advanced energy options.

Research Value

Research results from the ANT Program increase confidence and reduce risks associated with developing advanced nuclear plant designs by incorporating current plant operating experience and results from focused research and development. The research addresses issues that could impact the ability to efficiently license, construct, start up, and operate advanced light water reactors worldwide. As examples, ANT participants gain access to the following:

  • The EPRI Utility Requirements Document, a comprehensive set of plant functional requirements developed over the last 20 years to inform utilities considering the construction of a nuclear plant, emphasizing areas that are most important to achieving excellent performance with respect to safety, performance, constructability, and economics

  • Research results in the area of data-centric configuration management, including data interoperability standards, equipment schema, and data handover processes that plant owners can implement to achieve effective configuration management

  • Materials management matrices for advanced nuclear plant designs that can serve as living documents for managing life-cycle material issues

  • Equipment reliability knowledge and tools that can be incorporated into new plant designs to increase the potential for meeting business goals such as plant availability and sustainable high capacity factors

  • Refined methodologies for applying risk-informed pre-service and in-service inspection techniques to advanced nuclear plant designs

  • Significant research and collaboration with ASME code to facilitate the use of high-density polyethylene in safety-related applications

  • Research supporting design and demonstration of next-generation nuclear plants, including small modular reactors

To enable the safe, reliable, long-term operation of new nuclear plants, it is important that they be provided with the best technology available; the Advanced Nuclear Technology supports this objective through research and technology transfer activities.

Approach

The ANT program encompasses a diverse set of stakeholders, designs, and technologies. To maximize our impact, efforts are targeted on issues where science and technology help accelerate solutions for new plant deployment and safe, reliable operations. Therefore, the ANT Program pursues issues and projects that meet these key goals:

The ANT Program works to reduce the overall deployment risk and uncertainty for new nuclear plants by focusing on R&D that can reduce the cost of new plant construction through increased construction speed and first-time quality, and reduce the cost of systems and components and their installation.  The program also targets projects that improve lifetime operations and maintenance (O&M) costs, facilitate high capacity factors through increased equipment reliability and reduced material degradation, and use technology to reduce O&M costs.

The ANT Program also supports the development and application ofnew and existing technology to reduce costs and increase safety and reliability. Technology application takes two forms. Existing technologies from inside and outside the nuclear industry are leveraged to make those technologies available to new nuclear plants. This is done by finding, defining, and extending useful and valuable existing technologies; performing necessary R&D to prove the efficacy of those technologies in nuclear applications; and working with codes and standards bodies and informing regulators to ensure that new technologies are usable. The ANT Program also performs R&D to help solve challenges brought by new plant designs in the areas of construction and O&M that need resolved to ensure optimized performance.

Lastly, the ANT Program facilitates common approaches across the fleet through use of the EPRI collaborative model. EPRI has a long history of using its collaborative model to generate industry standardization through common approaches and cooperation in developing technologies, processes, and guidance. This model can help facilitate adoption, particularly though codes and standards bodies, and help streamline regulator interaction through independent thought leadership. EPRI has shown over the years that use of the collaborative model can significantly reduce costs and increase safety and reliability.

The ANT program has identified three technical research areas to guide its efforts related to risk reduction, use of advanced technology, and fleet-wide approaches.

Projects and issues within the Engineering, Procurement, and Construction technical area primarily address the siting, design, construction materials, and construction activities of the physical plant, including modular construction. Key objectives are to help decrease construction costs, improve schedule, and maximize quality.

The Materials and Components technical area primarily addresses class 1, 2 and 3 piping systems and related components such as valves, heat exchangers, and pumps. Research activities aim to determine optimal methods for fabrication, installation, and operation; identify and develop new applications of materials and components; and identify and develop new or improved methods for joining, inspecting and maintaining piping and components to support decreased installation and O&M costs and increase reliability and safety.

The Modern Technology Application technical area aims to maximize the use of existing, new, and potentially non-nuclear enabling technology in new nuclear plants. Technologies such as digital I&C, digital and multi-reactor control rooms, improved sensors, process automation, data management, and fleet wide monitoring offer potential for increased reliability and reduced O&M costs through an increase in operational efficiency.

The ANT Program purposefully collaborates across EPRI to ensure our sibling research programs are prepared to take on oversight of key issues affecting newer designs as they mature and gain operational experience.

Accomplishments

The EPRI Advanced Nuclear Technology Program helps accelerate industry activities aimed at enabling and building confidence in new nuclear plant deployment. Significant recent accomplishments include:

  • Continued global participation and collaboration, including membership from 30 U.S. and international utilities and critical nuclear industry vendors.

  • In collaboration with the U.S. Department of Energy, completed Revision 13 of the Utility Requirements Document. Revision 13 including additional material in several technical areas, as well as Fukushima-related requirements, and also features extensive support for light water small modular reactors.

  • Completed a revision to the new nuclear plant siting guide, providing an update for site selection and evaluation, including additional insights for small modular reactor siting.

  • Updated the Nuclear Power Plant Information Turnover Guide, providing guidance to ensure that new plants have the data and information needed for operations.  This work complements recent work on data-centric configuration management, showing substantial potential savings when embracing the technology.

  • Continued evaluation of EPRI's Water Chemistry Guidelines for advanced light water reactors in the context of their applicability to new plant designs, including considerations for ensuring top performance at the beginning of plant operations.

  • Released additional updates on the use of powdered metallurgy-hot isostatic pressing for the fabrication of near-net-shape components and for the elimination of dissimilar metal welds in plant components, which would help mitigate common degradation mechanisms.

  • Completed an additional pilot project investigating the use of risk-informed inspection along with the concept of risk-informed break exclusion, with results that demonstrate applicability to passive plant designs.

  • In collaboration with the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE), completed initial work examining aerosol deposition behavior for integrated pressurized water reactor containments. Follow-on work with the DOE will conduct experimental testing.  Results from this work will inform decisions related to reducing the emergency planning zone for small modular reactors.

  • In collaboration with the U.S. Department of Energy and industry stakeholders, completed a report that identifies and defines technologies, as well as medium- and long-term research needs, to optimally staff and operate small modular reactors in a cost-effective manner.

  • Continued work with high-density polyethylene in safety-related applications, releasing findings on the long-term oxidative resistance of butt fusion joints and the material properties affecting butt fusion.

Key Activities

Advanced Nuclear Technology Program research and development for 2017 will continue its focus on risk mitigation, use of advanced technology, and common fleet-wide approaches.

Specific efforts include:

  • Resolution of environmentally assisted fatigue concerns for new and operating nuclear plant materials.

  • Development of acceptable practices for applying risk-informed approaches to new plants, reducing costs while maintaining plant safety.

  • Resolution of open issues to facilitate Class 3 safety-related applications of high-density polyethylene pipe.

  • Emergency planning zone optimization for small modular reactors, potentially reducing O&M costs.

  • Investigation of a process for performing real-time nondestructive evaluation on piping while welding.

  • Research and testing of high-strength rebar, high-strength concrete, mass concrete, and self-consolidating concrete, in safety-related nuclear power plant applications.

  • Research on the use of augmented reality in the construction process.

  • Development of cyber security guidelines for new construction.

  • Initiation of a 3-year program on Advanced Manufacturing processes and techniques.

  • Initiation of a 4-year program on Advanced Nuclear Systems (GEN IV).

Selected reports and products may be prepared in whole or in part in accordance with the EPRI Quality Program Manual that fulfills the requirements of 10CFR50 Appendix B, NQA-1-1944, and 10CFR21. The QA status of reports and products will be marked and identified.
