Overview

Road Maps

EPRI has developed the following roadmaps to guide research in key technical areas. These roadmaps provide a communication tool for determining what success looks like, identifying research tasks necessary to meet goals, and clarifying roles for all stakeholders.

  • Science and Communication of Low Dose Radiation Risk - 1.79MB PDF
Program Description

The generation of radiological hazards is an inherent byproduct of nuclear plant operation. Proper management of radiation exposure is a top priority for the nuclear industry to protect workers and the public, meet industry performance goals, comply with regulations, and be good stewards of the environment.

The Radiation Safety Program conducts research to manage radiological risks to workers, members of the public, and the environment for the complete life cycle of a nuclear power plant. The program investigates improvements to nuclear plant operational and decommissioning practices that can enhance public and worker safety while reducing risks associated with waste management and radiation exposure.

Research Value

Effective management of the radiological hazards produced by nuclear power is important for continued safe operation of the global fleet, the development of new plants, and plant decommissioning at end of life. The Radiation Safety Program develops guidelines and technologies for cost-effective low-level waste management and disposal, tools and strategies for dose and source term/radiation field reduction, and guidance for groundwater and environmental protection. Radiation Safety Program participants gain access to the following:

  • Strategic roadmaps outlining research gaps across multiple organizations and the collaborative actions needed to address these gaps. Active roadmaps address source term reduction and low-dose radiation risk.

  • Technologies, evaluations, and guidelines that can reduce the generation and disposal of solid and liquid low-level waste (LLW). LLW evaluations, for example, have identified optimization recommendations valued at more than $75 million per year.

  • New source-term reduction and radiation protection techniques that can reduce radiation dose rates and worker exposure. Source-term reduction studies have identified methods for reducing radiation fields by as much as 50% over five years.

  • Technical guidance for early detection, mitigation, and remediation of groundwater contamination, an issue of public and regulatory concern.

  • Technical guidance for improved monitoring and protection of workers.

  • Advanced ALARA (as low as reasonably achievable) planning and dose reduction tools for high dose tasks.

  • Technical guidance for risk-informed regulations in low-level waste, radiation protection, and groundwater protection that can address public safety and environmental stewardship concerns.

  • Comprehensive evaluations of low-dose radiation health effects and risks to inform radiation protection standards, practices, and communication.

Approach

The Radiation Safety Program develops guidance and tools to reduce the risks and costs associated with waste management, radiation protection, and environmental protection. The program also conducts plant evaluations and captures generic lessons learned that can be shared across the industry.

There are both base and supplemental portions of the program. Base research focuses on developing program guidance and the tools and technologies to reduce waste volumes, worker radiation dose, and groundwater impacts from nuclear plant operations and decommissioning activities. To address strategic objectives established for its programs, EPRI has developed seven research focus areas to describe the current work of the Radiation Safety program.

ALARA Strategies and Technologies: Worker exposure is optimized when you take into account both radiation field reduction strategies, such as source term control and shielding, and work process or equipment design improvements that result in less time (or no time) spent in the radiation field or the ability to do the work remotely or from a greater distance from the source. This research focus area includes research related to the use of remote technologies, advanced ALARA planning tools that includes a decision logic for source term reduction, novel shielding applications, and high-dose job optimization strategies.

Radioactivity Generation and Control (Source Term Reduction): The reduction of plant radiation fields and plant effluents is a continual activity at many plants. This area of research and development is collaboratively funded with the Water Chemistry program and addresses the need to expand and enhance understanding of radioactivity and radiation field generation and transport processes. Based on the fundamental understanding of the generation process, tools and techniques are evaluated and developed to improve control of radioactivity for reducing radiation fields and effluents. 

Radiation Safety Guidance: The primary goals of nuclear plant radiation safety programs are the protection of people and the environment. Guidelines and sourcebooks are the tools that enable these goals to be consistently met. The Radiation Safety Program has developed a series of guidelines and sourcebooks in the areas of radiation protection, source term reduction, radiological environmental protection, and low-level waste management that inform plant practices; in some cases, these guidelines are considered global standards.

Radiation Measurements and Dosimetry for Workers and Public: Radiation protection programs rely on detection technologies to identify and quantify radioactive hazards in the workplace and general environment. This information is used with exposure assessments to quantify the dose to workers and the public. This research focus area investigates advanced detection and monitoring technologies and provides recommendations for how the information from these technologies could be used to inform source reduction, dose reduction, and effluent strategies. In addition, more accurate dosimetry and dose calculation methodologies will be investigated to improve the quantification of the dose to workers and the public.

Optimization of Industrial and Radiological Safety: Radiation Safety and Industrial Safety are two of the safety pillars for the nuclear industry. At times, however, efforts in these areas may be done without fully understanding potential unintended consequences for those elements common to both programs. An optimized approach, strategy, and guidance will be developed in this research focus area to address situations where radiological and industrial safety concerns are present so that an optimum decision can be made to better protect the worker.

Low-Dose Radiation Health Risks: Improved understanding of radiation health risks is increas­ingly important for informing regulations and public per­ceptions, as well as informing decisions regarding continued operation of the global fleet of nuclear power plants, build­ing new plants, and decommissioning at end of life. The research in this focus area will be used to: 1) Inform regulatory policies governing radiation protection through interpretations of low-dose risk models for consideration by the scientific commit­tees responsible for developing international standards for radiation safety (e.g., ICRP, UNSCEAR, BEIR VII, NCRP, etc.), and 2) Support science-based communication of radia­tion risks to public stakeholders by providing the technical basis for standardized risk communication documents.

Decommissioning Technology: Development and execution of a safe, efficient, and cost-effective decommissioning program requires input from many disciplines, and can significantly benefit from prior experience and the availability of innovative technologies to address specific decommissioning activities. EPRI’s decommissioning research efforts compile best practices from past and ongoing decommissioning projects, develop structured and practical guidance for executing an effective decommissioning program, and facilitate technology transfer between nuclear plant owners and industry experts to streamline decommissioning of nuclear power plants.

Accomplishments

EPRI’s Radiation Safety Program supports industry efforts to enhance the safe handling and management of low-level waste and to drive reductions in public, environmental, and personnel exposure to radiation. The program develops and demonstrates innovative technologies, converts industry operating experience into practical guidelines, and explores alternative approaches for more effective management of radiological hazards.

  • Revised the PWR Standard Radiation Monitoring Program (SRMP) and BWR Radiation Level Assessment and Control (BRAC) programs to improve the ability to identify trends, evaluate performance of source term reduction technology, and identify research needs. A primer for In-Plant Gamma Spectrometry was published to inform the industry of the various technology options, applications, and benefits of these measurement tools.

  • Investigated the feasibility of using a simplistic model of the activity incorporation process to predict shutdown dose rate variations from plant operational history and coolant chemistry data.

  • Developed a sourcebook to optimize reactor cavity decontamination and improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the process.

  • Provided recommendations and guidance for enhancing the risk assessment of systems, structures, and components (SSCs) and work practices (WPs) based on the analysis of historical leaks and spills of licensed materials at nuclear power plants.

  • Developed generic scaling factors for technetium-99 and iodine-129 that can be used for low-level waste characterization. Application of these generic scaling factors can result in far greater accuracy in accounting for these hard to measure radionuclides.

  • Updated the RadBench™ LLW benchmarking software to support expanded international use.

  • Completed a review of the Atomic Bomb Survivor Life Span Study to advance understanding of dose and dose rate effects. Using that dataset along with the mouse studies utilized by the Biological Effects of Ionizing Radiation VII committee (BEIR VII), the evaluation concluded that a DDREF of <2 was not substantiated.

  • Completed a review of the epidemiology and mechanistic studies concerning cataract risks and found that the probable risks for cataracts are likely increased at a radiation exposure level somewhat less than earlier estimates, but there is currently not enough information to make any specific conclusion with regard to the chronic exposure threshold for cataracts. The study results were incorporated into the National Council on Radiation Protection (NCRP) commentary on cataracts.

Key Activities

The Radiation Safety Program research and development for 2017 will sustain progress toward improved management of waste handling and disposal, reduced worker dose, and improved detection and monitoring of groundwater. Specific efforts will include the following:

  • Provide industry guidance on how best to implement the changes in the newly revised Branch Technical Position on Concentration Averaging and revise on-site storage guidelines to include updates in operating experiences and regulatory changes.

  • Perform research to gain fundamental knowledge of how unexpected plant operating experiences related to chemistry mitigation strategies can affect local micro-environments; also, continue investigations of activity transport models for dose rate predictions.

  • Complete assessment of technologies that generate a hydrophobic surface at the plant-worker interface to reduce worker exposure and contamination events.

  • Develop a comprehensive understanding of the impact of activated silver and antimony species on plant radiation fields.

  • Provide practical guidance for improving lens dose monitoring and protection at nuclear facilities.

  • Continue investigations of cancer and non-cancer risks from exposure to ionizing radiation by performing a review of cardiovascular risks, childhood leukemia risks, and an analysis of selected epidemiologic cohorts.

  • Provide technical guidance for efficient and effective life of plant groundwater protection program implementation, identifying opportunities for optimization, enhancement, preventative maintenance, and decommissioning planning.

  • Investigate the sources and dose impacts of newly identified hard-to-measure radionuclides in nuclear power plant effluents and waste streams.

  • Establish an International Dose Effect Alliance (IDEA) that provides an international platform for collaboration on low-dose radiation health effects research.

  • 41.09.01.01: LLW Technical Strategy Group
    23-May-2016

    Optimized low-level waste (LLW) management at nuclear power plants supports efficient plant operations. Efficient liquid LLW processing ensures that plant water and water storage capacity is available to support plant operations and that liquid effluent quality is maintained. Effective solid LLW management ensures compliance with regulations and can enable cost savings associated with LLW processing and disposal. Current industry LLW technical issues include waste processing, disposal site development, waste characterization and classification, blending, encapsulation, solidification, and equipment reliability. Awareness of industry best practices supports the development and continuous improvement of LLW management strategies.

  • 41.09.01.02: Radiation Management and Source Term Technical Strategy Group
    23-May-2016

    Radiation fields and their source term affect the collected radiation exposures incurred through work activities at a nuclear plant. Many of the factors that influence source term and radiation fields can be controlled, including plant design, core design, fuel performance, materials of construction, chemistry regimes, worker practices, outage scheduling, and training. Changes in one area can cause unexpected implications on source term behavior and the resulting radiation fields in another area. The Radiation Management and Source Term Technical Strategy Group (RMST TSG) strives to enhance the understanding of radiation field generation and to identify opportunities to reduce worker dose.

    23-May-2016

    Leaks and spills from nuclear power plant operations can potentially impact site soil and groundwater throughout the plant’s operating life and eventual decommissioning. New nuclear power plants under construction should begin developing their groundwater protection programs early in the project planning process. A robust groundwater protection program should include an effective groundwater monitoring program to quickly detect and characterize leaks and spills, and a detailed remediation plan that can be implemented during operation or decommissioning as needed. Awareness of industry best practices supports the development and continuous improvement of groundwater protection programs.

Overview

Road Maps

EPRI has developed the following roadmaps to guide research in key technical areas. These roadmaps provide a communication tool for determining what success looks like, identifying research tasks necessary to meet goals, and clarifying roles for all stakeholders.

  • Nuclear Decommissioning Technology - 1.84MB PDF
Program Description

Decommissioning of commercial nuclear power reactors is a complex process typically requiring ten years or more to complete, at a cost of more than $600 million. As the large number of plants that began operations in the 1970s and early 1980s near the end of life, the number of plants entering into decommissioning over the next 10 years will increase. Technology advances in all phases of the decommissioning process can enhance efficiency, reduce cost and schedule, improve worker safety, and reduce waste generation.

Development and execution of a safe, efficient, and cost-effective decommissioning program requires input from many disciplines, and can significantly benefit from utility experience and the availability of innovative technologies to address specific decommissioning activities. EPRI’s decommissioning research efforts compile best practices from past and ongoing decommissioning projects, develop structured and practical guidance for executing an effective decommissioning program, and facilitate technology transfer between nuclear plant owners and industry experts.

Research Value

The Decommissioning Technology Program provides a structured approach for capturing lessons learned from worldwide decommissioning efforts and for tracking relevant operational efforts in waste management and environmental remediation. These lessons learned are incorporated into generic guidance for the nuclear plant fleet. The program also develops and demonstrates technologies that address the unique challenges related to decommissioning. Program participants gain access to the following:

  • Enhanced planning tools to guide decommissioning

  • Lessons learned from decommissioning and other relevant activities at other plants

  • Evaluation and assessment of results from the application of advanced technologies for decontamination and dismantlement, site remediation, waste management, and site characterization

  • Basic research and development to enhance the technical basis used in responding to regulatory requirements

  • Guidance on unresolved issues in groundwater and soil protection and remediation, low-level waste management, site characterization, radiation dose modeling for site release, and license termination

The efficient decommissioning of a nuclear plant allows the site to be released for unrestricted beneficial use as quickly as practical after plant shutdown. Performing the work in a cost-effective manner benefits current and future customers. Accurate site characterization and release also ensures future users of the site may do so with acceptably low risk.

Approach

The Decommissioning Technology Program evaluates and documents all relevant utility experiences in decommissioning and related areas. This knowledge base informs research and development efforts focused on technical challenges associated with decommissioning activities, including development and demonstration of innovative technologies. The program facilitates technology transfer through scheduled decommissioning workshops and plant-specific decommissioning support meetings.

  • Archive experience and lessons learned related to decommissioning regulations and technology

  • Assess strategies for operating plants that could minimize subsequent site contamination and waste generation during decommissioning

  • Identify critical elements associated with development and maintenance of an effective decommissioning plan

  • Evaluate options for disposal of wastes from decommissioning plants

  • Develop and demonstrate advanced technologies and improved methodologies for decommissioning activities

Accomplishments

The EPRI Decommissioning Technology Program captures more than 20 years of experience in the successful decommissioning of commercial power plants. The program also includes nearly 20 years of research and development results covering critical technical areas in plant decommissioning, including planning and strategy development, program cost estimation, waste treatment and management, large component/structure decontamination and dismantlement, and final release of the plant sites for unrestricted use. Program results are available through technical reports, software, and workshop proceedings. The program also offers a forum for utilities to share current experiences and discuss effective solutions associated with plant dismantlement and decommissioning.

  • In 2015 and 2016, held decommissioning workshops in the United States, the United Kingdom, and Japan to bring together utilities, industry and government experts, and experienced decommissioning vendors to review both current technologies and new technologies under development.

  • Developed guidance for transitioning from operations to decommissioning. The guidance includes a review of regulations and experience globally.

  • Evaluated more than 200 decommissioning technologies developed by the U.S. Department of Energy for applicability to commercial plant decommissioning. This evaluation resulted in identification of more than 50 field-ready technologies that may be deployed to assist in performing a range of plant dismantlement and characterization activities.

  • Developed guidance on best practices for management of radioactive wastes during decommissioning. This guidance included experiences from ongoing and completed decommissioning projects in the United States, Belgium, France, Germany, and the United Kingdom.

  • Developed guidance on best practices for management of contaminated concrete. This guidance also includes global experiences from ongoing and completed decommissioning.

Key Activities

Decommissioning program research and development for 2017 will focus on addressing several key technical challenges faced by plants in active dismantlement. Additional efforts will be applied to incorporate industry experience into planning and decision-making tools. Consistent with the mission of the program, efforts to collect and evaluate industry decommissioning experience will continue to derive effective guidance for future plant decommissioning efforts. Project topics may include the following:

  • Develop a web-based database of decommissioning operating experience

  • Investigate the use of advanced system automation and robotic technology for reactor internals segmentation

  • Develop more accurate estimates of trace hard-to-measure radionuclides in activated metals that are important to waste characterization

  • Develop guidance for operational plants to facilitate decommissioning

  • Support technology transfer for U.S. Department of Energy decontamination and demolition technologies

  • Update preplanning and decision-making tools

  • Develop guidance for management of hazardous materials during decommissioning

Overview

Road Maps

EPRI has developed the following roadmaps to guide research in key technical areas. These roadmaps provide a communication tool for determining what success looks like, identifying research tasks necessary to meet goals, and clarifying roles for all stakeholders.

  • Water Chemistry Guidelines for Advanced Light Water Reactors - 0.22MB PDF
  • Chemistry Technologies for the Mitigation of Corrosion Product Fouling - 1.59MB PDF
Program Description

Water chemistry conditions at nuclear power plants affect material corrosion rates, fuel performance, and plant radiation fields. Inadequate attention to water chemistry can result in increased frequency of out-of-specification conditions that could result in plant shutdown, and in extreme cases may lead to rapid degradation of plant components. The Water Chemistry Program performs research and development activities, evaluates operating experience, and develops guidance to optimize plant performance, mitigate corrosion, achieve and maintain design fuel performance standards, and minimize plant radiation fields. 

Research Value

Water chemistry control is critical to the economic operation of commercial power reactors, as well as to the long-term aging management of critical plant components. The Water Chemistry Program develops technical guidance that can be incorporated into nuclear plant procedures to optimize water chemistry control. Research results help nuclear plants create strategic water chemistry plans for maximizing plant availability and cost efficiency in a manner consistent with safety and regulatory requirements. Water Chemistry Program members gain access to the following:

  • Strategic roadmaps outlining research needs associated with key issues—such as chemistry guidelines for advanced light water reactors and strategies for reducing plant radiation fields—and the collaborative actions needed to address these needs.

  • Cost-effective chemistry optimization tools and techniques to improve plant safety, availability, and performance.

  • New chemistry applications through first-of-a-kind technology demonstrations. For example, field demonstration of EPRI's cobalt sequestration resin (CoSeq™) showed a nearly three-fold increase in the removal of cobalt as compared to typical ion exchange resin and planned demonstrations of new online anion analysis technology that could reduce resource burden for monitoring these important species.

  • Software-enabled improvements in chemistry control, diagnostic capabilities, and staff productivity.

  • Enhanced technology transfer through plant-specific collaborations and technical strategy groups.

  • On-site assessment support to benchmark plant chemistry and identify opportunities for optimization.

  • Access to an extensive database of worldwide plant chemistry data.

Approach

The Water Chemistry Program combines basic and applied research with industry operating experience to develop guidance and technologies for nuclear power applications. The program provides a comprehensive suite of water chemistry tools, including guidelines, sourcebooks, new operating and monitoring technologies, chemistry control and assessment software, technical strategy groups, and on-site assessments.

Base research addresses many aspects of effective water chemistry control, including technically based chemistry guidance, first-of-a-kind technology demonstrations, and software tools development.  To address strategic objectives established for the Water Chemistry Program, EPRI has developed five research focus areas (RFAs): 

  • Chemistry Guidance: The key products delivered from this program include the BWR Water Chemistry Guidelines, PWR Primary Water Chemistry Guidelines and PWR Secondary Water Chemistry Guidelines, which are applied throughout the world and are mandated through the NEI 03-08 materials industry initiative in the United States.  These documents, in addition to other chemistry sourcebooks, are the culmination and main technology transfer vehicle for EPRI’s research and development activities related to water chemistry control.  Efforts in this RFA address the needs related to effective guidance for water chemistry control in nuclear power plants as technology continues to advance and understanding of the fundamental processes is enhanced.

  • Radioactivity Generation and Control (Source Term Reduction): The reduction of plant radiation fields and plant effluents is a continual activity at nuclear plants.  This research area, conducted collaboratively with the Radiation Safety program, seeks to expand and enhance understanding of radioactivity and radiation field generation and transport processes.  Based on this enhanced understanding, tools and techniques are evaluated and developed to improve control of radioactivity for reducing radiation fields. 

  • Management and Corrosion Product Behavior and Impacts: General corrosion of plant components releases corrosion products into the coolant that can reduce heat transfer efficiency and increase fouling of critical systems, potentially impacting plant performance and operability.  This research area seeks to understand corrosion product behavior to better control the generation, transport and deposition of corrosion products and mitigate the effect of corrosion products throughout the power plant.  While overlap exist between the fundamentals of corrosion and radioactivity generation, research in this area focuses on the non-radiation field related species (bulk-type species).

  • Chemistry Monitoring and Control: Power plant water chemistry control requires analytical techniques and protocols for effective monitoring, technically based control limits, and techniques to adjust and maintain water chemistry within optimum limits.  This RFA develops new and enhanced analytical methods, including online analysis techniques; develops new technologies for water treatment, including purification media; and assesses research results to support water chemistry control limits, or in rare cases, establish new control parameters.

  • Chemical Mitigation: While materials have improved over time, there continues to be a need to understand the fundamental impact of chemistry control on materials degradation modes such as environmentally assisted cracking (inter-granular stress corrosion cracking, IGSCC; primary water stress corrosion cracking, PWSCC; lead-assisted stress corrosion cracking, PbSCC; outer diameter stress corrosion cracking, ODSCC; etc.).  Past work has analyzed the impact of noble metal application in BWRs, zinc addition, steam generator chemical cleaning of the PWR secondary side, and elevated hydrogen operation in the PWR primary system. Near-term work in this RFA will focus on oxygen control alternatives to hydrazine and fundamentals of new environmentally assisted cracking mechanisms like PbSCC.

Through separately funded projects, participants gain access to additional research activities. Technical strategy groups provide a forum for nuclear plant operators to discuss common interests related to resins, filters, chemistry technologies (for example, zinc, On-line NobleChem™, dispersants), and overall chemistry optimization. User groups focus on improvements and lessons learned and technology transfer through the web-based Smart ChemWorks™ software. Furthermore, implementation and evaluation support for a number of chemistry technologies are available—including startup hydrogen injection, feedwater iron optimization, cycle chemistry, startup and shutdown chemistry, zinc application, dispersant application, open and closed cooling water chemistry, and resin/filter assessments.

Accomplishments

EPRI’s Water Chemistry Program supports nuclear power industry efforts to improve water chemistry control and assess impacts on other plant systems and components. Water chemistry research provides members with the guidance and technologies to improve operational flexibility, reduce operations and maintenance costs, reduce dose, and reduce material degradation risks.

  • Evaluated technical options for responding to the worldwide shortage of lithium hydroxide enriched in lithium-7, which is used to control pH within plant guidance limits without generating excessive tritium.  The three-pronged approach included evaluating industry use of lithium-7, including opportunities for reduction and plant impacts; development of a technology to recover lithium-7 from spent resin; and analysis of alternatives to lithium-7, such as the use of potassium hydroxide.

  • Published initial results evaluating technology for creating passive oxide films on plant wetted surfaces, which could reduce life-of-plant corrosion product formation and transport, ultimately reducing radiation fields, heat transfer and fouling issues. 

  • Completed assessment of available online monitoring technologies for analysis of anion concentrations, and selected a technology for demonstration at an operating plant.

  • Published water chemistry guidance for advanced light water reactors, including additional guidance to support hot functional testing, establishment of initial system cleanliness and optimal plant startup. Issued guidance for advanced pressurized water reactor and boiling water reactor designs.

  • Released a major update to the Plant Chemistry Simulator in support of improved chemistry modeling and assessments, including increased modeling flexibility (for example, dual feedwater and turbine trains, deaerator operations, and access to the latest version of the MULTEQ database).

  • Published the results of fundamental research on high-temperature aqueous boric acid chemistry. The accurate assessment of boric acid chemistry is important to PWR primary lithium control, and can impact PWSCC rates, fuel performance, and plant radiation fields.

  • Published a multi-year assessment of plant operating experience with dispersant applications to provide guidance in optimizing the value from this technology.

  • Developed an online interface of PWR shutdown chemistry data, enabling users to quickly complete independent benchmarks of plant performance relative to other industry observations.

  • Published the results of a multi-year evaluation to significantly improve primary system chemistry control during shutdowns and guidance for long-term layup of PWR systems. This work is aimed at mitigating issues known to have developed during plant shutdowns and provides guidance on potential corrective actions.

  • Published a revised version of CIRCE for modeling and evaluating PWR secondary chemistry impacts, such as the effect of amine optimization on the long-term fouling of steam generators.

  • Published an updated version of MULTEQ with new and revised species, including cobalt species, lead and nickel titanates, chloride species, and iron and sodium phosphates.

  • Successfully supported commercialization of cobalt sequestration resin (CoSeq®) for application in filter demineralizer systems, which had been applied at five operating BWRs through early 2016.

Key Activities

Water Chemistry Program research and development for 2017 will focus on technology developments and assessments to continually improve guidance and tools for optimized chemistry control. Specific efforts will include the following:

  • Continue collecting and evaluating global BWR and PWR water chemistry data through EPRI's Chemistry Monitoring and Assessment (CMA) project to benchmark specific water chemistry regimes, optimize plant operation, and support key research and development activities.

  • Continue development of the CMA web access tools to include access to operational chemistry and BWR data.

  • Complete review and assessment of available industry experience on the use of filming amines for application in the PWR secondary system. This assessment will identify steps required to qualify candidate filming amines for plant application.

  • Finalize revision to the PWR secondary chemistry guidelines for publication in early 2017.

  • Identify and resolve concerns with the use of advanced amines in PWR secondary systems with respect to potential effects on turbine materials.

  • Continue assessment of techniques for surface passivation of new or chemically decontaminated components to reduce radiation source term buildup.

  • Complete assessment of technologies that generate a hydrophobic surface at the plant-worker interface to reduce worker exposure and contamination events.

  • Develop demonstration of online analysis of deleterious anion species and evaluate technologies for online analysis of corrosion products. 

  • Complete a fundamental study on the effect of surface micro-chemical environments on activity transport and deposition.

  • Continue fundamental research to include new species and update current thermodynamic relationships in the MULTEQ database.

  • Initiate work to understand the impact of dispersant application on PWR secondary side deposits.

  • Publish revised guidance for condensate polishing system operation to optimize performance with current media and equipment.

  • Continue development of software tools for completion of standard BWR chemistry calculations like BWR conductivity, KOH for pH control, and an ion exchange module.

Selected reports and products may be prepared in whole or in part in accordance with the EPRI Quality Program Manual that fulfills the requirements of 10CFR50 Appendix B and 10CFR21. The QA status of reports and products will be marked and identified.

  • 41.09.03.03: Pressurized Water Reactor Technical Strategy Group
    23-May-2016

    Improved understanding and awareness of the chemistry-related issues encountered across the nuclear fleet – and the responses to these issues – can enable improvements in plant performance. For example, PWR chemists can incorporate many technologies to optimize performance based on plant-specific needs and issues.

    • Zinc is being increasingly applied to reduce plant dose rates and reduce susceptibility to primary water stress corrosion cracking (PWSCC), but concerns still exist for plants with the highest boiling-duty cores.

    • Application of elevated hydrogen for mitigating PWSCC crack growth rates of Alloy 600 and its weld metals remains an area of interest, as demonstrated by the increase in industry cycle average hydrogen concentrations over recent years. 

    • Filter and resin technologies to reduce activated corrosion product (for example, cobalt) concentrations in the primary system remain areas of significant work.

    • Dispersant application in the secondary system to significantly reduce steam generator fouling and improve performance is beginning to gain ground and is expected to increase significantly over the next several years.

    • In addition to primary and secondary chemistry control, cooling water chemistry guidance has recently been updated and published for plant chemists, providing improved guidance for the use of chemicals to mitigate corrosion, biological growth, and scale formation in these systems. Performance metrics have been defined, and can be used to track the effectiveness of chemical treatment.

    Recognizing the extensive industry experience in all of these areas, nuclear plants can benefit from the sharing of industry best practices to resolve common technical challenges and contribute to safe, reliable plant operation.

A variety of system designs, septa types, precoat materials, resins, and application and backwash procedures are used across the fleet in reactor water and condensate cleanup systems. Depleted zinc oxide addition through the plant’s feedwater system is also applied throughout the majority of the BWR fleet for dose reduction, and On-line NobleChem™ (OLNC) is becoming standard practice for most BWRs for mitigation. The impacts on fuel performance, stress corrosion crack mitigation, radwaste and exposure reduction need to be balanced and carefully managed by plant chemists and operators.

Overview

Road Maps

EPRI has developed the following roadmaps to guide research in key technical areas. These roadmaps provide a communication tool for determining what success looks like, identifying research tasks necessary to meet goals, and clarifying roles for all stakeholders.

  • Long-Term Operations Aging Management - 2.30MB PDF
  • Long-Term Operations Enhancement and Modernization Technology - 2.09MB PDF
Program Description

Nuclear power plants around the world are an important source of non-carbon emitting generation. Even when major plant components must be replaced or upgraded to extend operating life, these plants often represent a cost-effective, low-carbon asset. The decision to extend nuclear plant life involves a host of interrelated technical, economic, regulatory, and public policy issues. Unknown or uncertain technical inputs impact the decision-making process both directly and indirectly: directly, through design and operational contingencies; and indirectly, through impacts on regulatory actions and public policy.

Recognizing the many technical challenges confronting extended nuclear plant operations, the Long-Term Operations Program is conducting an array of research and development (R&D) activities to ensure that the public, nuclear plant owners, regulatory agencies, and all interested stakeholders have the information needed to make sound decisions regarding the ability of a nuclear plant to sustain safe, reliable, and economic operations.

Research Value

The Long-Term Operations (LTO) Program is developing the technical information on which to base decisions regarding extended nuclear plant life. Research results will not only inform those plant owners considering life extension past 30, 40, or 60 years, but also those with relatively younger plants considering the long-term impacts of aging. Participants in the LTO program gain access to technical solutions and information to support the following needs:

  • Identifying key technical barriers that may be life limiting

  • Investigating cost-effective modernization opportunities

  • Informing potential regulatory issues

  • Informing business case decisions for extended operations

  • Defining the technical basis for aging management programs that can support safe, long-term operations

Research conducted through the LTO Program provides the public, nuclear plant owners, regulatory agencies, and other interested stakeholders with the information needed to make sound decisions regarding the ability of a nuclear plant to sustain safe, reliability, economic operations.

Approach

The factors driving interest in long-term nuclear plant operations correspond to specific challenges where technical insight can effectively inform decision making. Although these challenges touch different aspects related to long-term operations – from the physical condition of the plant to the allocation of capital budgets for plant refurbishment – they all require focused R&D to ensure that technical constraints and opportunities are fully understood. The LTO Program is designed to address these constraints and opportunities.

The program accomplishes its objectives through an integrated strategy that involves research defined by the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI), collaboration on complementary research activities with the Department of Energy's (DOE) Light Water Reactor Sustainability (LWRS) Program, and engagement with other global entities such as the Materials Aging Institute, the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), CANDU Owners’ Group (COG), and Japan’s Central Research Institute for the Electric Power Industry (CRIEPI).

The activities conducted through the LTO Program are identified in association with nuclear plant owners, regulators, and other key stakeholders. The project also builds on the technical experience and expertise accumulated through EPRI leadership in the U.S. license renewal effort in the 1990s and early 2000s.

Research activities are focused in six technical areas:

  • Primary system metals material aging, including the reactor pressure vessel

  • Concrete and containment aging

  • Risk and safety analysis methods

  • Instrumentation and control and information technology

  • Electrical cable aging

  • Aging management programs, plant demonstrations and pilot projects.

Accomplishments

EPRI's LTO Program is a large research effort with broad collaboration across EPRI technical program areas and EPRI’s research partners. Key recent results include:

  • Maintenance and updates to a prioritized Long-Term Operation Issue Tracking Table. This table is the basis for collaborative R&D programs between the DOE, NRC Research, international research organizations, and EPRI. The Issue Tracking Table is updated annually to reflect the current state of knowledge, and to ensure that the right research is being done at the right time to support LTO decisions.

  • Participation in the IAEA International Generic Aging Lessons Learned (IGALL) project. EPRI completed a cross-reference assessment of the aging management programs in the IGALL and in EPRI reports to support global implementation of the IGALL; this assessment was posted to the IAEA IGALL website.

  • Worked with DOE LWRS Program to develop a robust database defining the effects of radiation exposure on concrete mechanical properties and initiated a finite element analysis modeling project to quantify the margins of safety for the limiting biological shield wall configuration with up to 80 years of radiation exposure.

  • Collaborated with DOE and NRC Research to develop an integrated roadmap of cable R&D projects to inform long-term operations and determine cable remaining useful life. Recent activities focused on harvesting field aged cables, testing methods for submerged cables, pursuing advances for condition monitoring technology, and synergistic testing of cables in a high-temperature radiation environment.

  • Published a research report on screening and testing for reactive concrete aggregates; these results can be used to support decisions regarding aging management of concrete structures susceptible to degradation due to environmental conditions.

  • Collaborated with DOE to design and install a hot cell at Oak Ridge National Laboratory, which will be used to demonstrate hybrid laser and friction stir welding processes as repair options for highly irradiated materials. Such technologies could be used for repairing reactor vessel internals.

  • Supported technical meetings with the NRC, Advisory Committee on Reactors Safeguards (ACRS), and NRC Commissioners on EPRI work regarding the technical basis for aging management. Two lead plants in the United States, one PWR and BWR, have expressed their intent to submit a second license renewal (SLR) application to the NRC in the 2018 to 2019 timeframe. 

Key Activities

Long-Term Operations research for 2017 will focus on the following:

  • Work with the Boiling Water Reactor Vessel and Internals Project (BWRVIP) to develop a strategy for implementing a surveillance capsule program for monitoring vessel fluence impacts out to 80 years of operation.

  • Work with BWRVIP and the Materials Reliability Program (MRP) to update and revise EPRI reports needed to inform the technical basis for second license renewal in the United States, and extended operations around the world. High-priority technical reports cover vessel internals, cast stainless materials, and nickel-based alloys inspections.

  • Analyze temperature and radiation data collected from a PWR and BWR to assess and adjust actual temperature and radiation data for cable systems in operating plants.  This data will be used to inform remaining useful life (RUL) qualifications.

  • Work with DOE and NRC Research to harvest cables from shutdown plants to assess field aged cable conditions and perform accelerated aging tests.

  • Publish technical reports providing the technical basis to inspect, monitor and evaluate civil structures with potentially reactive aggregates.

  • Continue R&D efforts on characterization, modeling, and mitigation of intergranular stress corrosion cracking in nickel alloys and irradiation-assisted stress corrosion cracking in stainless steel.

  • Support global efforts through IAEA to revise the IGALL document with additional operating experience and lessons learned on best practices for aging management.

  • Demonstrate the hybrid laser and friction stir advanced welding techniques on irradiated samples in a hot cell at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory.

  • Work with DOE LWRS program to support an integrated control modernization project at a host plant. 

Selected reports and products may be prepared in whole or in part in accordance with the EPRI Quality Program Manual that fulfills the requirements of 10CFR50 Appendix B and 10CFR21. The QA status of reports and products will be marked and identified.

Overview

Program Description

Historically, most nuclear power plants have operated as baseload units and have been optimized for continuous full-power operation. This situation is changing for some plants as more renewable generating capacity is brought on-line and as market dynamics change.

Flexible operations is defined as any mode of operation that is not baseload. Not all nuclear plants will need to consider flexible operations. Decisions regarding flexible operations are dependent on local grid conditions, contributions from renewables and distributed generation, consumer behaviors, and utility fleet economics. Plant owners considering a transition to flexible operations will benefit from technical insights that inform changes in plant operating practices, staff training needs, protocols with independent (transmission) system operators, the design and licensing basis, and physical plant modifications.

Research Value

The dynamics of the grid are changing rapidly due to increasing penetration of renewables, distributed energy, and changing consumer behaviors. These changes may result in a greater need for increased flexibility of dispatchable generation to maintain grid reliability. Based on local grid conditions and utility fleet economics, flexible operations of nuclear power plants could become part of a utility fleet management strategy to maintain grid reliability. Flexible operations also may emerge as a new requirement for new plant projects; in some countries, the new plants will represent a large load on a small grid and will have to operate flexibly during periods of low demand.

The Flexible Operations Program conducts research to inform decisions regarding flexible nuclear plant operations and characterize associated impacts on plant health and grid reliability. The program collects operating experience on flexible operations, supports coordinated research among industry stakeholders, and executes EPRI R&D projects designed to identify and manage potential impacts from flexible operations on the plant and its components.

Approach

EPRI is conducting research and development (R&D) to evaluate the impacts of flexible operations on nuclear power plants with respect to fuel integrity, chemistry controls, plant reliability, and other parameters. The research applies to nuclear plants that currently need to operate flexibly, to those plants evaluating the need for flexible operations, and to new plants considering flexible operations as a part of their design and licensing basis.

The program accomplishes its goal through an integrated strategy that draws on subject matter experts across the EPRI nuclear sector, incorporates operating experience from EPRI’s Generation sector, and collaborates with the U.S. Department of Energy, International Atomic Energy Agency, Institute of Nuclear Power Operations, EDF, and the nuclear steam supply system vendors.

Research activities are grouped into the following areas:

  • Operating experience, plant feasibility studies, and readiness reviews

  • Fuel integrity guidelines

  • Chemistry, low-level waste and radiation management guidelines

  • Impacts on balance of plant and flow-accelerated corrosion 

  • Impacts on primary side components 

EPRI also has initiated a number of research imperatives to drive collaboration on cross-cutting industry priorities. One of these is related to flexible operations: “Enable Cost Effective Flexible Operations in Central Station Generation.” An EPRI team is coordinating an integrated, holistic approach using cross-sector resources.

Accomplishments

The Flexible Operations Program provides broad coordination and collaboration across EPRI’s technical program areas.  Key research results include:

  • An Approach to Transition Nuclear Power Plants to Flexible Operations (3002002612): This report provides guidance to develop a change management plan for nuclear power plants considering flexible operations options.

  • Flexible Plant Operations Assessment and Management Matrix (3002004360): Provides a method to systematically identify potential vulnerabilities and management strategies associated with operating at a reduced power level for extended periods of time and for implementing flexible operations.

  • Convened an expert panel comprising representatives from the major fuel vendors, INPO and nuclear plant operators to identify knowledge gaps and research needs related to fuel performance and integrity.  Recommended updates to operating practices for flexible operations are being developed.

  • Collected, reviewed and analyzed water chemistry data from both PWRs and BWRs during periods of flexible operations. Trends have been detected in the data and recommendations for increased sampling and monitoring of chemistry condition are being developed.

  • Collected, trended and modeled data on crud transport in PWRs during periods of flexible operations. Recommendations based on this data are being developed.

  • Conducted two site visits to collect data on the impacts of flexible operations on the balance of plant.  The data has been reviewed and common trends have been detected. This data, in addition to data to be collected from additional site visits, is being rolled up into a summary report documenting lessons learned and recommendations.

Key Activities

The Flexible Operations Program research for 2017 will focus on the following:

  • Continue sharing operating experience between utility members, vendors and stakeholders on lessons learned and best practices for flexible operations.

  • Update the existing gap matrix on flexible operations to identify possible research areas and prioritization of future R&D projects.

  • Publish guidance to ensure continued fuel integrity during periods of flexible operations.  This will take into account ramp rates and duration of power cycles to prevent pellet-clad interaction (PCI) failures during periods of flexible operations.

  • Publish recommended changes to the EPRI PWR and BWR water chemistry guidelines to ensure adequate chemistry controls and monitoring during periods of flexible operations.

  • Update EPRI technical reports on crud transport in PWRs and BWRs during periods of flexible operations. Based on the results of ongoing crud transport modeling, develop recommended changes for the primary water chemistry guidelines to maintain fuel integrity due to crud related issues.

  • Continue site visits and data collection on the impact of flexible operations on balance-of-plant components. The results of these site visits will be shared as lessons learned and operating experience reports.

  • Publish the results of studies with the nuclear steam supply system vendors on the impacts of flexible operations on primary system components. One specific project to be completed in 2017 involves a quantitative assessment of the impact of flexible operations on PWR core internals, with recommendations for inspection and monitoring strategies.

Sherry Bernhoft, 704-595-2740, sbernhoft@epri.com

Overview

Program Description

Key Research Question:

To better characterize and resolve fuel reliability issues, fundamental understanding of material behavior and properties in as-irradiated conditions is needed, as well as insights into the mechanisms involved during irradiation. A generic, long-term research and development program examining these issues can help ensure safe and reliable use of light water reactor (LWR) core materials and components. Since 1982, EPRI has led the Nuclear Fuel Industry Research (NFIR) group, an international collaboration of utilities, fuel vendors, and research laboratories. The NFIR program seeks to understand fundamental in-reactor behavior of fuel, cladding, control materials, and other core components and to share this valuable knowledge with the industry.

Objectives:

The NFIR program seeks to understand fundamental in-reactor behavior of fuel, cladding, control materials, and other core components, and to share this valuable knowledge with the industry. NFIR performs experimental projects and data interpretation to provide a cost-effective source of fundamental fuel performance data. The program takes advantage of the knowledge and expertise of multiple stakeholders and experimental facilities to generate valuable information not obtainable otherwise. Research projects in four main areas help address fuel reliability issues: (i) hydrogen pickup mechanisms in zirconium based alloys; (ii) advanced characterization of UO2 fuel variants, including separate effects and synchrotron based investigations on fuel fragmentation; (iii) shadow corrosion issues on cladding and core components; and (iv) test reactor irradiations of reference and advanced fuel pellet variants.

Research Value

The knowledge and data obtained through these projects will be factored into fuel design modifications, new fuel designs, and operational strategies targeting higher fuel reliability. NFIR-VI projects will continue to provide fundamental materials properties and behavior data that lead to improved fuel products by improving the knowledge about the behavior of fuel and core components materials. The discussions for NFIR-VII will be initiated with NFIR participants in 2014, and NFIR-VII is expected to launch in 2016.

Approach

The focus in NFIR continues to be on longer-term fundamental R&D that would be beyond the reach of any individual participant.

The NFIR program is conducted in a series of multi-year phases, each containing several research projects. EPRI has launched NFIR-VII in 2016 and in discussions with NFIR members, the R&D topics listed below under Key Activities are to be included in NFIR-VII R&D portfolio.

Accomplishments
    • Successful completion of five phases, each lasting ~ 6-7 years.
    • All fuel industry stakeholders have been voting members.
    • Cost effective collaboration with proven accomplishments:
      • Lead rod program in Gösgen— advent of Low-tin Zr-4;
      • Concept of duplex fuel rods first emerged out of NFIR meetings, followed by the first LTA in Grohnde;
      • Pioneered disc irradiation for fuel variants—twice over!
      • Dimensional Stability Project: Set the standard for systematic study on irradiation growth behavior;
      • Pioneered cost-effective separate effects studies for fuel fragmentation behavior under LOCA and RIA type transients focused on mechanism involved.
      • Projects directly applicable to Dry Storage Issues (HRO, DBTT);
      • Not just Zry and UO2: Programs on B4C and IASCC in Steels and Ni-base alloys have also been included.

     

Key Activities
  • Shadow Corrosion in BWRs: Understand the dependence of shadow corrosion on material variables and fuel design.
  • Mechanistic Studies of Hydrogen Pickup (HPU) in Zirconium Alloys: Investigate material factors that affect HPU.
  • Hydride Precipitation and Hysteresis Effects in Dry Storage: Confirm whether or not existing hydrides cause an increase in the precipitation temperature and quantify associated precipitation temperature increase.
  • Effect of [Li] on PWR Corrosion: Identify gaps in current understanding of the effect and conduct a Round Robin of [Li] concentration profile through oxide films using various experimental methods.
  • Advanced Characterizations and Annealing Studies on UO2 Fuel Variants: This topic has multiple embedded objective—(a) Develop fuel that is capable of delaying onset of high burn-up structure (HBS) in fuel pellets; (b) Reduce volatile FP release and thus reduce propensity of clad failure by pellet-clad interaction stress corrosion cracking (PCI-SCC).; (c) Produce experimental data to model high temperature release of fission gas and volatile fission products from fuel; and (d) Produce data to model fuel temperatures at the beginning of life at low burn-ups.
  • Irradiation of New Fuel Variants for future R&D: Create an inventory of forthcoming fuel variants up to high burn-ups for future PIE, characterizations, and OOP tests.

Concurrent to discussions and implementation of NFIR-VII, the remaining final deliverable reports of NFIR-VI Projects are being completed in 2017-18. The following long-term irradiation projects from NFIR-VI will also continue into NFIR-VII

  • Irradiation Growth and Thermal Stability of Cold Work and Irradiation Defects in Model Zirconium-based Alloys containing 1% Nb: Pre-hydrided Zr-alloy variants are under irradiation in BOR-60 MTR to pursue irradiation growth, damage annealing, and post-irradiation creep
  • Impact of hydrogen below and above solubility limits on the irradiation growth of a number of improved channel alloys and reference materials is being examined after exposures in Advance Test Reactor (ATR) to different fluence levels up to 30 dpa

Program Name: Air and Multimedia Toxics Health and Risk Assessment
text:
Overview

Program Description

EPRI’s Air and Multimedia Toxics Health and Risk Assessment Program (Air Toxics) provides cutting edge, independent scientific data to inform power companies, their stakeholders, U.S. and international policy makers, and the public of the health risks associated with potentially hazardous power plant emissions. The program is regarded by industry and public agencies as a critical and highly respected source of scientific information on air and multimedia toxics. The Air Toxics program focuses on two primary areas of research. First, the program conducts basic health science research to address cutting-edge questions on health effects and public health risk assessment of hazardous air pollutants (HAPs), including arsenic, mercury, selenium, nickel, chromium, cadmium, and trace organics. These comprehensive health effects studies are applicable to all routes of human exposure (inhalation, ingestion, or direct contact), and to the establishment of environmental criteria. Second, working closely with other EPRI programs, Program 42 provides the data and tools for assessing the impacts of trace substances both by atmospheric transport and via transfer and transformation in other media. These assessments focus on which routes of exposure are most critical, and quantify the impacts likely to result.

With the coal and oil utility industry now fully in compliance with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Mercury and Air Toxics Standards (MATS) rule, EPRI is undertaking evaluation of the human health risks remaining from the post-MATS industry’s emissions. Trace metals and other substances, such as arsenic, may continue to be regarded as posing unacceptable public health risks when post-MATS assessments of “residual,” or remaining, risk are completed. This is particularly the case when multiple emission and discharge routes from the power plant are considered. Thus, power companies need to continue investigate whether their emissions may pose risks to public health by all routes of exposure. At the same time, emerging data assessments may be driving health standards to more stringent levels, despite uncertainties regarding basic health effects (both cancer and non-cancer). The two trends – tighter health standards combined with the potential for additional reductions being required in HAPs emissions – necessitate closer examination of remaining health risks from power industry emissions in the context of all sources of those toxicants.

Research Value

The Air Toxics program focuses on several issues of key importance to power industry operations and planning. As regulatory and operational environments evolve, the program’s research is oriented around emerging issues likely to increase in importance in the next several years. The program develops data and methods for assessment of human health impacts, from fundamental health effects studies to regional-scale exposure and health risk assessments. The research conducted in this program benefits all stakeholders including the public by providing health information to develop trace substance risk assessments based on sound science and by developing tools to meet any air toxics regulations in the most cost-effective manner.

The program is intended to provide improved estimates of environmental impact. As one example of this, U.S. community exposure to arsenic, whether via water supplies or the atmosphere, typically is much lower than in certain overseas regions in which health studies have been conducted and results used to set U.S. regulatory standards for arsenic. EPRI research has focused on biological response at these much lower doses to determine if there is a threshold below which health impacts may not be expected to occur. This includes evidence for threshold behavior for both cancer and non-cancer impacts of arsenic.

EPRI development of refined exposure assessment methods has the potential to inform the process on how standards are interpreted by the research community and public agencies. EPRI stack sampling programs in the 1990s (PISCES field sampling) used this exposure assessment modeling to refine field protocols and allocate resources by focusing on sampling those substances with significant risk potential. This EPRI multimedia exposure model was cited by a National Academy of Sciences panel as an example of a recommended approach to exposure and risk assessment.

One important focus of Program 42 is to inform the power industry about developments in the research community that may impact industry planning. The continuing research on mercury is now focused on analyzing and synthesizing emerging data to determine if there are spatial and temporal trends that can be linked to known changes in emissions. This emphasis on source-receptor relationships is a critical yet difficult issue to address for trace substances (such as selenium and arsenic) that have not only natural sources, but many human sources as well. The Air Toxics program develops fundamental measurement and modeling methods to distinguish contributions due to utility emissions from other sources.

Approach

The program integrates basic health science research with risk assessments useful for environmental planning. Basic health research includes controlled laboratory studies and, in some cases, epidemiological studies, as well as an integrated approach to better understand the toxicological effects of trace substances. This work is integrated into the development of exposure and risk assessment tools. An essential part of exposure assessment is detailed modeling of the fate of trace substance emissions and the fraction that enters ecosystems and waterways.

The research approach is to first evaluate which exposure pathways may result in risk levels of concern and which substances play the greatest role in driving those risks. Those screening results are used to help guide more detailed investigations. Model development, and particularly development of methods to evaluate inter-media transfer processes, is an essential part of the process. The goal is to account for the fate, and impact, of these stack emissions (as well as the off-site impacts of other discharge pathways, both liquid and solid wastes). Modeling results allow an assessment of the levels of exposure to particular substances by community residents in the vicinity of power plants. Those exposure levels are combined with the substance dose-response relationships to calculate human health risks. The work is carried out through site-specific case studies as well as industrywide assessments of environmental impacts. When exposure pathways other than air are demonstrated to play critical roles in exposure, the work cooperates closely with those EPRI programs that specialize in surface water, groundwater, and byproduct assessments to provide more exact results. The scientific results from this program are highly applicable to the international community.

Accomplishments

The Air Toxics program provides distinguished, recognized international expertise in HAPs and multimedia toxics transport, fate, and health impacts. Scientific results are conveyed to federal and state decision-makers as well as international agencies considering multinational conventions. The program has an established record of providing research results through open peer-reviewed literature, as well as communication tools focused on key audiences. A key goal of the cooperative research effort is a high multiplier effect: significant use of EPRI resources through collaboration with and guidance of joint research efforts. Some recent highlights include:

  • A comprehensive, integrated research program centered on low-dose cancer effects of inorganic arsenic has demonstrated that arsenic exhibits a threshold below which no adverse biological effects – either cancer or non-cancer – would be expected to occur, and thus that linear extrapolation from high doses to zero is not appropriate.

  • Basic health research on chromium(VI) shows that this toxicant does not act via a mutagenic mode of action via ingestion and thus that the shape of the concentration-response curve at low doses is not linear to zero.

  • Analyses of national mercury databases over a 15-year period showed that no clear pattern of decline in mercury deposition was yet evident at regional or state scales, nor any evidence of east-west differences.

  • In a regional assessment, linked air and watershed modeling showed that arsenic and selenium added to the system from stack emissions resulted in levels well below health-based water quality criteria.

Key Activities

In 2017, the program will continue to focus on characterizing the occurrence and multimedia partitioning of toxic substances in fossil-fuel-fired power plants, especially on evaluating emissions from For 2017 the program is oriented around two primary goals: fundamental research results and exposure assessment methods development. Evolution of the power industry due to economic, regulatory, and resource constraints has broadened the scope of studies required. Increasing concern about arsenic, as well as heightened regulatory scrutiny, emphasizes the need to focus on its complex dynamics in the environment. Specific efforts will include the following:

  • Basic health studies of chromium’s cancer effects in a highly leveraged project.

  • Studies of arsenic as an air and multimedia toxic of continuing concern, including evidence of arsenic entering the environment from power industry sources via multiple pathways.

  • Review and analysis of the EPA’s Integrated Risk Information System (IRIS) program’s toxicological assessments of arsenic and chromium, both of which are expected in 2017.

  • Development of improved risk assessment tools for evaluation of post-MATS exposures and risk.

  • Quantification and clarification of the health effects of key toxicants by all exposure routes.

  • Integrative studies of source-to-fate-to-effects pathways for toxicants of relevance.

  • Improved methods to quantify environmental trends for mercury and other toxicants.

Estimated 2017 Program Funding
$1.8 M
Program Manager
Naresh Kumar, 650-855-8758, nkumar@epri.com

Last Updated
  • Health Effects of Arsenic and other Toxics
    08-Jun-2016

    Quantifying the exposure-to-health effects relationships of trace metals such as inorganic arsenic and hexavalent chromium continues to be of critical importance to understanding the potential for harm to public health and the environment from current and legacy emissions. The need to provide substantive data to aid in scientifically supported environmental and regulatory decision-making remains crucial. Results of ongoing inhalation cancer risk assessments of power generating facilities show that trace metals continue to play the major role in calculated risk as power plants change in response to economic and regulatory drivers. By providing improved information to assess the quantitative relationship between health endpoints (cancer and non-cancer) and metals, this project helps to resolve the basic uncertainties and critical data gaps vital to informing a range of exposure and risk assessment needs encompassing research programs in air, water, and land.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Mercury Trends
    08-Jun-2016

    Mercury is expected to remain an issue for U.S. utilities as long as there are mercury emissions from power plants and levels of mercury in fish are deemed to pose a health risk to consumers. Work underway in 2017 is focused on that very question: whether there are significant observable trends in mercury contained in commercial fish, the primary exposure route for U.S. residents. The many emerging streams of data on mercury levels in the atmosphere, in precipitation, waterways, soils, wildlife, and humans have to be compared to information on human and natural sources of mercury, and how those are changing over time. Air & Multimedia Toxics program research will continue to investigate whether changes in mercury concentrations in various environmental compartments can be linked to decreases in domestic mercury emissions and changes in international emissions. One aspect of this work is investigation of alternative methods to link emissions trends over broad geographic ranges with environmental trends in U.S. and adjacent areas.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Post-MATs Exposure and Risk Assessment
    08-Jun-2016

    The studies of risks remaining after MATS compliance, referred to as “residual risk,” will involve assessment of not only health risk via inhalation, but risk via other exposure routes (such as ingestion). As emissions data emerge, EPRI is carrying out a series of, first, screening and, then, more detailed inhalation risk assessments focusing on those substances and power plants posing the greatest potential for human health risk. These initial studies are being followed in 2017 by more focused multimedia exposure and risk analyses, with the potential for a many-fold increase in potential risk levels over those found for inhalation exposure alone. Application of both the EPA regulatory-application multimedia model and the EPRI TRUE-2 multimedia model allows development of uncertainty and variability levels in the resulting risks, as well as sensitivity analyses to determine the most critical factors in deriving risks by particular exposure routes. These determinations, in turn, provide critical information on the key uncertainties to help guide process and chemistry studies.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Toxics Fate and Transport Model Development
    07-Jun-2016

    Basic and applied research on methods to better assess human health risks of trace substances have evolved since the development and application of the EPRI TRUE (Total Risk of Utility Emissions) multimedia risk model. In part, the constituent media models used for TRUE have been supplanted by more complex models requiring increased computer capabilities. EPRI studies have shown the importance of including longer-term processes in such integrated transport/exposure/risk models; for example, the build-up of substances in ecosystems may significantly enhance subsequent concentrations in the human environment. On-going work in several EPRI programs has been addressing trace substance dynamics throughout the environment. Studies in the air, water, and other programs have, most recently, focused on mercury and arsenic in the environment, while emphasizing the utility origins of those substances. Additional research is needed to bring together the findings from the various environmental media to model the fate of substances once released from power plant sources, and their possible impacts on human health.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
