Overview

Program Description

Power company operations generate by-products and solid wastes that require engineering and environmental management to prevent contamination of land and groundwater. Historically, coal combustion products (CCPs) have been managed in landfills and ponds, or used in a variety of construction and land applications. The current trend in disposal is toward more dry management and landfill disposal of CCPs, and less wet management in ponds. CCP research focuses on accurate characterization of these materials, design and operation of landfills, closure of ponds, assessment of legacy sites, health and ecologic risk assessment, groundwater remediation, and environmental assessment of beneficial use applications. Key information needs include evaluating the effects of new air emissions controls on management of CCPs, assessing costs and engineering options for compliance with new CCP disposal and use regulations, describing the fate and transport of contaminants, and developing cost-effective strategies to minimize and remediate adverse environmental impacts. Increased monitoring of existing and legacy sites as well as intense public scrutiny of CCPs will likely result in the need for more groundwater assessments and corrective actions over the next ten years. This trend will necessitate the development of assessment tools and remediation methods tailored to the unique suite of inorganic constituents associated with CCP disposal sites.

The Electric Power Research Institute’s (EPRI’s) Coal Combustion Products - Environmental Issues program provides scientific data, engineering knowledge, restoration methods, models, and other advanced tools and guidance for environmentally protective, cost-effective soil and groundwater protection associated with fossil fuel–fired power plants and CCP storage, disposal, and use. Program results provide strong public benefit in providing cost effective and environmentally protective solutions.

Research Value

Results from this research helps evaluate and develop cost-effective management practices for complying with emerging regulations while ensuring potential risks to the public and environment from disposal and use of CCPs are acceptable. The U.S. power industry, for example, currently produces more than 100 million tons of CCPs annually. Annual costs for environmental management of CCPs are expected to increase sharply over the next five to ten years as a result of new disposal regulations. More specifically, research in this program helps minimize environmental impacts from CCP management and develop effective state-of-the-science corrective measures where impacts have occurred. It also provides power companies with information and data on environmental performance to inform the use of CCPs as a sustainable construction material and other commercial applications.  Disposal research benefits the public by supporting improved site performance and effective remediation technologies; beneficial use research advances sustainable material management in construction, thereby reducing land area required for disposal, mining and consumption of natural materials, and the overall carbon footprint of construction operations.

Approach

This program builds on years of research and tailored to meet customer needs related to specific questions of greatest interest. The program coordinates research activities with those of other industry groups and with federal and state research and regulatory agencies. This program delivers:

  • CCP characterization data
  • Geotechnical information for landfill management and pond closure
  • Geochemistry and groundwater transport assessments
  • Remediation technologies specifically designed for CCP constituents
  • Data and assessments on the health and ecological risks associated with CCP disposal and use, and
  • Tools to evaluate environmental performance of disposal and land applications.
Accomplishments
  • A portfolio of quick-turnaround projects to support detailed comments submitted to EPA on technical and economic issues raised in the proposed CCP regulations
  • A framework to quantitatively inform decision making when evaluating whether to close a CCP pond in place or close by removal, based on relative potential impacts to multiple environmental pathways.
  • Characterization of the impacts of new air pollution controls on CCP chemistry
  • Geotechnical data and guidance for safe closure of CCP ponds, and compatibility of geosynthetic and clay liners with CCP leachate
  • Guidance for groundwater monitoring and assessing groundwater quality impacts from CCP sites
  • Chemical profiles compiling information on fate, transport, and treatment of key constituents in CCPs
  • Research on leaching of concrete made with fly ash was used by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in a risk assessment to conclude that these products are environmentally safe
  • Nationwide field network to evaluate flue gas desulfurization (FGD) gypsum use in agricultural to increase crop yields and mitigate impacts to surface water from phosphorus runoff
  • Laboratory leachability and pilot field test of in situ groundwater remediation options for CCP constituents.

  • Launch of the Groundwater Resource Center, to perform research and provide education on advanced groundwater topics such as modeling and new hydrogeologic characterization methods.

Key Activities
  • Remediation technologies for CCP disposal sites
  • Design and operations for CCP landfills
  • Leachate management
  • Geochemistry and groundwater transport
  • Managing CCPs resulting from evolving air emissions controls
  • Risk analysis from inactive and legacy sites
  • Groundwater monitoring and data assessment
  • Fixation of metals in fly ash and highly soluble products to reduce leaching
  • Ash pond closures
  • FGD gypsum use as an agricultural amendment for controlling phosphorus in runoff
  • Environmental assessment of mine placement
  • Guidance regarding best practices for decommissioning old power plants
Estimated 2017 Program Funding
$3.1M

  • Assessment and Risk
    13-Jun-2016

    The need for environmental assessments at CCP disposal facilities and other power plant sites is expected to grow as CCP ponds are closed, plants are decommissioned, and groundwater monitoring requirements increase. Groundwater assessment costs alone can exceed $1 million per site. Scientific data, analysis tools, and models are required to provide a fundamental basis for understanding groundwater flow and transport and the potential for impacting groundwater and surface water resources.

    When potential impacts are identified, understanding risks is necessary to determine the need for further action and to select the optimum long-term plan for a site.  Publicized releases of either ash or dissolved constituents from CCP management sites have significantly heightened public and regulatory interest in environmental risks associated with these facilities. Objective evaluation is needed to delineate real versus perceived risk to potential receptors near these sites, and communication of the actual risk posed by a site are critical to ensuring appropriate response actions.

    Groundwater typically represents the primary pathway of concern at CCP management sites. This project provides power companies with the latest information and tools to assess and communicate the risks and impacts associated with CCP management sites and other power plant facilities. The research results provide:

    • Tools and data developed specifically for assessing the groundwater issues unique to CCP management sites and other power plant facilities
    • Health and ecologic risk assessment methodologies
    • Field and laboratory data on chemical transformations and groundwater transport
    • Consistent and well-developed basis for environmental remediation decision-making
    • Improved communications with the public on complex groundwater issues
    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • CCP Characterization
    13-Jun-2016

    Management options and environmental assessments for CCPs are driven largely by CCP physical and chemical characteristics. New and changing air emissions controls and advanced generation technologies substantively change the character of the by-products generated and their environmental behavior. Air emissions controls that impact fly ash from conventional coal-fired plants include injection of sodium/calcium sorbents for sulfur oxide reduction, injection of activated carbon and other sorbents for mercury control, and coal additives such as calcium bromide and cement kiln dust.  FGD solids can be impacted by scrubber additives, capture of oxidized mercury, and direct injection of activated carbon into the absorber.  FGD wastewater treatment systems for trace metals will produce new solid wastes.  Fuel blends and biomass coburning can also impact CCP characteristics.

    This research provides laboratory and field information on CCP characteristics and how CCPs behave in environmental settings. The results provide core data touching all facets of CCP disposal and use. The information is used to provide technical underpinnings for regulation, management strategy, risk assessment, and remediation. The research results:

    • Allow power companies to evaluate the impacts of plant modifications, such as fuel changes, air emissions controls, and flue gas additives;

    • Inform regulatory deliberations on management of CCPs under federal and state disposal regulations;

    • Support permitting, compliance, and groundwater assessment at CCP disposal sites;

    • Facilitate risk-based decision making considering the long-term behavior of CCPs in the environment; and

    • Support regulatory and public communications on environmental risks. 
    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • CCP Disposal and Use
    13-Jun-2016

    Power companies generate more than 100 million tons of CCPs every year. About 55% are disposed in landfills or impoundments. In 2015, the US EPA published the CCR Disposal Rule, establishing for the first time federal criteria for location, design, operation, and closure of CCR landfills and impoundments.  These standards include engineered liners and caps, leachate collection, groundwater monitoring, fugitive dust control, stability assessment, corrective action, and posting of site information on a public website. These represent new requirements for many facilities, especially at power plants with older CCR impoundments.  One significant effect of the rule will be the closing of many CCR impoundments and replacement with new or existing landfills. 

    The CCR Rule will drive change in disposal site design and operation over the next few years, accelerating the trend away from wet management, and toward engineered landfills and increased beneficial use. The cost to the industry for managing newly produced CCPs will exceed a billion dollars per year; costs of managing legacy sites could be much higher. Research under this project will provide power companies with options for complying with new disposal requirements, to improve environmental performance and reduce long-term liability in a cost-effective manner. The research will be coordinated with Program 78 research on CCP Use to evaluate environmental performance of use applications. The research results will help to:

    • Provide information and data on alternatives for compliance with new requirements

    • Develop cost-effective management and closure options

    • Control CCP management costs

    • Inform rulemakings and citizen concerns on management standards for CCP sites and mine reclamation, and

    • Provide data to support environmentally acceptable use of CCPs. 

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Remediation
    13-Jun-2016

    The need for corrective action at power company sites is expected to grow as new groundwater monitoring requirements are instituted at CCP management facilities (particularly ash ponds) and as older sites are closed. Legacy groundwater impacts will increase in importance over the next decade as a result of heightened awareness and changing water quality standards. Groundwater remediation costs can easily exceed $10 million for a single site, and in some cases can be much higher. Retired power plant properties also represent liabilities that require some level of site restoration prior to property transactions or development.

    Research is needed to provide data on the effectiveness and costs for a range of remediation alternatives, on technologies optimized to work within the framework of the CCR Rule, to tailor existing treatment and remediation methods to power plant sites, and to advance evolving technologies.  In situ methods, such as chemical injections and permeable reactive barriers, are largely undeveloped for CCP sites, although previous EPRI research has suggested that these technologies have potential.  

    This project will provide information and tools assist power companies in effectively addressing groundwater remediation and site restoration projects using the latest technologies in this rapidly evolving field. Specific benefits of this research include:

    • Remediation methods are evaluated and tailored to address the mix of constituents commonly found in soil and groundwater at power plant sites,

    • Laboratory and field tests provide basic information and guidelines for developing remediation approaches,

    • Significant cost savings can be realized with prescreening of available technologies and targeted remediation based on the research results, and

    • Successful remediations/restorations provide the community with improved water quality and facilitate the productive use of former industrial properties.

Overview

Program Description

Most former manufactured gas plants (MGPs) ceased operation by the 1960s, but by-products and wastes, often disposed of in the plant’s vicinity, still remain and have the potential to cause adverse environmental impacts. More than 3,000 former MGP sites exist in the United States and Europe. Many still require either investigation or remediation, at estimated cleanup costs typically in the millions of dollars per site. The wastes include tars (containing polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons [PAHs]), ammonia and cyanide wastes, and oils and petroleum compounds, all of which can contaminate groundwater, soils, and sediments in nearby water bodies. Also, there is the potential for degradation of ambient air during site remediation activities. Indoor air quality in the vicinity of these MGP sites may be affected by transport of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) through the soil and into the building. Site managers need credible data and information on alternative investigation and remediation techniques and appropriate site-specific cleanup criteria.

 

The Electric Power Research Institute's (EPRI's) Manufactured Gas Plant Site Management program develops cost effective remediation, monitoring, and containment solutions for utilities to reduce the environmental and economic liabilities of highly challenging contaminant mixtures residual in MGP legacy sites. Research includes projects that assess site investigation methods and cost-effective alternatives for containment or remediation of contaminated soil, sediment, and groundwater. Program research informs regulatory deliberations and helps companies develop and implement cost-effective, environmentally protective management strategies for MGP sites. The program also addresses indoor air quality issues resulting from soil vapor intrusion (SVI) into buildings situated near MGP sites.

Research Value

Remediation and management of former MGP sites is a high-cost and high-liability endeavor. EPRI’s MGP research on rapid and effective MGP site characterization; development and evaluation of technologies for remediation of contaminated soil, sediments, and groundwater; and realistic assessment of risk from coal tar/PAH toxicity continues to be invaluable to the MGP community, providing substantial cost savings to individual companies and the industry as a whole. Continuing research, especially on remediation of contaminated sediments, demonstrations of alternative remediation technologies, and assessment of SVI/indoor air quality issues, can result in significant cost savings for site management and remediation, as well as reducing the potential for added environmental and economic liabilities from these legacy sites.

This research is expected to benefit the public by expediting the assessment and implementation of cleanup projects, more effectively using resources in site remediation projects, and ultimately with lowered electricity rates as more sites are closed and redeveloped.

Approach

The MGP site management program provides scientific data, methods, and tools for the efficient characterization, assessment, and remediation of former MGP sites. The program helps site owners improve control of emissions/odor issues, evaluates alternative methods for remediating and potentially redeveloping MGP sites, and monitors key health risk issues. This program delivers:

  • Unique collaborative workshops and industry-wide symposia
  • Twenty-five years of EPRI and peer-reviewed publications and documentation and a large network of experts
  • Field studies assessing the viability of SVI investigation methods employing innovative techniques such as microbial genetic methods to metabolize recalcitrant PAHs in soils, forensic chemistry, moisture monitoring, and sorption sampling
  • Modeling techniques such as the Remedial Options Assessment Model (ROAM), used to evaluate MGP site operations and maintenance costs, and the Model for the Assessment and Remediation of Sediments (MARS), used for assessing impacted sediment issues
  • Methods for rapid screening of MGP sites, providing for more cost-effective and thorough site investigations, and
  • Evaluations of site remediation alternatives, including thermal treatment, in situ chemical oxidation, and smoldering.  
Accomplishments

This research advances the impacts of state-of-the-art investigation, assessment, and remediation of former MGP sites on soil, sediment, and groundwater. Modeling helps site managers evaluate cleanup alternatives, and the program responds quickly to emergent regulatory issues such as SVI and naphthalene risks. The program also assesses alternative site remediation measures, providing clear and issue-specific guidance to site managers on feasible options for meeting individual site requirements. Program accomplishments include:

  • Identification and demonstration of alternatives for remediation of MGP-impacted sediments
  • Development of improved PAH analytical methods providing more scientifically accurate measurements in soils and sediments
  • Guidance on MGP-impacted sediment assessment/remediation, including application of bioavailability concepts, monitored natural recovery, and sediment capping
  • Review and identification of improved methods for assessing difficult-to-access areas at MGP sites
  • Continuing evaluation of methods to assess the performance of MGP soils solidification and resources to determine the applicability, implementation, and assessment of soils solidification, and
  • Tracking of PAH toxicity information, including developments in the EPA’s Integrated Risk Information System (IRIS) and preparation of comments to the Science Advisory Board.  
Key Activities

Program R&D for 2017 will focus on sediment remediation, contaminant characterization, monitoring of PAH risk-related regulatory developments, and NAPL (non-aqueous phase liquids) mobility evaluations. Specific efforts will include:

  • Demonstration of biodegradation of PAHs absorbed in sediment caps
  • Laboratory studies to determine bioavailability of PAH’s in soil
  • Continued risk assessment evaluations of naphthalene and other relevant PAHs, including examination of the Relative Potency Factor approach for determining the carcinogenicity of PAH mixtures and the IRIS reassessment of benzo(a)pyrene
  • Participation in Interstate Technology Regulatory Council (ITRC) development of technical regulatory guidance
  • Demonstration of the applicability of sensors for long term monitoring of groundwater
  • Redevelopment issues associated with solidification technology
  • Sediment capping construction and monitoring identification and management
  • Evaluations of forensic methods for source evaluations of PAHs

  • Assessment of tools for tracking requirements for monitoring  long term MGP site conditions

Estimated 2017 Program Funding
$0.8M

Last Updated
  • Air Monitoring and SVI
    07-Jun-2016

    Emissions of VOCs and odors can be associated with remediation activities at MGP sites. Monitoring systems are often needed to insure that fence line concentrations of contaminants meet standards. Improved systems for emissions monitoring and for control of odor and emissions from the sites may be needed.

    In addition, the release of VOCs from soils or groundwater at MGP sites can cause SVI into buildings or can cause odor or VOC emissions during excavation of contaminated soils. These issues are receiving increased regulatory attention through guidance documents or permit requirements from regulatory and health agencies. Costly SVI investigations are being required on or near MGP sites. Additional indoor air data collection may be required to reduce uncertainty due to temporal variability in indoor air quality. Subsurface depressurization systems are sometimes required in spite of any identified vapor intrusion. Perimeter air monitoring during remediation is also usually required, but uncertainty still exists on how to interpret the data obtained.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Contam. Migration Contain
    07-Jun-2016

    Site managers are seeking remediation alternatives to dig-and-haul operations in places where there is limited ingress/egress or where buildings and roadways exist over a former MGP site. The use of in situ treatments such as chemical oxidation, solidification, or advanced chemical oxidation and biological treatment will be considered important technologies to investigate. Other in situ technologies, such as thermal treatment, containment wall, barrier, or aquifer modification technologies, may require further evaluation.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Contaminant Characterizat
    07-Jun-2016

    Gaining regulatory closure for sites with residual tar contamination can be difficult. Accepted protocols are needed for evaluating residuals and how they behave in the subsurface, particularly their impact on groundwater. Availability of soil contaminants by organisms can be significantly less than their gross concentrations. In addition, identification of sources of contaminants can be important in allocating liability for contaminated site cleanups.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Risk Assessment Studies
    07-Jun-2016

    Coal tar contains a number of PAHs, exposure to which can be associated with increased probability of cancer incidence. Remediation endpoints for sites contaminated with coal tar are driven by the carcinogenicity of these compounds, which include benzo(a)pyrene and naphthalene. Conflicting data on the human carcinogenicity of some of these compounds have led to the development of conservative cleanup criteria. Cleanup levels - that are risk based, are supported by sound science, and are protective of human health - may result in a significant reduction in remediation costs.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Sediment Assessment and Remediation
    07-Jun-2016

    Remediation of coal tar–contaminated sediments remains an expensive and technically difficult problem for MGP site managers. There is a need to explore alternative remediation strategies such as in situ remediation and monitored natural recovery. Issues related to cleanup-level requirements remain tied to the toxicity of MGP contaminants to benthic and other aquatic organisms.

Program Name: Transmission and Distribution and ROW Environmental Issues
text:
Overview

Program Description

As the electric transmission and distribution (T&D) infrastructure expands and ages, and as new rights-of-way (ROW) standards are developed, power companies need to manage human health risks and minimize environmental impacts from and species interaction with power delivery systems to maintain safe and reliable grid operation. System components, such as service centers, substations, and cables, face issues related to spills, runoff, and cleanups, and life-cycle decision making is a critical route to improved environmental performance. Environmentally acceptable options are needed for selecting and managing utility poles and dielectric fluids, designing facilities, and remediating contamination. Efficient, cost-effective ROW vegetation management and transmission line siting are increasingly important for compliance with new reliability standards. In addition, power companies need to reduce avian interactions with generation and T&D facilities and protect sensitive species and habitats during ROW construction and maintenance, while recognizing opportunities to optimize ecological assets on new and existing ROWs.

The Electric Power Research Institute's (EPRI’s) T&D and ROW Environmental Issues program delivers information, tools, and methods for preventing, characterizing, and remediating soil and water contamination at T&D facilities, as well as for designing and retrofitting T&D facilities. Data and products from the program support information needs for scientifically sound regulations and cleanup standards for chemicals associated with T&D and ROW facilities and operations, as well as providing engineering, science, and business tools to aid in their management. The program also provides balanced, cost-effective solutions for addressing the economic and environmental challenges of siting, developing, managing, and upgrading T&D ROWs whether above or below ground. Innovative tools, practical guidance, and state-of-the-art information help companies control ROW costs and improve service reliability while protecting natural resources and addressing public, regulatory, and other stakeholder concerns.

Research Value

Program research has documented savings of $10 million per year industrywide for used oil management, $1.5 billion per year for management of creosote and pentachlorophenol utility poles as nonhazardous waste, and $500,000 at a single site by demonstration of the true risk of a mineral oil spill. The program also helped save one company $1 million in spill prevention, control, and countermeasure (SPCC) regulatory compliance costs. Program research also expedites transmission line siting and ensures system reliability by addressing ecological issues associated with vegetation management standards, reducing ROW maintenance costs, and enhancing ecological value through Integrated Vegetation Management (IVM). The program also improves a utility’s ability to assess and prevent bird strike impacts, enhances ecosystems along T&D ROWs, and provides materials to help companies communicate with regulators and address public concerns. This program provides:

  • Scientific information and data to help power companies make optimal decisions on T&D ROW equipment choices and remedial approaches
  • Characterization information on substances related to environmental and human health risk, and strategies to reduce financial risk and operations and management costs
  • Constructive engagement on federal oversight of transmission vegetation management, and information for regulatory development
  • Opportunities for proactive environmental management to decrease potential for outages and fines, and shorter time frames for siting new transmission lines
Approach

This program addresses environmental challenges at substations, service centers, and T&D ROWs with options assessment, fate and transport studies, and remedial approaches. It facilitates communications with stakeholders through data and life-cycle studies, and examines a growing societal focus on sustainability by looking at issues such as the large resource represented by out-of-service utility poles. The program conducts field studies, best-practice surveys, risk assessments, workshops, and technology development and demonstration projects. This program is closely coordinated with EPRI’s Power Delivery & Utilization (PDU) research in delivering collaborative environmental science- and engineering-based solutions to environmental T&D challenges. This program delivers:

  • Tools to cost-effectively manage legacy polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), and research to inform PCB remediation activities;
  • Software tools for advanced spill simulation to examine environmental impacts of leaks such as oil spills and to support discussions with regulators;
  • Technology evaluations for alternate transformer oil containment;
  • Pilot tests to expand remediation options for spills and leaching of substances such as arsenic;
  • Environmental risk management decision tools that assist in the prioritization of equipment inspection and replacement needs;
  • Collaboration with other industry groups such as the Avian Power Line Interaction Committee, International Society of Arboriculture, Utility Arborists Association, and government agencies;
  • Continuing support for the international symposia on environmental concerns in ROW management;
  • Integrated vegetation management (IVM) field assessments of transmission vegetation management practices to aid utilities in reducing vegetation management costs while addressing environmental and sustainability goals;
  • Long-term vegetation management field studies to reduce vegetation management costs and address issues identified during IVM field assessments;
  • Field manipulative studies to support observational and retrospective studies spanning one to three years to evaluate vegetation management practices to promote pollinators, and
  • Development of innovative tools to reduce avian and other animal interactions at utility facilities.

The technical results of this program are highly relevant to international utilities and other stakeholders.  The focus of the program work is T&D ROW, however any ROW large enough to impact or be impacted by the biodiversity and vegetation would benefit e.g. gas pipeline construction, underground utility construction, telecom ROW, Wind Farm ROWs.

Accomplishments

This program provides data, tools, and information that deepen understanding of the environmental consequences of company actions, including operations and remediation. Using sound scientific information from this program, companies have:

  • Cleanup endpoints for substations contaminated with dielectric fluids or arsenic that represent acceptable risk and lower cost;
  • Substation retrofit plans acceptable to regulators that minimize risk and reduce costs; 
  • Development of “immediate” estimates of potential oil losses in failure events;
  • Efficient management of materials and equipment as nonhazardous, where appropriate, at the end of useful lifetimes;
  • Deployment of a Bird Strike Indicator at utility sites to clarify operational impacts and reduce liabilities from avian interactions with facilities;
  • Analysis of compliance with North American Electric Reliability Corporation (NERC) vegetation management standards; and
  • Guidance and information to address invasive species on transmission ROWs.
Key Activities

Program R&D for 2017 will focus on minimizing and managing environmental and human health risks from operation of the power delivery system and on providing information to expedite transmission line siting, reduce transmission outages, and minimize adverse avian interactions. Specific efforts will include:

  • Improving approaches to identifying environmental impacts from leaking PCB-containing equipment and exploring associated risks,
  • Investigating alternative transformer oil containment technologies,
  • Developing information to clarify and mitigate avian interactions and environmental impacts with facilities,
  • Developing information to reduce health risks to utility workers during herbicide application,
  • Developing environmental information on best vegetative management practices to assist utilities in upgrading and siting of transmission lines, and
  • Developing information on pollinators and transmission line rights-of-way
Estimated 2017 Program Funding
$1.85M

Paul Chu, 650-855-2362, pchu@epri.com

Last Updated
  • Avian and Animal Interactions with Powerlines
    07-Jun-2016

    Birds and other wildlife interact with power structures in many ways. Some structures (towers, poles, and stacks) and associated ROW habitats can provide favorable sites for bird nesting, roosting, and foraging and for hunting activities for a wide variety of bird and other animal species, without affecting operations. At the same time, birds are at risk from potential interactions with these structures, including collisions with wires and towers, and birds and other wildlife can be subject to electrocution (transformers, conductor configurations).

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Integrated Vegetation Management (IVM) and Inspection Techniques
    07-Jun-2016

    All ROWs are managed with the general goal of providing safe and reliable transport of electricity. ROW managers strive to meet these goals by developing low-growing vegetation that persists over the long term. For most ROW managers, active management is required to create desired vegetation and related environmental conditions. ROW vegetation management represents a major cost for the industry, with individual company costs in the range of $5–$20 million per year.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • PCBs: Mitigation and Remediation
    07-Jun-2016

    Polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB)-containing dielectric fluids were used extensively in electrical equipment until their use was banned in the late 1970s. Utility companies are continuing to remove legacy equipment that contains PCBs. This equipment can be difficult to identify, so strategies for identification and removal are needed.  In addition, PCBs were incorporated into a wide range of industrial materials and consumer products, including paints, caulks, mastic, wire insulation, and lubricants.  Due to their chemical stability, PCBs are still found in these materials and in the environment decades after their initial use.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Utility Poles: Assessment and Impact
    07-Jun-2016

    Poles are a huge and valuable asset of a utility company. Companies need to manage poles across the pole life cycle with practices that ensure engineering performance, manage costs, and protect the environment and human health. This process begins with selection of the optimal pole for each setting, continues through careful use, and ends with final disposition that recognizes the asset value and minimizes ongoing risk.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center

Overview

Program Description

EPRI’s Water Quality and Watershed Protection Program provides scientific information and tools to characterize the risks of wastewater discharges and non-point sources of pollution; help power companies meet permit requirements; and assist stakeholders, regulatory agencies, and policy makers in managing aquatic resources to benefit water quality, aquatic communities, wildlife, and human health.

Electric power facilities generate wastewater that can contain metals, additional dissolved constituents, and suspended solids and, in combination with other point and non-point sources of pollution, may contribute to aquatic and human health risks. Reducing scientific uncertainties and reliance on default assumptions in risk assessments is essential to ensure cost-effective and environmentally protective compliance strategies, as well as to inform permitting, regulatory, and resource management decisions.

How power companies manage, treat, and discharge wastewater will be continually influenced by community pressures and diverse regulatory requirements such as:

  • Water Quality Criteria: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) plans to review all ambient water quality criteria for possible revision over the next five to ten years.

  • Air Quality Regulations: As regulations are adopted for ozone, particulate matter, SO2, NOx, and hazardous air pollutants, new fuels and environmental control technologies may influence the characteristics of power plant wastewaters, as well as nonpoint sources of pollution (i.e., atmospheric deposition, runoff, etc).

  • Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA): The SDWA establishes Maximum Contaminant Levels (MCLs) for compounds such as arsenic that can be captured by environmental control systems and thus found in wastewater.

  • State Rules and Permits: States issue discharge permits to meet EPA guidelines, but always have the option of adopting stricter limits for individual waste water discharges in response to community concerns or site-specific conditions. Some states are beginning to address storm water discharges and their effect on aquatic life. At least one state has established numeric water quality criteria for stormwater.

  • Total Maximum Daily Load (TMDL) Management: Increasingly, TMDLs are being applied to manage point and nonpoint source pollution through watershed-wide planning initiatives that create opportunities for water quality trading.

The Water Quality and Watershed Protection Program advances scientific knowledge and develops methods and tools to mitigate the risks associated with power plant discharges of mercury, arsenic, selenium, nitrogen, and other compounds into aqueous environments. The program helps industry, regulators, and other stakeholders develop and implement cost-efficient strategies for watershed protection. It delivers advanced analytical and modeling techniques to allow site-specific conditions and new understanding of environmental behavior and dose-response relationships to be incorporated in regulatory and permitting processes. It also expands the knowledge base and available options for addressing mercury and nitrogen emissions, developing and meeting TMDL requirements, and implementing watershed management strategies.

Research Value

EPRI brings a comprehensive approach to water quality management and watershed protection, accounting for multimedia emissions from power plants, the impact of new environmental control systems on wastewater discharges, and the contributions of other point and non-point sources. The research provides scientific, risk-based information and tools for use by members, regulators, and other stakeholders in developing permit limits, regulations, standards, TMDLs, and management plans addressing human health, aquatic toxicity, eutrophication, and other issues.

By helping reduce reliance on assumptions that may not accurately estimate risks, the program supports economically and ecologically sound decision-making. The public perceives that watershed and ecosystem protection can be costly and burdensome. With well-considered actions reflecting sound science and risk-based decision-making, sustainable water resource management goals can be achieved, and in turn benefit the public by helping to manage or ensure lower electricity costs. When applied appropriately, EPRI’s knowledge base, tools, and recommended technologies can also assist power producers in meeting environmental quality objectives in a resource-efficient manner.

The research conducted in this program benefits all stakeholders, including the public, by providing information on the risk to human health and the environment from wastewater discharges to aquatic environments from power generation facilities including natural gas facilities and solar thermal generation as well. The program also develops modeling tools to explain the fate and transport of these discharges to inform regulatory developments. The scientific results and tools developed in this program are highly applicable to international utilities.

Approach

EPRI research addresses current priorities and emerging issues, including risk-based management of mercury, arsenic, selenium, nitrogen, and other contaminants on a site-specific and watershed-wide basis; implementation of best management practices and advanced analytical methods; and effects of environmental control equipment, such as scrubbers on power plant discharges and receiving waters. The program also examines concerns not yet widely recognized, such as how changing wastewater discharge characteristics may affect threatened or endangered species. This program delivers the following:

  • When updated selenium ambient water quality criteria are published, EPRI will develop a guidance document on developing site-specific criteria protocols for compliance with new selenium limits;

  • Research on mercury to enhance understanding of its cycling in aqueous environments, speciation and bioaccumulation, and health impacts and to develop site-specific compliance criteria protocols;

  • Presentations to state and federal decision makers and other stakeholders considering the fate and transport of mercury and other constituents in aqueous environments;

  • Evaluation of non-cancer effects of concern for arsenic;

  • Development of an arsenic multimedia fate, transport, and health risk screening model;

  • Information for watershed and TMDL regulatory compliance and management decisions on mercury, nitrogen, ammonia and other nutrients, metals, and sediments;

  • Water quality trading and ecosystem services approaches to reduce environmental impacts of nutrient runoff and costs of permit requirements ; and

  • Collaborative work with other EPRI programs in areas such as atmospheric deposition, effluent characteristics, and the effects of weather patterns on water availability and quality.

Accomplishments

Engaging domain experts, collaborating with and providing technical assistance to regulatory and other agencies, and developing peer-reviewed literature are critical to informing the development of cost-effective and protective regulations and permit conditions. Applications of program results have produced documented site-specific compliance cost savings ranging from tens of thousands of dollars up to more than $10 million. Program accomplishments include the following:

  • Research results supported ambient water quality criteria for arsenic at state and federal levels;

  • Research increased the understanding of the fate of mercury in the environment and helped place power plant emissions in a global context, informing policy and regulatory dialogues;

  • Members, federal agencies, and state agencies use the Dynamic Mercury Cycling Model (D-MCM) to examine and predict sources of mercury and mercury bioaccumulation in aqueous environments;

  • Members use the methylmercury guidance document to guide sampling and modeling to inform regulatory decisions; and

  • EPRI established a trading framework and functioning market for the world’s largest water quality trading program for market-based nutrient reduction.

Key Activities

Program R&D for 2017 will continue to focus on the ambient water quality criteria issue, with a new effort to examine arsenic health non-cancer end point(s). The program will begin the development of a multimedia fate, transport, and health risk model to evaluate potential human health impacts from trace substances entering the environment from power plants via air emissions, surface and groundwater discharges, and by-product streams, with the initial effort focusing on arsenic. Specific efforts will:

  • Develop a multiple ion toxicity (MIT) model to evaluate the toxicity of total dissolved solids for site-specific permitting needs and for evaluating cost-effective and protective wastewater treatment options;

  • Develop a model to evaluate the toxicity of storm water discharges to aquatic organisms;

  • Develop an improved scientific basis for estimating arsenic health risks for non-cancer end point(s);

  • Develop a multimedia screening risk model for arsenic and other constituents; and

  • Develop information on potential risks to aquatic organisms from total dissolved solids in wastewater and/or nutrients, which will support the development of the MIT model.

Estimated 2017 Program Funding
$1.15M

John Goodrich-Mahoney, 860-245-5852, jmahoney@epri.com

Research Projects

EPRI Members: View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
Non-EPRI Members: Contact Program Manager - John Goodrich-Mahoney; 860-245-5852; jmahoney@epri.com
Last Updated
  • Aquatic Life Criteria Development
    07-Jul-2016

    U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (U.S. EPA) develops national ambient water quality criteria, which are then implemented by the states. Power companies are subject to limits on metals and other pollutants in their waste water discharge permits based on existing criteria, and also on new criteria, as those are developed and implemented. There is a need for improved methods for the development of water quality criteria to ensure that the criteria reflect the latest science. Over the long term, there is a need for development of modeling approaches that describe more accurately the risk to aquatic life and human health from the release of metals and other pollutants to surface waters.

    The Dynamic Mercury Cycling (D-MCM) Model is such an approach. The D-MCM is a Windows™ based simulation model for personal computers. It predicts the cycling and fate of three major forms of mercury (methylmercury, inorganic Hg(II), and elemental mercury) in aquatic systems, including lakes, rivers, wetlands and marine systems. D-MCM is a time-dependent mechanistic model, designed to consider the most important physical, chemical and biological factors affecting fish mercury concentrations. The model is set up to run both deterministically and probabilistically, the latter using a Monte-Carlo approach.     

    Another approach, which is under development, is the Multi-ion Toxicity (MIT) Model, which is being development with close cooperation with the EPA. This model is a possible replacement for the EPA aquatic life conductivity benchmark of 300 ?S/cm. This conductivity level is expected to be technologically difficult and costly to achieve. In addition, the conductivity approach does not provide an indication of water composition, information that may be needed to accurately assess the potential for multi-ion toxicity to result at a given conductivity level. Several benefits will be realized, if a technically defensible assessment approach for MIT is achieved. First, it will provide a quantitative basis for evaluating levels of major ion mixtures in surface waters that are consistent with the intended level of protection to be provided by water quality criteria. It will also serve to limit the needless expenditure of resources to achieve improved treatment levels that may not yield meaningful environmental benefit, and to focus resources on those settings where more advanced levels of treatment may be warranted.  In short, it will provide an improved basis for making an informed decision regarding the most efficient way to allocate limited resources to achieve improvements in environmental quality.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Arsenic Health Risk Estimates
    15-Jun-2016

    The association between environmental inorganic arsenic exposure and cancer health effects such as that of skin, lung, and bladder is well known.  In vitro genomic responses to arsenic in human lung and bladder cells may reveal relative similarities in response across human target tissues.  Cancer risk has been the driver of understanding the potential for health effects following exposure for arsenic health risk estimation, with linear extrapolation default methods employed by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (U.S. EPA).

    Revisions to the U.S. EPA’s Integrated Risk Information System (IRIS) process, however, may result in new non-cancer endpoint(s) of concern that have not been the focus in past arsenic non-cancer health risk evaluations.  A review of recent studies that have linked arsenic exposure to an exceedingly wide range of non-cancer health endpoints (including dermatological, developmental, neurological, respiratory, cardiovascular, immunological and endocrine effects) is necessary to evaluate the likely non-cancer endpoint(s) of concern.  Critical review is essential to identify strengths and limitations of these studies, as well as data gaps.  Assessment of arsenic-related genomic responses already available for human cells may reveal information relevant to non-cancer endpoints as well.  Results will be integrated into a new, comprehensive, science-based non-cancer risk framework for arsenic that may then be applied to future regulatory revisions of the arsenic ambient water quality criteria.  This work will be coordinated with the Program 42 Air and Multimedia Toxics Health and Risk Assessment.  

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Dynamic Mercury Cycling Model (D-MCM)
    15-Jun-2016

    New hazardous air pollutant regulations and subsequent controls will reduce mercury emissions and deposition from coal-fired power plants.  However, the degree to which controls will affect the environment and improve public health is still uncertain.  To cost-effectively maximize the benefits of these controls, it is critical to have a detailed understanding of mercury cycling and the bioavailability of mercury to potentially affect human health.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • TMDL and Watershed Issues
    20-Jan-2017

    A principal strategic United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) objective is to use a watershed approach through the implementation of Total Maximum Daily Loads (TMDLs) and watershed-integrated National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permits to achieve protection of water resources. This approach creates a growing number of new, complex research needs. Research is needed to address the following:

    • Understand how to effectively manage storm water runoff;
    • Couple watershed and air quality models to address TMDLs where atmospheric deposition is a major source of pollutants (such as nitrogen, acidity, mercury, selenium, and arsenic);
    • Derive, allocate, and implement complex TMDLs (involving, for example, selenium, and arsenic impacts); and
    • Understand technical basis of impairment listing processes.

     It is important to be aware that TMDLs can supersede NPDES permits, resulting in more restrictive discharge allowances.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Water Quality Trading
    17-Jun-2016

    Water quality trading is one of several United States Environment Protection Agency (EPA)-approved market-based approaches for addressing complex environmental issues. This project will continue work to establish water quality trading as a business-appropriate, cost-effective, and ecologically defensible option for the electric power and other sectors in complying with increasingly stringent permit limits and in-stream water quality standards. Building on EPRI’s Ohio River Basin Trading Program, now the largest water quality trading program in the world, EPRI will identify lessons learned, opportunities, hurdles, and optimizations that can be applied to any program in the country.  

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center

Program Name: Fish Protection at Electric Generating Facilities
text:
Overview

Program Description

The Electric Power Research Institute's (EPRI’s) Fish Protection at Electric Generating Facilities Program provides tools, technologies and analyses for power plants (steam electric, hydropower, pumped storage, and marine and hydrokinetic) to cost effectively protect aquatic communities in accordance with U.S. and international fish protection requirements.

A primary challenge for power plant owners is to ensure adequate water supplies for operations while protecting aquatic life in the lakes, streams, rivers, estuaries, and oceans those operations impact. In the United States, the Clean Water Act §316(b) requires plant owners to install fish protection technologies on cooling water intake structures, while §316(a) requires management of thermal discharges. Section 316 compliance is regulated under the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) program with national regulations issued by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). The U.S. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) regulates hydropower projects for investor owned and state facilities, and federal facilities (U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and Bureau of Reclamation) are regulated under the National Environmental Policy Act. In 2014, final §316(b) regulations for existing steam electric facilities with once-through cooling were issued, which require installation of cooling water intake fish protection technologies and possible retrofit of cooling towers. Plant owners are also required to perform numerous studies to support determination of Best Technology Available (BTA) for reducing impingement and entrainment. In addition, facilities are seeing increasingly stricter permit requirements limiting their thermal discharges to prevent aquatic impacts. The outcome of the regulatory process will impose significant costs on the power industry, and the need for cost-effective fish protection technologies will be a critical element of future research to identify and test appropriate technologies. Additional research will be needed to support members and resource agencies as they conduct required monitoring studies.

EPRI’s fish protection program assesses the effects of power plant cooling system operation on fish and other aquatic life. Results support the development of effective intake and discharge protection approaches for workable operating permits at individual facilities. By improving the technical basis for regulatory, permitting, and operating decisions, this program serves the public interest in effective resource management while meeting industry-wide imperatives to control costs, ensure or exceed environmental compliance requirements, manage business risks, and provide affordable electricity.

Research Value

EPRI performs extensive research on fish protection technologies for cooling water intake structures and waterpower (conventional hydropower, pumped storage, and marine and hydrokinetic) projects and procedures for assessing impacts on aquatic communities. The research has demonstrated the site-specific nature of aquatic impacts, the efficacy of various technologies for different fish and shellfish species, improvements to technologies to enhance survival rates, and technology costs and value of the benefits achieved. This program helps environmental compliance managers and power plant operators effectively manage water resources and protect aquatic communities in accordance with fish protection regulations. Program information may reduce compliance costs, enhance permitting processes, and identify cost-effective management strategies. The research supports the development of aquatic life protection approaches for cost-effective operating permits at individual facilities. It also provides access to new and enhanced fish passage and protection technologies, information on fish protection–related issues, and information on cost, economic, environmental, and electric system impacts of compliance and licensing/relicensing requirements. The public will benefit from minimized impacts to aquatic environments, cost-effective compliance, and license/relicensing strategies that will have minimal impact on electricity rates.

EPRI fish protection R&D identifies and evaluates technologies for improved fish passage and protection, informs all stakeholders in the permitting and licensing process with sound technical information, and provides technical information for cost-effective environmental compliance that contributes to affordable, reliable and sustainable electricity. The technical results and tools developed in this program are strongly applicable to international utilities.

Approach

This program provides information, analytical tools, innovative mitigation technologies, and expertise to help environmental compliance and licensing/relicensing managers and power plant operators effectively manage water resources and protect aquatic communities in accordance with fish protection regulations. The program also provides information and methods to support technology performance evaluation and monitoring. The program delivers:

  • Collaboration with industry, professional scientific societies, and federal agencies

  • Translation of complex scientific and engineering information into easy-to-understand, site-specific problem solving

  • Credibility with regulatory and resource agencies when addressing specific permit and licensing/relicensing issues

  • Biological sampling and fish health assessment information and protocols

  • Analysis and performance evaluation of fish protection and passage technologies (traveling screen systems, vacuum pump systems, wedge-wire screens, barrier net systems, downstream fish passage technologies), including technology design, construction, operation and maintenance requirements, efficacy and costs

  • Thermal discharge risk analyses and variance procedures

  • Analysis of conventional hydropower and pumped storage fish passage, water quality and other environmental issues

  • Information on environmental issues in the marine and hydrokinetic technology industry

Accomplishments

Program information supports current industry compliance and licensing/relicensing efforts as well as updates to guidance on thermal discharge assessment variance procedures. The information is expected to support a regulatory structure that is informed by the best available scientific and engineering information. Program accomplishments include:

  • Information on performance of intake fish protection technologies in identifying BTA for new and existing power plants

  • Impingement mortality and entrainment sampling guidance and information in support of §316(b) compliance

  • Technical resource documents on fish protection technology performance and costs

  • Web-based taxonomic key for identifying entrained fish and shellfish eggs, larvae and juvenile life stages

  • Technical information on the utility of DNA for identifying fish and shellfish eggs, larvae and juvenile life stages (may be critical for T&E species)

  • Technical information on the impacts and the environmental and economic benefits of reducing impingement mortality and entrainment

  • Review of thermal tolerance limits in the literature and evaluation of how different laboratory methodologies affect thermal tolerance determinations

  • Extensive information on the costs of a cooling tower retrofit requirement (more than $100 billion to retrofit cooling towers, with an estimated benefit of $16 million per year to recreational and commercial fisheries)

  • International research on fish protection issues in France and other localities, continuing to provide value internationally

  • Performance assessments on upstream and downstream fish passage technologies, and

  • Resource assessments for hydrokinetic energy (wave and riverine).

Key Activities

Program R&D for 2017 will focus on developing information on technologies to reduce impingement and entrainment, assessing environmental benefits, evaluating the environmental and economic trade-offs of once-through cooling versus closed-cycle systems, developing approaches for resolving discrepancies between laboratory and field studies for establishing thermal fish protection criteria, information sharing on §316(a) and §316(b) issues, and the environmental impacts of waterpower technologies (conventional hydropower, pumped storage, and marine and hydrokinetic technologies). Specific research efforts will include:

  • Conferences and workshops for power plants on specific water body types (i.e., reservoirs, rivers, estuaries) where impingement and entrainment technology options and related issues can be discussed

  • Continued research into the performance of intake fish protection technologies for reducing impingement mortality and entrainment

  • Technical data and guidance on performing studies to identify BTA for entrainment control

  • Technical data and guidance for the performance of traveling water screen and fish return system optimization studies

  • Technical data and guidance for the design, installation, and operation of fish return systems

  • Technical data, guidance and tools for improved identification of fish and shellfish eggs and larvae

  • Engineering, economic, and environmental consequences of potential closed-cycle cooling system retrofits on power plants with once-through cooling systems

  • Updated guidance for performing economic benefit analyses

  • Technical briefs that provide interim updates on critically important waterpower environmental issues

  • Conferences and workshops where waterpower environmental issues and opportunities can be explored and discussed, and

  • Collaboration opportunities with colleagues in the waterpower industry to share experiences, learn best practices, and develop common solutions to waterpower environmental issues.

Program Manager
Douglas Dixon, 607-869-1025, ddixon@epri.com

Research Projects

EPRI Members: View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
Non-EPRI Members: Contact Program Manager - Douglas Dixon; 607-869-1025; ddixon@epri.com
Last Updated
  • Biological Sampling and Economic Research
    25-Jan-2017

    Around the world, power plant and other industrial operations with cooling water intake structures (CWIS) are increasingly seeing regulatory requirements to reduce mortality to fish and shellfish caused by impingement and entrainment (I&E). In 2014 the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) issued final Clean Water Act §316 regulations (Rule) to control I&E at existing facilities and new units at existing facilities with once-through cooling. Compliance with regulations requires sampling of fish and shellfish in the aquatic environment in the vicinity of cooling water intakes and discharges, as well as from intake structures and within power plant cooling water systems. Water body type (for example, lake, reservoir, estuary, and river), power plant cooling system configuration and operation, and intake fish protection technology all present site-specific challenges to collecting representative sample data. The health of impinged and entrained fish before their contact with power plant systems can also compromise the interpretation of sample results and fish protection technology performance. The final Rule requires several applicant studies related to characterizing impingement and entrainment, assessing the economic benefit of alternative fish protection technologies as well as many future technology performance monitoring studies, which will be a challenge for permit applicants and permit authorities and may raise questions from the public at large. The new regulation also requires consideration of potential impacts to rare, threatened and endangered species. This project will provide the requisite learning to assist permit applicants, resource agencies and regulators, and the public in conducting technically sound sampling programs and economic benefit analyses and interpreting the results.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Environmental and Economic Impacts of Closed Cycle Cooling Retrofits
    25-Jan-2017

    The 2014 EPA §316(b) Rule for existing facilities requires that facilities with once-through cooling and actual intake flows ? 125 MGD evaluate the feasibility, cost and non-water quality impacts associated with a potential retrofit of a closed cycle recirculating system (CCRS) to reduce entrainment.  This information is provided in the Technical Feasibility and Cost Evaluation Study (r10) and Non-water Quality Environmental Impacts Study (r12) reports submitted to Permit Authorities according to permit renewal schedules or schedules developed in consultation with them. Research in this project area supports the cost-effective completion of these studies with the best available engineering and scientific information.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Environmental Aspects of Waterpower
    02-Jun-2016

    The key question for maintaining existing waterpower or developing new projects, including those for conventional hydropower, pumped-storage, and marine and hydrokinetic devices, is the extent of their impacts on the aquatic community and, where impacts exist, how they can be best mitigated or minimized, thereby maintaining flexible operation of the units or contributing additional low-carbon renewable energy.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Fish Protection Technology Research
    25-Jan-2017

    Identification of cost-effective fish protection technologies for installation at cooling water intake structures to control impingement and entrainment of fish and shellfish is a primary goal of industry in seeking to comply with the Clean Water Act §316(b) New and Existing Facility rules. EPA promulgated a final Rule for existing facilities in 2014. The Rule requires power plants with design intake flows exceeding 2 million gallons per day (MGD) to reduce impingement mortality via one of several options, including reducing cooling water intake structure design through-screen velocity to less than 0.5 feet per second (fps), meeting an impingement mortality performance standard, optimizing the performance of fish-friendly traveling water screens and fish return systems or demonstrating that impingement occurs at extremely low levels. EPA identified modified ("fish-friendly") traveling water screens with a maximum open dimension equivalent to a 3/8-inch square mesh and fish return systems as Best Technology Available (BTA) for meeting the impingement mortality standard. Facilities with design intake flows exceeding 2 MGD are also subject to reducing entrainment mortality; however, only facilities withdrawing more than 125 MGD actual intake flow must submit a Comprehensive Entrainment Characterization Study, evaluate entrainment reduction technologies (including closed-cycle cooling and fine-mesh screens), and evaluate their environmental impacts and benefits (nine specific factors must be evaluated). Entrainment compliance is determined by the permitting authority on a case-by-case basis and could result in a determination ranging from the existing cooling water intake structure being deemed BTA to a requirement to retrofit closed-cycle cooling.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P54.004 - Thermal Discharge Risk Analysis
    27-May-2016

    As a result of recent extended droughts in many regions, increased societal demands for water withdrawals, continued concern about protection of aquatic biota, and growing demand for more electric power, there is renewed interest in the management and consequences of thermal discharges. Once through cooling, steam electric plants discharge waters at elevated temperatures into nearby surface waters. These waters can potentially have adverse effects on fish and macroinvertebrates. Key questions regarding these discharges include: protection of endangered and threatened species, differences between field observations and laboratory measurements of fish responses; interaction of thermal discharge issues with other issues such as §316(b); Total Maximum Daily Loads (TMDLs), NPDES permits; interactions of thermal discharges with other pollutants; and macroinvertebrate responses.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
