Program Name: Water Availability and Resource Risk Management
text:
Overview

Program Description

EPRI’s “Water Availability and Resource Risk Management Program” develops state of the art tools and analyses for power companies to address water resource planning needs in addition to other resource management requirements.

Power and other industry operations, equity, and financing are threatened by constraints on water and other natural resources. Cultural resources, ecosystem health, biodiversity and ecosystem services are examples of other resources of concern to industry and the general public. Several factors are focusing more attention on water availability/use and are putting pressure on the power industry and other sectors to increase water use efficiency and minimize overall water consumption and withdrawal. These factors include population increases coupled with regional population shifts, competing demands among all water users, climate variation, and aquatic ecosystem protection. This scrutiny has significant implications for electricity generation and transmission operations and growth, including power plant siting and water resource resiliency. If existing power plants cannot access sufficient water for cooling or other needs, power companies may be forced to reduce power output or shut down plants, and siting and construction of new assets may be stalled. The same types of operating and growth impacts could impact other commercial operations in different sectors of the economy.

The Electric Power Research Institute's (EPRI's) Water Availability and Resource Risk Management Program develops tools, knowledge, and data that power companies and other stakeholders need to understand the perspectives of all water resource stakeholders, participate in evolving Energy/Water/Food Nexus development, build resilience strategies for a natural resource–constrained future, and address questions raised by lending institutions and investors concerning potential resource–based limitations on business operations and growth. Research focuses on developing and evaluating integrated resource risk management and forecasting tools, developing and testing metrics to measure resource management outcomes, assessing use, cost and benefits of nontraditional water resources, understanding cross-media phenomena impacts on resources, learning fundamental principles of ecosystem management and protection, and mitigating impacts of resource limitations on operations.

Research Value

Water resource sustainability and resource stewardship are receiving increased interest from many constituencies. Examples include the following:

  • The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA’s) Office of Water requested the Science Advisory Board to provide consultation on the data, information, and analytical methodology needed to evaluate the value of water to the U.S. economy and provide a resource for future decision making

  • Financial institutions, stakeholders, and stockholders are requesting that utilities and other companies develop water use (water stewardship) data and water resource resiliency plans as driven by the ongoing discussions of the energy/water nexus by the U.S. Government Accountability Office (GAO) and the U.S. Department of Energy.

The Program’s research develops and implements cost-efficient, risk-based strategies for improved power plant water use efficiency, reduced power plant water demand, and management of increasing climate variability impacts on utility operations. Research is also applicable to other commercial operations and water use sectors. The focus is on development and evaluation of resource management and forecasting tools, development and testing of integrated engineering/economic risk management plans, development and enhancement of nontraditional water sources, creation and tests of water management metrics, and identification of resource conservation opportunities. Whether used domestically or in an international setting, these research results can promote more-effective plans for managing water and other critical resources. This research will help power companies site future thermal generation facilities as well as consider location of other generation sources such as renewable technologies. The same tools can be used to support development and operations of other commercial activities. The public will benefit from such proactive planning measures and could see considerable savings in the cost of electricity and improved protection of the environment and ecosystem services over time through active management of water and other resources.

The economic and social vitality of a community is dependent on its ability to meet both its water and energy needs. This Program provides knowledge and tools to assist all segments of the community to prudently manage community water resources. The Program also delivers, to federal, state and local agencies, data and tools to support effective, cost efficient natural resource risk management. The technical results produced in this program are broadly applicable to international utilities and stakeholders.

Approach

This program delivers scientific knowledge, practical guidance, proven decision-support tools, resource risk management strategy evaluations, and technology assessments. The program delivers:

  • Decision-support tools for water and other resource management, development of water and other resource knowledge centers, and integrated sustainability assessments of regional power and water supplies

  • Guidelines, tools, and information to evaluate benefits of water-saving technologies and to conduct resource risk assessment and management studies

  • Strategies for and information on use of nontraditional water resources, such as waste treatment plant effluent, saline groundwater, produced water from oil and natural gas extraction, agricultural drainage, storm water runoff, and water transfers.

  • Data, information, and tools to assess and manage ecosystem properties and services to offset regulatory constraints, and

  • Efficient resource management for maintenance and growth of electric power generation capacity

Accomplishments

For the last decade, EPRI has been a leader in research and communication of the emerging issue of the energy/water sustainability. EPRI has published more than 20 technical reports on the subject, covering research needs, national water availability assessments, water resource risk management methodologies, and technical evaluations to reduce power plant freshwater use. EPRI has played a key role in numerous professional society, foundation, and government workshops and conferences to address the energy/water nexus, such as with National Academy of Sciences, GAO, National Science Foundation and ARPA-E. Existing EPRI research suggests that facility-specific savings can range from tens of thousands to tens of millions of dollars. Program accomplishments include:

  • Engineering and economic analyses of advanced cooling technologies and use of nontraditional water sources

  • Analyses of trends in water resource quantity and quality and implications for the power industry,

  • A national assessment of water availability for thermoelectric power generation

  • A national assessment of water withdrawal and consumption across all water-using sectors on a county and small watershed resolution

  • Forecast of electric power sector consumption and withdrawal for scenarios of the evolution of the electric power generation fleet under a variety of regulatory and economic conditions

  • Assessment of storm water use by thermoelectric generation

  • Decision support frameworks for energy/water integrated planning

  • Application of widely used analytic frameworks to conduct resource risk assessment and management studies, and

  • A leadership role in establishing the relevance of ecosystem services to the power industry and other business communities.

  • Launching of a program (Program 195) to develop research to support listing decisions and conservation of threatened and endangered species

  • Development and launch of a successful multi-state water quality trading program, now managed in Program 53.

Key Activities

The program will complete studies on evaluating alternative sources of water and analyzing the economics of watershed management strategies to protect water and other resources. Based upon member prioritization of proposed studies and available funding, The program will initiate studies on water resource resiliency planning, testing previously developed water management metrics, evaluating costs of water conservation strategies and technologies, evaluating market-based approaches to water resource management, assessing effects of wet/dry weather cycles on the electric power sector, conducting a national forecasting analysis of water consumption across all water using sectors, linking and testing cross-media ecological effects models, and evaluating regulatory and business impetus for water resource conservation measures and ecosystem service assessments. This program's research is an integral component of EPRI's cross-sector water research, which includes demonstrations and pilots of emerging technologies and proof-of-concept studies of novel technologies to reduce power plant freshwater use and reduce the cost of treating and transporting water and wastewater. The Water Availability and Resource Risk Management program evaluates the efficacy of these different technologies to meet community and regional electric power/water resource sustainability needs.

Estimated 2017 Program Funding
$1.5M
Program Manager
Robert Goldstein, 650-855-2154, rogoldst@epri.com

Research Projects

EPRI Members: View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
Non-EPRI Members: Contact Program Manager - Robert Goldstein; 650-855-2154; rogoldst@epri.com
Last Updated
  • P55.001 - Water Availability
    27-May-2016

    Rapidly growing demand for clean, fresh water, coupled with the need to protect and enhance the environment, have made many regions vulnerable to water shortages. Such shortages could cause reductions in current supplies of electricity and could have direct impacts on power system planning and expansion.  These shortages can also impact other water-use sectors and have a negative impact on the environment.  Climate variability is also increasing the impact on water resources.   Water and energy shortages can occur relatively suddenly and can have adverse impacts on local and regional economies. To address this critical issue, research needs include creation and demonstration of decision-support tools for watershed management and power plant water use, development of water resource knowledge bases, and integrated resiliency assessments of regional power and water supplies.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P55.002 - Resource Risk Management
    27-May-2016

    The economic health of the power sector and society at large can be impacted by resource constraints of which water is only one. In addition, properties owned by power companies can contain valuable natural resources whose protection can result in financial gains and losses to the owners. Multiple approaches and concepts, which are not mutually exclusive, have been proposed as natural resource management tools, such as ecosystem management, natural resource stewardship, environmental assessment, and ecosystem services. Federal and state resource management and environmental protection agencies are actively studying the application of these different approaches and constructs. This key questions the project addresses focus on how resources the power sector owns and utilizes can be managed cost effectively and perhaps with revenue production.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center

Program Name: Effluent Guidelines and Water Quality Management
text:
Overview

Program Description

The Electric Power Research Institute's (EPRI’s) Effluent Guidelines and Water Quality Management Program is the focal point for electric power industry wastewater characterization data and analyses to scientifically inform regulatory guidelines for effluents. The program supports plant wastewater management needs and conducts data analysis into cost and performance of treatment options.

Research in this program provided the basis for informing the rulemaking process to revise effluent guidelines for wastewater discharges into surface waters at existing steam electric power plants. In September 2013, EPRI submitted public comments to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) on the proposed guideline revisions regarding the costs and expected pollutant removals for various treatment technologies as applied to effluents of concern. The 2015 final rule set numeric limits on wastewater from FGD systems and restricted the discharge of transport waters for fly ash and bottom ash. The final rule did incorporate some revisions to the numeric limits for selenium, mercury, arsenic, and nitrate/nitrite in flue gas desulfurization (FGD) wastewater as well as allowed flexibility with the use of bottom ash transport water for FGD make-up. In parallel, some U.S. states and regions are considering low parts-per-trillion limits for mercury and other metals

The program supports FGD and other wastewater treatment operations by evaluating and assisting in the development of online, real-time water quality monitors to assist wastewater treatment operation and effluent monitoring. The program also develops sound guidelines for effective management of low-volume, non-ash wastewater streams and conducts studies to accurately characterize industry water management practices. As the rulemaking process progresses additional opportunities for input may emerge. This program will continue to review and analyze any additional data to more broadly characterize trace elements in power plant wastewater steams, to evaluate the overall performance and costs for wastewater treatment options for trace metals and nutrients, as well as overall plant wastewater management options.

The research in this program is coordinated with EPRI’s Water Management Technology program.

Research Value

Program research helps inform the regulatory process and provides information to facility owners to manage the effluent guideline revisions as well as develop wastewater management strategies. As water discharge permit limits for trace metals and nutrients tighten, power companies need accurate analytical methods and online, real-time water quality monitors, reliable data, and independent performance and cost data for plant wastewater management. In addition, as power plants install air pollution control technologies to meet the hazardous air pollutant standards, these technologies—such as bromide addition, mercury re-emission chemicals or dry sorbent injection e.g. trona—may also impact wastewater and its treatability. Science-based analyses and extrapolation of the data will be necessary to help inform various stakeholders, including regulatory agencies, industry, and the public – as well as assist power plants manage plant wastewater. Key motivations for this research include the following:

  • The best scientific data available are needed for informing the continued rulemaking as well as assisting power plants with compliance and wastewater management. This includes characterization and treatability analysis for all possible plant design, operating conditions and coal properties expected across the existing fleet.
  • Accurate and adequately sensitive analytical methods including online, real-time water quality monitors are needed to assist in water treatment operations and to reduce the likelihood of permit violations to avoid false permit violations, and to decrease capital and operating/maintenance costs for wastewater treatment.
  • Evaluation of the cross-media impacts of air pollution control technologies on wastewater discharges is needed to assure compliance capability.
  • Data are needed to assist in managing bottom ash transport water in closed loop bottom ash transport systems.

The program’s research will ultimately benefit all stakeholders, including the public, by minimizing adverse impacts to the environment as well as minimizing the overall costs of managing wastewaters from electric power generating facilities.

Approach

EPRI characterizes power plant waters, evaluates and develops analytical methods and water quality monitors, and independently evaluates the overall performance and costs for various wastewater management options. Program results are communicated through briefings for key stakeholders, including regulatory and other government agencies; reports; presentation materials; information summaries for public consumption; and service on various advisory panels. This program delivers:

  • Online, real-time water quality monitors to assist in wastewater treatment operations and compliance
  • Summary evaluation of industry-wide wastewater treatment capital and operating and maintenance costs, as well as general overall treatment performance
  • Wastewater management strategies to assist in compliance with existing or revised discharge permits
  • Industry-specific data and information and scientifically-sound data assessment that helps determine the basis for informing the rulemaking as well as assisting power plants manage their wastewater
  • Guidance in managing bottom ash transport waters, specifically closed-loop systems without a discharge
  • Guidance in managing low-volume plant wastewaters
Accomplishments

The program's research informs industry, regulators, the public and other stakeholders about potential discharge limits and feasibility of treatment technologies as they relate to effluent guideline revisions. Program information has also been useful to power companies that install new FGD systems, negotiate new wastewater discharge permits, and plan wastewater treatment and management options. Program accomplishments include:

  • Characterization of FGD wastewater treatment influent and effluent for trace metals and nitrates/nitrites,
  • Laboratory treatment studies to optimize trace metals removal in FGD physical/chemical systems,
  • Development of cost estimation approaches for FGD wastewater treatment, including physical/chemical, biological, and thermal zero liquid discharge (ZLD),
  • Laboratory evaluation of selenium chemistry in wet FGD systems,
  • Characterization of selenium and mercury in FGD waters and its potential treatment implications,
  • Comments to the EPA on the proposed effluent guidelines revisions, as well as the draft and revised permits for Public Service of New Hampshire Merrimack station,
  • Characterization data and predictive tools for estimating trace metals in ash pond wastewater,
  • Guidelines for plant process wastewater management of total suspended solids, pH, and trace metals,
  • Engineering studies to evaluate the conversion from wet to dry bottom ash handling systems
Key Activities

Program R&D for 2017 will continue to focus on mercury, selenium, arsenic, and nitrate/nitrite water characterization, for which EPA has finalized new standards for FGD wastewater. As power plants install air pollution control technologies such as bromide addition, mercury re-emission chemicals, or trona injection, these technologies may impact FGD and ash pond wastewater and its treatability for key trace metals such as mercury and selenium. Such technologies may also have possible downstream impacts such as the potential to form trihalomethanes (THMs). Specifically, the research will:

  • Continue support of stakeholders in informing the ongoing effluent guidelines rulemaking, including synthesis analyses of data from EPA and others to support the rulemaking and other available data, as well as conduct studies to accurately characterize industry wastewater management practices
  • Provide accurate and reliable analytical methods including online water quality monitors,
  • Evaluate the impact of MATS flue gas controls, e.g. Hg re-emission additives, bromide, trona, and activated carbon injection on FGD wastewater, and
  • Provide industry-wide analysis of costs and benefits of potential wastewater treatment approaches, including physical/chemical, biological, and thermal ZLD approaches.

In 2016, a new project is being launched to evaluate and assist in the development of water quality monitors to support wastewater treatment operations. The program will continue to coordinate heavily with EPRI’s Power Plant Multimedia Toxics Characterization and Coal Combustion Products Environmental Issues programs to develop a more comprehensive understanding of the multimedia aspects of managing these effluent constituents, as well as with the Water Management Technology program to inform treatment technology research needs for meeting new effluent criteria. As EPA finalized the Effluent Guidelines rule in 2015, the program will continue to seek advisor feedback, and make adjustments to 2017 R&D as needed.

Program Manager
Paul Chu, 650-855-2362, pchu@epri.com

Overview

Program Description

The Electric Power Research Institute's (EPRI’s) “Power Plant Multimedia Toxics Characterization Program” provides state of the science information on pollutant partitioning and chemistry essential to power companies making environmental management decisions in an evolving landscape of fuel, environmental controls, and operating conditions.

In the United States and internationally, current and future air toxics emission, water discharge, and solid waste disposal regulations are likely to result in tighter limits and increased compliance costs for power companies and other industrial emissions sources. Control technologies for achieving increasingly stringent limits can be complex and costly to implement, especially in view of the potential need for flexibility to operate power plants in a cycling mode. Emissions from power plants into different media are closely interrelated because of transport from one medium to another. There is a critical need to address environmental releases in a holistic manner so that a pollutant removed by a control technology from one medium (such as air) does not adversely affect the levels in other media (such as water or solid waste). There will also be an increasing impetus to minimize the overall environmental footprint of power plants, achieved through retrofit and further optimization of existing power plant operations. The program will benefit companies in the U.S. and internationally who currently operate coal and gas-fired plants as well as those planning to build cleaner plants in the next 10-20 years.

EPRI's Power Plant Multimedia Toxics Characterization Program provides methods and tools for measuring and managing potentially toxic emissions and discharges from power plants, and prepares power companies to meet evolving regulations. The program helps industry, the scientific community, and the public evaluate discrete multimedia environmental impacts, as well as impacts that might result from changes in fuel composition or fuel blend, use of natural gas, implementation of new or enhanced pollution control technologies, or changes in plant operating practices. The research is coordinated with related work on emissions control technologies, air toxics risk assessment, as well as work on water characterization and management of combustion by-products. In view of the rapidly changing energy portfolio requirements, and the increasing deployment of alternative fuels such as biomass and distributed energy generation (e.g., fuel cells, solar) the program is embarking on new research to fully understand their environmental impacts.

Research Value

This program focuses on clarifying the chemistry and partitioning of pollutants in power plant process streams. EPRI began its power plant toxics characterization research more than 25 years ago. This long term outlook helps EPRI better anticipate issues, inform evolving regulations, and develop practical solutions. The research performed under this program enhances understanding of pollutant chemistry, provides methods and tools to accurately characterize the chemicals, and facilitates development of more effective pollution control strategies. Improved sampling and analytical methods can help reduce the risk of permit violations. The research provides credible emissions data to help power companies respond to permitting and regulatory requirements. The program addresses environmental impacts from use of natural gas as well as alternative fuels such as biomass, biofuels, and their co-firing with conventional fuels.

The program develops emissions estimates that are used as by other programs for risk assessment research. Measurement data produced by the program (and other sources) is compiled into the Power Plant Toxics Measurements Database, the most comprehensive database available on HAPs emissions. It is an online database containing primary information on the concentration partitioning of substances in power plant process and discharge streams. While this database has significant value in providing historical information on power plant emissions for regulatory purposes in the United States, there are also direct applications of the data for power companies managing pollutants in process streams internationally. The program assists power companies with Toxics Release Inventory (TRI) reporting by providing reporting software and emission factors, helping to minimize the cost of environmental compliance and make electricity more affordable. The TRI project will focus increasing attention on water issues to help address relevant issues in view of the recently revised Effluent Limitation Guidelines.

The Program’s research will ultimately benefit all stakeholders, including the public, by minimizing the overall costs of managing potentially toxic substances emanating from electric power generating facilities as well as minimizing adverse impacts to the environment.

Approach

This program simultaneously characterizes air emissions, water discharges, and land releases holistically, to account for the inter-media transfer of multimedia pollutants, such as selenium. This approach facilitates implementation of a ‘cradle to grave’ multimedia toxics management philosophy and helps minimize the cost of overall environmental compliance as well as the environmental footprint of power plant operations. This program delivers accurate characterization of chemical substances in fossil fuel-fired power plants waste streams and fuels. Characterization of power plant emissions and discharges requires accurate and sensitive analytical methods; where these do not exist, this program supports method development studies. The technical results from this program are highly applicable to international utilities.

An example of the holistic approach followed in this program is reflected in EPRI’s independent research planned to address post-MATS (Mercury and Air Toxics Standards) issues. MATS limits hazardous air pollutant (HAPs) emissions from coal- and oil-fired power plants. The regulation requires a residual risk assessment of the post-MATS industry and a technology review to assess whether additional regulations are appropriate to protect human health after the industry has complied with MATS. This may include an Information Collection Request (ICR) in 2018. The program research will compile lessons learned from a 2010 HAPs ICR and may propose to conduct new field sampling campaigns to assist in characterizing the HAPs emission profiles, especially for new power plant configurations where limited data currently exists. Recent revisions to effluent guidelines for the steam electric generation industry published, and recently issued rules regulating coal combustion residues (CCRs) from power plants may have a profound impact on the more effective management of water discharges and solid wastes, respectively.

Accomplishments

Research derived from this program has credibility with regulators and the scientific community alike as a source of independent scientific information. Data generated from this program are valuable to power companies in improved plant operations and cost-effective environmental compliance. Program accomplishments include the following:

  • Assessed the multimedia fate of mercury in power plants with selective catalytic reduction and wet flue gas desulfurization (FGD) systems, as well as those of selenium and boron in wet FGDs

  • Developed updated tools (the Power Plant Multimedia Toxics Database and TRI software) for environmental compliance and improved plant operation.

  • Developed revised emission factor estimates for several HAPs of interest using the voluminous data from 2010 HAPs ICR as well as enhanced statistical techniques

  • Contributed to EPRI’s comments to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) on measurement issues with the proposed Effluent Limitation Guidelines.

  • Provide extensive comments on EPA’s proposed HAPs Maximum Achievable Control Technology (MACT) rule (now called the MATS rule); identified many significant errors in the data used to calculate MACT limits. EPA acknowledged EPRI’s scientific contributions in enhancing the quality of the ICR database, and the final MATS rule included recommendations from EPRI’s comments.

  • Developed the QuickSEM as a mercury emissions reference method, a cost-effective sorbent-tube continuous mercury emissions monitoring system, later approved by the EPA as Method 30B.

Key Activities

In 2017, the program will continue to focus on characterizing the occurrence and multimedia partitioning of toxic substances in fossil-fuel-fired power plants, especially on evaluating emissions from natural gas–fueled power plants and coal- and oil-fueled power plants with novel pollution controls. The program will continue to enhance the Power Plant Toxics Measurements Database and TRI reporting software, evaluate analytical methods for substances of environmental concern, and conduct multimedia environmental characterization and evaluations of power generation technologies and the associated environmental controls. The program will:

  • Summarize the lessons learned from the 2010 HAPs ICR, the current state-of-art with sampling /analytical methods and provide input on the design of a possible future ICR.

  • Potentially conduct new field sampling campaigns to assist in characterizing HAPs emission profiles, especially for new power plant configures such as Activated Carbon Injection (ACI) and bromide injection where limited data currently exists and to evaluate sampling/analytical methods.

  • Update the TRI for Power Plants software with new emission factors for coal-, oil-, and petroleum-coke-fired power plants, incorporating the large amount of data gathered during the 2010 ICR.

  • Continue populating the Power Plant Multimedia Toxics Database with power plant waste stream characterization data to meet TRI and other needs.

  • Evaluate, develop, and validate sampling and analytical methods for multimedia characterization, using the program website as the clearinghouse for media-specific sampling and analytical methods.

  • Evaluate multimedia environmental impacts of air pollution control technologies (such as bromide and/or sorbent injection for mercury control, alkali sorbents for acid gas control) as well as fuel changes.

  • Develop emission factors for HAPs from natural gas-fired power plants and conduct a preliminary assessment of the potential multimedia challenges associated with the expected increased use of natural gas in electricity production.

  • Conduct a preliminary assessment of the potential environmental issues emanating from the wide scale use of alternative fuels such as biomass and deployment of distributed energy sources such as solar and fuel cells.

Last Updated
  • Post-MATS HAPs
    • Post-MATS HAPs Characterization of Multimedia Releases
      08-Jun-2016

      In 2012, EPA issued a final MATS rule that regulates HAPs emissions from coal- and oil-fired power plants. Compliance with the final rule began in April 2015, with a number of facilities were granted a compliance extension for one-year to April 2016.

      EPA is required to conduct a residual risk assessment of the post-MATS industry by the 2020 timeframe as well as a series of technology reviews, to assess whether additional regulations may be needed to protect human health after the industry has complied with MATS. This may include an Information Collection Request (ICR) which could be conducted around the 2018 timeframe.  Thus, power companies need to continue to characterize and investigate their post-MATS emissions and their potential risks to the public. The results from this project would help refine and inform any future HAPs ICR.

      There is a need to examine multimedia releases (e.g., FGD water discharges and solid wastes) in addition to air emissions because technologies for controlling HAPs air emissions will impact the nature and composition of FGD wastewater discharges and solids such as coal ash and FGD byproducts (gypsum).

      As the future generation fleet becomes more flexible, there is going to be an increase in cycling of fossil-powered power plants. Thus, there is a need to characterize emissions during startups and shutdowns because of increased cycling; these emissions can be significantly different from steady state values – especially for organics.

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Program 59 Membership Projects
    • Environmental Database Evaluation and Compilation
      07-Jun-2016

      Companies need to know the chemical characteristics of fuel, reagents, and waste streams released from power plants to comply with existing environmental regulations and prepare for anticipated regulations (MATS, ELGs, and CCR), design pollution control devices, and estimate composition of air emissions and water discharges under changing operating conditions. Companies also need to compare emissions from power plants with different configurations to make decisions on plant modification and inform fuel purchasing decisions.

    • Multimedia Issues Related to Non-Conventional Power Generation
      07-Jun-2016

      Rapidly changing energy portfolio requirements in many states are leading to renewed interest in alternative fuel sources such as biomass and biofuels, as well as in distributed generation. However, the multimedia environmental issues associated with use of these energy sources need to be fully understood to allow for their efficient and environmentally safe deployment. Compared to conventional fuels such as oil and gas, biomass and biofuels are expected to result in different emissions profiles due to their different and more heterogeneous composition, as well lower energy content. In addition, waste flows from and within power plants are expected to change, especially when alternative fuels are co-fired with coal. For distributed generation technology such as fuel cells for power generation air emissions are really not a problem; however, waste issues such as disposal /management of used catalysts (typically metals) will need to be addressed, most effectively on a life cycle basis.

    • Multimedia Release from Natural Gas Generation
      07-Jun-2016

      Combustion of natural gas for electric power generation is increasing in the United States due to retirements of coal-fired power plants and the availability of relatively inexpensive natural gas. Natural gas combustion generally produces lower emissions of criteria pollutants and air toxics emissions per unit of energy produced compared to conventional coal-fired power plants. However, these emissions still need to be characterized and are subject to federal, state, and regional emissions limits. Power company staff may need to quantify emissions for permitting, emissions inventories, and Toxics Release Inventory (TRI) reporting. Measuring emissions from natural gas-fired sources is challenging because of the relatively low concentrations. This project will compile existing test data, identify data gaps, and remedy the data gaps in hazardous air pollutant (HAPs) emissions from gas-fired power generation sources via well-designed field studies. The collected test data will be used to develop robust emission factors for combustion turbines, reciprocating internal combustion engines, and other unit types of interest. Since gas-fired plants are expected to be more frequently operated in a cycling mode (rapid startup and shutdown), the emission profile during cycling mode also needs to be ascertained.

      In addition to air emissions, there is a need to quantify potential impacts to water and land from natural gas combustion. Natural gas fired plants use water primarily for cooling. Water discharges from the plants can potentially have an impact on water bodies from which water is withdrawn and returned, and on aquatic life. The volumes of solid and liquid wastes generated from natural gas-fired plants are much lower than coal-fired plants, but may present unique management challenges. Attention also needs to be paid to the interplay between media – i.e., potential transfer of pollutants from one medium to another, to facilitate holistic management of the chemicals of interest.

    • Sampling & Analytical Methods
      07-Jun-2016

      Accurate characterization of potentially toxic chemicals in fuels, reagents, intermediate process streams, air emissions, liquid and solid waste streams, and other discharges is essential for developing effective strategies for multimedia management of these chemicals. Some existing sampling and analytical methods do not have the required sensitivity or specificity to meet increasingly stringent regulatory needs. Better methods, and validation of existing methods, are needed to support compliance monitoring. The drivers for this research are regulatory programs that require new pollution control technologies and impose increasingly strict limits on emissions to air, land, and water. For example, FGD systems will divert some metals from stack gas to wastewater. Power plants facing tighter surface water discharge limits for these metals may not be able to measure them accurately with existing analytical methods. Preservation techniques for samples that avoid changing or contaminating the sample will become increasingly important.

Program Name: Electric and Magnetic Fields and Radio-Frequency Health Assessment and Safety
text:
Overview

Program Description

The Electric and Magnetic Fields (EMF) and Radio-Frequency (RF) Health Assessment and Safety program supports and conducts research addressing key environmental health and safety issues related to public and worker exposure to electromagnetic field environments associated with electric power system infrastructure. Historically, issues investigated power frequency (60 Hz) fields produced by transmission and distribution (T&D) lines, generating stations, and substations. Over the forty-plus years since EPRI’s founding and as the science evolves, the program adapted its research portfolio to focus on health and safety issues related to power frequencies. The portfolio includes streamlined efforts related to cancer and reproductive outcomes, drawing from several disciplines including epidemiology, exposure assessment, life sciences, and engineering.

Smart grid technologies, distributed energy resources (DER), the large-scale introduction of electric vehicles and associated charging infrastructures, the expansion of wireless communications, and other innovations drive the expansion of the spectrum of interest for residential exposures to radiofrequencies up to 3 gigahertz (GHz, a billion Hz). Along with the power frequency health and safety issues that remain under investigation, the program periodically addresses RF issues that include field characterizations of smart meter emissions, ambient urban environments, electric vehicles and associated charging operations, and commercial solar photovoltaic installations. Communication of its results and perspectives to all stakeholders remains a core part of the program.  Research efforts contribute to the public benefit in terms of environmentally responsible electrical energy, and further the vision of a flexible, resilient and, connected electrical grid. 

Research Value

This program addresses high-priority issues concerning potential health effects related to EMF and RF exposures by contributing to the body of scientific knowledge, contributing to accurate health risk evaluations and informing exposure guideline development. The EPRI EMF program is the longest-running comprehensive research program addressing ongoing and emerging EMF and RF health issues, bringing EPRI an international reputation as an authoritative source of EMF information. EPRI research provides scientific information to address issues raised by local constituencies with respect to new facility construction or upgrades (transmission lines, substations). Such input provides public benefit because when delays are shortened it directly translates to reduced project costs associated with expensive rerouting and undergrounding. Over the past ten years, the EPRI program has focused on the basis for the association between childhood leukemia and residential magnetic fields. However, the program has responded to other needs which periodically surface such as conducting first-of-its-kind measurements of RF emissions from smart meters, creating information for the public, regulators, and the scientific community.

 

The program addresses key health and safety issues related to exposure of the general public and utility workers to electromagnetic environments from across the non-ionizing spectrum. With respect to power frequency magnetic fields, the health endpoints of highest priority include childhood leukemia, miscarriage and neurodegenerative diseases. The program has also conducted characterizations of environments associated with new technologies, including smart meters, electric vehicles and their charging apparatus, wireless bus charging, commercial solar photovoltaic facilities, and the background urban RF environment. EPRI research are published in the peer-reviewed literature and incorporated into international risk assessments, and public utility commission/public service commission proceedings for approving new line and substation projects.

Approach

This program provides research results, information, and analyses that inform public dialogue and regulatory oversight concerning EMF and RF health and safety issues, including:

  • Timely, reliable EMF and RF scientific research results, communication materials, relevant background information, and analyses of key studies;
  • Publicly accessible, up-to-date information on EMF and RF research, health risk evaluations, and regulatory actions;
  • Epidemiologic and experimental research investigating high-priority residential and occupational EMF and RF health and safety issues;
  • EMF and RF exposure characterization research;
  • Educational materials, including instructional EMF/RF DVDs, tutorials, and RF safety awareness training;
  • Studies on potential EMF interaction with implanted medical devices; and
  • Research on the potential effects of EMF on aquatic life from submerged DC cables.
Accomplishments

Through peer-reviewed scientific publications, presentations at scientific meetings and seminars, and participation in scientific and technical advisory panels, the program staff has an international reputation for conducting objective scientific research. Recent accomplishments include:

  • Development and evaluation of innovative study designs to address selection bias in epidemiologic studies of magnetic fields and childhood leukemia;
  • Peer-reviewed publications on characterization of RF levels in the ambient urban environment, and RF emissions from plug-in vehicle charging, wireless bus charging, commercial solar photovoltaic generation, and wireless smart meters;
  • Successful development of a mouse model of childhood leukemia;
  • Capture of methods, assessment of race/ethnicity and socioeconomic status and childhood leukemia for a California-based case control study;
  • Software and instrumentation characterizing and benchmarking residential and occupational EMF and RF exposures;
  • Updated EMF public information brochure;
  • Three-part video series on EMF covering all aspects of the power frequency health issue with companion illustrated booklets;
  • Several briefs on issues such as GPS use near transmission lines and EMF and electric vehicle (EV) chargers; and
  • Evaluation of magnetic field effect thresholds in humans
Key Activities

Streamlined high priority research and effective communications form the foundation for the 2017 program. Specific efforts in 2017 include:

  • Final analysis of pooled data on childhood leukemia and distance from power lines (will include data from the California Power Line Study);

  • Completion of the California Power Line Study, which uses California birth and cancer registry data and innovative GIS techniques to examine childhood leukemia incidence as it relates to residential distance from transmission lines;

  • Completion of exposure systems for use in leukemia mouse model experiments to determine whether exposure to magnetic fields affects disease development;

  • Expansion of large-scale, international epidemiologic study (TransExpo) aimed at reducing selection bias;

  • Assessment the relationship of magnetic field exposure and personal mobility with miscarriages in subjects treated at an assisted reproductive technology clinic;

  • Further investigation of potential EMF/RF interference with active implanted medical devices (such as, pacemakers and defibrillators);

  • Completion of “EMAlert” - a personal monitor  that informs workers of the presence of fields that may possibly disrupt an implanted pacemaker or defibrillator, and

  • Additional research on magnetophosphene thresholds in human subjects.

Estimated 2017 Program Funding
3.83

Ximena Vergara, 650-855-2315, xvergara@epri.com

Last Updated
  • PS60A: EMF and RF Health Assessment: Community and Residential Studies
    09-Jun-2016

    The EMF and RF Health Assessment project set focuses on community and residential studies using exposure assessment, epidemiologic and laboratory approaches. Transfer of up-to-date information on current EMF research to EMF/RF issue managers at P60 member organizations is needed to address ongoing public concerns along with input to access a version of the EMF Workstation 2015 software for modeling both electric and magnetic fields in residential and occupational settings. Access to the EMF and RF Information Project enables research summaries and information to address public concerns about EMF and health with the most current information available.

    • EMF and RF Exposure Assessment Related to Emerging Technologies
      09-Jun-2016

      This project addresses the need to characterize electromagnetic environments across the non-ionizing spectrum: from 0 Hz (DC) to over 5 gigahertz (GHz) or greater, which includes 50/60 Hz fields associated with transmission (ac and dc) and distribution (T&D). These electromagnetic environments, among others, include RF exposures from advanced metering infrastructure (AMI), electric vehicles and their charging infrastructure (including wireless charging), and distributed energy resources (DER). Accurate exposure characterization is essential for addressing public and worker concerns about the potential new exposure environments and potential health effects.

      Distributed generation such as offshore wind turbines and tidal and wave energy generators alike will need to be linked to the mainland system through undersea cables. There is also an ongoing development of transmission capacity under bodies of waters (sea, lakes, and rivers). Potential impacts due to EMF from these submerged underwater cables will need to be evaluated in numerous aquatic species. Finally, integrating the expanding amount of distributed energy resources (DER) seamlessly into the smart grid will become a priority challenge from an engineering perspective. The large-scale deployment of DER may likely produce current pathways through distribution lines and grounding systems which may require attention as these new environments are in closer proximity to the public and may stir public concern.

    • EMF and RF Information Project
      09-Jun-2016

      Public and worker concerns over possible health effects from exposure to the extremely low frequency (ELF)-EMF and RF fields associated with the electric power system and sources such as panel antennas, wireless networks, and automatic metering infrastructure drive the need for new scientific research. Renewed concerns over EMF may arise in association with planning and deployment of new or expanded T&D projects. Power companies and their staff must be positioned to communicate to their customers, regulators and employees relevant EMF and RF information.

    • Health Studies Related to EMF and T&D Infrastructure
      09-Jun-2016

      International and national and risk assessments conducted by agencies such as the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) and the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS) concluded, primarily based on the epidemiologic association between ELF-MF and childhood leukemia, that magnetic fields are possibly carcinogenic to humans. In 2007, the World Health Organization published an assessment reaffirming IARC’s conclusion.  However, the organization noted uncertainties remain for childhood leukemia as well as several other health endpoints, including miscarriage and neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer’s disease and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.  Along with well-conducted, focused research to resolve scientific uncertainties, effective communication is essential to translate current EMF health research. Moreover, construction of transmission lines in rural areas or linking offshore renewable generation to the mainland grid raise concerns about potential effects of EMF exposure on community health such as fish migration.

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • PS60B: EMF and RF Health Assessment: Occupational Studies
    09-Jun-2016

    The EMF and RF Health Assessment Occupational Studies project set produces scientific research and information on important occupational EMF/RF health and safety issues. The project set can provide data needed for improving basis for EMF and RF exposure guidelines. Current guidelines protect against neurostimulatory (EMF) or thermal (RF) effects arising through known biophysical mechanisms; however, guideline limits have yet to combine all the recent advances in dosimetry, dose-effect relationships, and exposure modeling, to which EPRI research has contributed significantly. Along with conducting research, EPRI continues to monitor guideline revisions and other developments. The EPRI occupational project set continues to provide technical summaries of medical implant and ELF and RF literature and to identify gaps in research. EPRI occupational health studies focus on neurodegenerative diseases, particularly amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and Alzheimer's disease, among electrical and other workers. As both implanted active (e.g., pacemakers, defibrillators) and passive (e.g., plates, screws, artificial joints) medical devices, are increasingly being used by active workers and the general population potential interference from ELF and RF/EMF exposure remains a concern.

    • EMF and RF Occupational Health
      09-Jun-2016

      The EMF and RF Occupational Health project set includes a focus on epidemiologic, exposure guidelines, and exposure assessment relevant to the workplace.  With respect to epidemiologic work, the World Health Organization (WHO) assigned a high priority to research ALS among those working in electrical occupations and Alzheimer's disease in relation to magnetic field exposure in its 2007 EMF health risk assessment.  Exposure guidelines and standards aim to protect persons against adverse electrostimulation for frequencies less than about 100 kHz.  For higher frequencies up to 300 GHz, guidelines and standards aim to protect against adverse effects associated with tissue heating.  Uncertainties remain about the scientific bases for these exposure limits and their relationship to dose.  As new work environments are created as electric companies plan new transmission and distribution projects and deal with increasing electricity demand by delivering electricity from alternative energy resources. Finally, accurate exposure assessment is critical for minimizing worker exposures near RF, wireless facilities and other emerging energy technologies.

Overview

Program Description

Workplace injuries affect employee health, quality of life, occupational productivity, and job satisfaction. Efforts to reduce the burden of injuries and illnesses, medical costs, and productivity losses, while helping to improve worker morale and workforce retention, are a critical part of electric power company operations. Within the electric power industry, typical risks may result from poor ergonomic design in equipment, misguided procedures, and long-term or repetitive exposure to various physical and chemical agents. Companies must develop strategies capable of protecting workers while meeting compliance with worker health and safety requirements for reliable, uninterrupted delivery of electricity to customers. Regulatory standard setting and rulemaking by the Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA), as well as sister agencies in Canada and the European Union, influence the amount of exposure monitoring, injury prevention and training programs, and engineering controls or best practice guidelines required within the electric sector.

The Electric Power Research Institute’s (EPRI) Occupational Health and Safety program provides scientific research needed for informed decisions about control methods geared toward workplace injury and illness prevention. Products, tools, and design recommendations emerging from this research help electric power companies maintain safer, healthier work environments and control labor-related costs. The research identifies injury and illness trends, develops cost-effective ergonomic interventions and designs, and addresses critical occupational exposure issues. The program serves as the foundation for occupational health and safety–related work within the electric utility industry.

Research Value

Lost productivity and medical costs from occupational injuries significantly contribute to operational costs, reliability, and workforce retention within the electric power industry.  Scientific research provides the basis for informed health and safety practices for current and anticipated future electric utility infrastructure. This program provides the scientific research needed for informed decisions on strategies for injury prevention, safety program targets, exposure controls, regulatory compliance, and intervention and training methods.The research provides insight into future health and safety deliberations and an integrated approach for occupational planning in the electricity sector based on the integration of health, exposure, and surveillance data. If effectively integrated within the safety management systems of electric power companies, EPRI products and research results may contribute to the reduction of these effects.

Approach

This program delivers research, data, analyses, and expertise that help electric power companies effectively address occupational health and safety issues. The program transfers information, knowledge, and research results through many avenues:

  • Easy-to-read handbooks describing ergonomic interventions, best practices, and design guidelines
  • Presentations to industry, the scientific community, and regulatory agencies
  • Monthly webinar forums for discussions on recent safety research topics of interest
  • Reports and peer-reviewed literature on toxic and potentially toxic workplace exposures that provide data for regulatory guidelines and compliance
  • Annual Safety research conferences, technology R&D initiatives, and thought-leadership-driven cross-organizational collaborations
Accomplishments

The Occupational Health and Safety Program strives to produce leading edge research in several worker safety and health-related arenas.  Among the accomplishments of the past year and continuing into the coming year are the following studies:

  • Heat Stress:  Development of new measures revealing significant increases in core body temperature and associated physiological strain with various electric utility industry specific scenarios
  • Occupational Health and Safety Database:  Industry’s only detailed data source for longitudinal tracking and analysis of injury/illness surveillance data
  • Ergonomic Research:  Evaluation of ergonomic impacts and intervention on bucket control-related muscle strain/fatigue; also provides a decision tool design for EPRI ergonomic handbooks implementation
  • Occupational Exposure Database:  Utility membership database tool designed to provide industry specific sampling and exposure incidence information – for identifying constituents of concern
  • Noise Exposure Risk:  Electric utility industry specific research characterizing occupational noise environment and potential risk of worker noise-induced hearing loss and evaluating reduction measures
  • Driving Safety:  Research on recorded driving event data and its feasibility in predicting geospatial risk, i.e. “Risk Mapping” to support safety planning and driver coaching
Key Activities

The following key electric utility industry research challenges have been categorized by EPRI’s advisory team and informs a 2017 and beyond action plan:  1) Identifying and quantifying human health impacts associated with exposure to chemical, physical, and biological hazards, some of which have yet to be characterized, 2) Providing cost-effective countermeasures and intervention strategies to facilitate mitigation of workforce health and safety risks,  3)  Developing and using information integration tools for better assimilating workforce-related adverse health incidence data, 4) Establishing industry-wide safety risk management process improvement guidelines and standards and 5) Fostering a “Beyond Compliance” approach through establishment of an EPRI Safety Center of Excellence.

To date, several major areas of research have been established and expanded to characterize risks to the electric utility workforce and determine efficacy of countermeasures and intervention methods.  Program highlights include ongoing world-class applied research structured into the following project areas:

  • P62.001 - Occupational Health and Safety Database:  A unique source of detailed, comprehensive, standardized injury and illness rates and statistical analyses specifically for the electricity industry; it serves as a baseline measure of injury occurrence for the sector, enabling consistent long-term analysis, benchmarking, and anchoring of leading safety and injury prevention indicators.
  • P62.002 - Ergonomics Research:  This research identifies injury trends; characterizes new occupational human factors and ergonomics risks; and develops potential new cost-effective, end-to-end ergonomic interventions and/or designs to help ensure workers are free from disabilities when they retire.
  • P62.003 - Occupational Exposure and Health Studies:  These research studies focus on building infrastructure for exposure characterization and health impacts of temperature extremes, noise, chemical and industrial hygiene stressors, and other safety concerns (such as shift work and driving safety) within the electric utility sector to inform regulatory policy and health-protecting strategies.
Estimated 2017 Program Funding
$1.4M
Program Manager
Lovely Krishen, 865-218-8075, lkrishen@epri.com

Last Updated
  • P62.001 - Occupational Health & Safety Database
    01-Jun-2016

    This surveillance project produces the Occupational Health and Safety Database (OHSD), a unique source of detailed, comprehensive, standardized injury and illness rates and statistical analyses specifically for the electricity industry. This database serves as a baseline measure of injury occurrence for the sector, enabling consistent long-term analysis, benchmarking, and anchoring of leading safety and injury prevention indicators. The OHSD provides a linkage tool for analyzing the effectiveness of injury control, safety intervention strategies, and regulatory requirements around a given reference point (sector and individual company level).

    This research will also identify key, leading indicators which can be used throughout the electricity industry to monitor and evaluate proactive injury and illness prevention efforts. By establishing common leading indicators useful data can be provided to members to establish benchmark levels of performance in prevention activities.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P62.002 - Ergonomic Research
    01-Jun-2016

    A long-term series of field observation, laboratory, and engineering studies has characterized the role of ergonomic factors across work tasks, resulting in process recommendation and design remedies across the sector. This project continues to mature by analyzing the translation and relative success of this science within the sector, including helping identify methods for economic evaluation and effective application. These studies will continue to identify and feed back into the development of additional ergonomic research.

    This research will also explore corollary and causal relationships between intervention strategies and actual injury performance. This will involve a detailed review of specific injury types (e.g. soft tissue, sprain and strain) and the subsequent impact of the mitigation strategies had on reducing these types of injuries. Intervention strategy specifics, implementation timelines, training and education efforts will be analyzed to show the relationships.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P62.003 - Occupational Exposure and Health Studies
    01-Jun-2016

    This research investigates relationships among injury and illness occurrence rates, lifestyle factors, and workplace exposures. Current issues of interest include exposure to physical (temperature extremes and noise) agents, chemical (beryllium, sulfur hexafluoride decomposition, dioxin/furan) agents as well as respiratory (silica, welding fumes, etc.) agents. Development of a comprehensive, sector-specific exposure database continues in order to better inform workplace monitoring, thereby providing significant cost savings by pooling available industrial hygiene data from participating companies.

    Exposure characterization and epidemiologic research will continue to address occupational and lifestyle factors potentially associated with injuries and illnesses, together with statistical analyses of existing occupational exposure and health information, provide further insight into causal relationships and mitigation strategies. The research will seek to develop processes members may use to successfully protect employees from exposure constituents, as well as provide proactive engineering controls which can be incorporated into operational activities reducing exposure potential.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center

Overview

Program Description

The majority of fossil plants worldwide are more than 30 years old and are experiencing increased demand for operational flexibility while addressing age-related issues for major components. High-energy steam and water piping systems are among the most important safety issues at fossil plants and must be managed reliably through the aging process. Safety and availability loss due to pressure part failures are two key issues driving R&D on major fossil power plant components. Boiler tube failures (BTFs) continue to be the leading cause of lost availability in fossil-fired steam plants worldwide.

The Electric Power Research Institute’s (EPRI’s) Boiler Life and Availability Improvement Program (Program 63) collaborates internationally to develop technology and guidance on safe management of boiler component life to increase reliability and reduce operation and maintenance (O&M) costs. Efforts focus on advanced inspection techniques for early and accurate identification of component damage; analytical tools to predict remaining life and risk of in-service failure; and decision-support tools to help balance risk and benefit under a variety of operating scenarios.

Research Value

Power generators need to balance the risks and costs of the largest, most costly equipment in the power plant and focus on using proven technologies to create solutions. By using the results of the R&D in this program, plant owners and operators can:

  • Reduce the costs of lost availability due to boiler tube failures when program results are applied comprehensively
  • Increase the safety of high-energy and high-temperature piping systems
  • Increase safety through control of flow-accelerated corrosion (FAC) in fossil plants
Approach

The program portfolio includes guidelines, reports, software code, and tools applicable to all boilers, focused on the goals of optimal availability and performance.

  • Research on boiler component inspection and monitoring develops reliable and cost-effective nondestructive evaluation (NDE) techniques to reduce O&M costs and improve life-management options. NDE developments in other industries also are evaluated for application to fossil plants.
  • Tools for boiler component life management provide a comprehensive approach to creating technical bases for minimizing in-service component damage and for component remaining-life assessment. Both areas are critical for high reliability and maximum equipment life.
  • High-energy steam and water piping safety and reliability of high-energy piping systems in fossil power plants are enhanced by information provided on how damage mechanisms affect piping components and on remaining life tools. Tools are developed that allow engineers to more accurately predict the remaining life of piping systems.
Accomplishments

EPRI’s Boiler Life and Availability Improvement program has created and successfully demonstrated a world-recognized program to reduce boiler tube failures by understanding damage mechanisms, their root causes, and corrective options for root causes. Highlights include:

  • Development of the most comprehensive suite of guidelines and analysis tools for boiler component life management
  • Guidance, training, and analysis tools for FAC management in fossil plants
  • Leadership in developing and demonstrating NDE technologies for boilers, high-energy piping, and flow-accelerated corrosion (FAC)
  • Boiler tube failure reduction program training to help guide utilities in reaching goals for availability
  • Boiler reliability interest group meetings twice a year for members to meet and discuss industry issues and the latest technologies
Key Activities

The program R&D will focus on developing life-assessment technologies for piping and header base metal degradation. Specific efforts will include:

  • Research and development of tools such as small sample removal and testing procedures to predict remaining life of seamless pressure parts
  • Guidance to address damage from evolving operating modes within current fossil fleet, including fuel switching, cycling, and low loads
  • Technology and information to support reliable operation of new and advanced fossil boiler and boiler component designs
Estimated 2017 Program Funding
$5.4M
