Last Updated
  • Application of Lifing Calculator - Lifing of Soft Grade 91 Materials
    09-Jun-2016

    EPRI developed a lifing calculator to predict remaining creep and fatigue life for Grade 91 steels approximately five years ago.  It has since been upgraded to include several other low alloy materials.  One of the key benefits to using this EPRI product is it is the only software to contain creep properties on soft Grade 91 which may have resulted from uncontrolled processing.  An identified need for this lifing calculator is documentation on application examples and benefits realized from its use.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Assessment of Eddy Current Arrays for Replacement of WFMT for Crack Detection
    08-Jun-2016

    Wet Fluorescent Magnetic Particle Testing (WFMT) is generally used during initial fabrication inspections and post service inspections to determine if surface breaking flaws are present.  This inspection is normally performed around welds or other areas where surface flaws are expected.  The process is messy and requires a dark environment to be performed.  Freezing weather adds additional challenges to use of this approach.  Eddy current inspection has been shown to be able to be quickly performed with no mess or surface preparation and potentially could be performed more economically for these inspections.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Assessment of Eddy Current Arrays for Detection of Hidden Seam and Girth Welds
    08-Jun-2016

    In recent EPRI research, eddy current equipment, using specialized processing, was shown to be able to locate repair welds in cast Grade 91 valves.  Locating longitudinal seam and girth welds in piping systems is often a difficult task, and made more difficult if the weld has been ground or machined smooth on the outside surface.  Traditional methods include acid etching which is a time consuming (due to surface preparation requirements) and can have some amount of risk (due to use of the acid).  Even acid etching sometimes will not reveal the weld if the weld had been normalized.  This work will explore if eddy current arrays can detect hidden seam and girth welds in low alloy headers and piping systems.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Boiler Tube Failure Application
    09-Jun-2016

    Boiler tube failures (BTF) and cycle chemistry corrosion and deposition problems remain the leading causes of availability losses in fossil-fired steam plants worldwide. EPRI has developed an extensive integrated boiler tube failure reduction/cycle chemistry improvement program with over 20-years of experiential data and research.  The program was last updated in 2006 and an update is needed to capture additional operating experience.  

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Component Specific Testing
    20-Jun-2016

    The transition of fossil power plants to more flexible modes of operation increases the susceptibility of major components to unanticipated degradation and is the focus of ongoing EPRI research.  In thick section components, a concern has been identified that increased cyclic operation, especially at high temperatures may result in additional fatigue damage accumulation, impacting life management of these components. 

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Damage from Cycling of Supercritical Power
    09-Jun-2016

    Many supercritical boilers have transitioned from base loaded operation to load following and even start/stop cycling.  Previous EPRI research indicates that this type of operation is expected to lead to more mechanical and thermal fatigue damage.  Collection of industry experience regarding the major supercritical boiler components impacted by cyclic operation is needed.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Damage to Tubing from Sootblower Maintenance
    09-Jun-2016

    Sootblowing erosion continues to be one of the leading tube failure mechanisms within the boiler.  Many of the factors that cause sootblower erosion to occur are related to maintenance issues, e.g., water in the steam due to improper superheat or maintenance of insulation and steam traps.  Maintenance guides exist within EPRI for the sootblower from a mechanical standpoint.  However, recommended practices to reduce the damage from sootblowing operations are needed. 

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Demonstration of Eddy Current Glove for Boiler Applications
    08-Jun-2016

    Improvements in the inspection of traditional boiler areas of constrained access is needed. A novel delivery technique for eddy current inspections has been developed by EPRI for use in Heat Recovery Steam Generators.  This technology may offer significant improvement in boiler inspections, particularly for components and locations with rough or irregular surfaces. 

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Evaluation of Damage Potential from Bang and Clean Tube Cleaning
    09-Jun-2016

    A new method of cleaning boiler and heat recovery steam generator (HRSG) tubing has been developed in Europe and recently demonstrated in the US.  This pressure wave cleaning approach utilizes bags filled with ethane gas and oxygen that are held close to tubing and detonated.  Past research on use of explosives for tube cleaning has shown the velocities that may damage tubing.  It is unclear how the velocities under the pressure wave approach compare to traditional methods. 

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Experience Report on CrMoV Piping
    27-May-2016

    While United States power plants have traditionally used lower alloyed steels like Grades 11 and 22 for steam piping systems, chrome moly vanadium (CrMoV) materials have been used for many years in Europe, Africa, and other parts of the world.  The strengthening mechanisms for this alloy have demonstrated low ductility failures which make life assessment activities challenging. 

    Typical damage in high temperature piping systems is related to welds, either in the weld metal or the Type IV location.  Life assessment of these systems has typically been performed using a combination of calculations and inspections and damage is generally repaired by welding.  At some point, after significant damage and repair of welds, damage will accumulate in the parent metal.  How to address this damage is an industry concern as the area involved does not lend itself well to an inspection life management technology.  It is expected that damage will first be seen in bends and then in lesser stressed straight sections of pipe.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Flexible and Curved Arrays for Detection of Boiler Tube Cracking
    08-Jun-2016

    Current examination methods of boiler tubes are significantly resource intensive, require multiples passes along each tube crown, manual scans without automatic records and many times the damage characterization is subjective.  There exists an industry need to improve upon current examination technologies and the application of these technologies.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Flexible Operations Handbooks - Volume Three, Steam Touched Components
    09-Jun-2016

    Flexible operation plays an increasing role in power plant operation. Many conventional coal- and oil-fired power plants were originally designed for baseload operation—that is, either operation at full load or shutdown. Although damage as a result of flexible operation occurs throughout a fossil-fired unit, the specific area of interest of this report is water-touched boiler components.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Further Exposive Cleaning Research - Binary Cord Guidance
    09-Jun-2016

    In previous research on explosive cleaning of boilers, EPRI recommend that binary cord explosives not be utilized.  The velocity from this type of explosive was high relative to stick type of explosives.  Control and placement is also more difficult than stick type explosive resulting in higher probability of damage to surrounding components. If a lower velocity det (detonation) cord could be found or developed, it may provide good results for areas that are difficult to clean with stick type explosives.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Guided Wave for Wall Loss and Cracking in Membrane Walls
    08-Jun-2016

    Loss of wall thickness in waterwall panels requires evaluation to maintain component integrity.  The ability to use advanced nondestructive evaluation technologies, such as guided waves, offers the potential to detect wall loss and cracking in membrane welded waterwall panels.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Life Assessment Handbooks - Cold Reheat Piping
    27-May-2016

    EPRI has built an extensive library of life assessment documents that may be utilized to understand component life and health conditions; boiler tube failures, component assessments, long seam inspections, piping guidelines, etc.  However, wading through this content requires a significant amount of time and resources.  A simplified and streamlined document is needed to help plant staff execute on lifing studies of key components in a timely and cost-effective nature.  The 2017 effort will be to develop a handbook on Cold Reheat Piping.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Lifing of Aged Grade 22 Materials
    09-Jun-2016

    Grade 22 has been used successfully in power plant applications requiring reasonable high-temperature strength and resistance to oxidation.  The most common applications are in superheater and reheater tubing as well as high-temperature headers and piping.  A majority of the life assessment predictions for this material is based on short term creep tests on new parent metal and cross welds.  There is a need to better understand in-service material behavior that will allow the industry to develop more accurate and predictive life assessment models.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Mechanical Engineers Contribution to the Understanding of Circumferential Cracking
    09-Jun-2016

    In 2015, EPRI investigated the physical thermohydraulics of supercritical water in waterwalls.  The project found that close to the pseudo-critical boiling point changes in the water’s ability to absorb heat from the tubing could result in temperature spikes within the tube metal.  Most investigations in pseudo-critical boiling within tubing has been limited to single tubes, not membrane panels.  It is important to understand the impact of pseudo-critical boiling on membrane panel performance and reliability.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • NDE for Detection of Axially Oriented Blasting Damage in Boilers
    08-Jun-2016

    EPRI research shows that blasting damage in tubing initiates in the inside surface or midwall in superheat and reheat tubing.  Traditional ultrasonic inspection should be able to find the damage but with the massive amount of surface area where this type of damage could occur, it would be very time consuming to perform this type of inspection.  This project will investigate nondestructive evaluation technologies to rapidly detect blasting damage in superheat and reheat tubing.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • NDE Methods of Detection of Early Stages
    08-Jun-2016

    Recent research into detection of damage in Grade 91 has shown that traditional NDE methods may not find damage until very late in life.  This is because of the damage location and how it manifests.  This research will answer the question if any other NDE methods are more appropriate to detect damage earlier in this material.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P63/P88 Joint Life Management
    19-Jul-2016

    Current life management approaches for advanced creep strength enhanced ferritic (CSEF) steel Grades 91 and 92 predominately rely on random inspection and using traditional, borrowed strategies from the experience base for low alloy steels. As evidenced by the complexity of Grades 91 and 92, and an evolving service experience which includes a number of failures documented in key EPRI reports, it is clear that a defined, well-engineered approach to life management is required which enables the owner/operator to better rank and prioritize susceptible components or systems for inspection. In this way, the uncertainty in life management will be reduced and the probability to finding damage (should it exist in a system or component) will be increased. 

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Replication Guideline for Life Assessment
    09-Jun-2016

    Replication (the use of an acetate film to produce a likeness of the surface microstructure) has been used for many years as an indicator where a component may be in its lifetime.  It provides many benefits but also has been misapplied in many instances.  It only provides information about the microstructure on the surface and should not be used where damage is expected to develop subsurface.  Most of the guidance on use of acetate films was developed for low alloy steels.  Unfortunately, this has been misapplied to alloys like Grade 91. Guidance on proper use of acetate films is needed.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Survey of the Effect of Ceramic Coatings on Waterwall Tubes on Key Plant Historian Attributes
    09-Jun-2016

    Ceramic coatings have been installed on waterwalls primarily to protect from corrosion on the fireside.  The coatings have also been shown to be effective for mitigation of slag buildup/accumulation and ease of cleaning.  However, there is a need to evaluate whether the application of ceramic coatings to waterwalls has any effect on heat transfer in the waterwalls or other parts of the boiler.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Ultrasonic Waveform Feature Analysis
    08-Jun-2016

    Traditional ultrasonic techniques are based on measurements of wave velocity.  If current industrial ultrasonic equipment also contained advanced signal analysis or post processing capabilities this could be used to interrogate the waveform in order to provide for early creep damage detection.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Update of Fossil FAC Advisor to Incorporate Latest Research
    09-Jun-2016

    The ability to predict the occurrence of flow-accelerated corrosion (FAC) in an operating plant is key to safe and economical operation. EPRI’s Fossil FAC Advisor employs complex empirical models to predict the location and severity of FAC throughout a plant’s coolant system.  Program 63 (Boiler Reliability), in collaboration with Program 64 (Cycle Chemistry) have been sponsoring research on several FAC damage influence mechanisms including two phase flow and entrance effect.  An update to the FAC Advisor software is needed to incorporate these improved understandings in damage influence mechanisms.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Update of the BTFR Books (including Chemistry)
    09-Jun-2016

    Boiler and heat recovery steam generator (HRSG) tube failures have been the primary availability problem for operators of conventional and combined cycle plants for as long as reliable statistics have been kept for each generating source. In 2011 EPRI produced a three-volume set of documents to provide owners and operators with the technical basis to address tube failures and create permanent solutions (Boiler and Heat Recover Steam Generator Tube Failures: Theory and Practice.  EPRI report 1023603: Volume 1: Fundamentals, Volume 2: Water-Touched Tubes, Volume 3: Steam-Touched Tubes).  The significant amount of additional operating experience now available since first publication of this series needs to be captured and documented to provide improved guidance to reduce boiler tube failures.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Update of the BTFR Overview Document
    09-Jun-2016

    The Boiler Tube Failure Reduction (BTFR) Overview document provides valuable information for utilities developing a new BTFR program.  It provides examples of tools that can be used, an example of a corporate directive, and results from the original program development and rollout. Development of a more prescriptive appendix that will guide users in how to set up a new program is needed.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Usefulness of Post Exposure Testing
    09-Jun-2016

    Proper failure analysis and material testing of components removed from service is crucial to increasing the information database of operating power plants.  One example is information gathered from a recent evaluation of a failed Grade 91 header from Europe.  Detailed investigation into why the header failed early has guided EPRI to issue a new material specification.  Post-service-exposure testing may include small sample or standard size tests to better understand material degradation.  Understanding how dissimilar metal welds fail are also a possibility. 

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Validation of Oxide Thickness Lifing Models using Retiring Tubing
    09-Jun-2016

    The life assessment methodologies used for superheater and reheater tubing and contained in software like EPRI’s TULIP computer code are based on oxide grown in short-term elevated temperature tests and benchmarked against moderate term service-aged tubing.  With tubing being removed from service after extensive hours of operation (up to 500,000 hours), a unique opportunity is now available to measure oxide thickness and characterize the microstructure of these long-term service relevant oxides in order to benchmark and potentially improve the oxide thickness models used in EPRI life assessment methodologies.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center

Program Name: Boiler and Turbine Steam and Cycle Chemistry
text:
Overview

Program Description

Safety and availability loss due to failures are two key issues driving R&D on major fossil (coal, simple-cycle and combined-cycle gas) power plant components, especially in older plants. Operators need to minimize major causes of lost availability and associated maintenance costs related to corrosion and inadequate cycle chemistry to prevent boiler and/or heat recovery steam generator (HRSG) tube failures, steam turbine blade/disc failures and flow-accelerated corrosion (FAC).

Generation assets are experiencing increasing demands for greater operating flexibility, low-load operation, and more frequent unit shutdowns and cycling. These demands are raising additional key issues, including the dynamic impacts on plant systems and the preservation of equipment. Operators need to minimize and mitigate the increased risk of corrosion damage and component failures resulting from these operating regimes.

 The Electric Power Research Institute’s (EPRI’s) Boiler and Turbine Steam and Cycle Chemistry Program (Program 64) offers guidelines, technology, and training materials to help plant operators manage water/steam cycle chemistry, reduce unplanned outages and operations and maintenance (O&M) costs, and improve unit efficiency, as well as address chemistry requirements of flexible operation and proper equipment storage.

Research Value

The industry needs to balance the risks and costs of the largest, most costly equipment by using proven technologies to create solutions. By using the results of the R&D in this program, members can:

  • Improve overall unit availability and flexibility: Losses due to improper chemistry have a 1% or more effect on unit availability
  • Reduce steam turbine efficiency losses: Chemical and metallic oxide deposits reduce turbine efficiencies by up to 2%
  • Reduce chemistry-related boiler and HRSG tube failures
  • Reduce incidence of FAC damage and failures: FAC is both a personnel safety and component availability concern
  • Reduce chemistry-related O&M costs
  • Improve methods of major equipment preservation and storage
  • Reduce incidence of chemistry-related corrosion damage associated with low-load and cyclic operation
  • Improve cycle chemistry programs to excellent or world-class status

This program enhances the reliability and safety of water-steam-cycle-driven power plants (including coal, natural gas combined-cycle, biomass and solar thermal). The program R&D investigates the corrosion and deposition damage mechanisms of the components in water-steam cycles and provides guidelines, technologies, and management practices to maximize their reliable and safe operation.

Approach

Cycle chemistry guidelines, technologies, and training materials support efforts to minimize operating risks associated with corrosion and deposition. Technical tools developed through this program include unit-specific chemical treatment methods, operating limits, and monitoring guidelines to improve plant availability, efficiency, minimum load operation, startup times, and equipment storage. Chemistry guidelines address all critical aspects of fossil plant water/steam cycle chemistry, including boiler and feed-water treatments; chemistry and corrosion control in the steam turbine phase transition zone (PTZ); corrosion in the boiler/HRSG and water/steam cycle; FAC in high-energy piping and air-cooled condensers; deposition in major plant components in the water/steam cycle; shutdown/startup/layup; condensate polishing; makeup, instrumentation; chemical cleaning; and corrosion concerns in copper and other alternative materials of construction.

Members can use the guidelines, research information, and models developed from these activities to identify specific actions needed to address deficiencies consistent with individual unit characteristics. Application of risk assessments and best practices provide managers tools to evaluate conditional situations in an informed and cost-effective manner.

Accomplishments

Cycle chemistry guidelines, technologies, and training materials support efforts to minimize operating risks associated with corrosion and deposition. Technical tools developed through this program include unit-specific chemical treatment methods, operating limits, and monitoring guidelines to improve plant availability, efficiency, and startup times. Recent accomplishments include:

  • Complete set of cycle chemistry guidelines for all fossil plants and cycle chemistry treatments
  • Model for the corrosion and deposition process in boiler waterwalls and HRSG evaporator tubing
  • Advancement in the understanding of high-temperature oxides in supercritical waterwall tubes
  • Solvent evaluation and guidelines for chemical cleaning of supercritical steam generators
  • Interim guidelines to address corrosion issues in air-cooled condensers
  • Assessment and guidance for the application of amine chemistries in fossil plants
  • Modeling of corrosion product transport in the feedwater cycle
  • Guidelines for makeup water treatment
  • Cycle chemistry instrumentation selection and data validation
  • Advancement in the understanding of two-phase FAC in feedwater heaters, HRSG evaporators and heater drains
  • Benchmarking processes to assess plant or system chemistries
Key Activities

The program R&D for 2017 will focus on reducing corrosion damage associated with steam turbine and FAC. Specific efforts will include:

  • Development of amine treatment guidance
    • Neutralizing amines
    • Filming amines
  • Evaluation of the effectiveness of surface active chemistry such as filming amines for:
    • Mitigating feedwater component corrosion rates
    • Mitigating online and offline boiler tubing corrosion mechanisms
  • Development of monitoring techniques and methodologies for neutralizing and filming amine applications
  • Field evaluation/demonstration of new FAC monitoring techniques
  • Utilizing advanced instrumentation for enhanced cycle chemistry control
  • Alternative approaches to chemical cleaning and waste handling
  • Alternative approaches to equipment layup and preservation
  • Validation of steam purity limits and action levels

Last Updated
  • Advanced Approaches to Flow Accelerated Corrosion Control
    05-May-2016

    Component damage associated with flow-accelerated corrosion (FAC) is often very localized and isolated. The subtle variations in the environmental conditions (chemistry) are not identifiable as contributory to significant changes in the corrosion rate. Due to the confined nature of the corrosion activity, measurement of the results of the corrosion through techniques such as corrosion product transport or physical inspection are insensitive to reaction kinetics. Treatment regimes to mitigate corrosion activity are principally focused on establishing corrosion potentials which favor stabilization of the metal or metallic oxide; however, real-time measurement of the corrosion rate at the site in actual field or simulated conditions of localized attack resulting from FAC are typically unavailable.

    Electrochemical corrosion measurements at condensate/feedwater temperatures with a probe assembly designed to promote a mode of corrosion (e.g., orifice to simulate FAC) have been established using various techniques in laboratory test loops. The adaptation of these techniques to an online probe providing a real-time measurement of corrosion potential may permit for improved cycle chemistry monitoring and corrosion control. A second method using active acoustic emission external to pipework has also been demonstrated in the lab to effectively detect when FAC is active and when it has been stifled by switching to an oxidizing chemistry. The development of a field tool using this technology may lead to improved maintenance planning and corrosion control.

    Direct measurement of actual or simulated conditions would be beneficial in assessing the risk of upset condition of contamination or loss of chemical control and the corrosion hazards to operating conditions. Commercial development of online FACmonitoring of corrosion rates will provide not only improved guidance but an essential measurement of the cycle chemistry control.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Evaluations of Boiler / HRSG Corrosion Inhibition of Filming Amines
    05-May-2016

    Filming amines have been demonstrated to form hydrophobic films on subcritical and supercritical fossil boiler tubing. Filming has been achieved in both steam-touched (superheater/reheater) and water-touched (waterwall) tubing. A hydrophobic film is anticipated to inhibit corrosion by disrupting corrosion cells; however, to date the level of this corrosion inhibition for known offline and online boiler/HRSG tube corrosion mechanisms has not been quantified. There is the potential that film formation can impact corrosion fatigue, stress corrosion cracking, pitting, and underdeposit corrosion mechanisms. This project would look to establish the level of corrosion inhibition achieved in actual field applications of filming amines.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Filming Amines: Film Formation Online Monitoring Techniques
    05-May-2016

    Filming amines have advantages in corrosion control over traditional treatments. Through the formation of hydrophobic films on internal steam/water surfaces, they can disrupt corrosion cells. These products have been shown to significantly improve corrosion product transport in numerous fossil plant field applications. However, conventional power plant chemistry monitoring techniques are incapable of evaluating whether film formation has occurred, significantly complicating continuous control and optimization of filming amine-based treatments. Additionally, variation in filming amine formulations means that there is no single analytical technique for evaluating the presence of the chemical in water and steam samples. In addition, as the chemical formulations vary, there is also no universal correlation between the concentrations found in flowing water and steam samples and the level of film formation, which is how these chemicals afford protection.

    The industry needs a fully articulated treatment for filming amines that companies can use to optimize these treatments independently of chemical suppliers.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Flow-Accelerated Corrosion Guideline Update
    29-Aug-2016

    Feedwater system piping and tubing failures due to flow-accelerated corrosion (FAC) have occurred in conventional fossil plants and economizer/evaporator tubing in Heat Recovery Steam Generators (HRSGs) over at least the last 30 years. Worker fatalities have refocused attention on controlling damage due to FAC. These updated guidelines, which will describe the tasks and approaches required for an effective FAC control program in fossil and combined cycle plants, present a strategy for inspection- and cycle chemistry-based activities.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Neutralizing Amine Treatment Guideline
    05-May-2016

    Development of definitive science based guidelines for the use of neutralizing amines in the steam and water cycle treatment of fossil power plants. This project is the culmination of 6+ years of research into the application of neutralizing amines for control of cycle chemistry related damage mechanisms in fossil conventional and combined cycle plants. The document will develop guidance based on fundamental laboratory and field application research that has established:

    • the chemical properties of neutralizing amines through all temperatures and pressures in fossil steam and water cycles

    • an understanding of how neutralizing amines impact on all cycle chemistry related damage mechanisms in fossil steam and water cycles, &

    • the monitoring, application and control necessary with neutralizing amines to prevent damage and provide a fully optimized chemical treatment

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Smart Alarms: Development of Smart Chemistry Alarms
    06-Jun-2016

    Cycle chemistry monitoring is designed to prevent damage from occurring in the steam / water cycle. Due to the nature of cycle chemistry monitoring though the instruments can be subject to measurement errors as well as issues where a parameter is out of specification for a non-critical reason. This complicates the development of meaningful alarms for cycle chemistry monitoring. A common example of a measurement error are the errors associated with the measurement of cation conductivity once the cation column has exhausted. A common example of a non-critical out of specification conditions is the steam cation conductivity upset typically associated with a startup where carbon dioxide causes the measurement to go significantly out of specification. In both cases typical chemistry alarm logic would indicate a major excursion even though in both cases there was no actual risk of equipment damage. Since the vast majority of chemistry excursions are associated with these types of events, where the equipment is actually not at risk, operators can become desensitized to the chemistry alarms and assume they are always not relevant. It is possible using techniques from EPRI’s Cycle Chemistry Instrumentation Validation: Relationships of Cycle Chemistry Parameters Report 1019641, to develop smart chemistry alarms which only come in when an actual chemistry event is occurring such as a condenser leak or pH excursion.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Validating Action Level for Steam Purity
    05-May-2016

    Steam purity and other chemistry limits have different operating experience-based action levels, which allow for a time period of operation (e.g., 24 hours) above limits prior to forcing a unit shutdown to mitigate the risk of corrosion and deposition damage. These experiential action limits have not been validated. With many fossil units requiring increasingly flexible operations, in which they face a need to be available at specific times to meet the electricity supply requirement in markets where non-dispatchable renewables are dominant, quantifying the risk from out-of-spec operation becomes more important. This study will attempt to validate the values used for steam purity action levels by associating them with more specific corrosion risks.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Water Treatment System Guidance – Operator Editions
    06-Jun-2016

    Cycle chemistry guideline documents typically exceed 200 pages, and in the case of the makeup guidelines exceeds 800 pages. These documents are developed for specialist plant staff to provide a comprehensive understanding of the chemistry mechanisms and the overall treatment technology. The extensive detail in the documents make them generally inaccessible to plant generalist staff, such as plant operations staff. Despite the fact that these documents often contain much pertinent information for generalist staff’s roles and responsibilities. This project would distill the key guidance on the operation and troubleshooting of common demineralized water production equipment necessary for generalist operations staff.

Overview

Program Description

The power generation industry today requires strategies for maintaining turbine-generator system availability. This requires a focus not only on maintenance outage planning and execution, but on mitigating risk of unplanned outages as well. EPRI’s research program addresses the changing needs as the coal and gas fleet adapts to an evolving mission profile.

The EPRI’s Steam Turbines-Generators and Auxiliary Systems program (Program 65) supports continuous improvement in the safety and availability of steam turbines, generators, and auxiliary systems. It supports all aspects of turbine-generator component life-cycle management.  This support is accomplished through applied research in component life management, preventive maintenance, condition assessment, advanced monitoring, and control systems.

The program fosters collaboration among all industry stakeholders to support proactive strategies and best-practice sharing to solve industry reliability issues. The ongoing research and technology transfer activities fully support the needs of member organizations seeking to improve knowledge and effectiveness of turbine-generator system engineers.

Research Value

Using an integrated approach that incorporates work from related EPRI programs and industry input from user groups, this program focuses on reducing operations and maintenance (O&M) costs, managing risk, providing technical support for plant staff, and producing information to support upgrade studies and asset management strategies. Research results inform run/repair/replace decisions and provide detailed guidance for planning and performing critical overhaul and maintenance activities.

By participating in this program, plant operators obtain information that they can use to:

  • Reduce maintenance costs
  • Maintain high asset availability
  • Take proactive measures to lower operating risks
  • Extend component life
  • Increase staff technical expertise and awareness of industry issues

Involvement in the program can help:

  • Educate participants about turbine-generator (T-G) issues and solutions
  • Provide opportunities to share information with industry experts, engineers, major T-G original equipment manufacturers (OEMs), and vendor/service providers worldwide

This program improves the reliability and availability of steam turbines and generators, key drivers of overall plant performance for all asset types. It is essential for plant viability, and therefore bulk power availability, to cost-effectively maintain and operate large steam turbine generators. Safety of the power plant environment is also dependent of effective management of component failure risk, which is an element of this program. 

Approach

This program produces a range of deliverables including published guidelines, software, web applications, specialized sensors, and technical meetings/webcasts. Specific project selection is based on periodic advisor input and issue prioritization. The portfolio addresses current areas of need such as flexible operations, risk management, component upgrades, nondestructive examination, condition monitoring technologies, preventive maintenance (PM) guides, and repair strategies. Project advisory groups are involved in project scope creation, draft report reviews, and sharing of research implementation best-practices. The Turbine-Generator Users Group (TGUG), included with Program 65 membership, provides an effective forum for sharing emerging issues and research implementation experiences, as well as guiding further EPRI research in key areas. In addition, program members have access to recorded technical webcasts, an annual newsletter, and a catalog of past research abstracts. These documents allow members to easily disseminate the latest knowledge to key staff at the main office and plants.

Many members begin their participation in Program 65 research through regular participation in the TGUG biannual meetings. These meetings are member-run forums for sharing technical knowledge, awareness of emerging reliability issues, and O&M best-practices among turbine-generator system engineers. The group also provides a structured forum for engaging the major turbine-generator equipment manufacturers worldwide. Program members also are eligible to attend the workshops associated with the biannual group meetings.

Potential projects for the following year's R&D portfolio are discussed and prioritized with the program member advisors during the program advisory meetings held twice yearly. Roundtable discussions held at the advisory meetings, as well as the TGUG, provide opportunities for EPRI's collaborative R&D to immediately address emerging issues that broadly affect the industry.

Accomplishments

EPRI’s Steam Turbines-Generators and Auxiliary Systems program is recognized in the power industry as an authoritative source for up-to-date information on turbine-generator issues and solutions. Several documents, many updated periodically, have become guiding resources for the industry. These resources are increasingly important in training and educating new staff. EPRI has created a successful process for continual dialogue among all industry stakeholders, including commercial suppliers, that focuses on key technical issues and resolutions. Some key specific accomplishments of the program include:

  • Guidelines for reducing the time and cost of turbine-generator maintenance overhauls and inspections
  • Maintenance to address damage mechanisms specific to combined-cycle generators
  • Comprehensive guidelines for maintenance of electrohydraulic control (EHC) system fluid
  • Maintenance guides covering seven key turbine-generator auxiliary systems
  • Series of reports covering emerging technologies and procedures for assessing the health of generator insulation through monitoring
  • Guidelines for maintaining generator stator water cooling systems
  • Technical information to guide management of lubrication oil, lubrication systems, and journal bearings
  • Over 50 recorded webcast tutorials covering all aspects of turbine generator reliability
  • Comprehensive guidelines for troubleshooting turbine steam path damage, published in detailed reports as well as handbook formats
  • Turbine-generator equipment and component repair and purchase specifications
  • Web application for support of fluid film bearing run-replace decisions, Turbine-generator component nondestructive evaluation (NDE) testing and application guidance
  • Shaft torsional vibration measurement system demonstrated in commercial plants
  • Searchable compilation of over 1000 past TGUG meeting technical presentations as a resource for solving current turbine-generator issues.
Key Activities

The program R&D for 2017 will focus on component risk management, condition monitoring, plant operation changes due to flexible operation, and the education of utility plant staff through workshops, seminars, and webcasts. Specific efforts will include:

  • Assisting in flexible operation of coal assets through research on alternative layup protection strategies
  • Outage intervals of generators under flexible operation Lab demonstration of turbine valve and actuator online condition monitoring technology
  • Web-based resource to support members’ turbine-generator risk management programs
  • Shaft voltage/current monitoring to assess generator stator core condition
  • Electrohydraulic control system preventive maintenance
  • NDE of stress corrosion cracking in pinned-finger blade dovetails
  • Turbine-Generator User Group meetings and technical webcast series

Last Updated
  • Operations and Maintenance Cost Reduction
    • Electrohydraulic Control System Owner's Guide
      31-May-2016

      The electrohydraulic control system (EHC) supplies high pressure fluid to control operation of the steam turbine valves.  These valves are critical to protecting the steam turbine against overspeed events as well a regulating steam flow to match unit output demands.  The EHC system function is to maintain proper fluid purity and regulate pressure.  There is a need for a comprehensive guide for plant engineers responsible for the EHC system.  The guide should describe system operation, a preventive maintenance regime, troubleshooting tips, and advances in technology.

    • Guidelines for Reducing the Time and Cost of Turbine-Generator Maintenance Overhauls and Inspections: 2017
      08-Jun-2016

      Steam turbine generator outages are often critical path and therefore a major factor in asset availability.  Outage performance is achieved with proper planning, procurement, execution, and close-out. There is a need for a comprehensive industry resource that can educate and guide system owners through the entire outage process with best practices, work templates, and sample specifications. Common tasks such as balancing and alignment can consume time during the outage. There is a need for information and tools that ensure these tasks take the minimum time required at the end of the overhaul.

    • Operator Training Modules for Decisions Following Unusual Generator Events
      31-May-2016

      Unusual events such as stator core over fluxing, synchronization out of phase, loss of cooling water to hydrogen coolers, loss of excitation etc., can inflict significant damage and accelerate the aging process.

       

      Anecdotal evidence shows the industry experiences inadvertent energizing of the generator at standstill with significant rotor damage about every 24 month. Similarly, generator core over fluxing that may require partial core lamination replacement occurs about every 3 years. These incidents are caused by equipment failure but often made worse by human error.

       

      Since these events occur infrequently, the operator may not have prior experience to recognize the event and act to limit the consequential damage.

    • Outage Intervals for Generators used in Flexible Operations
      31-May-2016

      Most generators that are in service today were not specifically designed for weekly or daily shut downs. In addition, wide-spread use of renewable generation requires fast loading of conventional assets.

      The generator rotor and stator will experience frequent copper winding expansion, mechanical and thermal stresses, accelerated aging and low cycle fatigue for rotor components such as the “J strap”.  The effect of this on condition of each generator depends on design, vintage, past operating duty and maintenance. 

      Equivalent Operating Hours (EOH) calculations are often used to determine inspection intervals. An example is the VGB Guideline R 167 “Overhaul recommendations for turbo-generators”. The weighting factors used to multiply the operating hours, number of starts/stops, hours on turning gear, active and reactive power, and operating duty have been agreed upon by various original equipment manufacturers, however, the guideline does not provide technical basis for these weighing factors.

      There is a need to develop a process for determining inspection intervals that are plant-and machine-specific.

    • Shaft Voltage/Current Monitoring for Generator Condition Assessment
      31-May-2016

      U.S. power plans experience a generator core meltdown about every five years. This catastrophic failure occurs without warning and the root-cause investigation is hampered by destruction of the evidence.

      The stator core can be damaged during an outage. During operation vibration of loose core lamination, foreign object impact cause deterioration of core lamination insulation, which results in electrical currents circulating through the core material, causing it to severely overheat and melt.

      Generator condition monitors (GCM) provide strong indicators of severe overheating of the core insulation. The indication of overheating does not prevent the core damage, but it can limit the consequential damage and identify dangerous operating ranges.  The industry needs an earlier indication of core health degradation to reduce the risk of a costly catastrophic failure.

    • Turbine Generator Asset Management Benchmarking Process Development
      31-May-2016

      There is a continual need for a framework for conducting self-assessment of asset management practices relative to critical power plant equipment.  This self-assessment would ideally allow companies to benchmark their practices against a broad range of peer organizations, as well as against other standards to manage reliability.  This framework will provide justification for increasing spending on O&M, or point out areas where costs could be reasonably reduced without compromising reliability.  There needs to be a strong focus on application of new technology to assist in asset management cost reduction.

    • Turbine-Generator Fluid Forum
      31-May-2016

      Issues with properly maintaining lubrication oil and electrohydraulic control (EHC) fluid properties to minimize forced outage rates continue to challenge the industry.  Many of these problems arise from changes made by the fluid supplier that are not fully tested in a real operating environment.  Other issues are due to poor O&M practices that lead to fluid degradation.  Troubleshooting the resulting real-world fluid problems requires specific knowledge and experience.  There is a need for documented case studies of real plant fluid degradation issues to guide the industry in reducing unavailability.

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Turbine-Generator Risk Management
    • Bearing Action Advisor (BAA) Decision Support Tool
      31-May-2016

      There is need for a technical basis to support the run-replace decision that follows discovery of damage to the pad surfaces of fluid-film bearings during inspections. In previous years of activity in this project, Version 1.0 of the Bearing Action Advisor (BAA) web application was developed and made available for use by EPRI members. This web application allows the user to define basic parameters of fluid-film bearings. These bearing types include cylindrical or bumper thrust. With the parameters, the user can also provide input on observed damage. The BAA tool then calculates the load-carrying capacity and risk associated with a decision to keep the pad in service.

      In 2017, Version 1.0 of the BAA will be updated to Version 2.0, which will include tilt-pad bearing types. There will be a need following this release to promote use of the new software and support individual member applications. From this activity, enhancements to the tools can be defined for future releases.

    • On-line Turbine Valve Health Monitoring
      31-May-2016

      There is an industry need for improved condition-based maintenance of hydraulically-actuated steam valves used for turbine applications. The current time-based approach to scheduling overhaul intervals is, in many cases, conservative and results in increased maintenance costs. It is also possible that increased time-based intervals would fail to observe valve condition degradation, resulting in costly unplanned maintenance.

      This multi-year project will examine the technical feasibility of incorporating on-line valve condition monitoring, with a focus on the major component degradation mechanisms inherent to the valve and actuator.  The research will focus on the use of existing sensors, or new, commercially-available sensors that can be cost-effectively deployed on stop and control valves. New methods for analyzing the valve control signals as a way to detect emerging degradation will also be researched. The overall result of the EPRI research will be an assessment of the technology needs, costs, and impacts to the plant of widespread deployment of on-line valve condition monitoring. Follow-on work involving prototype system installation at a host plant would be considered based on the findings of this research.

    • Turbine-Generator Risk Management Resource
      31-May-2016

      Risk is increasingly used as the basis for decisions by plant asset owners who are seeking to lower O&M costs without compromising availability. System owners need easy access to up-to-date information that informs risk evaluation and mitigation. In addition, there is a need to efficiently communicate this risk in a form that is understood by a range of stakeholders.

      In 2014-15, EPRI has responded to this need for steam turbines and generators by developing the concept for a Turbine Generator Risk Management Resource (TGRMR). This web application is a structured, searchable repository for technical information as well as operational experience collected by EPRI that relates to turbine generator risk. This work culminated in the Version 1.0 production release of TGRMR during 2016.

Overview

Program Description

Despite possible restrictions on greenhouse gas emissions, fossil fuels will remain an important contributor to the world's power generation supply. For example, the U.S. Energy Information Administration predicts that global consumption of coal by power plants will increase by 50% between now and 2035, and global consumption of natural gas will increase by 70% over that same time period.

Intrinsic differences exist between coal and natural gas power plants, but they share a commonality in many of the issues that will affect their future use. These issues create a need for long-term research with three primary goals, all of which are addressed by EPRI’s Fossil Fleet for Tomorrow program (Program 66):

  • Develop new methods for generating power from fossil fuels that are dramatically more efficient and reduce CO2 emissions.
  • Develop cost-effective processes to capture CO2 and optimize their integration in the power plant to minimize the impact on generating efficiencies and cost of electricity.
  • Research technologies that can operate in a highly flexible manner to meet fluctuating power demands.
Research Value

The program focuses on identifying and advancing a portfolio of advanced fossil fuel-power generation technologies with dramatically higher generating efficiencies than the current fossil fleet. These are coal- and natural gas-based technologies not commercially available today, including Rankine cycles with steam temperatures exceeding 1200°F (650°C); closed Brayton cycles using CO2 as the working fluid; integrated gasification combined-cycles (IGCCs) with gas turbine firing temperatures exceeding 2700°F (1500°C); oxygen-blown combustion processes; and power generation concepts based on chemical looping and fuel cells. Beginning in 2016 the portfolio was expanded to include reciprocating internal combustion engines and large-scale, non-battery energy storage systems such as compressed air storage that could help fossil plants meet flexible operating requirements.

The program's R&D scope:

  • Provides engineering and economic information on advanced fossil power technologies to support generation asset owners’ decision-making processes;
  • Serves as a source of the best-available information on the status of advanced fossil power generation technology.
  • Shortens the development time for promising CO2 capture technologies through the cosponsoring support of the U.S. Department of Energy National Carbon Capture Center – a "plug-and-play" pilot- and sub-pilot-plant-scale testing facility.
  • Identifies the critical R&D tasks needed for promising technologies to advance toward commercial scale.

The goal of this program’s research is to provide society with economic options that allow continued use of abundant fossil fuels while also addressing the environmental concerns attendant with those fuels. 

Approach

EPRI works with the Department of Energy (DOE), the International Energy Agency, technology suppliers and developers, and numerous international R&D organizations to coordinate efforts and resources. This program’s scope includes both natural gas- and coal-based power generation technologies that decrease CO2 emissions.

  • Engineering and economic evaluations and market assessments of advanced fossil generation options help power generators screen technology options and assess the economics, expected environmental performance, and technical and economic risks of a broad range of technologies.
  • Co-sponsorship of DOE's National Carbon Capture Center (NCCC) allows EPRI to have input on the selection of technologies tested at the center and provides EPRI with early knowledge of the test results to inform its own research.
  • EPRI's  staff support the Fossil Fleet for Tomorrow program and identify key technical challenges faced by individual technologies and identify logical R&D pathways to surmount those challenges.
Accomplishments

Highlight of the program include:

  • A comprehensive review of “novel and innovative” power generation concepts such as chemical looping and cycles that use supercritical CO2 as the working fluid. These reviews now form the basis of an online database of novel and innovative fossil power technologies accessible by members.
  • Presentations to policymakers, written responses to DOE “requests for information,” and other outreach activities have provided guidance to members and key power industry stakeholders on the status of advanced fossil technology research, development, and demonstration activities.
  • Continued progress in the development of high-temperature boiler and steam turbine materials for ultra-supercritical (USC) steam conditions up to 760ºC (1400ºF). Testing of the world’s first steam loop operating at these elevated temperatures in a coal-fired power plant was completed after more than 16,000 hours of exposure to hot flue gas. The Program 66 team is now serving as the technical leaders of the US DOE/Ohio Coal Development Office Advanced USC Component Test (ComTest) project.
  • Concepts were examined to meet a proposed CO2 emission limit of 1100 lb/MWhr (500 kg/MWhr) for new coal power plants, which have shown that the thermal efficiencies of such plants could be several percentage points higher than the fleet average of existing US coal power plants.
Key Activities

The program R&D for 2017 will focus on informing stakeholders about the status of advanced fossil power generation technologies that could be available for commercial application in the 2020s and beyond. It will also make targeted investments in the development of the most promising options or in technologies that could have applications in multiple processes. Specific efforts may include:

  • A global “technology watch” of advanced combustion-based fossil fuel power generation technologies.
  • Support of the DOE's National Carbon Capture Center and advanced Rankine cycle materials development projects.
  • A detailed economic evaluation of a advanced power generation technology.
  • An assessment of the technology status and economics of large-scale, non-battery-based energy storage systems as an alternative to operating fossil power plants at part-load where they are less efficient when demand for fossil power is low.

  • PS66A: Advanced Technology Evaluations
    07-Jun-2016

    The objectives of this project set is to provide the public and power generation industry with up-to-date information on the development status and expected economics of advanced fossil fuel (primarily coal and natural gas) power generation options that could offer significant improvements over today's technology, particularly for power plants that must limit CO2 emissions.

    New learning expected from this project includes up-to-date economics of coal and natural-gas-based power generation options that incorporate commercial or near-commercial technologies for CO2 capture; insights into the timelines for the development of more advanced fossil power generation technologies such as Rankine cycles with steam temperatures exceeding 1200°F (650°C); and natural gas-fired closed Brayton cycles which use supercritical CO2 as the working fluid. 

    • Detailed Feasibility Study
      07-Jun-2016

      International engineering-procurement-construction contractors and equipment suppliers offer construction cost databases that are constantly updated as new power projects are completed. It is very expensive for individual companies to perform annual detailed engineering assessments of each major generation technology – as much as several hundred thousand dollars per technology -- needed to develop performance and cost data for critical asset decisions. The industry can significantly reduce those costs by collaborating to get the information that they need for generation planning purposes. EPRI’s Fossil Fleet for Tomorrow program’s Engineering-Economic Evaluation project (1-106013) uses collaborative resources to produce up-to-date cost and performance estimates for current and emerging coal and natural gas power generation technologies. This 2017 detailed engineering project will focus on the cost and performance of coal gasification and natural gas-based technologies that incorporate carbon capture.

    • PS66A Special Topics
      07-Jun-2016

      Each year the Fossil Fleet Advanced Technology Evaluations project set (PS66A) intends to investigate a special topic which will be chosen based on feedback from members.  Topics covered in previous years include reciprocating internal combustion engines (RICE) and whether coal-fired power plants could meet proposed CO2 emissions standards by moving to high efficiency technologies.

  • PS66B: Advanced Technology Development
    07-Jun-2016

    New power generation technologies take many years to move from concept to commercial reality. Consequently, to have advanced fossil fuel power generation options ready for commercial use in the next decade, critical research and development activities need to be carried out now and must be sustained in the future.

    This project set will nurture enabling technologies which underpin several promising power generation options, and also advance key options by either identifying the important R&D needs or by direct investment in R&D projects aimed at moving technologies up the development ladder.

    New learning may include increased understanding of the technical barriers of specific power generation technologies, improvements in materials that could be used in multiple advanced power generation technologies, and identification of design options which could increase the flexible operation capability of new fossil fuel power plants.  A special topic to be investigated in 2017 will be the status of large-scale, non-battery energy storage technologies which could be used in conjunction with large fossil power plants to meet demands for variable power output.  This will complete the investigation into this topic which was started in 2016.

    • IGCC R&D Roadmap
      09-Jun-2016

      The second generation of integrated gasification combined-cycle (IGCC) power plants is now being built or planned following nearly two decades of commercial demonstration at multiple units. State-of-the-art IGCC plants have efficiencies equivalent to that of pulverized coal power plants while exhibiting equal or superior environmental performance and lower water use. Although this technology has been and is being demonstrated in several gasification plants, a number of key technological advances have also been identified that could contribute to increasing net plant efficiency by more than 11 percentage points while cutting the cost of electricity in half. It is key for future deployment of this technology that CO2 capture strategies are integrated without significantly impacting the overall plant efficiency.

    • Non-Battery Bulk Energy Storage
      09-Jun-2016

      Ever-increasing penetration of non-dispatchable renewable power generation to the power grids in many parts of the world have resulted in large variability in the operation of the dispatchable power components, mainly coal and gas generation. Not only does this relatively unpredictable changing power demand place physical stress on the plants, it also leads to inefficient operation of these assets which can result in a net increase in the specific CO2 emission rate. In addition to stand-alone energy storage technologies, fossil plants with carbon capture technology could contribute to short-term storage of renewable energy by adjusting the operation of the capture process when electricity demand is very high or very low.

      With carbon capture-enabled fossil plants available, the salient questions to be investigated are:

      • What are the cost and performance characteristics of commercially available storage systems?

      • What energy storage strategy best fits with carbon capture enabled fossil plants?

      • How do energy storage-capable carbon capture processes compare with standalone technologies on a techno-economic basis?

    • Optimizing Integration of PCC with Fossil Power Plants
      10-Jun-2016

      Over the past decade significant research has been applied to improving both CO2 post-combustion capture (PCC) technology and fossil power plant efficiency.  However, there still remains an opportunity to improve the integration between a fossil power plant and a PCC system.  This project will examine options for  decreasing the cost and improving the overall efficiency of a fossil (coal or gas) power plant with CCS.

Overview

Program Description

Instrumentation, controls, and automation are enabling technologies that cut across all areas of plant operations and performance. Every component, process, system, and person relies on the data and information collected from sensors and instrumentation, as well as the computed response and actions from actuation hardware, process controls, and automation. The integration and advancement of these technologies contribute to the safe, reliable, efficient, and cost-effective operation of the plant.

The Electric Power Research Institute’s (EPRI’s) Instrumentation, Controls, and Automation program (Program 68) identifies, develops, and demonstrates state-of-the-art sensing, monitoring, analytics, automation, and control system technologies to manage and optimize power generation assets including equipment condition, system performance, and plant optimization. As large-scale central generating stations undergo mission profile changes and the installed infrastructure ages, there is renewed emphasis on the need for more comprehensive monitoring, diagnostics, and automation of select operations along with upgrades in process control schemes.

Research Value

Maintaining the availability of existing power generating plants, integration in to/with a diverse generating portfolio, engaging a new workforce, and enabling future plant performance are critical for the power industry. Through collaborative R&D, Program 68 focuses on providing integrated instrumentation and control (I&C) solutions that enhance processes, technologies, and operations, empowering program member companies to:

  • Research on broader implementation of automation and improved process controls for operational performance.
  • Improve reliability through integrated anomaly detection, diagnostics, and prognostics.
  • Identify and develop sensor and instrumentation technology to support automation and control functions, as well as approaches for comprehensive equipment condition monitoring and system performance. 
Approach

Technology development and demonstration projects address critical aspects of plant instrumentation and control systems, including advanced controls, automation, improved loop tuning, and equipment diagnostics. Applied research is conducted in collaboration with host sites at member utilities, expert consultants, universities, laboratories, and equipment vendors.  Products developed by this program include technical reports, guidelines, process specifications, webcasts, and technology transfer workshops.

Accomplishments

Control engineers, system owners and technicians focus on optimizing instrumentation and control systems to improve plant reliability and efficiency while minimizing cost. This collaborative R&D program has provided:

  • Guidelines on instrument selection, calibration, data analysis, control loop tuning, and control loop performance monitoring.
  • Technical reports documenting  demonstrations of new technologies for advanced control algorithms, automated controls tuning, multi-loop controls tuning, and application of model predictive controls.
  • Technical reports documenting demonstrations of sensors, wireless data transmission, and advanced anomaly detection algorithms.
  • Technical reports and guidelines for digital system configuration management, I&C steam temperature control strategies, automation for cycling, data integration for process control, and cyber security practices.
  • Fleet-Wide Monitoring Interest Group (FWMIG)
Key Activities

The I&C program for 2017 will focus on the following advancements, demonstrations, and technology transfer efforts:

  • Advanced control technologies with a focus on operational flexibility
  • Instrumentation and control technological advances
  • Collaborative demonstration on improved steam temperature control for heat recovery steam generators (HRSG)
  • Fleet-Wide Monitoring Interest Group (FWMIG)

  • Advanced Control Series: Remote Control and Operation of Renewable Assets
    15-Jun-2016

    The assets for power generation are becoming more diverse and distributed with the introduction of solar, wind, hydroelectric and the introduction of hydro pumped storage sites. Ownership and operation of the renewable assets is also changing which may change the responsible parties for operation and maintenance.  Many renewables assets are monitored and controlled remotely with on-site maintenance and operation being overseen by personal that oversee over a large regional area. Profiling current practices and approaches to remote process control, operation, and monitoring are needed to support transitioning of the renewable assets into the mainstream portfolio of power generation companies and members.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Demonstration - Steam Temperature Control Strategies for Combined Cycle Units
    14-Jun-2016

    Many combined-cycle (CC) units are being operated differently from original design and as a result, accelerated degradation of components and failures have increased.  In addition, the baseline process control schemes around the Heat Recovery Steam Generator (HRSG) are not adequate for the changes in duty cycle and are contributing to degraded performance. For HRSGs, inadequate steam temperature and attemperator control are important areas for improved measurement and control. Other CC plants, in an effort to avoid HRSG damage due to poor steam temperature control, operate at reduced steam temperatures and pay a penalty in reduced thermal performance.

    There is an industry need to demonstrate improved process control of steam temperature control and attemperator operation in an effort to reduce damage and improve thermal performance.  This project will survey advanced control system strategies and select an approach that will be demonstrated through simulation as well as testing on a full-scale CC unit.  Successful completion of this project will allow operators of CC unit’s s to determine whether improvements in steam temperature control can be cost-effective and lessen impact on component degradation. 

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Demonstration of Low Cost Sensors: Acoustic sensors
    14-Jun-2016

    A number of new or emerging low cost and/or wireless sensors are available for monitoring process, equipment, or component condition. However few if any of these sensors were developed for power plant applications.  While the idea of pervasive sensing throughout a plant is attractive, the cost/benefit justification is not significant enough to warrant the installation of many of the commercially available sensor systems.  The value proposition is more attractive when the sensors are low cost and have a minimal installation effort (e.g. wireless) and provides data that can identify a change, issue, or fault. There is a need to select and demonstrate low cost sensors to determine usefulness in performing power generation specific measurements for more efficient operations and maintenance. 

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Improved Sensors and Expanded Measurement Options for HRSG Operation
    14-Jun-2016

    The growth of new Combined Cycle (CC) units and increased duty cycles for the installed base of CC units has created new needs for these plants including a heightened interest in improving the operation and condition monitoring of the Heat Recovery Steam Generator (HRSG) portion of the plant. Many HRSG designs have limited instrumentation and employ basic process control which impacts the ability to optimize HRSG performance and assess the condition of the equipment. With an increase in duty cycle, components, materials, and equipment are stressed causing accelerated degradation. Additionally, rapid ramp rates tend to create greater distributions in heat and drive the process controls to irregular modes and experience more extreme oscillations in the process. To make improvements in process control and enact a more comprehensive condition monitoring effort of critical components within the HRSG, more instrumentation and continuous measurement of process variables are needed.  

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Online Monitoring Guide for Power Plant Equipment Condition
    14-Jun-2016

    On-line monitoring (OLM) of equipment provides early detection of equipment degradation and failure; and OLM is an expanding practice for the industry.  There are varying degrees of OLM implementation across the industry including choice of sensor types, selection of measurement categories, insight into data quality, and degree of data utilization. Because of the continued investment and expanding interest in OLM, there is a need to provide a current objective-based guide to support members in their efforts to select and implement on-line sensors along with using the data collected in an effective manner. 

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Use of Wireless Sensors for Control: Technical and Regulatory Concerns
    14-Jun-2016

    Wireless sensors are appealing to power industry because of low installation cost and reduced time required for installation. Power industry has started adopting wireless sensors for monitoring power plant assets; however, there are technical and regulatory concerns in adopting wireless sensors for control purposes. In order to address these challenges it is important for the power industry to gather and document the information regarding these challenges and to understand where wireless may be used in a safe and secure manner.
