Overview

Program Description

The Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) works with  organizations to collaboratively research and develop maintenance processes and technologies that improve the safety, reliability, and performance of equipment and plant organizations. EPRI’s Maintenance Management & Technology program (Program 69) provides research that enables power generation plant owners and operators to address common industry challenges related to maintenance program effectiveness and functionality. Projects include efforts to identify potential causes of equipment failures, effectively monitor and assess the condition of equipment, and proactively plan for equipment maintenance. A significant part of these research efforts involves the management and communication of data and information necessary for monitoring and maintaining power plant assets.

Research Value

This program helps its members transition to, and sustain, the most efficient and effective practices associated with plant maintenance. The key attributes of an optimized program are adoption of information management needed to support a condition-based approach to maintenance, and replacement of costly corrective maintenance with proactive preventive maintenance. The focus of this program is on providing an integrated solution that addresses the needs for processes, technologies, and skilled people, which enables condition-based maintenance. Using the results of this program, members can:

  • Achieve operation and maintenance excellence through an integrated approach that includes process improvements, technologies, and knowledge management.
  • Address current issues associated with the need for flexible plant operations, asset retirement, and new reliability standards.
  • Standardize O&M programs, processes, and procedures.
  • Increase plant availability and reliability through improved maintenance management and organizational efficiency.

Approach

The ongoing evolution of enhanced plant maintenance processes and technology is an inherently collaborative activity, involving member companies, industry experts, and EPRI staff. The program focuses on the following areas:

  • Plant maintenance processes that focus on development and improvement of both fundamental and new best practices experienced throughout the industry. Technical reports covering detailed aspects of condition-based maintenance, work management, maintenance basis, outage planning/execution, human factors, corrective action and continuous improvement.

  • Plant maintenance technology R&D that facilitates the deployment of these technologies, which are essential to achieving desired performance. This includes technologies to support the identification and optimization of preventive maintenance (PM) tasks, the management of predictive maintenance (PdM), diagnostics, prognostics, and risk management. The software products in this project offer databases members can use to apply component and system knowledge and perform effective equipment analysis.

  • Users groups, meetings, and workshops that provide a structure for sharing peer information about, and experiences with, plant maintenance. These venues include the Equipment Reliability Interest Group (ERIG), Plant Health Monitoring User Group, Work Planning User Group, Digital Worker Interest Group, Condition Maintenance User Group (which incorporates the Predictive Maintenance User Group (PdMUG), Vibration Technology Forum (VTF), Infrared Thermography Acoustics Forum [formerly IRUG], Lubrication and Bearing Workshop), and others.
Accomplishments

Asset managers, maintenance managers, engineers, planners, and system owners need resources related to processes and technologies, to help achieve high performance in plant availability, reliability and efficiency. To help supply these resources, this program has developed:

  • Products supporting the development and application of plant reliability processes and standards at members’ facilities.
  • Products that aid in benchmarking.
  • More than 200 technical reports, technical updates, and software products that cover both strategic and tactical maintenance processes including all aspects of preventive/predictive maintenance, work planning, work execution, outage management, and human performance.
  • A software package to facilitate integrated equipment diagnostics (Asset Fault Signature Database and Diagnostic Advisor) and prognostics (Remaining Useful Life Database and Remaining Useful Life Advisor). These products include databases of known equipment fault indicators and failure models that are used to assist plant staff with both the diagnosis and prediction of plant equipment failures.
Key Activities

The program R&D for 2017 will maintain the focus on improvements in maintenance processes and related technologies. Specific research subject areas will include some of the following topics:

  • Identifying and developing advancements in condition monitoring and assessment techniques for electrical equipment.
  • Documenting the process for developing a model maintenance program for a given plant system.
  • Standardizing the assessment process by addressing each aspect of plant operations and maintenance and providing an assessment tool in which policy, process, and execution can be evaluated without relying on the assessor’s experience and objectivity.
  • Developing a comprehensive configuration management guideline that addresses maintaining design requirements, drawings, procedures, and documentation throughout the life of the plant.
  • Developing a guideline to implement an equipment reliability program for a fossil generation organization that may be experiencing changes in its mission profile.
  • Performing a comparative analysis of the two major approaches to asset management in the UK and the US to determine strengths and weakness of each approach and where each would best apply, as well as comparing these two equipment reliability programs to the major asset management standards -- namely AP 913 and ISO55000/PAS55.
  • Developing a guideline for electromagnetic signature measurement and detection.
  • Conducting new research testing and demonstrations that enhance and advance smart monitoring and diagnostics (Smart M&D) capabilities.

In addition, Program 69 provides opportunities for its members to network, share experiences and learn together through the various user/interest groups, including:

  • Condition-Based Maintenance User Group (CBMUG)

  • Infrared Thermography Acoustics Forum

  • Lubrication Forum

  • Vibration Technology Forum

  • Equipment Reliability Interest Group

  • Work Planning Interest Group

  • Digital Worker Interest Group

  • Plant Health Monitoring User Group

EPRI 3420 Hillview Avenue, Palo Alto, California 94304 © Electric Power Research Institute, Inc. 2001-2017 All rights reserved

Overview

Program Description

Combustion modifications should be viewed as the first step in any emissions control strategy. Recent and impending regulations, such as the Cross State Air Pollution Rule (CSAPR), the Mercury and Air Toxics Standard (MATS), the Effluent Limitation Guidelines (ELG), and the European Industry Emissions Directive (IED), will make an even stronger case to deploy cost-effective combustion-based controls for not only the reduction of nitrogen oxides (NOx), but also as part of a holistic approach for cost-effective reduction of SO3, mercury and other air toxics, unburned carbon, and effluent treatment.

Forced outages due to fireside corrosion, circumferential cracking, and deposition of ash (e.g., slagging and fouling), which in many cases are significantly exacerbated by low-NOx operation, remain a costly issue. As coal plants shift to lower-cost/lower-quality coals, innovative and cost-effective solutions are needed to maintain boiler tube reliability.

Two general issues addressed in the EPRI’s Combustion and Coal Quality Impacts program (Program 71) include combustion and fuels impacts on boiler tube life, and impacts of combustion modifications and fuel quality on emissions. Both of these issues require an understanding of fuel quality considerations; accurate measurement and control of coal and air flow to individual burners; and improved performance of mills, burners, and other critical combustion -related hardware. This program provides the knowledge and resources needed to develop, demonstrate, and apply cost-effective combustion-based solutions to resolve these and other combustion- and fuels-related issues.

Research Value

The Combustion and Coal Quality Impacts Program focuses on a holistic approach to combustion and fuel quality impacts, including emissions, performance, and reliability.

  • Avoiding a single forced outage due to fireside corrosion, circumferential cracking, or slagging and fouling is important to plant operation and reliability.
  • Optimization of the combustion process can enable improved performance of downstream environmental controls. For example; lowering of furnace gas temperatures may substantially reduce mercury, as well as CO2 (through improved boiler efficiency), and reduce SO3 oxidation through the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) system. Lower NOx levels entering the SCR serve to reduce reagent consumption (lowering operating costs and benefitting mercury oxidation) and extend catalyst life.
  • Quantification of the increased operating costs associated with lower-quality coals can enable informed decisions on acceptable blend ratios and fuel specifications, to be balanced against savings in fuel costs.

Program 71 benefits the power industry and public at large by improving the reliability of fossil-based power generation (e.g., by reducing boiler tube failures), and reducing emissions.

Approach

Projects will help mitigate fireside corrosion and other operability issues in low-NOx systems; develop and demonstrate cost-effective emissions controls through combustion modifications; and assess the impacts of coal quality on emissions, performance, and reliability. The general approach is to develop and demonstrate cost-effective solutions to key issues, conduct comprehensive demonstrations, correlate data, and provide ample technology transfer through the publication of best practices, technical updates, and user-led forums (webcasts, meetings, and workshops).

Accomplishments

Over the last several decades, EPRI has led the power industry in identifying, quantifying, and seeking cost-effective solutions to operability and performance issues in fossil generating stations associated with low-emissions operations such as fireside corrosion, circumferential cracking, and fuel quality impacts. Accomplishments include:

  • Predictive tools to assess the impacts of coal quality on the total cost of operation.
  • Development of advanced models to predict and assess methods of combating fireside corrosion consequential to implementation of low-NOx systems;
  • Innovative, cost-effective technologies for combustion NOx controls, such as advanced staging methods.
  • Slagging and fouling guidelines that offer quantifiable methods of identification and mitigation methods for ash deposition issues.
  • Site evaluations of gaseous species measurements using advanced laser diagnostic tools, to quantify improvements in emissions reductions and boiler efficiency.
  • Best practices for plant engineers and operators to understand and respond to instances of accelerated fireside corrosion and circumferential cracking of boiler tubes.
  • Laboratory and field assessments of various boiler tube coatings for their ability to mitigate fireside corrosion while minimizing circumferential cracking.
  • Sponsorship of workshops, conferences, and webcasts in which funders and other key industry participants can share ideas and best practices and outline needed solutions.
Key Activities

The P71 program R&D for 2017 will continue to focus on a holistic approach to combustion optimization, including combustion and fuel quality-related impacts on emissions, performance, and operability. Specific efforts may include:

  • Combustion issues experienced during flexible operations, including load-following during periods of high ramping, lower load operation, and the use of lower quality coals and blends.
  • Cost-effective solutions to minimize the impacts of low-NOx combustion and fuel quality on boiler tube life, such as fireside corrosion, circumferential cracking, and ash deposition.
  • A holistic approach to assess the impacts of combustion modifications strategies on all pollutants, including NOx, fly ash LOI, CO, mercury, and SO3.
  • Predictive tools to assess the impacts of coal quality, boiler design, and operation on emissions, performance, and reliability (including fireside corrosion and slagging and fouling).
  • Strategic use of co-firing gas to ensure fuel flexibility, and as a method of minimizing emissions and operability issues.
  • Advanced sensors and feedback loops to quantify gaseous species distributions (i.e., O2 and CO) and enable corrective actions that optimize fuel/air distribution in the boiler.

Last Updated
  • PS71A: Combustion and Fuel Impacts on Boiler Tube Life
    07-Jun-2016

    Cost-effective solutions are needed to reduce the number of costly forced outages stemming from fireside corrosion, circumferential cracking, slagging and fouling, and other boiler tube impacts consequential to low-NOx operation and fuel quality considerations. This will entail the ability to quantify the tradeoffs between savings in fuel, NOx reduction, load cycling, etc. against the cost of tube failures and other operability issues. For example: Will the savings achieved by using a lower cost fuel or blend, or by achieving a lower NOx level, or by increasing the rate of load cycling, outweigh the negative impact on boiler tube life, and the increased probability of early boiler tube failures?

    In addition to combustion and fuel quality considerations, this Project Set will continue its assessment of utilization of boiler tube coatings.  Although weld overlays are a proven method of alleviating fireside corrosion, associated problems with circumferential cracking may be exacerbated.  Accordingly, holistic understanding of potential solutions and trade-offs are needed.  

    This Project Set also assesses the use of gas co-firing as a method of not only increasing fuel flexibility, but of a way to minimize operability impacts and reducing emissions.

    • Combustion Impacts on Operations
      03-May-2016

      This project is being undertaken in response to the increased demand of coal-fired power generators to operate over an extended load range.  According, there is a need to better understand issues and develop best practices associated with low load operation and increase in the number of cold starts, including impacts on reliability (e.g., corrosion), emissions (e.g., operation without SCR), and performance.

    • Fuel Flexibility and Predictive Tools
      03-May-2016

      Utility fossil fuel boilers are designed to meet performance guarantees based on a “specified range” of fuel properties. With continued competitive pressures, pulverized coal fired units have or are planning to switch to lower priced coals and blends which may substantially alter fuel properties from the original design. This may result in impaired plant performance caused from ash deposition issues (slagging and fouling) and fireside corrosion. To minimize these impacts on Boiler tube life and reliability, understanding the consequences of changes in fuel properties and/or blends is critical.  Current prediction techniques and tools are limited for certain coal types and do not include the non-additive fuel interactions or boiler operating parameters when firing blends, leading to inaccurate predictions. Therefore, there is a need to develop and validate the next generation expert advisory tools which provide reliable predictions depending on the boiler design, operational conditions and fuel properties.

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • PS71B: Cost-Effective Emissions Control via Combustion Modifications
    07-Jun-2016

    Combustion modifications are the most cost-effective first-line approach to reducing emissions—primarily of NOx but also mercury and other air toxics, sulfur trioxide (SO3), CO, and unburned carbon. This project set will assess emissions reductions that are achievable with combustion modifications in a holistic manner by considering fuel quality, boiler design, flexible boiler operating modes, as well as constraints imposed by other site-specific factors.

    In addition to emissions reduction in the combustion process itself, this project set will also assess the impacts of combustion modifications and fuel quality on downstream environmental controls. For example, consideration will be given to the impacts of furnace exit gas temperature (FEGT) on mercury oxidation and SO3 formation across the SCR, and total emissions impacts on ESP, baghouse, FGD, sorbents, as well as wastewater treatment and solids disposal systems.

    This project also will also evaluate (1) the application of advanced sensors and monitors and their benefit when used to optimize the overall combustion process, and (2) strategic use of gas co-firing as a cost-effective means of lowering emissions.

    • Combustion Optimization and Advanced Measurements
      04-May-2016

      Identification of optimum operating scenarios at coal plants requires the ability to evaluate potential tradeoffs between the boiler and different pollution control systems. For example, the increased deployment of scrubbers for SO2 control, has resulted in many utilities burning a broader range of lower cost coals, or coal blends, many of which have a higher sulfur content. As a result, operational efficiency tradeoffs can arise between boiler operations and achieving compliance for multiple pollutant species. Consequently, a need exists for a holistic methodology that enables utilities to determine the least overall cost approach for maintaining NOx, CO, Hg, and SO3 emissions compliance through both boiler and SCR operations, while also taking into account potential cost impacts that may be encountered with different operating scenarios (i.e. lower furnace water wall wastage from deep staging with higher sulfur fuels). In support of this effort, necessary tools will ultimately be developed and assessed for identifying optimum boiler and SCR operating conditions.

      The methodology will not only take into account potential tradeoffs between boiler staging versus SCR inlet NOx levels and reagent consumption for achieving a target NOx emission level, but impacts on mercury oxidation due to changes in fly ash UBC levels, flue gas ammonia concentrations at the SCR inlet, SCR inlet temperature, as well as flue gas SO3 concentrations.

      Given the broad shift in coal plants from base load dispatch, to a cycling response to system load demand, advanced measurements and integration with optimization technologies will also be investigated. The goal of these investigations will be to identify cost effective approaches capable of providing enhanced dynamic boiler fuel/air control capability in response to changing loads with varying mill patterns and operating conditions.

    • Holistic Assessment of Combustion Modifications
      04-May-2016

      Boiler criteria pollutant emissions (NOx, CO, SOx, particulates), and trace toxics (mercury, HCl) are a function of coal properties, boiler design, as well as boiler operating parameters, as well as the ability to optimize the boiler fuel/air distribution. Trade-offs frequently can arise between minimization of criteria pollutants and overall boiler performance, which will be assessed using case studies and other means. The ultimate goal will be to benchmark emissions performance associated with optimum boiler operating conditions as a function of coal type and boiler design based on ability to optimize controllable combustion parameters (mill performance, fuel/air distribution, etc.) to better enable identification of optimum boiler operational strategies.

      This project will also examine future emerging technology options, such as ultra-low NOx burners, combustion additives, as well as other enhanced combustion technologies that do not have a well-documented application history within the coal-fired boiler utility industry. These technologies will be assessed through (1) maintenance of an advanced NOx control website, which summarizes pertinent findings from conferences, journals, and a review of patent applications and awards, (2) assessment of advanced coal cleaning methods, (3) laboratory or field evaluations of new hardware or combustion enhancement additives, as well as (4) assessment of the performance and accuracy of new combustion diagnostic tools such as TDLs for SO3, NO, and other gaseous species.

EPRI 3420 Hillview Avenue, Palo Alto, California 94304 © Electric Power Research Institute, Inc. 2001-2017 All rights reserved

Overview

Program Description

Power generators need information on long-term performance, applicability, and costs of technologies for controlling mercury and other air toxics, NOx, SO2, acid gases, particulates, and other pollutants. Balance of plant (BOP) and multi-media issues resulting from all environmental controls need to be better understood and addressed. Technology advancements such as lower-cost and better-performing sorbents and SCR catalysts improvements to allow more flexible operations, and information on the economic incentives for using alternative, lower-quality, or blended fuels.

Research Value

The Electric Power Research Institute’s (EPRI’s) Integrated Environmental Controls program (Program 75) R&D efforts will focus on minimizing capital and operating costs, reliability risks, and BOP impacts of environmental compliance. Program members can benefit through:

  • Optimized performance and resolution of operability issues for sorbent injection systems, SCR catalysts, electrostatic precipitators (ESPs), baghouses, and flue gas desulfurization (FGD) controls.
  • Assessments of the impact of flexible operations for all pollutants, including cycling and load-following.
  • Impacts of lower quality fuels and blends on all environmental controls, along with methods of minimizing the negative impacts of lower quality fuels;
  • Demonstrations of lower-cost emerging technologies.
  • Minimization of BOP and multi-media impacts, such as ash and gypsum sales, FGD water effluent, etc.

Program 75 benefits the power industry and public at large by enabling power generators to cost-effectively and reliably reduce all emissions in an integrated manner.

Approach

This program will develop and test advanced environmental controls that are cost-effective, reduced operations and maintenance (O&M) issues, and fewer BOP impacts than current offerings. The program assists operators of SCRs, sorbent injection systems, ESPs, baghouses, FGDs and other post-combustion environmental controls optimize practices for maximum reliability and performance.

Accomplishments

Over the last several decades, EPRI has led the power industry in developing, demonstrating, and operating cost-effective controls for air toxics, NOx, particulates, and SO2 controls. Accomplishments include:

  • Application-specific data on mercury control by sorbent injection and SCR/FGD co-benefits.
  • Understanding of how to manipulate FGD chemistry to manage captured mercury and selenium, and minimize re-emissions and downstream effluent impacts.
  • Development of databases of long-term performance evaluations for new and regenerated SCR catalysts.
  • Approaches to minimize the impact of mercury controls on ash and gypsum usability or landfilling.
  • Development of novel air toxics, NOx, SO2, particulate, and acid gas controls that offer the potential for lower-cost.
  • Identifying practices adopted to minimize sorbent injection, FGD, SCR, ESP and baghouse O&M costs while meeting stringent emission limits.
  • Environmental controls software tools such as CatReactTM for SCR catalyst management, ESPM, the Quick Access ESP Performance Troubleshooting web page, and TOXECON®, an EPRI-patented process for capturing air pollutants.
  • Demonstrating an option for high-mercury and particulate removals with no impact on ash usability.
  • Annual technical updates on industry experiences with all emissions controls.
Key Activities

Specific R&D efforts in 2017 may include:

  • Improved understanding of FGD chemistry, enabling reductions in mercury re-emissions and water effluent impacts.
  • Improved understanding of sorbents, including performance capabilities for new formulations, balance of plant impacts, and development of a simplified standard method for sorbent characterization.
  • Assessment of air toxics, NOx, SO2, and particulate emissions during flexible operations, such as startups, shutdowns, load ramping, etc., along with strategies to minimize emissions during these periods.
  • Improved mercury control (while maintaining needed NOx levels) by SCR/FGD co-benefits.
  • Evaluation of novel concepts such as halogen on demand (HOD), mercury oxidation SCR catalysts, Rapid Sorbent Validation Protocol (RSVP), fixed-bed carbon, etc.
  • Further understanding of the impacts of particulate removal on FGD performance.
  • Boiler/SCR optimization of NOx levels for lowest cost, integrated emissions, and highest plant reliability.
  • Fuel quality impacts on SCRs, ESPs, FGDs, baghouses, sorbents, and other controls.
  • SCR catalyst management techniques and options for lowest overall cost of SCR operation, including regeneration options.
  • Advanced instrumentation for monitoring NH3, NOx, and SO3.
  • Development and updating of SCR catalyst testing protocols for both NOx and mercury speciation.
  • Further deployment of the Portable Catalyst Test Facility (PCTF) to enable site-specific assessments of catalyst performance over a range of process operating conditions.
  • Identification and resolution of issues most germane to gas-fired SCR applications.
  • Methods to improve ESP performance, such as improved flow distribution, reduction of air in-leakage, and low-cost upgrades.
  • Assessments of new baghouse fabrics and best operating practices, especially in high-SO3 applications.
  • Technology transfer to members and sharing of user experiences through workshops and webcast.

Last Updated
  • PS75A: Particulate and Opacity Control
    14-Jun-2016

    MATS (mercury and air toxics) regulations will require coal-fired power plants to not only meet very stringent limits for filterable particulate matter (FPM), but to do so with increased PM loading and difficult-to-capture materials. FPM limits will be achieved with either ESPs or baghouses. Future regulations may require even lower FPM limits or inclusion of condensables. The industry needs R&D to evaluate and improve the performance of these technologies, including:

    ESPs:  two areas seem to affect PM and opacity compliance with ESPs, first is normalization of deviance for maintenance practices and second, is that some electrostatic precipitators (ESPs) are or became undersized because of changes in plant operational changes to meet envirnmental regulations like MATS. For instance, ESPs are being used to collect an ash with significantly different properties than coal fly ash alone, or greater PM loading than originally designed. These situations, along with the desire to reduce or eliminate SO3 flue gas conditioning in plants that use activated carbon injection for mercury control, will require the ESP to be optimized or upgraded. If the ESP well maintained and with good mechanical condition, significant improvements in ESP performance may be realized by retrofit of advanced power supplies, improvements in inlet flue gas distribution and/or reduction in air in-leakage, or other methods to condition the incoming dust laden flue gas. Understanding the impact of sorbent use on ESP performance is a key parameter that will indicate the extent of margin required for the ESP to perform at the required removal efficiency to remain compliant.

    Baghouses:  Baghouses (aka fabric filters) are deployed to realize low FPM emissions independent of fuel properties, and for compliance with MATS limits associated with HCl, mercury, and other trace metals. However, the addition of sorbents changes the particulate properties significantly. These changes can impact bag life and pressure drop, leading to increased cost and energy penalties. Research is needed to develop countermeasures and new bag materials that can operate under different conditions associated with hazardous air pollutants (HAPs) control.

    Condensables: Although not regulated at this point in time, it is in the interest of the power industry to assess recent available data, with the objective of establishing trends between condensable particulate matter (CPM) measurements and plant type, fuel type, AQC systems, Method used, etc.  CPM measurement methods and agreement regarding what needs to be included in the definition of total CPM should also be included in this assessment. Solutions for reduction of CPM with current technologies can then be identified.

    • Holistic Solutions for Optimizing ESP Performance under New Regulations
      08-Jun-2016

      Can the existing particulate control device fleet meet the needs of the current and upcoming regulations? Two areas seem to affect particulate matter, opacity and multi-pollutant compliance with ESPs. First, many plants are forced to consider normalization of deviance for prioritizing equipment maintenance. Second, changes in plant operation due to plant dispatch, fuel quality or to meet environmental regulations like MATS impose greater demand on the particulate control device than original design. For instance, ESPs are being used to collect an ash with significantly different properties than coal fly ash alone, or to collect a greater PM loading than designed for. These situations, along with the desire to reduce or eliminate SO3 flue gas conditioning in plants that use activated carbon injection for mercury control, often requires the PM control device to be upgraded. If the ESP is in good mechanical condition, significant improvements in ESP performance may be realized by retrofit of advanced power supplies, improvements in inlet flue gas distribution and/or reduction in air in-leakage, along with methods to condition the incoming dust laden flue gas if so needed. Understanding the impact of sorbent use on ESP performance is a key parameter that will indicate the extent of margin required for the ESP to perform at the required removal efficiency to remain compliant.

    • Particulate Control: Baghouses
      14-Jun-2016

      Consequential to recent environmental controls regulations (such as Mercury and Air Toxics (MATS)), there is a need in the power industry to develop and demonstrate technologies that maximize reductions in particulate matter (PM) emissions from fossil-fried power plants while minimizing the capital and operating costs, reliability risks, and BOP impacts.

    • Solutions for Mitigation of Condensable Particulate Matter Formation
      08-Jun-2016

      U.S. power plants are required to measure particulate emissions in stack gases to obtain and comply with air permits, other regulations and to provide emissions data for state and federal emissions inventories. In addition, some local governments have required facilities not only to monitor solid (filterable) particulate emissions, but also to test for Condensable Particulate Matter (CPM), which consists of species that are gaseous at stack temperatures but that may condense into a liquid or solid form after release from the stack at ambient conditions.

      Information is not readily available on how many U.S. power plants are currently required to comply with CPM limits. In 2006, EPRI surveyed recently permitted coal-fired units with emission limits established under best available control technology (BACT) and lowest achievable emission rate (LAER) requirements. Of those facilities with PM limits that included condensable PM (about half of the 66 units listed), the total PM10 limits ranged from 0.012 to 0.05 pounds per million British Thermal Units (lb/MMBtu). The report noted that while limits that included only filterable particulate matter (FPM) appeared to be trending downward over time, there was no such trend for PM limits that included both filterable and condensable PM. It is anticipated that changes to U.S. regulations will require measurement and reporting of CPM in the near future. In 2008, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) issued a final rule to implement the new source review (NSR) program for PM2.5. The rule requires CPM to be considered in NSR actions on or after January 2011 if the facility is located in areas designated as nonattainment or attainment/unclassifiable for the PM10 or PM2.5 National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS). The designation of nonattainment areas and the process of development of State Implementation Plans (SIPs) is still in progress. EPA has also indicated that CPM must be considered for air permits that include PM10 and PM2.5 issued under the Prevention of Significant Deterioration (PSD) program.

  • PS75B: Air Toxics and Acid Gases Control
    12-May-2016

    In order to minimize the costs of complying with emissions regulations, development and testing is needed for controls of air toxics and acid gases that are cost-effective, have lower operations and maintenance (O&M) issues, and have fewer balance-of-plant (BOP) impacts than current offerings. Research is needed to:

    • Ensure that emission limits can be met continuously, especially during fuel changes, startup, shutdown, load-following, and upset conditions
    • Ensure that solutions exist for lower-quality fuels (e.g., high ash, high SO2)
    • Ensure that BOP issues such as corrosion, impact on flyash salability or landfills, and flue gas desulfurization (FGD) effluent are addressed for plants adding halogens, chemical additives,and sorbents
    • Ensure that the effect of oxygen reduction potential (ORP) on “re-emissions” chemistry of elemental mercury and selenium partitioning from the FGD effluent is understood, and re-emissions are minimized. Also, ensuring maximum mercury oxidation across the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) unit.
    • Document long-term performance of all available control options
    • Continue development and demonstration of more cost-effective chemical additives, sorbents, mercury oxidants and novel approaches
    • Provide guidance for properly controlling and integrating power plant emissions control equipment to comply with regulatory limits with minimal overall BOP impacts.

    Specific projects that are planned to be addressed in the P75 Project Set B will include:

    • FGD Chemistry
    • FGD Flexible Operation
    • Integrating MATS into Plant Operations
    • Sorbents and Chemicals
    • SCR / FGD CO-Benefits
    • Halides and BOP Issues
    • Impact of Particulate Removal on FGD operation
    • ESP Performance
    • Baghouse Performance
    • Low Cost SO2 Options

    These projects are covered in more detail in the individual project level overviews

    • Best FGD Practices for Flexible Operations
      04-May-2016

      Flexible operations of coal-fired power plants resulting from the demands of today’s energy market include more frequent start-up shut downs, significant load swings and fuel variability (including use of lower quality coals).  Changes in wet FGD operation during these transient periods and their impacts on chemistry related to both SO2 capture and other air toxics are not well understood. For the utility industry to reliably meet regulations in air toxics controls and effluent discharges while minimizing O&M costs, there is an immediate need to understand the issues and quantify the effects from flexible operation during startup/shut down, day-night cycling, fuel switching and periods of low load operations.

    • Low Cost Options for SO2 Control
      04-May-2016

      The long term viability of aging fossil fuel generation assets has made the investment in emission control technologies more difficult to manage. The recent complex mix of proposed and pending air, water, and solids regulations for fossil power plants and the need for increasing fuel and operational flexibility places significant strain on power plants to maintain emissions compliance under ever changes conditions and requirements.  For those generating assets not currently equipped with SO2 technologies such as wet or semi-dry FGD systems lower cost options for SO2 removal are required.  Typically these option include Dry Sorbent Injection

    • SCR Mercury Oxidation
      04-May-2016

      SCR mercury oxidation continues to be a key focus among members as a “co-benefit” technology. In addition to reducing NOx, SCR catalysts also oxidize mercury, facilitating mercury removal downstream in a wet FGD system.  However, SCR mercury oxidation performance is highly sensitive to multiple parameters, including ammonia and halogen concentrations in the flue gas.  More data are needed to characterize mercury oxidation performance and deactivation of catalysts in real-world operating scenarios. The data will contribute to the development of catalyst management strategies, as well as predictive methods, both of which aid utilities in meeting MATS compliance goals.

    • Sorbent and Chemical Technologies
      31-Jan-2017

      Consequential to recent environmental controls regulations (such as Mercury and Air Toxics (MATS)), there is a need in the power industry to develop and demonstrate technologies that maximize reductions in mercury and other air toxics while minimizing the capital and operating costs, reliability risks, and BOP impacts

    • Toxics Control by Wet FGD
      04-May-2016

      Better understanding of FGD chemistry will enable improved capture of mercury and other air toxics, thereby allowing easier yet cost effective compliance of air pollution control mandates, such as MATS.  In addition, this will also enable achievement of better quality effluent discharge to the wastewater treatment system, resulting in easier compliance with water regulation such as the Effluent limitation guidelines (ELG). 

      Previously in this project and in other EPRI-funded research, it has been determined that mercury, selenium, and other trace elements in coal are captured at varying percentages by wet FGD systems. It has also been determined that a parameter called oxidation-reduction potential (ORP) in the FGD slurry can have a direct or indirect impact on the control of some trace elements across the FGD systems.

      There is no quantitative theoretical or empirical understanding of how wet FGD design and operation can be varied to control ORP at desired levels. Data collection at full-scale wet FGD systems and further bench scale investigations have helped better understand the parameters that control the ORP levels in wet FGD systems and that correspondingly impact sulfite oxidation, mercury phase partitioning, mercury re-emissions, and manganese oxidation and phase partitioning. Future efforts need to focus on how to best “tune” the FGD Chemistry to optimize capture and fixation of toxic materials with minimum impact on wastewater treatment operations, by-product utilization or disposal.

  • PS75C: SCR Performance Optimization
    13-May-2016

    SCR systems have become a major component in the operation of most fossil fired power plants.  Accordingly, there is a need to implement best practices and resolve key operability issues to reduce costs and maximize SCR system performance. In addition, in anticipation of more stringent NOx limits while simultaneously capitalizing on mercury co-benefits, methods of lowering SCR outlet NOx levels from both existing and new SCR systems—such as improved reagent/NOx mixing upstream of the catalyst, advanced instrumentation and control, and improved catalyst formulations—need to be demonstrated. Issues associated with lower-quality fuels (which may contain high levels of arsenic phosphorous or sulfur) need to be resolved.  As flexible operation becomes more common for most units, SCR operation will need to be extended to load ranges significantly lower than originally designed.

    Specific projects planned for P75 Project Set C will include:

    • Cycling, Load Following and Low-Load impacts on SCR operation
    • SCR Catalyst Management
    • New SCR formulations and design
    • Boiler/SCR Opt., Adv. measurements 
    • SCR O&M Issues
    • SCR Co-Benefits
    • Gas Turbine SCR and CO Catalyst Systems

    These projects are covered in more detail in the individual project level overviews.

    • Boiler/SCR Optimization and Advanced Measurements
      19-May-2016

      Identification of optimum operating scenarios at coal plants requires a holistic assessment so as to evaluate potential tradeoffs between different systems. For example, the increased deployment of scrubbers for SO2 control, has resulted in many utilities burning a broader range of lower cost coals, or coal blends, many of which have a higher sulfur content. As a result, operational efficiency tradeoffs can arise between boiler operations and achieving compliance for multiple pollutant species. Consequently, a need exists for a holistic methodology that enables utilities to determine the least overall cost approach for maintaining NOx, CO, Hg, and SO3 emissions compliance through both boiler and SCR operations, while also taking into account potential cost impacts that may be encountered with different operating scenarios (i.e. lower furnace water wall wastage from deep staging with higher sulfur fuels). In support of this effort, necessary tools will ultimately be developed and assessed for identifying optimum boiler and SCR operating conditions.

      The methodology will not only take into account potential tradeoffs between boiler staging versus SCR inlet NOx levels and reagent consumption for achieving a target NOx emission level, but impacts on mercury oxidation due to changes in fly ash UBC levels, flue gas ammonia concentrations at the SCR inlet, SCR inlet temperature, as well as flue gas SO3 concentrations.

      Given the broad shift in coal plants with SCR systems from base load dispatch to cycling response to system load demand, advanced measurements will also be investigated with the goal of providing enhanced SCR control capability that can better respond to changing SCR inlet NOx profiles, reagent and NOx reduction requirements, etc.

    • SCR Catalyst Management and O&M
      11-May-2016

      SCR catalyst management continues to be a key focus in the industry, covering both deNOx and mercury oxidation performance. SCR owners must choose between OEM and regenerated catalyst options, as well as advanced mercury oxidation formulations. Catalyst performance and deactivation data are needed to make timely, cost-effective catalyst replacement decisions. Sufficient independent laboratory capacity for performing catalyst activity measurements (using existing EPRI guidelines) is critical for providing deactivation data. In addition, methods are desired for independently (or internally) developing catalyst replacement recommendations based on the data.

      SCR O&M also continues to be a key priority.  Proper design and maintenance of catalyst cleaning systems, LPA screens, control instrumentation, and reagent storage/feed systems can significantly reduce the costs of SCR operation.

    • SCR Flexible Operation
      04-May-2016

      Increased variability in commercial power and relative fuel prices are forcing changes to fossil asset dispatching. In addition, increased deployment of renewable generation over the next decade will force coal plants to provide system load-balancing services. Specific operational changes expected for coal plants include two-shifting, high ramp rates, high unit turndown, and reserve shutdown. Performance of environmental control equipment, such as selective catalytic reduction (SCR) systems, represents a limiting factor in achieving necessary operational flexibility for optimum generation dispatch. Given these limitations, there is a need to demonstrate low-cost operational strategies that can increase asset dispatch flexibility, while maintaining environmental control equipment performance, and minimizing the short- and long-term impact on system costs and equipment damage.

Overview

Program Description

Coal-fired power plants increasingly need robust, accurate, and certifiable continuous emissions monitors (CEMs) for mercury, particulate matter (PM), acid gases, and -- potentially -- selenium. Experience with continuous mercury monitors (CMMs) remains limited, and their operation and maintenance (O&M) are labor-intensive. PM monitors are not yet routinely used, and their calibration currently is cumbersome, while hydrochloric acid (HCl) is not measured continuously.

Of particular interest to a number of power companies are instruments that continuously measure solids (filterable) and aerosols (condensable PM, acid gases (e.g., HCl, and hydrogen cyanide [HCN]), and ammonia in post-flue gas desulfurization [FGD] stack conditions).

Enabling technology needs for these species include:

  • Sampling techniques that lend themselves to the very low pollutant concentrations that may be required by applicable air standards. Mercury and Air Toxics Standards (MATS) limits, especially for mercury;
  • Acceptable ways to calibrate PM monitors at plants with wet stacks without having to disrupt the operation of the wet SO2 control.
  • Direct measurement of mass emissions to overcome the uncertainty of indirect measurements as PM characteristics change.
  • Emission measurements for gas-fired generation, including ultra-low NOx and CO measurements for combined cycle units.
  • Utilization of continuous monitoring instrumentation for process control of emission control technologies.
  • Operation and maintenance practices for mercury CEMs that enable operators to gather lessons learned for other CMMs users.
Research Value

The Electric Power Research Institute’s (EPRI’s) Continuous Emissions Monitoring program (Program 77) helps members evaluate and implement monitoring options to meet measurement needs using robust, accurate, and easy-to-operate instruments. Benefits include:

  • Save months of plant instrument technician and environmental engineer time needed to make newly procured monitoring technologies work.
  • Prepare for anticipated mercury measurement requirements below today’s proven quantization levels, as well as PM measurements (filterable and condensable) as surrogates for non-mercury metal hazardous air pollutants (HAPs).
  • Optimize NOx and sulfur trioxide (SO3) control operations, or flue gas conditioning for electrostatic precipitator (ESP) performance, via in situ continuous measurement systems for ammonia (NH3), SO3, and sulfuric acid.
  • Reserach the ability and applicability on stacks to install advanced “sensors-on-a-chip” for power plant applications.

Program 77 research benefits the power industry and public at large by enabling reliable power plant emissions monitoring, resulting in reductions in emissions of continuously monitored pollutants such as mercury and other trace metals, particulates, SO2, and HCl and other acid gases.

Approach

This program promotes the development and validation of accurate, robust, and low-maintenance CEMs monitoring and reporting capabilities. It has a near-term emphasis on continuous particulate mass, HCl, and measuring low mercury concentrations. Based on similar technologies and skills, the program also develops and validates gas monitoring systems intended for optimizing pollutant control operation. Looking ahead to further cost constraints, it identifies, develops, and demonstrates innovative measurement systems with the potential to significantly reduce CEMs costs in the longer term. Some components of this effort will be performed jointly with the Sampling and Analytical Methods project (P-59.002) in EPRI’s Environment Sector.

Accomplishments

EPRI’s leadership in identifying and resolving performance and O&M issues with CEMs is recognized by the power industry, CEMs equipment suppliers, and regulatory agencies, especially the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). This recognition is demonstrated annually by the successful CEMs User Group meetings organized by EPRI, which attracts strong participation by the EPA, vendors/exhibitors, and users.

A number of EPA decisions in on mercury monitors in recent years have relied in part on EPRI’s R&D findings, as presented to the EPA by industry. Examples include:

  • EPA approval of the sorbent trap method for continuous mercury monitoring and use as a reference method.
  • EPA approval to use an instrumental reference method in lieu of the complex, costly, slow-turnaround-time Ontario Hydro batch method.
  • Accelerated development of National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)-traceable calibration procedures for CMMs.
  • Determination of CMMs' abilities to measure low mercury concentrations, leading instrument vendors to develop and demonstrate monitors capable of measuring accurately the very low concentrations expected after implementation of MACT standards.
  • Proposed methodology for calibrating particulate mass emission monitors that avoids the need to exceed emission limits for other pollutants.
  • Strong positive response by the host power station and instrument suppliers to a PM monitor troubleshooting and development test platform organized and managed by EPRI.
Key Activities

The program R&D for 2017 will focus on completing efforts to demonstrate the capabilities of CMMs to measure very low mercury concentrations, especially in the presence of bromine, and to operate with less-intensive staff demands; finding and assessing reliable and accurate CEMs for HCl; revisiting the search for methods to measure condensables in wet stacks without artifacts; and completing field tests of techniques to calibrate continuous PM monitors without unusual processes. Continuing efforts to reduce uncertainty in flue gas flow measurements and CO2 in support of greenhouse gas emissions reductions will be demonstrated. Additional efforts may continue the development and demonstration of continuous in situ spatial measurements of NH3 and SO3 in the boiler back end for process control.

  • Program 77 Supplemental Projects
    • Characterization of Stack Particulate Matter
      05-May-2016

      Many electric generating units (EGUs) are required to monitor particulate matter (PM) emissions using continuous emissions monitoring systems (CEMS).  Under the proposed MACT rules many more are expected to install PM monitors.  The current PM CEMS calibration procedure, Performance Specification 11 (PS-11), requires simultaneous sampling of stack emissions with PM CEMS and EPA Reference Method 5 (M5) over a range of concentrations attained by adjusting plant load and/or modifying (i.e., de-tuning) PM controls. 

      PM characteristics such as particle size distribution (PSD) may change during load adjustments or de-tuning, and these changes may affect the measurement in the PM CEMS monitor.   More specifically, if the plant operated in a way that would cause a significant change in the PM characteristics reaching the stack, this could affect the existing correlation curve for the PM CEMS.

      In addition, power plants are more often operating out of their “regular” operating mode.  This could be due to more cycling, longer low load operation and quicker ramping rates due to dispatch needs.  These scenarios could also produce PM with different characteristics and affect the existing correlation curve for the PM CEMS. 

    • Demo of Alternative for Particulate Matter
      04-May-2016

      Some electric generating units (EGUs) are required to monitor particulate matter (PM) emissions using continuous emissions monitoring systems (CEMS). Many more expect they will have to install PM monitors under proposed MACT rules. Currently, simultaneous EPA manual reference method tests (EPA Reference Method 5) must be used to calibrate and audit these PM CEMS, following EPA Performance Specification 11 guidelines (PS-11).

       The current PM CEMS calibration procedure, Performance Specification 11 (PS-11), requires simultaneous sampling of stack emissions with PM CEMS and EPA Reference Method 5 (M5) over a range of concentrations attained by adjusting plant load and/or modifying (i.e., de-tuning) PM controls. These tests are complicated, time consuming, and expensive to perform.  The need to modify plant operating procedures to achieve a range of PM concentrations for calibrating PM CEMS represents a significant burden to plant operations.  There is a clear need for better methods to calibrate and audit these PM CEMS, providing sufficient concentration range while eliminating complicated modifications to plant operations.

       Under other EPRI-sponsored efforts two alternative PM CEMS calibration methods have been developed.  The first and the furthest along in development is the quantitative aerosol generator (QAG).  The QAG produces precisely known quantities of PM aerosols.  The QAG nebulizes a salt solution which acts as the surrogate for the PM in the stack.  The second alternative method is the portable particulate matter calibration system (PPMC).  The PPMC also produces known quantities of PM aerosols but instead of using a salt solution a slurry of fly ash and or fly ash substitute is atomized.

  • Program P77 - Continuous Emissions Monitoring
    • Alternative for Particulate Matter (PM) Continuous Emission Monitoring Systems (CEMS) Calibration Methods
      04-May-2016

      The United States Environmental Protection Agency’s promulgated Mercury and Air Toxics Standards (MATS) require coal-fired electric utilities to monitor for non-mercury hazardous air pollutant (non-Hg HAP) metals. One option for meeting this requirement is to monitor particulate matter (PM) emissions as a surrogate for non-Hg HAP metals with a continuous emission monitoring system (CEMS). Current PM CEMS calibration procedures (PS-11) require simultaneous sampling of stack emissions with PM CEMS and EPA Reference Method 5 (M5) over a range of concentrations attained by adjusting plant load and/or modifying PM controls. These tests are complicated, time consuming and expensive to perform. The need to modify plant operating procedures to achieve a range of PM concentrations for calibrating PM CEMS represents a significant burden to plant operations. In some cases, an adequate PM concentration range cannot be defined during the short-term PS-11 test, which can restrict the operating limits of the coal fired power plant (CFPP) to unnecessarily low levels. (The restriction is due to the PS-11 limitation on the upper end of the correlation, see PS-11 §8.8.) An improved calibration approach that provides sufficient concentration ranges while eliminating complicated modifications to plant operations is clearly needed.

    • MATS Monitoring Improvements
      04-May-2016

      On February 16, 2012, EPA issued National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants from Coal-and Oil-fired Electric Utility Steam Generating Units. Since proposing the rule in May 2011, EPA has typically referred to this as the Mercury and Air Toxics Standards (MATS) rule.  The MATS rule established emissions standards for new and existing coal- and oil-fired electric generating units (EGUs). 

      The MATS rule establishes emission limits for mercury (Hg) and provides two approaches for demonstrating continuous compliance.  The MATS rule also establishes hydrogen chloride (HCl) emission limits for coal- and oil-fired units.  Many, but not all, coal-fired units will have the option of monitoring and complying with an SO2 limit in lieu of HCl.  However, in the MATS rule, oil-fired units must monitor and comply with an HCl emission limit. For the heavy metals (non-Hg metals) emission limit, the MATS rule provides several compliance options, including the installation and operation of a particulate matter (PM) continuous emission monitoring system (CEMS).  The MATS rule presents significant monitoring challenges to EPRI members simply because the emission concentrations that need to be measured are quite low.

    • Stack Flow Measurement Studies
      12-May-2016

      In recent years EPRI has been quantifying heat rate improvements using plant-installed Continuous Emission Monitoring System (CEMS) instrumentation to access potential heat rate improvements. Recently a series of best practices were proposed following a “super-RATA” field test in 2015 and it was found that the stack gas volumetric flow rate measurements contributed the most significant uncertainty to the heat rate calculation. Therefore there is a need to further improve stack flow measurements by reducing calibration uncertainties.

Overview

Program Description

Management of coal combustion products (CCPs) is expected to shift from predominantly disposal to predominantly beneficial use over the next several years. Disposal of CCPs is increasingly expensive, a potential long-term liability, and subject to growing public opposition. Conversely, beneficial use can be a source of revenue, often eliminates long-term liabilities by incorporation into new products, and is looked upon favorably by the public. The US Environmental Protection Agency (US EPA) exempted most beneficial use applications from the CCP disposal rule published in 2015, providing further incentive to move away from disposal and toward use. In addition to freshly produced CCPs, ponds and landfills provide an immense resource of stored raw materials going forward that has only recently begun to be tapped. However, many challenges exist to increasing CCP use, including: varying CCP quality due to changes in plant dispatch and operations; impacts of air emissions controls for mercury and acid gases on CCP quality; increasing production of flue gas desulfurization gypsum exceeding the needs of the wallboard market; increasing volumes of spray dryer by-products that are difficult to use in conventional applications; and processing of CCPs stored in ponds and landfills.

The Electric Power Research Institute’s (EPRI’s) Coal Combustion Product Use program builds on years of investigation into current and new uses for CCPs. With greater certainty following the publication of the CCP disposal rule, the focus in 2017 is on technology development, including testing to evaluate the engineering and environmental performance of promising applications for CCPs. A second area of research will focus on mitigating changes in CCP quality that may negatively impact their potential for use, such as sorbents injected for air emissions controls. A significant new long-term research direction is the characterization and processing of CCPs stored in ponds and landfills for targeted applications. To facilitate acceptance in the marketplace, the research will coordinate closely with marketers and end-users, and provide communication vehicles for technical information for industry, regulators, and the public. The technical results from this program are highly transferable to international utilities.

Research Value

The CCP Use Program research helps to:

  • Minimize CCP disposal costs, which are expected to increase significantly under new regulatory requirements;

  • Limit long-term liabilities associated with operating and maintaining large disposal sites;

  • Retain or earn new revenue by selling CCPs into a variety of acceptable markets;

  • Supporting sustainable and low cost construction and agricultural practices using CCPs in lieu of virgin raw materials.   

   

Approach

The program provides information on CCP quality and the engineering and environmental performance of CCP uses. To maximize the benefit of the research, EPRI collaborates with marketers and end-users, trade organizations such as the American Coal Ash Association (ACAA), and government entities such as the U.S. Department of Agriculture, the Federal Highway Administration, and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, to address significant technical barriers to CCP use at the local and national level. The work will be performed using a combination of base research for broad applications and targeted projects for specific applications.

The scope of the program includes:

  • Established CCPs products, such as fly ash in cement and concrete products and FGD gypsum in wallboard;

  • Geotechnical applications, such as road base, structural fills, mine fills, and waste stabilization; 

  • Products using “off-spec” CCPs, such as spray dryer solids, and ash containing activated carbon or elevated sodium levels;

  • New or growing technologies, such a geopolymers, alternative cements, asphalt, and agricultural applications;

  • Communications on the engineering, environmental, and life-cycle benefits of CCP uses.

Accomplishments

  • Managed collaborative research team including utilities, government agencies, industry, and academia to demonstrate the value and environmental acceptability of using FGD gypsum and other FGD solids in agricultural applications for phosphorus mitigation;

  • Assessment of the impacts of air emissions controls on ash use applications;

  • Assessment of ash markets in North Carolina, beneficiation options, and innovative technologies;

  • Series of EPRI reports were used to support CCP use legislation in Michigan;

  • Extensive laboratory testing to demonstrate the feasibility of using a wide range of fly ash types to improve the characteristics of asphalt;

  • Collaborated on development of data on leaching of concrete made with fly ash that was used by the U.S. EPA in a risk assessment to conclude that these products are environmentally safe;

  • Demonstrated no significant risk from mercury released from concrete made with fly ash, wallboard made with FGD gypsum, or use in agriculture.

Key Activities

  • Evaluating the use of fly ash geopolymers for stabilization/solidification and advanced cementitious applications;

  • Assessing alternative emission controls and operational processes for mitigating impacts on CCP quality;

  • Performing engineering and environmental assessment of road applications;

  • Developing data and procedures for recovery of CCPs from ponds and landfills for use;

  • Helping inform the U.S. EPA risk assessments related to beneficial use;

  • Continuing research on use of FGD gypsum in agriculture; supporting USDA and US EPA risk assessment and development of practice standards;

  • Supplemental project opportunities for spray dryer absorber materials, asphalt applications, mine reclamation, and use of ash that does not meet typical concrete specifications.

  • CCP Quality for Beneficial Use
    09-Jun-2016

    The chemical and geotechnical properties of CCPs are a key consideration in beneficial use applications.  Increasingly, CCP properties are changing in response to changes in air emissions controls under the Mercury and Air Toxics regulations.  Changes in plant dispatch can significantly impact CCP consistency.  In addition, utilities are increasingly seeking to use CCPs previously stored in ponds and landfills.  In many cases, these changes will result in CCPs that do not meet typical specifications for use in concrete, wallboard, and other construction applications.

    In order to increase or even maintain current levels of CCP use will require thorough knowledge of factors impacting CCP quality given the broader trends within the electric power industry.   This information can be used to judge the impact of changes in CCP quality for various use opportunities, to develop operational approaches to improving CCP quality and consistency, and to identify uses that are not sensitive to CCPs of varying quality. This includes assessment of beneficiation technologies to improve CCP quality, and recovery of CCPs from  storage in landfills and ponds.

    The information developed under this project will:

    • Provide power companies with data to evaluate the impacts of plant controls and operations on the ability to market their CCPs;

    • Provide methods for improving CCP marketability;

    • Provide information on the technologies and economics of recovering CCPs from landfills and ponds.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • CCP Use Technologies
    09-Jun-2016

    Power companies use about 40-45% of the CCPs produced annually. This percentage range has been relatively consistent for the last 12 years.  Technologies for using fly ash in conventional portland cement concrete and FGD gypsum in wallboard are well established from both an engineering and regulatory perspective, however these uses still only accounted for less than one-third of the fly ash and FGD gypsum produced in 2014. Changes in CCP quality due to increased air emissions controls may further render some CCPs unsuitable for conventional uses. 

    Development and demonstration of modified or new technologies will be needed to significantly increase use. This project will work with the use industry to identify and develop CCP use technologies, and provide third-party technical information to judge their engineering and environmental performance. The information developed under this project will:

    • Deliver a framework for evaluating both existing and new CCP uses;

    • Provide participating companies with detailed engineering and environmental information for promising uses;

    • Develop broad information on economics and life cycle assessment; and

    • Allow companies to better evaluate vendor proposals.

     

     

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Markets and End Use Resources
    09-Jun-2016

    CCP use is closely tied to the markets, end-users, regulators, and public perception.  Development of a product or technology will be of only academic interest without the support and interaction with stakeholders outside of the conventional power plant environment.  Collaboration with marketers and end-users is critical to obtaining acceptance within the technical community.  Communication with the public on the benefits and environmental acceptability of CCP use is necessary to facilitate acceptance. 

    This project focuses on engaging with marketers and other external stakeholders in shaping the research agenda, evaluating the costs and benefits of CCP use, and communicating the research results to end-users, regulators, and the public. Short and easily digested communications will be developed for selected topics, and Workshops will be held to disseminate industry trends and research results. The project will:

    • Provide a direct connection between power companies and the CCP use market;

    • Help ensure research results are available to the appropriate stakeholders;

    • Inform discussions related to the costs and benefits of CCP use; and

    • Provide communications pieces for use with regulators and the public.

Overview

Program Description

Users of natural-gas-powered simple-cycle (SC) and combined-cycle (CC) plants for power generation continue to benefit from the increased worldwide supply of natural gas fuel, and from the continued environmental pressure to limit the use of coal-based power plants. They also continue to benefit from the expected limited growth of new nuclear power generation and the greater ability of natural-gas-powered plants to operate in cycling duty to accommodate the growing deployments of wind and solar power sources.

The asset value of natural-gas-fired gas turbines (GT), especially in CC plants, is on the rise. But cycling and high-temperature operations can adversely affect GT component life. Life-cycle costs, premature wear, failure risks, and environmental performance are critical issues affecting plant performance, reliability, and cost. Improved operational flexibility can help plants address load demands even as GT and CC technologies continue to evolve, providing significant efficiency gains and relative improvements in installed cost. Informed decisions about technologies and plant designs are especially important because efficiency, emissions, availability, maintainability, and durability are all key selection factors.

The Electric Power Research Institute’s (EPRI’s) Combined Cycle Turbomachinery program (Program 79) provides resources to address all aspects of the life management and the operational and maintenance (O&M) improvements of conventional and advanced GTs. It also addresses all aspects of CC plant-wide integration, including specific issues relating to the steam turbine (ST) and generator for CC applications.

Research Value

Members of this program can use the research to respond to the issues, challenges, and opportunities in integrating and operating CC assets in a rapidly expanding and changing power generation environment.  They implement specific and detailed engineering analyses in the areas of CC turbomachinery life assessment, risk management, and improved operation and maintenance of current assets.  

Approach

The program research portfolio has two primary technical objectives:

  • Provide a holistic approach and perspective on all R&D elements related to integrating all the equipment and systems of a CC plant.
  • Address all aspects of managing CC turbomachinery assets, including life assessment, risk management, O&M improvements, and technology advancements.

Specific technical interaction and allocation of resources between Program 79 and other EPRI programs such the CC HRSG and Balance of Plant program (Program 88) and the Steam Turbine-Generator program (Program 65) effectively utilize existing EPRI technical expertise and resources without duplication between programs.

The strategic objectives of Program 79 represent the following technical areas:

  • Gas turbine component life extension
  • Gas turbine and combined-cycle plant monitoring
  • Steam turbine and generators in combined-cycle plants
  • Combined-cycle plant integration
  • New combined-cycle plant designs, cycles, and upgrades
  • Gas turbine innovation and advancement

Each year the program’s projects and activities are aligned with one or more strategic objectives and within a five-year plan as the GTCC power industry moves forward. P79 members receive information about:

  • Plant-wide integration – topics including operational flexibility and controls, performance improvement and optimization, and GT, heat recovery steam generator (HRSG), and ST interaction and inter-system dependence.
  • Life assessment and risk management – topics including damage detection, root cause and solutions, and monitoring and life-predicting analyses.
  • O&M improvements – topics including component durability and damage tracking, and repair and refurbishment guidelines.
  • Technology advancements – topics including engineering and economic assessments, reliability and availability statistics of current turbomachinery RAM performance, and new and advanced equipment offerings and capabilities.

Accomplishments

For the last 30 years, EPRI’s GT and CC research programs have provided high-quality technical evaluations and products to support better operation and maintenance of existing assets, and provide objective, timely, life-cycle perspectives on technology choices and improved plant designs, including:

  • Model-specific repair guidelines for widely used 50/60-Hertz (Hz) machines
  • Replacement part procurement guidelines for D/E- and F-Class models
  • Compressor and rotor root-cause analysis and O&M solutions
  • O&M guidance for DLN combustor systems and segmented feed pumps
  • Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) and CO catalyst deactivation assessment and improved emission controls tuning
  • Component durability analysis and damage tracking
  • CC performance monitoring and recovery
  • GT technology comparisons, best practices, and procurement guidelines/specifications
  • Lessons learned in GT/HRSG repowering
Key Activities

Program R&D for 2017 will seek to broaden EPRI’s focus on CC plant-wide integration issues, and increase interaction and joint projects with EPRI Program 88 and other EPRI programs including P65, P71 (Combustion Performance and Emissions Control), P87 (Fossil Materials & Repair), P104 (Generation Maintenance Applications Center, or GenMAC) and the Operations and Maintenance programs P68, P69, and P108. Program 79 also will seek to mitigate current GT dependability issues and reduce O&M costs, and track the characteristics of current and next-generation technologies. Specific efforts may include:

  • CC plant-wide flexible operation with emphasis on the latest gas turbine upgrades
  • Maintenance and operation of vintage frame and aero-derivative gas turbines
  • Assessment of GT-HRSG temperature interface operational optimization
  • Air-cooled generator maintenance experiences and best practices
  • Performance recovery and improvement: monitoring and diagnostics
  • Advanced thermal barrier coatings with lower conductivity and embedded sensing capabilities
  • Improved rotor non-destructive evaluation (NDE) for extended life
  • Advanced hot-gas-path upgrades and alternative parts
  • New/updated GT hot-gas-path repair guidelines
  • Managing dry low-NOx combustion systems
  • Design evolution, durability, and reliability for current GT models
  • Future trends for industrial GT technologies
  • New CC plant design basis and procurement specifications
