Last Updated
  • Combined-Cycle Turbomachinery
    • Advanced Combined-Cycle Plant Design and Construction
      14-Jun-2016

      There is a gas turbine industry-wide need to specify cost-effective state-of-the-art design features of new Combined-cycle plants for high efficiency, flexibility, maintainability and reliability.  This need has never been greater especially in north America where the price of natural gas is expected to stay extremely low and the supply is expected to remain extremely high over the next decade. 

      Owners and operators seeking to build new generation assets and very interested in the design and construction aspects of building combined cycle plants based on advanced (H/J class) gas turbines.  Given that US Engineering and Construction (E&C) firms have designed and built such advanced plants, their experience that may be applicable to owners/operators may be available.  A high quality front end engineering design (FEED) or pre-FEED report could be generated, and compared with designs based on F-class gas turbines from a decade ago. 

    • Assessment of Combined SCR/CO Catalyst Concept
      14-Jun-2016

      Combined SCR/CO catalyst concepts have been recently introduced for simple and combined-cycle power plants as emissions continue to be a critical priority for operating these plants.  The current and future requirement to cycle, ramp and fast start these plants has put even more pressure on the catalyst designers and manufacturers to optimize these systems and extend the useful life of the materials.  This situation has now required that an independent evaluation be completed to more fully understand and document the effectiveness of these catalyst systems.

      Recent advancements have yielded combined SCR/CO catalyst concepts, however, with the catalyst being a critical component of combined cycle operation, further evaluation is a necessity.  This particular work will focus not only on laboratory testing but will conclude with full-scale testing to determine performance and deactivation. 

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Life Assessmentt/Risk Management
    • Advanced Borescope Inspection Technology
      14-Jun-2016

      Power plant owners, operators, and maintenance managers seek new and next-generation technologies and approaches for decrease plant downtime and reduce repairs costs especially within the gas turbine flow path.  Although gas turbine OEMs provide explicit maintenance intervals based on hours and starts, the industry is more fully moving towards condition-based repairs and outage management.  Monitoring and inspecting prior to repairing and/or replacing costly gas turbine compressor, combustor and hot sections components has become attractive to gas turbine owners and operators in the current environment where life extension of parts is critical.

      The latest generation of borescope inspection equipment potentially offers improvements to access engine components and to quantify related damage.  Advanced visual borescope surface damage mapping can more fully characterize component 3-D surface damage using remote approaches.  The objective of this project is to determine advanced borescope enhanced capabilities to locate and quantify damage in the gas turbine combustor, compressor and hot section flow path.

    • Compressor Rotor Rim Inspection
      14-Jun-2016

      Operational reliability operating statistics (ORAP from SPS) indicate that gas turbines and steam turbines are the dominant contributors to unplanned outages with an unplanned unavailability of 4 to 6% for a typical plant.  Complex, tightly integrated gas turbines in particular are subject to cascading damage from failed inlet compressor blades/vanes, combustor hardware, or hot section parts.  Rebuilding such equipment with custom, high cost components often requires an extended outage to accommodate the long lead times of manufacturing new components and transport to off-site repair shops.   Component stress analysis and material testing are used to address cracking in the rim attachments and the general structural integrity of gas turbines subjected to high hours and high starts.

      Gas turbine rotor life is increasingly limited by damage to the disc rims and blade attachment slots.  Developing and refining field inspection techniques capable of detecting and sizing blade rim attachment slot cracks without destacking rotor assemblies will be of great value and significance to decreasing overhaul costs and outage delays.

    • Single Crystal Superalloy Degradation
      14-Jun-2016

      Cracking in rotating blades and loss of prime-reliant cooling are the key concerns in advanced, high-temperature designs in gas turbine hot sections.  Maintenance of the power center-line equipment such as the gas turbine represents the largest portion of the combined-cycle non-fuel plant budget.  With increasing capacity factors, fewer outage windows are available to schedule maintenance.  A related factor is the long lead times often required to obtain new and/or refurbished costly custom parts such as advanced model-specific super-alloy hot section blades and vanes. 

      Single crystal superalloy hot section components are increasingly used in F-class and advanced gas turbines.  A greater understanding of unique single crystal degradation mechanisms is needed to help manage risks and associated maintenance decisions.  Noteworthy is the recent change of ownership in the gas turbine industry of the Alstom GT 24/26 fleet that does contain single crystal super-alloys in the hot section.  GT 24/26 owners and operators are seeking additional options to the parts and services providers in the past and additional understanding of the durability characteristics of these super-alloy materials.

      The objective of this project is to test single crystal materials and service-aged components to characterize the degradation mechanisms.  Obtaining additional single crystal samples is critical for the success of the project.

    • Vertically Cracked Thermal Barrier Coatiing
      14-Jun-2016

      Cracking in the ceramic thermal barrier coating (TBC) on combustor and hot flow-path parts and loss of prime-reliant cooling are the key concerns in advanced, high-temperature designs in gas turbine hot sections.  Maintenance of the power center-line equipment such as the gas turbine represents the largest portion of the combined-cycle non-fuel plant budget.  With increasing capacity factors, fewer outage windows are available to schedule maintenance.  A related factor is the long lead times often required to obtain new and/or refurbished costly TBC materials and application procedures. 

      Vertically cracked TBCs are becoming available in the broader repair/refurbishment aftermarket.  However, the specific coating procedures to produce the optimal structure with minimal side crack branching is not well defined and thus potentially a quality issue.  There is a need in the industry to more fully understand and detect incipient damage and the underlying root causes driving component damage and life limiting mechanisms. 

      The objective of the project is to define general processing parameters required to produce viable and durable vertically cracked TBCs.

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Operations and Maintenance Management
    • Combustion Dynamics Reference Guide
      14-Jun-2016

      The need for this reference guide is based on many conversations and discussions with combined-cycle and simple cycle gas turbine maintenance managers, engineers and especially plant operators that are given the task of safely controlling Dry Low NOx (DLN) combustion systems at all operating conditions.

      From the beginning of DLN combustion technology development in the late 1980's, combustion dynamics (CD) have been a major driver and issue for gas turbines.  High amplitude CD can be the symptom of a needed re-tune or can result in costly and untimely outages due to hardware failures.  The issue for monitoring and site personnel is to determine what the CD data represents: sensor failure, hardware failure, re-tune need, etc.  The purpose of this guide is to give understanding to CD through a quick-reference handbook giving examples and key understanding on why CD even exist and what CD mean in different situations.  

    • Pinging Protocol to a Assess Operational Risks in 7EA Gas Turbine Compressors
      14-Jun-2016

      GE 7EA gas turbine compressors have experienced vibratory cracking and/or vane liberation failures over the recent past.

      With ongoing examination into operational and ambient failure factors, 7EA users are in need of testing capabilities for in-situ compressor blades.  This pinging protocol assessment is based upon current GE guidance for users and examines the best procedure and equipment to utilize.  Note this protocol will not address whether a crack is present; however, the damping and frequency of resonance for each blade can aid in determine the order units in a fleet should be upgraded with the latest blades.  Overall, this work will give guidance on the likelihood of blade issues for one unit verses another.

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Plant-wide Integration
    • 7FA Cycle Deck – To Address Increased Base Load NOx Emissions on Aging DLN 2.6 Gas Turbines
      14-Jun-2016

      Many DLN gas turbines that have been through multiple hardware repair cycles have base load NOx emissions that have increased above their design value.

      During recent years, many DLN hardware upgrades have resulted in de-ratings on units where instead of an expected 10-15 MW increase, there is a 5-15 MW decrease from original base loading.  In some cases this is due to combustion dynamics restricting power output and in other cases (typically an issue for simple cycle units) NOx emissions are out of compliance, thus requiring the de-rating.  Whether simple- or combined-cycle, the development of this cycle deck tool will allow users of 7FA units to perform root cause analyses without the need and delays from GE. 

    • Air Filtration Life-Cycle Cost Analysis and Optimization
      14-Jun-2016

      Gas turbine owners and operators have identified inlet air filtration as a potential cost saving as combined-cycles are operating more frequently and experiencing more cycles.  Selecting the most cost-effective combination of inlet air filters and water wash frequency greatly impacts the gas turbine performance.  The gas turbine industry is in need of a tool that quantifies the complex interaction of filter pressure drop and particulate collection efficiency, compressor fouling and performance impacts, and their incremental effect on plant economics.

      Additional refinements are anticipated as experience is gained in the application of the Air Filtration Life-Cycle Cost Optimization (AFLCO) software with members operating gas turbines in simple cycle and combined cycle configurations.  Furthermore, some members may have the opportunity to measure ambient air particulate loading and size distribution over time and therefore refine the regional size distributions incorporated into the model.  Additional side-by-side filter tests in the field may provide additional insights on how well laboratory tests model filter efficiency increases as loading and pressure drop increase.  Other enhancements may include refining the model for compressor efficiency and dirt buildup on compressor blades and vanes.

    • Gas Turbine Performance Analysis Tool for Next Day Revenue Optimization
      14-Jun-2016

      For gas turbine power plants, accurate prediction of next-day output and heat rate is critical for optimizing plant dispatch order and maximizing plant revenues.

      Dispatching of power plants is a complex, economically driven operation.  Just as complex is gas turbine performance due to dependencies on unit condition and ambient conditions, which drives the economics of unit to unit operation.  Thus, having the most up-to-date models for determining optimal dispatch is tantamount.  This specific work is focusing on updating the Gas Turbine Performance Analyzer (GTPA) for next day forecasting for optimal dispatching based on near real-time output and heat rate capabilities. 

    • Gas Turbine/Combined-Cycle Operations and Maintenance Costs
      14-Jun-2016

      There is an ongoing requirement in the combined-cycle industry to quantify the cost to operate and maintain the plants over its lifetime.  Plant designers, planners and developers are constantly seeking more accurate cost details needed to make their projects successful.  This need has never been greater as the cost of natural gas is low (especially in North America) and the need for more flexible combined-cycle plants has never been greater with the decrease in coal usage and the increase in the deployment of renewable power.

      The current EPRI Combined-cycle Operations and Maintenance Cost Analyzer Version 8.7 was last updated in mid-year 2015.  Since that time, component and labor costs will have changed enough to warrant a review and update.  Furthermore, costs for newly released engines may become available.  Other enhancements may include refining the maintenance interval formulations based on revised OEM guidance and other improvements based on user feedback.

    • Joint P79/P65/P88
      14-Jun-2016

      All plant owners, operators, and maintenance organizations are constantly evaluating and reevaluating how to improve efficiency and reduce costs.  There is a constant need to compare plant RAM performance with other similar plants and identify main reasons for unplanned maintenance affecting outage hour.  This information is also needed when considering historical performance for supporting future procurement decisions.

      ORAP represents the most extensive database available for key RAM information, and P79 is a long-term supporter of ORAP managed by Strategic Power Systems (SPS). P79 is making arrangements to access the most updated information from SPS that can be extended to HRSGs and steam turbines.  Furthermore, given advances by SPS in developing web-based queries of ORAP, EPRI may be able to perform more customized analyses on particular topics.  Domestically, RAM data from NERC-GADS can also be included for comparison purposes. 

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Technology Advancements
    • Life Extension Assessment of Vintage Combustion Turbines
      14-Jun-2016

      Vintage or legacy combustion turbines (e.g., Frames 5, 6 and 7) are nearing or have reached their design service lives. With additional investment, turbine life may be extended and/or performance can be improved to help meet power demand.  The overall objectives of this effort are to gain a better understanding of industry best practices for managing flexible operating requirements; determine the impact on component life, cost and availability; and identify a means to monitor and control the impact on the plant.

      Simple- and combined-cycle plants are being forced to increase their operating flexibility in order to accommodate the variability of wind and solar power generation. These plants have increased their flexibility by decreasing startup times, operating at higher peak capacity during high demand periods, turning down to even lower loads while complying with emission targets, and maintaining higher efficiencies during turndown and load following, while reducing the operations and maintenance costs of frequent starts/stops and the impact on plant availability. The experience gained by these plants in implementing their strategies is captured in case studies.

Overview

Program Description

Today’s fossil power plants are tasked with flexible operations, pushing for maximum output during peak price periods, transitioning to low-load and multi-shift operation, and frequent fuel switching to take advantage of spot market opportunities. These practices can accelerate material damage in major power block components. New materials are being introduced for replacement of components in aging plants, in the building of higher-efficiency power plants, and in the construction of components with thinner walls for improved operational flexibility. Regulations on air and water quality have resulted in construction of new pollution control equipment and water management technologies that are more demanding on materials than older systems.

Improved knowledge of materials behavior in such environments allows for accurate prediction of remaining life, proper choice of repair strategies, and optimized material selection, fabrication, and repair. To address these needs, the Electric Power Research Institute’s (EPRI’s) Fossil Materials and Repair program (Program 87) provides integrated materials selection guidance, repair and welding technologies, and corrosion mitigation methods to improve equipment performance, reliability, and safety. Research is conducted in all areas of the fossil power plant, including the major power block (boilers, HRSGs, steam turbines, gas turbines, etc.) and the balance of plant.

Research Value

Safety and availability loss due to failures are two key issues driving R&D on major fossil power plant components, especially in older plants. Improved efficiency and reliability are two reasons for the selection of new materials for retrofit and new-build projects. EPRI’s Materials and Chemistry programs provide data on critical material degradation mechanisms, conduct materials and chemistry-related R&D for advanced generation technologies, and quantify the benefits of improvements. These programs help utilities balance the risks and costs of the largest, most costly equipment, and focus on using new technologies to create solutions. Members of the Fossil Materials and Repair program can use the R&D to:

  • Increase availability through better understanding of plant materials.
  • Minimize -- with the goal to eliminate -- repeat failures and equipment damage, and reduce outage frequency and duration by using improved knowledge of damage mechanisms and tools for life-assessment methods.
  • Reduce failures from high- and low-temperature corrosion.
  • Obtain in-depth knowledge of advanced ferritic and austenitic alloys and processes used to fabricate and join these alloys.
  • Select appropriate weld filler metals and processes for construction and repair.
  • Reduce outage time and manage maintenance costs through implementation of innovative repair techniques.
  • Maximize component life through improved materials selection guidance and procurement specifications.
Approach

Through a continuum of materials and repair guidelines, handbooks, technical projects, webcasts, position papers, and conferences/workshops, the program helps manage and reduce the operating risks associated with material degradation and failure. Projects develop industry-leading and scientifically based resources to aid in materials property estimates used to determine remaining component life, assess and conduct state-of-the-art repairs, decide on replacement materials, and address costly corrosion and erosion problems faced in real-world business settings.

Members of the program also benefit from direct access to the technical staff expertise, EPRI laboratories, and a worldwide research network. The program’s mission of research excellence has established EPRI as a leading organization for materials research for power plants. The program seeks to maximize member value through though internal EPRI collaboration with component-based programs, targeted government-sponsored research, and collaboration with US and international research organizations.

Accomplishments

EPRI’s Fossil Materials and Repair program conducts proactive R&D in all aspects of plant materials performance, repair and welding technology development, and corrosion mitigation. It has:

  • Provided industry leadership in addressing fabrication, installation, welding, and degradation of creep-strength-enhanced ferritic steels and advanced austenitic stainless steels.
  • Developed comprehensive International Steam Boiler and Steam Turbine Metallurgical Guidelines.
  • Provided guidance on behavior and remaining life of austenitic stainless steel materials used for superheater and reheater tubing applications.
  • Developed welding guidelines for boiler applications and advanced ferritic and austenitic alloys.
  • Published a series of metallurgical handbooks (Grade 11, Grade 22, X20, carbon steels, stainless steels, and advanced stainless steels).
  • Developed new models for assessing oxide growth and exfoliation.
  • Provided innovative solutions and new welding consumables for dissimilar metal weld damage repair and advanced steels.
  • Addressed low-temperature corrosion issues around the power plant, including guidance on selecting materials for environmental controls.
  • Effectively transferred technology through use of innovative tools and a proactive approach to addressing deficiencies in codes and standards.
Key Activities

The program R&D for 2017 will continue to focus on key issues, including the development of improved specifications through research on metallurgical risk factors; faster weld repairs using innovative techniques; application of small specimen testing for qualitative and quantitative life assessments in both boilers and turbines; technology transfer for post-weld heat-treatment procedures; materials selection for improved reliability in steam turbine components; and corrosion in the balance of plant. Key specific efforts are expected to include:

  • Development of a metallurgical risk factor for creep strength-enhanced ferritic (CSEF) steels and welds
  • Comprehensive guidance on the application of scoop sampling material databases for improved small-specimen remaining-life assessments on a component-specific basis.
  • New tools transferring developed post-weld heat treatment guidance
  • Improved understanding of damage development in thick-section dissimilar metal welds (DMW)
  • Improved filler metal selection for ferritic-to-ferritic dissimilar metal welds (DMWs)
  • Innovative repair developments
  • Improved guidance on low-temperature corrosion around the entire power plant
  • Technology transfer including webcasts, industry position papers, and improvements to codes and standards
Estimated 2017 Program Funding
$3.8M
Program Manager
John Shingledecker, 704-595-2619, jshingledecker@epri.com

Research Projects

EPRI Members: View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
Non-EPRI Members: Contact Program Manager - John Shingledecker; 704-595-2619; jshingledecker@epri.com
Last Updated
  • Combustion Turbine Weld Repair (Joint P79/87)
    31-May-2016

    When combustion turbine compressor and hot section rotor reach end-of-life, replacement of the rotor disc is generally performed.  However, long-lead times may be averted in some instances through weld repair of rotor discs.  While this is done routinely on steam turbines, it has not been performed on  gas turbine rotating components and currently there exists no fundamental materials research to support an alternative repair in lieu of replacement. 

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Dissimilar Metal Welds (DMWs)
    31-May-2016

    Dissimilar metal welds (DMWs) operating at high temperatures and pressures are a challenge for both short- and long-term power plant life management due to complex metallurgical interactions at high termperatures. The industry needs information to better understand DMW failure modes in order to improve guidance on the welding and fabrication of high reliability DMWs.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • FGD Wastewater Materials Selection and Compatibility (Field Testing) - Joint P185/87
    31-May-2016

    Increased emphasis on the treatment and removal of contaminants from power plant wastewater has gained industry attention as new effluent guidelines are now under consideration in the U.S. A key need is to reduce the total volume of water which must be treated by the power plant, and flue gas desulfurization (FGD) wastewater is the “last stop” for water leaving the plant which needs to be treated. To create less FGD wastewater, the FGD can be “cycled-up” and/or technologies such as membranes can be used to concentrate waste streams.

    These concentrated FGD brines contain high levels of halogens (chlorides, bromides, etc.), low pH values, and other solid and dissolved species. A plethora of materials options to construct treatment systems exist, ranging from alloys such as lower-cost stainless steels to very expensive nickel-based alloys or titanium. Non-metallic solutions such as coated steels and fiber re-enforced plastic (FRP) can also be used. The industry needs information about the mechanisms of corrosion and criteria for materials selection in these new environments, which currently are not well understood.  EPRI completed a laboratory study as a basis for this materials selection in 2016 and aims to evaluate these same materials in the less controlled real-world field environment to validate the study conclusions.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Met Risk Grade 91
    31-May-2016

    Long-term creep testing and service experience have clearly shown that composition and processing within the allowed specification for Grade 91 steel can effect long-term creep strength and ductility.  The concern over low ductility heats and the potential for shortened life due to notch weakening effects is a challenge to long-term life management.  This project is addressing this challenge through the development of a metallurgical risk factor which will facilitate screening of materials on the basis of composition and also provide the industry enhanced guidelines for procurement of components (which has already been released in EPRI position papers on chemistry and a publically available specification document).

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P87 Application of PWHT Model
    31-May-2016

    Post-weld heat treatment (PWHT) is a critical step in the application of materials in power plants. If a PWHT is conducted incorrectly, serious damage can occur including overtempering and/or anciculary damage to surrounding equipment. This is especially critical in creep-strength-enhanced ferritic (CSEF steels) because approaching or exceeding the intercritical temperature during PWHT results in significant degradation to creep life and long-term performance.  The industry needs to improve PWHT to also improve long-term performance of CSEF steels in power plants

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Service Experience of CSEF Steels in the Asia Pacific Region
    31-May-2016

    The Asia-Pacific region has the fastest growing coal fleet in the world and many of the highest-temperature plants make extensive use of creep strength-enhanced ferritic steels (CSEF). The industry needs to understand the materials challenges, including early (leading) indicators of what most likely will happen to materials used the most and at highest temperatures.  This project seeks to continually engage this region of the world to gain experience with components through industry surveys and assistance with failure investigations

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • SOK Low Temp Corrosion
    31-May-2016

    Corrosion costs the electricity industry greater than 2.3B USD/yr.  Much of this is corrosion is around the plant in supporting systems which operate at low temperature.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • SS SH/RH Damage
    31-May-2016

    Utilities are increasingly using high strength and advanced austenitic stainless steels such as 347H, Super 304H, 347HFG, HR3C, and alike.  Failures due to SIPH and relaxation cracking at attachments is not well understood but is critical to proper procurement of material, specifciations for fabrication, and inspection if failures are found.  

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Technology Transfer – P87
    31-May-2016

    Even the most impactful R&D results are of little benefit to the industry and the public if they are not delivered in ways that make them easily understood and utilized. EPRI's Fossil Materials and Repair Program (P87) has a comprehensive technology transfer plan to maximize member engagement, ensure timely delivery of results, and ensure industry leading materials R&D is effectively used in the power industry to advance safe, reliable, affordable, and environmentally responsbile electricity for society.

Program Name: Combined Cycle HRSG and Balance of Plant
text:
Overview

Program Description

The design of modern heat recovery steam generators (HRSGs) and balance-of-plant (BOP) systems is a complex interrelationship between many parameters and variables. HRSGs pose a unique set of operational challenges, due in part to their rapid startup capabilities; high operating efficiencies; multi-pressure circuits; reheat, once-through, combined drum/once-through systems; and numerous varieties available in the basic design. Preventing HRSG tube failures (HTFs) is a priority, but complex failure paths, which are influenced by cycle chemistry or thermal transients, are difficult to understand and mitigate. Limited access and other complexities make inspection and repair of HRSGs very difficult.

Today, the design philosophy of combined-cycle plants is evolving just as the electric power industry is evolving due to an influx of renewable energy, low natural gas pricing in the United States (even as costs are much higher internationally), and environmental issues. Many owners of combined-cycle plants are now rethinking the concept of baseload operation and looking at cycling operation. Because current combustion turbines do not have low turndown capabilities while maintaining emission limits, the ability to cycle a unit is the alternate solution.

Cycling plants are units designed to optimize plant operations by providing rapid startups, partial loading, and short shutdowns. These frequent changes in plant operation are not easily obtained in current OEM and operating design limits. To achieve cycling operation, both equipment and system design have to be considered. For this reason, cycling designs should accommodate several new features not considered for baseload units. Cycling operation should ensure satisfactory operation throughout the full operating range of the unit. Facility or plant designs should also consider conditions when the unit is not operating. A combined-cycle plant with operating flexibility can provide start, stop, and partial-load operation to match changing demand for power. However, these benefits can bring added costs due to wear and tear on equipment through thermal fatigue. These added costs associated with plant cycling cannot be totally eliminated; they may be minimized but must be considered for long-term reliability.

The Electric Power Research Institute’s (EPRI’s) Combined Cycle HRSG and Balance of Plant (BOP) program (Program 88) provides a complete set of technical tools to improve the performance and reliability of combined-cycle HRSGs and BOP equipment. The program includes a background of HRSG design and development, particularly over the last 10 years, in which HRSG designs have become remarkably complex, operating at significantly higher pressures and temperatures. It also provides a comprehensive understanding of available designs and tools for preparing procurement specifications for both new and used HRSG and BOP components based on past research and new technologies.

Research Value

Projects include unit-specific and pressure-circuit-specific chemical treatment methods and limits; optimal approaches to preventing HRSG tube failure; and methods for life assessment, nondestructive evaluation (NDE) options, welding, and other repair methods. Using the R&D from this program, members can:

  • Achieve tube failure rates consistent with their risk tolerance and financial models
  • Increase reliability through better understanding of thermal transients
  • Manage balance-of-plant issues facing the combined-cycle fleet
  • Optimize HRSG operational and shutdown guidelines through better understanding of thermal transients
  • Identify and correct cycling and thermal transient problems through chemistry cycle guidelines and methods
  • Optimize HRSG inspection and repair by using new hardware, NDE guidelines, and techniques for improving access
  • Establish inspection routines and life assessments of major components
Approach

The program portfolio has two primary technical objectives:

  • Provide a holistic approach and perspective on all R&D elements related to integrating all the equipment and systems of a CC HRSG.
  • Address all aspects of managing CC HRSG and balance-of-plant assets including life assessment/risk management, O&M improvements, and technology advancements.

Program members receive:

  • Guidelines that help operators monitor, identify, and minimize the effects of shutdown, startup, and thermal transients on fatigue life.
  • Information on life assessment and risk management (topics include damage detection, root cause and solutions, and monitoring and life-predicting analyses).
  • HRSG tube failures and life-assessment research, which is continuing to develop a comprehensive methodology to assess cycling capability, including optimizing startup in terms of thermal transients. The program also continues to document case studies and develop life-assessment tools and methodologies in this area.
  • HRSG NDE and repair R&D, which includes developing and demonstrating external inspection techniques with remote capability, developing final equipment for HRSG tube elbow replacement near headers, and assessing an internal coating technology to provide protection against FAC.
  • Information on O&M improvements (topics include component durability and damage tracking, and repair and refurbishment guidelines).
  • Technology advancements (topics include engineering and economic assessments, statistics of current HRSG and balance-of-plant reliability, availability and maintenance [RAM] performance, and new and advanced equipment offerings and capabilities).
  • Regional workshops covering HRSG tube failures, cycle chemistry, inspection, and FAC, assisting with the technology transfer of the program. 
Accomplishments
  • Thermal transient and cycle chemistry guidelines provide quantitative, specific suggestions for attaining the best possible performance from existing HRSGs. The guidelines also provide guidance applicable to new units for appropriate design of pressure parts.
  • Comprehensive guidelines on cycle chemistry for all HRSGs, including shutdown/startup chemistry and chemical cleaning.
  • A complete approach to identifying reasons for thermal transients, as well as related analytical tools.
  • Troubleshooting guide that, through a group of 57 questions, can help identify whether and which underlying causes (or both) of thermal transients are present in the operating practices or in the design of the HRSG.
  • Repair technology options, as well as a revision to the interim NDE guidelines, to include case studies of visual techniques and technology transfer specific to HRSG and BOP components.
Key Activities

Program R&D for 2017 will continue to focus on thermal transients directly responsible for damage to HRSG pressure parts. The scope of the program continues to expand and address end-of-life issues in the major components of the HRSG and incorporate balance-of-plant equipment. Specific efforts may include:

  • Exploration of technologies to address HRSG tube failures (HTFs)
  • Technology to assess balance of plant issues affecting the fleet
  • Case studies and development of HRSG life-assessment tools and methodologies
  • Further development and demonstration of remote capabilities for external inspection techniques
  • Exploration of technology for tube to header and dissimilar weld repair
  • Continue building preventive maintenance processes (PM basis) tools for the HRSG
  • Investigation of flexible operation short- and long-term effects
Estimated 2017 Program Funding
$3.0M
Program Manager
Bill Carson, 704-595-2698, bcarson@epri.com

Research Projects

EPRI Members: View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
Non-EPRI Members: Contact Program Manager - Bill Carson; 704-595-2698; bcarson@epri.com
Last Updated
  • Back-end Deposition
    08-Jun-2016

    Fouled HRSG finned tubes continue to penalize the industry. It is thought that a severely fouled HRSG can cause a several hundred thousand dollar hit to a unit's bottom line.

    Every plant’s annual maintenance program should include removal of HRSG gas-side deposits. Effective maintenance planning can be improved by closely monitoring specific operating parameters, such as CT backpressure, steam production and temperature (for each pressure level), and stack temperature, and comparing the data against corrected plant design conditions. In addition, plant heat rate and output should also be tracked. HRSG and combined cycle plants are not equipped with sufficient instrumentation to properly monitor changing parameters and provide adequate feedback for owners or operators to make decisions. a project to adequately detail when a cleaning can be justified from a heat rate performance rather than a load reduction due to fouling or back pressure on the turbine is greatly needed.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Balance of Plant issues
    08-Jun-2016

    A combined cycle unit is very similar in components to a conventional plant. The components are subject to the same extreme temperatures and pressures that a conventional unit has. Just like the BTF program, documentation of failure types and failure modes of valves, pumps etc is critical to accurate reliability analysis. There are areas related to balance of plant that can easily be overlooked  that can affect reliability and affect both safety and profit of the units.

    An initial literature and survey task is utilized to gain useful information. This could be coupled with previous EPRI research and reports to find similarities and highlight significant differences.

    A guideline or document would then lead owners and operators as to what to look for and the industry problems around the balance of plant issues facing them.  

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Drain Line Bellow Failures
    08-Jun-2016

    Thermal mechanical fatigue damage is irreversible and its expenditure must be minimized from first firing of the CT/HRSG to conserve life expenditure to meet the longer term planned service life of the unit. Implementation of modifications to correct design features that cause high life expenditure rates is often either impractical or very costly in time and material costs once the HRSG has been fabricated.

    A heavy stressed area of the HRSG is in the drain line and particularly the bellows protecting the drain lines. There bellows protect the high energy pipe drains and there have been several failures in the industry and several questions arise for repair and replacement. This project will set out to discover reasons for failures, timing and conditions of failures and establish a repair or replacement guideline.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • HRSG Flow Improvements
    08-Jun-2016

    In a typical heat recovery steam generator (HRSG), the inlet duct experiences a significant amount of turbulent, separated, unsteady flow. A common corrective action to mitigate the gradient is to install a flow distribution grid in the middle of the inlet duct to improve the flow quality. The fact that these distribution grids are repaired on a regular basis suggests that a solid understanding of the fluid mechanics—both steady and unsteady flow—could lead to better system performance and less facility downtime. To date, the electric power industry has lacked a comprehensive understanding of this process, and the designs for new installations usually do not address the issues associated with unsteady flow.  In a step toward a better understanding of the problem, the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) has supported research that uses a subscale model of a representative HRSG, described in detail in Section 2. An array of transducers was used to determine the magnitude and correlation of the unsteady pressure.

    Mal-distribution of hot gas through the HRSG: 

    • Increased pressure drop 
    • Non-design steam temperatures
    • Heat wasted up the stack
    • Vibration and other damage to HRSG internals.
    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • HRSG P91 Failures - Case Studies
    08-Jun-2016

    The changing thermodynamic characteristics of steam during startup conditions also produce component stresses and excess condensate that must be quickly drained. Less condensate is produced during fast startups, though more attemperation spray may be required to control steam pipe metal temperatures than when undergoing a routine startup. Low-load operations usually use more attemperation spray to control steam pipe metal temperatures than when undergoing a standard startup. Since low-load operations are generally at substantially lower pressures, this also offsets some of the more aggressive thermal characteristics of two-shift cycling under low-load operations. Many HRSG designs present condensate removal challenges during either type of start, which is a characteristic that varies greatly between HRSGs, even those built by the same manufacturer.

    Under cycling conditions, other undesirable side effects are also possible, such as greater risk of water hammer in the reheat piping, thermal quenching of hot component surfaces due to spray valve degradation, and leakage or failure of the pressure boundary at tube-to-header welds, riser piping to drums, crossover (connecting) piping, and drain connections. Temperature control (heat tracing and in some cases portable heaters) may also be required to prevent tube and header failure during freezing conditions

    These components can be severely affected especially when they are of a creep strength enhanced material such as P91. It is understood and researched among the standard  carbon components how this affects reliability and life but this project will set out to discover issues with p91, discuss when and where they occurred and help owners and operators understand when to look, where to look and how to respond if affected.  

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • HRSG Piping Life Assessment
    09-Jun-2016

    Heat recovery steam generators (HRSGs) often have substantial internal and external piping to connect the various boiler sections and to carry feedwater to the HRSG and steam from the HRSG. The piping systems and components for HRSGs have many features in common with those found in traditional utility boilers, and therefore life assessment concepts and practices for conventional piping are to a large extent applicable to HRSG piping. However, HRSGs pose their own unique set of operational challenges, and the damage and failure mechanisms affecting HRSG piping therefore present some special aspects that should be considered when it comes to life assessment.

    A project was completed in 2015 that summarized a few of the issues in the industry and some of the more common features of HRSG piping that have experienced failures, or that could theoretically be vulnerable. The report from that project  provided a summary of pertinent damage mechanisms, followed by a series of topical summaries on specific issues and concerns. To keep the document accessible and manageable in size, the summaries were confined to the main points, with references listed for other sources that can provide more detailed information on each topic. The summaries are consistently organized, with subsections that overview the affected components, discuss the damage mechanisms involved, and provide specific suggestions for life assessment processes—analysis, inspection, on-line monitoring, and mitigation. Carefully selected photographs and diagrams support the discussions for each topic.

    The approximately 20 years of operating experience in large HRSGs for power generation service has generated a large amount of knowledge and insight on vulnerabilities and failures related to both design and operation. Many of these have been documented extensively elsewhere, so this project aims to provide an overview of these mechanisms and also highlight some aspects (such as the potential for failure from large-bore branch connections) that have not been comprehensively documented in the past.

    Appropriate training programs on operational considerations for cyclic duty can help operators become more aware of conditions in which thermal stresses on plant components might be particularly excessive, and be better able to take corrective actions to avert them. In addition , the use of effective analytical tools, diagnostic monitoring and control of instruments can provide valuable benefits and guidance to plant operators for reliable and efficient operation under cyclic or flexible duty. This project will set out to highlight existing tools, examine deficiencies needed for HRSG component inspection and begin a series of projects to provide guidance to owners and operators on HRSG component life assessment.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Repair of Perforated Plate & Duct Liners in HRSGs
    09-Jun-2016

    A heat-recovery steam generator (HRSG) is much like other power generation equipment—run it at design conditions and chances are it will run with high availability and require only routine maintenance for many years. Mechanical problems within the HRSG are usually site- and vendor-specific, but experience has identified many common failure modes. The most common cause of HRSG failures (after malfunctioning equipment such as sprays or duct burner controls) is a change in operating profile, typically from base load to daily cycling, especially in markets with must-run wind generation. Although a change in operating routine doesn’t automatically translate into gross degradation in HRSG reliability, pressure parts are often susceptible to having less design margin and more vulnerability to consequential damage caused by other equipment.

    Inlet duct distribution grids or duct liners typically take a considerable beating in cycling service. With the increased interest in flexible operation there continues to be several distribution (Perf) plate and duct liners failures in theHRSG fleet. This project will survey the industry to determine when and where the failures are occurring. It will highlight inspection techniques, establish repair practices, and provide a benchmarking tool to help owners assess the importance of the issues.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Startup/Shutdown
    08-Jun-2016

    Flexible operation continues to play and increasing role in HRSG’s that were designed for base load operation. Each startup and shutdown can be very detrimental to the long term reliability and a single decision can affect years of life on these critical components 

    The most frequent occurring HRSG tube failure damage mechanisms include thermal, corrosion and creep fatigue. These are influenced by transiently high, thermally induced cyclic stresses caused by inadequate condensate attemperator control, and startup and shutdown rates which are too fast or do not allow the combustion turbine to match the capability of the HRSG tubing and headers. The objective of the overall work is to provide a set of tools and guidelines which operators can use to assess the thermal performance of the HRSG from design to operation. 

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center

Program Name: Air Quality Assessment of Ozone, Particulate Matter, Visibility and Deposition
text:
Overview

Program Description

EPRI’s Air Quality Assessment of Ozone, Particulate Matter, Visibility, and Deposition Program develops highly accurate measurement and modeling tools to assess the complexity of how emissions from the electricity generation interact with other emissions, their chemical transformation, and environmental fate.

The development and application of rigorous air quality models, accurate ambient measurements, and the use of assessment tools based on credible science are needed to inform air quality management programs, such as those required by the U.S. Clean Air Act. Improved techniques are needed for estimating impact of emissions from various sources and regions (U.S. and international) and determining the impact of local, regional, and international pollution, including cross-state transport. These tools and techniques also can be used, for example, to inform the process of rulemakings related to the National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS), develop state implementation plans (SIPs), and support activities such as the permitting of power plants worldwide. Over the past few years, as air quality standards have continued to be lowered, there is a need for advanced tools and refined scientific methods to address key challenges.

Given the already significant use of air quality models in regulatory applications and their continued expansion in setting air quality standards, it is imperative to improve or challenge the scientific premise supporting them and thus increase confidence in their use. This can be accomplished through a three-pronged approach of improving models, emissions inventories, and ambient measurements. It is clear that improving different air quality models (through better representation of chemistry and transport) is essential to informing decisions at different steps of the regulatory process. For the models to provide accurate results, the emissions data used as the input to the models should be developed with the best-available science and methods. Finally, only accurate air quality measurements can provide the “ground truthing” necessary to determine if the models are adequate for their proposed or intended uses, and more importantly assist in the basic scientific research that determines the mechanisms and modes of action that should be included during the model development process.

As the electricity system changes in the future into a multi-directional network of central and distributed generation, increased renewable and natural gas generation, microgrids, energy storage and electric vehicles, the resulting changes in emissions and their impacts must be assessed to determine their importance and relevance to future air quality. As these technology and electricity system changes are still ongoing, the range of potential associated environmental impacts (both positive and negative) have not yet been clearly defined or assessed. This program’s objective is to address the lack of data on key air quality issues by performing assessments needed to help lead the industry’s transition into the future.

Research Value

The electric power industry needs an enhanced understanding of how emissions from power plants —in combination with emissions from other sources —influence the chemistry in the atmosphere and thus affect the formation, composition, and ensuing health effects of air pollutants. Assessing, developing and improving air quality models, improving emissions inventories, and ensuring accurate measurements of ambient air quality, visibility, and deposition are the focus of this program. Domestic and international air quality standards continue to be key issues for power plant owners and operators. Through this program, EPRI informs and advances the science supporting air quality models used for policy development, regulatory decision making, permitting, and implementation planning. Program research also informs power company environmental compliance activities, asset management, and long-term strategic planning which ultimately benefits the public through improved environmental conditions and/or cost benefits to help make electricity more affordable. Program results also inform the public and other stakeholders. With this research:

  • Scientific data, modeling tools, and analytical resources facilitate comprehensive evaluations of air quality impacts from emissions and sources, enabling informed, science-based decision making;

  • EPRI assesses detailed scientific perspectives on environmental policy and regulatory deliberations of power plant emissions resulting from all major fuels and combustion technologies;

  • Frequency and quality of collaborations on multimedia environmental issues (such as water quality and ecosystem impacts from atmospheric deposition) and assessment of new technologies (such as electric transportation and distributed energy resources) increase;

  • EPRI keeps abreast of emerging air quality issues, including potential benefits and challenges of new generation technologies; and

  • EPRI provides independent communications and assessments of questions raised by policymakers, regulators, the public, and other stakeholders.

The research conducted in this program benefits all stakeholders including the public by developing tools and conducting analysis to meet air quality standards in the most cost effective manner.

Approach

Research products include air quality models and ambient measurements that clarify how emissions from different sources contribute to the formation of ozone, particulate matter (PM), regional haze, and atmospheric deposition. Additional products include research on atmospheric chemistry and ambient measurement methods essential to allowing scientists to identify the most harmful air pollution components. This program delivers:

  • Advanced air quality models, offering independent accurate representation of central site power plant and distributed generation technology emissions, chemistry, and transport in the atmosphere;

  • Multimedia research on the interactions between air quality and ecosystems, as well as between air quality and watershed management;

  • Technical expertise for effectively interpreting the science and policies introduced by regulatory agencies and different stakeholder community; and

  • Atmospheric measurements and development of relevant instrumentation, including microsensors, to identify air pollution components associated with adverse health impacts to inform development and application of modeling tools and source-receptor analysis techniques.

The technical results and tools developed in this program are highly applicable to international audiences.

Accomplishments

Advanced air quality models and assessment tools based on atmospheric science are critical to informing air quality management actions and air pollution standards. This program has:

  • assessed the environmental impacts of plug-in electric vehicles and non-road equipment in a collaborative study with the Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC);

  • hosted more than 100 researchers during the largest air quality field campaign, the Southern Oxidant and Aerosol Study, at our ground level monitoring site in Alabama through a collaboration with multiple federal agencies and numerous other research entities;

  • developed, and received regulatory acceptance of a new algorithm for more-accurate accounting of contributions to regional haze;

  • harnessed the rich dataset obtained by the Southeastern Atmospheric Research and Characterization (SEARCH) Network, which continues to evaluate poorly represented sources, clarify trends, evaluate models, and provide information essential to health studies;

  • conducted fundamental and applied air quality model development research resulting in improved science modules for PM in regulatory air quality models;

  • analyzed methodology for developing a secondary standard for NOx and SOx;

  • demonstrated the need for strict model performance criteria when using regional air quality models for regulatory purposes;

  • clarified the role of acids in the formation of secondary organic aerosol and improved representation of the process in air quality models;

  • implemented an advanced plume-in-grid module to better characterize specific impacts of power plant emissions on ozone, PM, and atmospheric deposition in air quality models;

  • developed advanced methods and tools for air permitting model applications, including the release of a new photochemical dispersion model, SCICHEM, for simulating SO2, NO2, O3 and PM2.5;

  • highlighted the importance of transboundary pollution in regional haze considerations; and

  • elucidated the impact of background ozone on attainment of stricter ozone standards.

Key Activities

The program’s R&D for 2017 will continue to focus on the development and application of air quality assessment tools. Key collaborations with EPRI programs addressing ecosystem/watershed management and distributed generation challenges will be crucial to inform policymakers, regulators, the public and other stakeholders. In 2017, program research will:

  • improve modeling of organic particles derived from vegetative emissions to better represent the contributions from natural sources to PM2.5;

  • evaluate air quality models that may be used for detailed ozone and secondary PM2.5 applications, cross-state air pollution abatements (transport) rules, and SIPs;

  • explore challenges in modeling ozone formation in regions near large waterbodies (such as near the Great Lakes and coastal zones);

  • evaluate Regional Haze Rule requirements for different Class I areas for the second implementation period using various assumptions on the IMPROVE algorithm and transboundary pollution;

  • perform independent and collaborative assessments of the Southeast Atmosphere Study data to improve chemical mechanisms, measurement instrumentation, and photochemical air quality models;

  • evaluate validity of biomass burning tracer chemicals in order to better constrain the contribution from wildfires and residential wood combustion to PM2.5 concentrations;

  • demonstrate the potential effects of uncertainties in the performance of ecosystem models and ecological assessments tools used in developing secondary standards based on deposition of NOx and SOx;

  • investigate novel instrumentation, such as microsensors, for use in either intensive or long-term continuous monitoring applications;

  • assess the impact of distributed generation and flexible operations of central site generation on air quality; and

  • continue to improve air dispersion modeling tools for regulatory applications related to for NO2, SO2, O3 and PM standards

Estimated 2017 Program Funding
$2.5 M

Last Updated
  • Air Permitting Models for SO2, NO2, Ozone, and PM
    08-Jun-2016

    The permitting process for power plants and other large industrial sources relies heavily on the application of air dispersion models. In order to satisfy requirements for modeling secondary pollutants, photochemical grid models have also been proposed for permitting applications. Models are used to determine compliance with increasingly stringent National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS) and other regulatory requirements such as New Source Review (NSR) and Prevention of Significant Deterioration. EPA’s modeling guidance, the Guideline on Air Quality Models (also known as “Appendix W”), is designed to provide consistency and equity in the use of modeling within the U.S. air quality management process; the guidance was revised in 2016 to address secondary fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and ozone (O3), in addition to sulfur dioxide (SO2) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2).  The revised Guideline provides guidance on how to address regional haze issues including applications for BART (Best Available Retrofit Technology) eligible sources.

    Current models and methods used for regulatory air modeling and visibility analyses (e.g, as part of requirement under the Regional Haze Rule) can result in overly conservative estimates of a source’s potential contribution to ambient pollutant concentrations and visibility impairment because of the simple nature of these tools and their application. The nature of new ambient standards and the requirement to satisfy stricter emissions constraints during operation of power plants requires models and methods no longer based on simplistic assumptions.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Air Quality Measurements and Analysis
    08-Jun-2016

    Improving the detail and resolution of atmospheric measurements is essential for understanding the fate and impacts of emissions and transformation processes in the atmosphere, studying the human health and ecosystem effects of air pollution, and determination of the best ways to represent those processes in three-dimensional air quality models and other assessment tools. High-quality, highly time-resolved measurements also are required for evaluation of air quality models. In addition, such measurements provide the necessary input to source-receptor models, which are used in weight-of-evidence analyses to determine sources contributing to pollution at a receptor site.

    However, most modeling studies rely only on ambient measurements from national monitoring networks, which for PM and its constituents are often taken only as a 24-hour average or cumulative measurements. These measurements can obscure or miss rapid changes in atmospheric composition or lead to poor interpretation of which sources are influencing air quality at a particular location. In addition, by necessity these networks typically use instruments designed first and foremost to be easy to operate, maintain and deploy, and some are becoming increasingly outdated. These methods may not provide the highest quality data in terms of chemical specificity, detection limits, or number of chemicals measured. Finally, static networks cannot cover all spatial and temporal locations of interest. Lack of high-resolution measurement data implies that air quality models are often not subject to rigorous evaluation, and use of those models can result in misinterpretation of model results, with subsequent impacts to air quality management strategies.

    Additionally, a suite of novel approaches for measuring ambient air quality have been developed and increasingly deployed in the past several years.  These include mobile and stationary monitoring with mid-tier complexity instruments and low-cost environmental microsensors.  These are collectively referred to as Next Generation Monitoring technologies, and their use is being actively promoted by federal research and regulatory agencies, such as the Environmental Protection Agency, the National Science Foundation, and others. These technologies have the potential to disruptively transform air quality monitoring, but they need to be rigorously tested against traditional monitoring approaches before being widely deployed.

    Therefore, it is crucial to continue development and deployment of novel instrumentation to evaluate performance and test viability for use in either intensive or long-term continuous monitoring applications. Novel instruments may include approaches considered part of EPA’s Next Generation Monitoring initiative (such as mobile monitoring and microsensors), or stationary monitors targeting new chemical constituents of the atmosphere or using new modes of detection. 

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Air Quality Models for Implementation of Ozone and PM Standards
    08-Jun-2016

    In response to increasingly stringent environmental regulations, there is a continuing need to enhance three-dimensional air quality models in their representation of the atmospheric chemistry and transport of ozone, PM, regional haze, and atmospheric deposition. Traditional research to improve three-dimensional air quality models has focused on their application in the development of state implementation plans (in other words, control strategies) for compliance with air quality regulations. Over the past several years, the use of these models has also been extended to other parts of the air quality regulatory process. Most notably, as a result of EPA response to petitions by environmental groups, three-dimensional air quality models have been proposed for single-source modeling related to ozone and secondary PM2.5 applications.

    In the coming years, EPA will develop new rules to address interstate pollution abatement based upon newer, more stringent levels of the National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS), and new methodologies to address interstate contributions to non-attainment areas and interferences with maintenance of attainment. Air quality models also are used for determining population exposures to air pollutants as part of epidemiological studies. Without testing the appropriateness of applying such models to these health studies, their conclusions remain in question.

    Although EPRI and other researchers have made significant improvements in the representation of organic particulate matter (PM) in current air quality models, there is a need to further improve models in this area. Enhanced models developed in this project will provide the best available tools to stakeholders for developing implementation plans to attain increasingly stringent ozone and PM standards and meet regional haze goals. For example, these models can be used to assess different control technology and control strategy options. The models will also inform the development of future cross-state air pollution abatement (transport) rules.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Atmospheric Deposition and Ecocsystems Impacts of SOx and NOx
    08-Jun-2016

    In the past several years, there has been increasing focus by the regulatory and scientific communities on atmospheric deposition as it relates to acid and nutrient loading in ecosystems. Atmospheric deposition of acids and nutrients can influence the biogeochemistry of ecosystems. Deposition of several atmospheric pollutants can lead to acidification, which has been associated with a decline in forest tree species and loss of biodiversity in aquatic ecosystems. Nutrient deposition has been associated with disruption in the biodiversity of ecosystems and eutrophication of water bodies, which can contribute to toxic algal blooms and fish hypoxia. EPA considered proposing a new Secondary National Ambient Air Quality Standard (NAAQS) for oxides of nitrogen and sulfur (NOx and SOx) based on an aquatic acidification standard that is related to the deposition of these compounds. As EPA renews its efforts to evaluate a Secondary NAAQS for NOx and SOx, it will continue to explore how other ecological impacts (terrestrial acidification and aquatic/terrestrial nutrient enrichment) also may be incorporated into the regulatory framework.

    Assessing the impacts of atmospheric deposition of nitrogen oxides and sulfur oxides, as well as reduced nitrogen species such as ammonia gas and associated ammonium particles, from different sources to potentially sensitive ecosystems and waterways continue to be important research directions to inform the development of Secondary NAAQS.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Emerging Issues, Flexibility, DER
    09-Jun-2016

    As the electricity system changes in the future  into a multi-directional network of central and distributed generation, increased renewable and natural gas generation, microgrids, energy storage and electric vehicles, the resulting changes in emissions and their impact must be reviewed and assessed to determine their importance and relevance to future air quality. These changes include (1) expanded use of small flexible fossil generation units for the direct production of electricity or to provide ancillary services that support the grid, (2) increasing amounts of consumer-facing electronics, (3) implementation of novel operational strategies for power plants and emissions control technologies. As these technology and electricity system changes are still ongoing, the range of potential associated environmental impacts (both positive and negative) have not yet been clearly defined or assessed. This project addresses the lack of data on key air quality issues by performing assessments needed to help lead the industry’s transition into the future.

    Traditional fossil fuel-fired central site generation facilities are also subjected to new, and sometimes extensive, changes of a variety of non-baseload operational conditions. This includes increased frequency of cycling, with a number of different types of ramping, turn down, and fluctuating patterns.  The drivers of flexible operations are numerous, and include increased amounts of intermittent generation entering the grid, uncertain fuel prices load growth and energy policy, active customer behavior (e.g., renewable and electric transportation installation), renewable portfolio standards, and more stringent environmental regulations. Despite this need for increased flexibility, unit operations need to comply with environmental regulations.

    Other technologies currently present on the grid, but expected to have increased future deployment, are distributed energy resources. In addition to providing for site-specific electricity needs, distributed fossil generation may also increase as a way to balance out intermittent renewable generation at various scales, as well as to provide ancillary services to grid stability. Currently the dominant source of distributed fossil generation both on the grid and behind-the-meter are diesel-fired reciprocating engines, as well as natural gas-fired combustion and aeroderivative turbines.  Future deployments will predominantly include natural gas-fired engines and turbines. The emission rates from some of these unit types are well known, while others have more limited data available from real-world operational settings. There are few comprehensive assessments of subsequent impacts to air quality as a result of operation of these units; it is important to understand the potential for both local and regional benefits and impacts.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Regional Haze and Urban Visibility
    08-Jun-2016

    EPA’s Regional Haze Rule (RHR) is a long-term regulation that requires visibility in Class I areas to return to natural levels by 2064. In attributing haze to emissions from a specific source, an important step is calculating the relationship between fine particle composition and haze by estimating how much light is scattered or absorbed by sulfate, nitrate, organic materials, black carbon, and other PM components.

    EPRI research developed a new algorithm, which was accepted by EPA, for calculating haze indices and attributing haze levels to specific components. Many outstanding issues still remain to understand the relationship between particle composition and haze, and further research is needed. EPRI designed studies to address these issues by collection of new particle and visibility data at Class I areas and by focused laboratory experiments. Further analysis of those data has demonstrated issues related with relationships between the fine particle composition and haze.

    Another key challenge with the RHR is how to define or determine the levels of natural visibility that each Class I area must achieve by 2064. EPA’s definition of this endpoint does not include transboundary anthropogenic pollutants, as well as new science pertinent to understanding naturally occurring levels of particles contributing to haze. Although EPRI research shows that states need to recognize the importance of transboundary pollution when developing plans for meeting regional haze progress goals, significant uncertainty remains in estimating the transboundary contribution of organic aerosol concentrations.

    Urban visibility has become an important research and regulatory issue, as EPA has increased efforts to develop secondary PM2.5 standards to protect visibility in urban areas. Some issues related to urban visibility are similar to the regional haze issues (e.g., relationship between fine particle and composition and visibility degradation), but separate studies focusing on urban areas are necessary to address knowledge gaps specific to urban visibility. One of these items is the adequacy, or lack thereof, of visibility preference studies that have been used by EPA in developing levels of visibility metrics in its first analysis of potential secondary PM2.5 standards based on protecting visibility. There is a need to conduct more-robust studies that can be applied at a national scale, rather than the current studies that consider only the preferences of people in the specific regions where the studies were conducted. Other issues include the frequently higher spatial heterogeneity and increased change of interferences that may exist in urban areas as a result of the more numerous types of emissions sources present there.
