Program Name: Assessment of Air Quality Impacts on Human Health
text:
Overview

Program Description

EPRI’s Assessment of Air Quality Impacts on Human Health program addresses key scientific uncertainties regarding the health effects of criteria air pollutants, with the objective of informing industry stakeholders, regulators, and the public - in the United States as well as internationally - to ensure the development of protective public health policies and standards based upon the latest scientific data and analyses.

Protecting public health and the environment is the primary goal of environmental regulation. However, how to achieve that goal is an ongoing dialogue among U.S. and international regulators, administrators, scientists, and other stakeholders. For example, in the US the Clean Air Act’s National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS) set limits for ambient concentrations of six pollutants (carbon monoxide [CO], lead, nitrogen dioxide [NO2], particulate matter [PM], ozone [O3], and sulfur dioxide [SO2]) considered harmful to public health. Recognizing that knowledge about health impacts of air pollutants evolves as scientific studies produce new results, air quality standards require periodic review of the science upon which the standards are based. Conducting research that informs this review process, as well as other regulatory actions and the health impacts of air pollution at the local, international and national level, is the focus of EPRI's Air Quality Health program.

The program’s health effects information, developed from epidemiology, toxicology, and exposure assessment studies, as well as applied risk assessment analyses, addresses key scientific uncertainties related to health effects of PM, ozone, and other air pollutants. The focus of current research is on closing research gaps related to several key scientific issues, including investigation of the long-term effects of air pollution; the existence of a minimum threshold concentration before health effects from various criteria pollutants start to occur; further study of the health effects of ozone; the extent of life shortening due to air pollution; and the methods employed for calculating benefits of air pollution regulations. In addition, the program’s forward thinking, proactive, and strategic nature ensures that the research also includes evaluation of the potential health impacts of new generation and non-generation technologies that may be part of the power system of the future.

Research Value

EPRI’s Air Quality Health program focuses on key issues relevant to the U.S. and international power industry. Risk assessments generate results to inform different aspects of NAAQS establishment for criteria pollutants in the U.S. Work on benefits of air pollution regulations is critical in developing realistic estimates for Regulatory Impact Analyses, for example, that reflect key scientific uncertainties. Continuing research on the extent of life shortening caused by air pollution is of high value in determining whether premature mortality is occurring in young, otherwise healthy people, or in elderly people in declining health. This is an important distinction from a policy perspective and may have a considerable impact on overall benefits ascribed to reductions in air pollution. The determination of whether a threshold exists – that is, whether there is a concentration below which health effects may not occur – is also a critical scientific question that to date has not been adequately evaluated.

A particular focus of EPRI’s Air Quality Health program over the past several years has been on ozone health effects. An instrumental chamber study of asthmatic humans, designed to better understand the threshold for ozone in a sensitive subpopulation, will be completed in 2017; the results of this study are expected to inform the next review of the ozone NAAQS. Additional epidemiological analyses of EPRI’s ARIES and Medicare datasets planned for 2017 will also inform this regulatory activity. This research is also important for generating health information relevant to international settings.

EPRI is also continuing important work on the health effects of PM components, as this research has the potential to catalyze a paradigm shift informing how PM is regulated. The current mass-based approach regulates total PM concentration; however, PM is composed of hundreds, if not thousands, of individual components, and there is a growing scientific consensus that not all of these components are equally toxic. This research addresses key scientific uncertainties to determine which components of air pollution are associated with negative health impacts (and which are not) and generates information to support health risk estimates of air pollution components. The value of the research is in its ability to more accurately identify the specific causative agents, and thus the sources of those agents, affecting human health and the environment.

With this research program:

  • Air pollution health research considers the full spectrum of pollutants necessary to ensure that public health is adequately protected; further, EPRI is the only research and development organization that addresses the unique power industry air pollution issues relevant to coal and natural gas-fired power plants  and how they fit into the larger picture of emissions from other sources

  • Peer-reviewed publications reporting research results provide input into regulatory standard-setting processes and inform the broader scientific and stakeholder community.

The research conducted in this program benefits local, regional, national, and international stakeholders, including the public, by providing information to help develop air quality regulations that are based on sound science.

Approach

EPRI takes the unique and multidisciplinary approach of combining epidemiology, toxicology, and exposure assessment studies, as well as applied risk assessment analyses, organized into an issue-based framework focusing on PM, ozone, risk and benefits assessment, and the power system of the future. For example, EPRI air quality health research is critical to informing the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) statute-required review of air pollution standards and its research will be considered in the next revision to the NAAQS for PM expected in 2021. EPRI also provides informative briefings to state and federal policymakers on its research results. Work is also focused on areas of high relevance to international settings. The issue areas use the following study designs/disciplines to achieve the required results:

Air pollution epidemiology studies examine human populations to determine the statistical links between pollutant exposures and adverse health effects.

  • Exposure assessment studies characterize the components and sources of air pollution to which people are exposed.
  • Toxicology studies (laboratory studies conducted in cell systems, animals, or humans) evaluate health impacts of pollutants under controlled conditions.
  • Risk assessment and other applied analyses focus on specific inputs or issues related to criteria pollutant risk assessment. 

All research results are published in the peer-reviewed scientific literature to ensure they can be considered in standard-setting activities as well as inform the scientific community. Importantly, the program’s communication activities also ensure that results are disseminated in formats suitable for stakeholders and public audiences. The scientific results from this program are highly applicable to international audiences.

Accomplishments

The Air Quality Health program focuses on developing key scientific information related to the health effects of criteria air pollutants. Major accomplishments include the following:

  • Program staff published two articles in the peer-reviewed literature that reviewed all available short-term and long-term studies related to PM components and health; the short-term article concluded that carbon-containing constituents warrant more attention, while the long-term article pointed to the scarcity of informative studies. Program staff also published a comprehensive review paper covering the state of the science of the health effects of organic PM.

  • Ongoing research related to benefits estimation tools indicates that when alternative assumptions regarding benefits inputs are made, estimated benefits from air pollution regulations can span a wide range that includes zero. Integrated uncertainty analyses incorporating probabilities further highlight the sensitivity of benefits estimates to input variables.

  • Research on the extent of life shortening finds that death in affected individuals is hastened by only several days, not months or years.
  • Short-term epidemiological studies (ARIES) point to the importance of carbon-containing PM in adverse health effects, while long-term studies (Medicare cohort) suggest that confounding (a type of bias) of the longer-term studies may be present.
  • EPRI toxicology studies have shown that adverse cardiovascular effects were primarily associated with trace metals from smelting, incineration, and metal processing sources, and that only mild toxicological effects were observed in rats exposed to coal combustion emissions.
  • EPRI’s epidemiological research highlights the importance of multi-pollutant models – those that consider many pollutants simultaneously – as those are a more realistic reflection of true human exposure and often show attenuated risks compared with single-pollutant models.

 

Key Activities

For 2017, program research will continue evaluating the relationships between air pollution and health. Specific efforts will include:

  • Analysis of a large nationwide cohort dataset to investigate key issues related to chronic health effects

  • Evaluate whether a threshold exists for PM2.5 and O3 below which adverse health effects may not occur

  • Continued critical evaluation of benefits assessment tools used in Regulatory Impact Analyses, including possible tool improvements and enhanced uncertainty analysis
  • Evaluation of ozone concentration-response models
  • Continued investigation of SO2 and NO2 health effects using epidemiological approaches
  • Evaluation of current and alternative regulatory approaches to PM risk assessment and management
  • Continuation of research on the extent of life shortening due to air pollution exposure
  • Multicity epidemiological studies to better determine the sources and components of air pollution responsible for observed health effects
  • Exploration of the impacts of the use of different exposure metrics (e.g., measurements, models) on epidemiological effect estimates
  • Evaluation of potential health impacts (or benefits) related to the power system of the future, which could include effects of fossil-based distributed generation, energy storage, and increased deployment of renewables.

 

 

Estimated 2017 Program Funding
$1.8 M

Last Updated
  • Benefits and Risk Assessments
    09-Jun-2016

    PM benefits and risk assessment plays a key role in Regulatory Impact Analyses (RIAs) for any EPA regulation that either targets PM directly or that includes co-benefits of PM reductions (for example, EGU [Electric Generating Unit] Mercury and Air Toxics Standards [MATS]). Both costs (control costs to meet a particular regulation) and benefits (monetization of health benefits purported to occur as a result of mitigation of air pollution) are considered as part of RIAs. Generation of primary health data from observational studies of human populations is critical for developing concentration-response functions that are used in benefit calculations. Once the data are generated from these long-term studies, many activities can be conducted using these and other data in the short term that can inform PM risk assessment. This project consists of a portfolio of research that is intended to address key issues related to risk assessment inputs or methodologies, or to the communication of risk to the public.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Health Effects of Future Power System
    10-Jun-2016

    Currently, the energy system is undergoing rapid change in efforts to be responsive to the needs for flexibility, resiliency and reliability in the future. This future energy system will consist of a multi-directional grid connecting central and distributed generation, increased renewable and natural gas generation, microgrids, energy storage and new technologies such as electric vehicles. The potential impacts of this system on public health have not been fully articulated or quantified as yet. It is critical that the positive and negative impacts of emerging energy technologies and their interconnections be investigated at early stages in advance of their widespread deployment in order to ensure proactive solutions, should issues be identified.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Health Effects of SO2 and NO2
    08-Jun-2016

    Air pollution is a complex mixture composed of multiple particle- and gas-phase materials. Two of the criteria gases regulated by EPA as part of the National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS) process under the Clean Air Act are sulfur dioxide (SO2) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2). The roles played by SO2 and NO2 in health effects attributed to air pollution need clarification to most effectively protect public health, particularly in light of recently proposed, or enacted, changes to the NAAQS for these gases, both of which are emitted directly from fossil fuel combustion. It is important to understand their roles in potential health effects so that risk management strategies can be designed to protect public health at the least cost.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Ozone Health Effects: Threshold Issues
    08-Jun-2016

    Ozone is regulated by the US EPA as a criteria pollutant under the Clean Air Act. Recently, the ozone National Ambient Air Quality Standard (NAAQS) was lowered to 70 ppb from the previous 75 ppb, continuing a trend of ratcheting down of the standard. This makes the issue of thresholds – that is, a level of ozone below which there may be no adverse effects – a critical issue for informing the development of any future ozone standards. Ozone is associated with power plant emissions due to the fact that it forms in part from NOx, which is directly emitted from fossil fuel combustion

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Particulate Matter Health Effects
    08-Jun-2016

    The NAAQS for particulate matter (PM) is reviewed on a five-year cycle. The current standard is often exceeded in many parts of the country, and secondary particles associated with power industry emissions (sulfate and nitrate) are a major component of ambient PM. There are many scientific uncertainties regarding the health effects of PM, including:

    • The PM sources and components most strongly associated with adverse health impacts;

    • The potential for bias in long-term study risk estimates that are currently used by EPA;

    • The extent of life shortening caused by exposure to PM; and
    • The potential existence of a no-effect threshold below which no adverse health effects may be expected.

     

    High-quality, scientifically robust, and focused epidemiological and toxicological studies are needed to inform regulators and other stakeholders about these issues.

Overview

Program Description

Energy storage and distributed generation technologies are attracting increasing interest from utilities and regulators as localized flexible grid assets. Storage can act as a buffer between electricity supply and demand, increasing the flexibility of the grid and allowing greater accommodation of variable renewable resources. Distributed generation (DG) entails the production of power at or near load centers, thereby augmenting or substituting electricity infrastructure with DG fuel infrastructure, where appropriate. Both storage and DG may provide temporary solutions for regional and local capacity shortages, and may provide relief to localized transmission and distribution congestion.

Technology advances, as well as investment in production capacity, have resulted in significant cost reductions of energy storage and distributed generation. However, the economic use of these technologies still generally requires the user to take full advantage of multiple potential benefit streams. The various applications that contribute to the value of distributed resources have different requirements, and the ways in which these requirements are coincident or competitive are still being explored. Technologies such as fuel cells, microturbines and small reciprocating generators are still relatively expensive in terms of installed capital cost, but low fuel costs and opportunities offered by the application of combined-heat-and-power (CHP) architectures may make them increasingly cost-effective options in the future.

It is important to understand the factors that may make storage and distributed generation technologies technically and economically viable in the future, whether the devices are owned and operated by utilities, by customers, or by third-parties. While storage and distributed generation options are rapidly maturing and are beginning to become practical in grid applications, there are still significant challenges to overcome:

  • Understanding the performance characteristics, cost, expected service lifetime, and relative maturity of various storage and distributed generation technologies in grid applications
  • Identifying the additional hardware, software, and user interfaces required to implement distributed resources on the grid
  • Defining the technical requirements for various applications of energy storage
  • Understanding the possible impact on transmission and distribution system planning, as well as construction and operations
  • Assessing the various uses of storage and distributed generation, including performance requirements, cost break-even points, and valuation
  • Understanding the effects of policy and regulation on the adoption and cost-effectiveness of storage and distributed generation applications
  • Understanding the environmental impact of storage and distributed generation

Research projects that address these challenges can help move practical storage and distributed generation technologies forward and enhance the value of these technologies to society.

Research Value

EPRI research focuses on facilitating the availability, use, and integration of grid-ready energy storage and distributed generation options for utility applications, as well as informing utilities, regulators, government agencies, and the general public on technical and economic issues, opportunities, and challenges related to the use of utility-scale energy storage and distributed generation.

The EPRI collaborative research environment enables engagement with utilities, technology developers, and other stakeholders to test and evaluate new technologies and products, define functional requirements for energy storage systems, develop tools and methodologies to analyze the effects of storage on the power delivery network and optimize their use, and create approaches that assess the business cases for storage in various applications and regions.

Through this program, utilities, government bodies, storage developers and vendors, electricity end users, and other stakeholders will be better informed about the opportunities and challenges facing electric energy storage and distributed generation technologies and products deployed on the grid.

This program conducts research to advance energy storage and distributed generation technologies as grid-integrated resources that can enhance the flexibility of the electricity system to manage peak demands and accommodate the intermittency of renewable resources, thereby improving the reliability and environmental impact of electric service to benefit society.

Approach

This EPRI research will be shared with program members in a number of formats, and is expected to include the following:

  • Strategic intelligence and specific technology assessments of energy storage and related distributed energy resource (DER) options
  • Industry white papers to inform stakeholders on the maturity of various energy storage and DER technologies and the potential of grid-related applications
  • Functional requirement documents and technical specifications for grid-connected distributed storage and generation systems that can increase the flexibility of distribution grids as well as the bulk power system
  • Deep dives into the cost and performance of energy storage and distributed generation technology options
  • Up-to-date case summaries of on-going energy storage demonstrations
  • Test reports providing data on the operating envelope, performance, and durability of emerging energy storage systems
  • Case studies to define storage operational requirements, suitable locations, and scale, as well as duration requirements of storage solutions for maximizing the expected benefits
  • Industry forums, such as the Energy Storage Integration Council (ESIC), which bring together utilities, vendors, integrators, regulators, and other stakeholders to discuss technical issues related to energy storage specification, deployment, and operation
Accomplishments

The Energy Storage and Distributed Generation program has delivered valuable information over the years that have helped its members and the industry in numerous ways. Some examples include:

  • EPRI created the Energy Storage Cost Benchmarking Database 1.0 (EPRI 1024279) in 2012, and is updating it in 2016. This interactive cost tool builds on work done in previous years, particularly the Energy Storage Technology and Application Cost and Performance Database (EPRI 1021932) with updated data on the cost, performance, and capabilities of energy storage systems for various applications in an Excel-based software tool. The goal of the database is to develop consistent installed costs, and operations and maintenance costs, for a set of selected energy storage systems providing an identified set of services.
  • In 2016, EPRI released an Energy Storage Cost Template and Tool to assist in the development of cost estimate for field installations of energy storage.  The tool, reviewed and released publicly through ESIC, is expected to be used by utilities and vendors to help standardize cost approaches for energy storage systems.
  • In 2015, EPRI released the Integration Guidelines for Energy Storage, a project management handbook for distribution connected energy storage developed and reviewed through the ESIC. 
  • EPRI released the Energy Storage Valuation Tool (ESVT) 4.0 in 2014.  A successor tool StorageVET, is scheduled for release in 2016. StorageVET is a software program that can help utilities and regulators understand when and where grid-connected energy storage systems can be justified in terms of benefit and cost. This tool is continuously refined and updated.  In early 2013, EPRI used inputs from the California Public Utility Commission Stakeholder Group for the Energy Storage Order Instituting Rulemaking process to inform the group's discussion on targets for energy storage adoption in California. Since that time, EPRI has worked with more than a dozen utilities to use and assess the analysis methodology in their service territories.
  • EPRI worked with the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE), the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association, (NRECA), Sandia National Laboratory, and several other stakeholders including a number of utilities, to develop the DOE-EPRI Energy Storage Handbook. Available free to the public from Sandia National Laboratory (SAND2013-5131), this handbook is a comprehensive introduction to designing, procuring, installing, and operating utility-scale energy storage systems, and serves as a resource to utilities, vendors, and other stakeholders in the utility energy storage area.
  • In 2013, EPRI established the Energy Storage Integration Council (ESIC), a technical forum in which electric utilities guide a discussion with energy storage vendors, technology researchers, government organizations, and other stakeholders to develop reliable, safe, and cost-effective energy storage options for the utility industry. In less than one year, the organization has grown to represent more than a hundred stakeholders in the energy storage area, addressing critical technical issues to support the imminent deployment of energy storage systems in several jurisdictions around the world.
Key Activities

In 2017, this research program expects to accomplish these objectives:

  • Continue refinement of StorageVET to allow faster and more accurate estimates of the value of grid-connected energy storage systems in various scenarios, based on case studies and applications in real-world utility cases.
  • Extend the methodology for distribution-level analysis of grid impacts of energy storage using OpenDSS or similar tools, and develop case studies that can inform the refinement of reference specifications, enhance the accuracy of value analysis tools, and inform the creation of appropriate algorithms for the control of energy storage.
  • Extend the methodology for bulk system-level analysis for the use of energy storage on the grid, using Plexos® or similar tools, and to develop case studies that can similarly inform the specification, analysis, and operational algorithms needed for the effective use of energy storage on the grid.
  • Continue conducting the Energy Storage Integration Council, and expand ties with DOE, the vendor community, and industry groups such as the Electricity Storage Association (ESA), the Institute for Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE), and the International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC).

  • PS94B: Energy Storage Technology and Analytics
    02-Jun-2016

    Current and emerging energy storage technologies and products could bring new opportunities for improved control and reliability of utility operations, reduced cost for new infrastructure and enhanced integration of renewable generation. However, utilities and other stakeholders require the right tools and guidelines to understand where energy storage makes sense, and how to apply it when it does.  Such information includes technical characteristics, technology performance and cost information, and guidelines for safe and reliable specification and integration of energy storage options.

    This project set provides a collection of foundational tools, analysis results, and industry guidelines for identifying, assessing, and integrating energy storage across a range of use cases.  This information is crucial for strategic planning, deployment, and operation of energy storage. As part of this project EPRI intends to produce annual in-depth technology assessments, track and assess cost and performance of energy storage products and projects across a range of uses, and develop tools, methods, and analyses of the benefits of energy storage relative to the costs.  EPRI also intends to produce individual assessments of energy storage technologies and to conduct the Energy Storage Integration Council, a forum bringing together utilities, vendors, government, and other research organizations for technical collaboration to advance a comprehensive set of energy storage integration guidelines across the lifecycle of energy storage projects.  

    In this project, EPRI seeks to address the following research questions:

    • What is the value of energy storage systems to generation, transmission, and distribution utility functions, as well as to end use customers, based on advanced analytical tools that model production cost, transmission power flow, distribution systems, and customer impacts?
    • What is the cost of energy storage today, and what is the impact of size, location, technology, and applications?
    • What is the detailed information on the technical performance and economics of specific energy storage technologies of interest?
    • What are the key technical issues and the current best practices and guidelines for the integration of energy storage projects?
    • P94.013: Energy Storage Valuation Analysis
      15-Jun-2016

      Energy storage is an emerging utility asset without consistent and validated approaches to benefit-cost analysis for use in utility planning and operational practices.

      This project develops foundational analysis tools, methodologies, and summary analyses that provide strategic information on the value of energy storage systems relative to their costs.  The primary investigation of this project is to determine how to determine the uses, locations, and technology characteristics of energy storage systems that make economic sense for deployment.  Techno-economic analyses are approached at different levels of detail, which include tradeoffs of cost, complexity, and accuracy.  This project will seek to develop methods that are appropriate for all levels of detail, including regional screening, site-specific benefit-cost analysis, and analysis that informs product and project design optimization. 

    • P94.014: Energy Storage Technology Cost Analysis and Database
      15-Jun-2016

      Energy storage is diverse asset class with many potential technologies, locations, sizes, and uses. This project researches and compares the cost structure of various energy storage technologies, based on vendor information, deep-dive technical assessments conducted over a period of time, and other deployment data as available. It also seeks to determine the relationships of cost and performance with the size, location, and use of energy storage products and projects.

    • P94.015: Energy Storage Technology Assessment
      15-Jun-2016

      Energy storage is a technological area evolving at a significant pace with a number of different technological approaches, including electrochemical, electromechanical, electrothermal, and other approaches.  This project conducts energy storage technology deep dives to investigate their present performance capabilities, advantages and disadvantages relative to other storage technologies, potential challenges to commercialization in utility applications, and cost structures.  The focus of this project is particularly on the underlying energy storage technologies, and assessment of the technology readiness and characteristics of these technologies in the context of project requirements for providing safe and reliable electric service.

    • P94.016: Energy Storage Integration Council
      15-Jun-2016

      The growing number of energy storage deployments is creating challenges for utility safety, reliability, and internal planning and operational processes. This project supports the Energy Storage Integration Council (ESIC), a collaborative technical forum with a mission to advance the integration of energy storage through open, technical collaboration, guided by the vision of universally-accessible safe, secure, reliable, affordable, environmentally responsible electricity.  Hundreds of ESIC participants include a diverse group of stakeholders, including electric utilities, energy storage vendors, system integrators, researchers, consultants, NGO’s and regulatory staff.  The primary purpose of ESIC is to work collaboratively to create public, technical reference guidelines for the integration of energy storage throughout the project lifecycle.

  • PS94C: Distribution Level Energy Storage
    02-Jun-2016

    Distributed energy storage technologies such as batteries have progressed immensely in the last decade, improving substantially in performance while dropping in price, as a result of sustained investment driven by the need for better storage technologies for mobile electronics and electric vehicles. Storage developers and integrators are now turning their attention toward developing complete grid storage products that incorporate storage technologies with power electronics, thermal management, and control systems. These products are still relatively immature, but are making rapid strides toward deployment.

    Meanwhile, utilities are beginning to address issues related to integrating storage to the grid, including interconnection, protection, communication, grid effects, and operational algorithms. Collaborative research bringing together efforts from utilities, storage vendors, integrators, and other stakeholders, can accelerate this process towards cost-effective energy storage products that are ready for deployment and operation as grid assets in substations, along the feeder, and beyond the meter.

    To implement these new products, utilities need empirical information on costs, performance, operational characteristics, reliability, risks, and durability. Research is required to better understand grid integration solutions and tools, including energy storage system capabilities such as performance, efficiency, and cycling capability.

    This project set focuses on applied research to facilitate the incorporation of energy storage technologies into complete, grid-ready storage systems that can be easily deployed on the grid, as well as methods to support the proper integration of such systems into the bulk grid. Research includes testing storage system capabilities and advancing grid-integration tools via case studies and tool development. Research also aims to understand the performance and technical readiness of energy storage technologies to provide desirable utility modes of operation under varying conditions. In addition, research examines the effects of storage on the grid in terms of stability, control, reliability, and impacts on transmission and distribution (T&D) system planning, construction, and operation to ensure that the physical connection of storage solutions is effective.

    • P94.017: Distribution Energy Storage Technologies and Products
      15-Jun-2016

      This project focuses on applied research to facilitate the incorporation of energy storage technologies into complete, easily deployable, grid-ready storage systems. Research may include:

      • Testing of distribution-level energy storage systems for performance, efficiency, life, and other parameters in  the laboratory and in the field.
      • Development of tools and models for distribution-level energy storage systems, potentially including sizing tools and performance models.
      • Reporting on related technologies such as power conversion, thermal management, and balance of plant for distribution energy storage.
      • Functional requirements documents, use case documents, technical specifications, and laboratory and field test plans for energy storage products.
      • Creation of best practices manuals for operations, maintenance, and disposal of distribution energy storage systems.
      • Investigation of requirements and considerations in contracting for energy storage systems as a service.

      The scope will depend on available funding as well as priorities expressed by members.

    • P94.018: Distribution Energy Storage Modeling and Analysis
      15-Jun-2016

      Traditional distribution planning techniques are well established in the power systems, yet the majority of energy storage systems are deployed in the field without these analyses. The technical studies done so far typically do not quantify the relative benefits of energy storage systems’ size and deployment locations. The storage systems on the distribution system have been deployed ad hoc depending on what manufacturers have offered in terms of rating (MW, MWh), controls, and performance. The fundamental issue with any of the current approaches used for energy storage assessment is that these valuation analyses are performed on an ad hoc basis. These analyses are typically performed without taking into consideration the technical attributes and operational capabilities of a distribution feeder to which it will connect. For a specific operational use of energy storage, the effects of combining primary grid services benefits with multiple secondary benefits are therefore difficult to evaluate quantitatively.

      The creation of a formal process is therefore required to understand the potential grid impacts and benefit of various PV deployments scenarios and opportunities of energy storage (utility-connected as well as customer sited) along the distribution system. To determine whether the energy storage system will fit into the utility’s grid system, this assessment will develop case study and data analytics necessary to perform the technical and cost/benefit analysis of realizing the potential solution opportunities of energy storage.

      The project will expand EPRI’s efforts to model the effects of grid-integrated storage in terms of voltage impact, control and communications, operational requirements, and identification of suitable locations and scale for connecting storage.

      Research may include the development of:

      • Tools and models for distribution-level energy storage systems, including grid-effects models and control modeling
      • Deployment guidelines highlighting procedures for siting, permitting, and site preparation at storage installation sites
      • Interconnection and integration guidelines for energy storage systems connected to the distribution system
      • Charge/discharge profiles, control schema, and communications protocols for distribution energy storage systems
      • Requirements and considerations in contracting for energy storage systems as a service

      The scope will depend on available funding as well as priorities expressed by members.

      What are the effects of energy storage systems on the distribution system, including voltage impact and operational requirements? Can modeling help site and scale energy storage systems for grid interconnection?

  • PS94D: Transmission and Bulk Level Energy Storage
    02-Jun-2016

    Cost-effective and reliable bulk energy storage can benefit the electric power delivery network by balancing supply and demand and optimizing bulk power resources, including nuclear, fossil, and renewable resources.  Bulk energy storage can also enhance transmission system effectiveness by allowing system operators to move energy at off-peak times when transmission lines are less fully loaded.  As state renewable portfolio standards (RPS) continue to increase, encouraging a high penetration rate of variable renewable resources, bulk power storage provides an important option to help utilities manage the variability of renewable resources.

    This project set examines topics such as:

    • Providing technical updates on cost, performance, operational capabilities and the development timeline of bulk storage technologies.
    • Developing laboratory and field test plans, as well as third party testing of bulk energy storage systems for performance, efficiency, life, and other parameters.
    • Understanding the system-wide benefits of bulk energy storage, such as reduced thermal generator ramping and lowering greenhouse gas emissions.
    • Modeling bulk storage to determine grid effects, preferred charge/discharge profiles, control schemes and ultimately bulk storage system value.
    • Demonstrating bulk energy storage systems for grid support and developing  deployment guidelines for siting, inter-connection and permitting.
    • Understanding the performance risks, financial risks and potential operational issues of  various technologies.
    • Creating a set of best practices for operations & maintenance of bulk energy storage systems.

    The scope of projects and tasks in this project set depends on available funding as well as priorities expressed by members.

    • P94.019: Transmission and Bulk Energy Storage Technologies
      15-Jun-2016

      Bulk energy storage systems have the potential to enhance grid flexibility, reliability and durability by providing many market-based services and facilitating better utilization of existing grid assets. Bulk storage can also enhance wind farm economics and facilitate variable generation integration. As a result, a wide variety of bulk storage technologies are emerging. Some of these technologies are at, or near, pilot-scale demonstration on the grid, while others are at earlier technology readiness levels. This project examines the questions of the performance, cost, functional capabilities and development timeline of select bulk storage technologies.

    • P94.020: Transmission and Bulk Energy Storage Modeling and Analysis
      15-Jun-2016

      Bulk energy storage systems have the potential to enhance grid flexibility, reliability and durability by providing many market-based services and facilitating better utilization of existing grid assets. Bulk storage can also enhance wind farm economics and facilitate variable generation integration.

      This project considers research questions such as the following. Can grid-connected bulk energy storage systems improve the value of large-scale grid assets, including variable renewable generation assets? How can energy storage technologies be deployed at the bulk grid level to improve the flexibility of the grid, thereby improving system reliability and efficiency and increasing the ability to accommodate large scale variable renewable generation?  Can the industry develop standard methodologies for modeling bulk energy storage that take into account the unique characteristics of storage?

  • PS94E: Customer-Sited Energy Storage and Combined Heat and Power
    14-Oct-2016

    The falling cost of energy storage technologies, along with government incentives and changes in regulations in some jurisdictions, has increased the interest in the placement of energy storage systems at customer sites.  Customer-sited storage has many potential benefits, including: 

    • Backup power to reduce the duration of power interruptions
    • Reduced demand charges
    • Shifting of locally-produced solar energy to match local demand
    • Support of electric vehicle charging
    • The possibility of conducting arbitrage if time-of-use rates are available. 

    Customer-sited storage can be even more attractive when tied with distributed energy resources.  EPRI is investigating how storage can be best integrated with technologies such as solar PV, solar forecasting, fuel cells, load management, and energy efficiency to improve reliability and value to the end consumer while also increasing the flexibility and reliability of the grid.

    Natural gas distributed generation can also have a strong value proposition for customers, particularly when combined with waste heat recovery. This high-efficiency approach particularly makes sense where the prices of both natural gas and electricity are high (such as parts of Europe and Asia).  Such applications are also worth study to understand the effect on other uses of distributed generation, such as providing resiliency. Regulatory and legislative actions are leading to increased adoption, and utilities would be wise to take these resources into account in their overall planning process, and possibly take advantage of them through an Integrated Grid approach.

    As these products become increasingly viable, it is important that utilities, regulators, customers, and other stakeholders acquire sound empirical information on performance, costs, operational characteristics, reliability, risks, and durability of customer-sited products. Research is required to better understand grid integration solutions and tools, including energy storage system capabilities such as performance, efficiency, and cycling capability.

    This project set focuses on applied research to understand the issues related to customer-sited energy storage and distributed generation, both grid-connected and off-grid. While utilities may not be directly involved with off-grid systems, it is important to understand the performance capabilities and limitations of such systems, as well as their costs. 

    Research also aims to understand the performance and technical readiness of energy storage technologies to provide desirable modes of operation for customers and the utility under varying conditions.

    • P94.021: Customer-Sited Energy Storage Technologies and Products
      15-Jun-2016

      Customer-sited energy storage systems are rapidly achieving viability and deployment in places across the world.  Several Japanese companies, including Panasonic and Hitachi, have released residential and commercial electric energy storage systems in Japan to address capacity issues in the wake of the Fukushima incident.  Likewise, German companies such as Sonnenschein have produced high-quality integrated residential storage products as a response to policy incentives favoring self-consumption.  More recently, companies such as Sunverge and Tesla have released prominent products into the North American market.  In addition, there are also a number of thermal storage systems on the market, including hot water heaters and ice storage systems, which can be used as effectively as electrical energy storage in many contexts.

      It is important for utilities, regulators, customers, and other stakeholders to understand how well these products work, how much they cost, and what is entailed in their operation.

    • P94.022: Customer-Sited Energy Storage and DG Modeling & Analysis
      15-Jun-2016

      The existence and deployment of customer-sited energy storage leads to the question of where such systems can be most useful to customers.  While the backup benefits of energy storage are well-understood, other applications, such as demand peak reduction, require more sophisticated technical and economic analysis.  It is also worth considering whether customer-sited storage might be used with solar to operate off-grid, and how other technologies such as load control can be used to enhance the value of storage.

    • P94.023: Combined Heat and Power
      15-Jun-2016

      Combined heat and power (CHP) is a unique opportunity to produce power and heat at high efficiency on the customer side of the meter, using distributed  generation devices.  CHP is typically conducted with a high-temperature energy conversion device such as a turbine or a fuel cell, set up in a system designed to collect waste heat from the energy conversion process.  This research will explore the options and considerations related to the deployment of customer-side combined heat and power (CHP) installations.

    • P94.024: Microgrids
      15-Jun-2016

      Microgrids are a potential strategy to improve power system resiliency while making good use of distributed renewable generation. The objective for each end-user, or community, is to build on the reliability of the existing grid connection in a compatible and interactive way. Detailed assessments are needed to evaluate objective and feasibility as a resiliency improvement, including validation of various arrangements, configurations, interconnection issues, communication methods, and control systems. Site-specific energy economics and environmental constraints are also critical aspects of feasibility.  The purpose of this project is to examine where microgrids are compatible, complementary, and appropriately interactive with the existing grid.

Overview

Program Description

The relationship between international and domestic climate policies and ultimately how domestic regulations are implemented can yield dramatically different outcomes in total cost and who pays. In particular, the form of domestic policies will influence the role of the power sector in achieving economy-wide greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions targets. In the U.S., where federal climate policy is being implemented sector-by-sector, policy incentives discourage electrification – effectively foregoing one of the most promising approaches to a lower-carbon future.

As individual nations and the global community seek realistic, achievable, and responsible paths forward, good information and careful framing of key questions are critical. The global power industry plays a key role. In the United States, climate policies are being implemented in a variety of ways that require an improved understanding of the fundamentals of the issue. Assessments of the potential impacts from climate change (such as the social cost of carbon) are being used as key elements of U.S. federal, state and local regulations. Internationally, the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), Conference of the Parties (COP21) concluded with an agreement that for the first time included commitments to limit GHG emissions from almost all of the world’s countries. The unique scientific, economic, and technological concerns of the power industry are critical to the policy debate, and research is essential to informing stakeholder discussions over the fundamental form and the details of these policy actions. Building the understanding and institutional capacity to implement efficient policies to reduce GHG emissions will take years, but the payoff will be considerable.

The Electric Power Research Institute’s (EPRI’S) Energy and Climate Policy Analysis program provides public- and private-sector decision makers with analyses and information on the potential costs and benefits of domestic and international policy proposals and regulations. The program’s modeling and analyses provide crucial information needed to make economically and environmentally sound climate and energy policy decisions, and also inform power companies of the possible near-, mid-, and long-term implications of different policy approaches, helping them to make better decisions. Program research focuses on estimating the economic costs of climate policy proposals against the backdrop of other energy, environmental, and economic policies; identifying cost-effective strategies and policy principles for reducing these costs, including evaluating adaptation and mitigation strategies for managing climate change risk; and comparing potential costs with the potential avoided risks of lower GHG concentrations. The research also examines the value of technological advances in limiting policy costs, and explores emission offsets as a large-scale, low-cost, and environmentally effective compliance strategy. Investing in technology and policy design research today is essential to having these emission reduction options available when needed in the future.

The research in this program provides essential inputs to, and is closely tied to, the complementary research conducted in two other program under Energy and Environmental Analysis: Analysis of Environmental Policy Design, Implementation and Company Strategy and Technology Assessment, Market Analysis and Integrated Portfolio Planning.  It also provide essential inputs into EPRI’s Integrated Energy Network effort.

Research Value

Well-informed policy choices can help society achieve environmental goals efficiently and effectively, avoiding problematic designs and saving trillions of dollars. This program has a strong track record of identifying critical issues, performing world-class research, and putting insights into the hands of companies, domestic and international decision makers, and the public dialogue at the right time. The program’s internationally recognized experts are effectively able to bridge the often-broad gap between the technical and policy communities. In particular, this program:

  • Analyzes the potential cost and benefit implications of domestic and international climate policy proposals, supplying policymakers and power industry executives with crucial, analytically rigorous information for economically and environmentally sound policy decisions;
  • Identifies policy principles and designs to minimize costs;
  • Provides a strong and respected analytical basis for representing power industry issues in climate policy discussions;
  • Quantifies the value of technological advances in limiting policy costs and climate risks; and
  • Explores the potential supply and role of emission offsets as a key compliance strategy, as well as new approaches for developing offsets.

The program’s modeling and analyses provide policymakers with crucial information needed to make economically and environmentally sound climate and energy policy decisions, and also inform members of the possible near-, mid-, and long-term implications of different policy approaches, helping them to make better decisions.

Approach

The program develops and applies innovative policy analysis tools, in house and with leading educational and external research groups from around the world, to inform the public policy discussions. EPRI staff lead collaborative research efforts, such as those undertaken by Stanford’s Energy Modeling Forum; play leadership roles in the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) and the U.S. National Climate Assessment; and participate on key U.S. National Research Council, Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), and Department of Energy (DOE) scientific panels. This program delivers:

  • Independent scenario analyses, published in peer-reviewed scientific journals, that evaluate the implications of key international and domestic policy choices;
  • Study results that can be used to develop presentation materials for internal and external communications;
  • Fundamental insights into the role of technology and the value of technological advances in achieving energy and environmental goals;
  • Multi-stakeholder workshops on climate policy design, emissions offsets, and other topics of interest (such as climate change risks and adaptation) for key leaders and technical staff in industry, federal and state government, international organizations, academia, environmental and other NGOs, the financial community, and other stakeholders; and

An annual session on Energy and Climate Research issues at EPRI ENV-VISION Conference which draws a broad government, research, and industry audience.

Accomplishments

EPRI’s climate policy research has a long track record of effectively informing international and domestic policy decisions. EPRI staff and research have played a critical role, introducing a number of fundamental concepts into policy discussions: the value of flexibility in where and when emission reductions are made, the essential role of technology advances in controlling the cost of policy, and the importance of electrification as emission limits tighten. The program has also played a leadership role in the analytical community, providing initial and sustained support over the past two decades for MIT’s Global Change Research Program and Battelle’s Joint Institute for Global Change Research. More recent program accomplishments include:

  • EPRI has been influential in the organization of research efforts through the Energy Modeling Forum, leading to the publication of special-issue journals on U.S. and international climate policy scenarios.
  • EPRI co-chairs the International Energy Workshop, a three-day annual international meeting of 200 energy policy modelers.
  • EPRI researchers have published peer-reviewed papers in numerous publications, including Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences; GHG Market Report 2015, International Emissions Trading Association; American Economic Review; and Climatic Change
  • EPRI researchers have participated in various expert panels, including: 1) Lead authors for the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Fifth Assessment Report; 2) National Academies of Science Implication of Tax Code on GHG Emissions Report; 3) U.S. National Climate Assessment Report; 4) EPA scientific advisory panel on the carbon neutrality of biomass; 5) National Academy of Sciences panel on the Social Cost of Carbon.
Key Activities

Program R&D in 2017 will continue to focus on gaining a better understanding of climate policy choices and their implications, and on exploring the institutions and information needed to improve the efficiency of future climate policies. Key priorities will be to improve understanding of global climate impact assessments and their relationship to U.S. regulatory development and to explore in-depth the role of economy-wide electrification. Specific efforts will include:

  • Examining the role of technology and electrification in reducing GHG emissions and improving economic efficiency, with more detailed assessments of reducing multiple air pollutants at a regional level.
  • Examining the key international energy drivers and goals for climate policy and their domestic implications;
  • Continuing to participate in community and governmental modeling and analysis efforts such as the Stanford Energy Modeling Forum’s series of studies on climate change and EPA scientific advisory boards; and
  • Continuing active development of land-use change, forestry, and agricultural modeling tools to inform policymakers and companies.

  • Climate Change Impacts Valuation and Risk Management
    07-Jun-2016

    Under the Climate Change Impacts Valuation area, the research conducted under this project would inform federal and other regulatory and policy processes through assessment and analyses of estimates of potential climate damages.  Federal and state agencies as well as policy leaders are using valuations of avoided climate impacts as justification for climate policy and to set greenhouse gas emissions standards (e.g., the social cost of carbon). This research effort will analyze and assess the underlying studies and tools that support climate benefit estimates.  This includes social cost of carbon modelling, U.S. specific impacts analyses, individual sector climate impacts studies (e.g., agriculture, cooling and heating requirements, morbidity and mortality, sea level rise), and fundamental inputs and tools (e.g., scaling uncertainty, historical uncertainties).

    Under the Risk Management area, the research conducted under this project will provide insights into trade-offs between climate risk management costs (mitigation and adaptation) and potential avoided climate risks.  Today’s policies and near-term strategies, such as regulations, for managing the risk of climate change should include consideration of the stakes and the odds, i.e., costs, value and probability.  However, current approaches associated with identifying climate policy objectives pay little attention to (a) the major uncertainties surrounding future climate change and the potential impacts of climate change, and (b) the potential costs associated with managing those uncertainties. As such, near-term strategies are not properly informed. The project will evaluate alternative characterizations of uncertainties (e.g., socioeconomic development, mitigation costs, physical climate system, and potential climate damages), and analyze hedging strategies that balance mitigation costs, adaptation opportunities, and uncertain climate consequences. The research will help evaluate potential implications for near-term decisions, identify circumstances that meaningfully influence decisions, and compare those circumstances to the state of scientific knowledge.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Economy-wide Analyses of U.S. Energy and Climate Policy Objectives
    07-Jun-2016

    Two principal policy initiatives to mitigate greenhouse gases (GHGs) have created renewed attention on economy-wide analyses approaches: current regulatory efforts under the Clean Air Act (CAA) targeting individual sectors, i.e., electric power, transportation, and oil & natural gas; and the U.S. pledge to reduce all GHGs under the Paris Agreement leading to a long-term 80% reduction goal by 2050.  Recent analysis have clearly identified a “Gap” between the long-term goal and the estimated reductions from CAA regulations.

    Research questions arising from the new policy initiatives to be addressed under Program 102 include: 

    • What will be the impact on and contribution from the power sector?

    • Is CAA sector-by-sector approach incentivizing or dis-incentivizing electrification?

    • What will various U.S. sectors contribute to overall reductions?

    • How could national policies impact the power system and consumers at the state and regional level?

    Previous economic analyses of economy-wide GHG mitigation point to the cost benefits of de-carbonizing the power sector first by deploying advanced generation technologies then electrifying the other sectors of the economy. Understanding and evaluating alternatives to the current carbon policy are important to put forward as policymakers and industry leaders seek out efficient approaches to mitigating GHGs.

  • National Impacts of International Climate Policies
    09-Jun-2016

    In December 2015, the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), Conference of the Parties (COP21) was held in Paris, France.  The meeting concluded with an international agreement that for the first time included greenhouse gas emission reduction commitments from most of the world’s countries, including specific pledges from over 185 countries. The agreement also included legal requirements for regular emissions reporting and updating of emissions reduction plans every 5 years.  In addition, low-carbon technology development, deployment, and finance were recognized as critical to long-run climate goals.

    The U.S. reinforced its Nationally Determined Goal to reduce emissions 26% to 28% below 2005 levels by 2025 while maintaining the long-term goal of reducing emissions 80% below 2005 levels by 2050.   This project will continue its focus on the following research questions: How might countries achieve their goals? How might policies interact across countries? How might economic sectors interact within and across countries? How might countries proceed beyond 2025/2030?  In addition, the project also will assess the importance of clean power technology deployment and how the electrification of end use technologies can mitigate emissions at the global level.

Program Name: Analysis of Environmental Policy Design, Implementation and Company Strategy
text:
Overview

Program Description

The electric sector faces a near-continuous series of policies and regulations creating compliance requirements that challenge operations and alter investment strategies. The most important is the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency’s (EPA’s) ongoing rulemaking limiting CO2 emissions from existing fossil generation under Section 111(d) of the Clean Air Act, known as the Clean Power Plan (CPP). Under the CPP, states are required to create plans to implement the rule. While EPA granted states flexibility in creating their plans, this flexibility means that states must make a number of fundamental choices such as rate or mass targets, market vs. non-market compliance mechanisms, and how to interact with other states. The many options introduce complexity to the plans and place a burden on the states to find the best path. The broad scope of this process, and its uniqueness compared to past regulatory efforts, creates many challenges for the states and increases the risk of unintended consequences. In addition to the Clean Power Plan, utilities face great uncertainty over the shape of CO2 policy beyond 2030, and how that will impact their own investment and business strategies today. 

Legal uncertainty over the future of the Clean Power Plan, expected tighter ozone standards, post-2030 CO2 policy, continued volatility of natural gas prices, rapidly expanding use of intermittent generation, and slow grid-delivered load growth (driven by increased energy efficiency, rooftop PV, and natural gas generation) creates a myriad of immediate challenges for electric company decision makers. Should a coal plant be retired, retrofitted, or converted to burn gas? How will the values of current assets change as other plants retire and as intermittent generation is integrated into the system? What do the current natural gas prices mean for returns on capital investments, and how could that outlook change? Will increased reliance on natural gas overload the gas transmission system at critical times and impact reliability? Will LNG exports drive up natural gas prices? How can the possibility of future energy and environmental policies be usefully included in analyses of near- and long-term decisions? Making well-informed decisions requires new information and new ways of analyzing decisions.

In addition, the electric sector is also facing the impacts of novel technologies now, and an accelerating rate of innovation for generation and customer-side technologies for the foreseeable future. The penetration of rooftop solar is stressing existing utility business models, increasing distribution costs while lowering net load served, and natural gas distributed generation may play a similar role in the future. Solar and wind generation are expected to increase the variability of the residual load, forcing the existing baseload fleet to operate more flexibility. Other nascent technologies continue to receive public or private support, such as storage, small modular reactors, demand response, and distributed generation, but their potential value and limitations given the uncertainties are poorly understood. Understanding the tradeoffs between differing technological pathways, independently of any policy drivers, and clearly communicating them can help inform current and future policy discussions and company decision-making.

To meet these challenges, the Electric Power Research Institute’s (EPRI) Analysis of Environmental Policy Design, Implementation and Company Strategy program develops and applies advanced modeling tools to provide public- and private-sector decision makers with fundamental insights regarding the cost and performance of policy and technology alternatives, for the electric sector and for the overall economy. Since 2012 the highest priority of this program has been to develop understanding and analytical tools to help power companies be more effective in participating in the CPP policy making process at the national level, and in the implementation at the state level in the future. The program also develops information, analyses, and tools to help inform company strategies in the face of emerging requirements and pervasive uncertainties. Research in this program supports EPRI’s Integrated Energy Network effort though focused pathways to reduce carbon and other emissions.

Research Value

Well-informed policy choices can help society achieve environmental goals while reducing policy costs. This program has a strong track record of not only performing world-class research but also getting the resulting information into the hands of decision makers at the right time. This program analyzes the potential cost and benefit implications of energy and environmental policy proposals, supplying policymakers and electric power industry executives with crucial information for economically and environmentally sound policy decisions. It also provides vital insights to help inform company investment decisions and strategies as companies work to comply with new environmental regulations and adapt to the current realities of changing fuel and electricity markets. Companies will be investing hundreds of billions of dollars of capital over the next decade to comply with energy and environmental regulations. Making well-informed decisions can potentially save companies and ratepayers tens of billions of dollars through lower compliance costs and less risky business strategies due to better understanding of potential policy impacts.

Approach

The program develops and applies innovative policy analysis tools, both in-house and with leading educational and external research groups, to inform public policy discussions and to support company strategy development. It produces methodologies that help companies understand how current investment choices may pay off in the short and long run, given the current, very uncertain investment environment. Policy insights are communicated primarily through presentations, briefings, and participation in expert panels. Company decision-support results are communicated primarily through webcasts, presentations, briefings, and EPRI technical reports. This program delivers:

  • Clear analyses of the key implications, for the electric sector and the economy, of energy and environmental policies;
  • A better understanding of strategies for complying with current and possible future energy and environmental policies, given a wide range of uncertainties;
  • Key insights into robust compliance and investment strategies; and
  • A strong track record for getting analysis results to key public and private decision makers.
Accomplishments

Policy designs for achieving an environmental goal can vary in cost by billions to trillions of dollars and can significantly affect returns on existing capital and on new corporate investments. Sound analyses and clear communication are critical to creating effective, efficient policies and effective corporate strategies. Program accomplishments include the following:

  • Conducted 16 webcasts with program members during 2015, all but one focused on a key element of EPA’s regulations for CO2 and the associated proposed federal plan. Also conducted numerous one-on-one webcasts and conference calls with program members.
  • Continued development and applications of a multi-region model of the U.S. economy (the U.S. Regional Energy, Greenhouse Gas and Environment model, US-REGEN) including detailed representation of the proposed CO2 regulations at the individual state level.
  • Explored practical limits to wind penetration and the long-distance transmission requirement for wide-scale deployment.
  • Developed comprehensive emission control cost data and analytical methods to inform company decisions to retrofit, retire, and/or convert capacity to other fuels such as natural gas.
Key Activities

Program R&D for 2017 will include the following:

  • Analyze the costs of specific proposed energy and environmental policies at the regional and national levels to inform policy discussions. The focus will depend upon resolution of expected legal appeals against the Clean Power Plan.  If the CPP survives appeal, this will include conducting analyses and creating background documents to help members work with their states and fellow utilities to create state plans that are cost-effective, robust with respect to critical uncertainties, and practical and straightforward to implement. If the CPP does not survive appeal, the focus will shift to analyzing likely climate policy and regulation, including the possibility of EPA using the Section 115 of the Clean Air Act, and/or other legal avenues for CO2 regulation.
  • Create information and approaches to help companies update business strategies and evaluate environmental compliance investments in light of an evolving and uncertain environmental policy landscape.
  • Conduct in-depth scenario analyses of specific technology pathways to explore potential implications for the electric sector. The goal is to identify pathways with high costs or benefits, to support discussions on policy options and long-term technology development, and help companies evaluate the associated risks.
Estimated 2017 Program Funding
$3.0M
Program Manager
David Young, 650-855-8927, dyoung@epri.com

    14-Jun-2016

    This project will help members understand and participate within their states in implementing EPA’s Clean Power Plan.  In general, this project estimates the economic costs of energy and environmental policies and regulations at the regional and national levels as needed to help inform policy development and company decision making. New, proposed, and future EPA regulations; state and regional renewable and climate policies; dramatic changes in fuel markets; and economic uncertainty combine to complicate analysis of new policies. Understanding and communicating the combined implications of policies against the backdrop of other key uncertainties is essential for good public and private decision making. Many aspects of combining different forms of policy are poorly understood. In particular, a better understanding is needed of the interplay between regulatory and market-based approaches to improve the cost-effectiveness of responses to emission reduction requirements.

    07-Jun-2016

    Multiple technological directions are being proposed or actively implemented in the electric sector in response to technological innovation and clean energy policies.  Some are still hypothetical, others are impacting the U.S. electric sector today.  The penetration of rooftop solar threatens existing utility business models, increasing distribution costs while lowering net load served.  Wind and solar penetration are expected to impact the fossil fleet, creating additional value for those generation units able to operate more flexibly.  Potential roles for storage, small modular reactors, demand response, and distributed generation are often discussed, but their value and limitations are poorly understood.  Understanding the tradeoffs between differing technological pathways and clearly communicating them can help inform current and future policy discussions and company decision-making.

    The electric sector is undergoing unprecedented change. Tightening environmental regulations combined with volatile natural gas prices, rapidly expanding use of intermittent generation, and slow load growth create a myriad of immediate challenges for electric company decision makers. Investment decisions have to be made now, yet the payoff for these decisions is unclear. Electric utility decision makers will need new data, methods, and analytical frameworks to navigate this sea change in their compliance and business environment.
