Program Name: End-Use Energy Efficiency and Demand Response
text:
Overview

Program Description

The electricity industry must meet customers' continuous demand for power as well as provide safe, reliable, affordable, and environmentally responsible service to customers. Utilities and policy makers in the United States and abroad are increasingly turning to energy efficiency as a resource to help address these challenges. Many U.S. states have enacted legislation that mandates specific energy-efficiency savings goals, and some explicitly require utilities to place energy efficiency as the first opportunity in their resource planning initiatives. Key to the realization of these goals is the development and adoption of emerging energy-efficient technologies and best practices.

In addition, it is important for utilities to characterize the grid impacts of customer interaction with emerging energy technologies, and to develop platforms for their integration as resources to enable an Integrated Power System. Interaction with the ‘connected’ customer that will provide both energy efficiency and demand response benefits that are crucial for the utility of the future.

Research Value

This program is focused on the assessment, testing, demonstration, deployment, and technology transfer of energy-efficient and demand-responsive end-use technologies to accelerate their adoption into utility programs, influence the progress of codes and standards, and ultimately lead to market transformation. The program also develops analytical frameworks essential to utility application of energy efficiency and demand response (DR) in order to enable the Integrated Power System, with particular focus on end-use load research and data analytics.

This program provides the following:

  • Objective, independent technical assessment, testing, and demonstration of emerging end-use technologies for energy efficiency and the enablement of DR technologies.
  • Framework to evaluate the readiness of emerging end-use technologies for utility programs along a research continuum spanning: technology scouting; assessment and lab testing; field testing and demonstration; field pilots; technology transfer; and full program rollout.
  • World-class laboratory facilities to test emerging end-use technologies in simulated environmental conditions, thereby mitigating members' technical risk for field demonstrations and larger-scale deployments or programs.
  • Multilevel assessment of enabling technologies for DR: components, sensors, and devices; systems for home and building energy management; and program integration into retail and wholesale markets.
  • Development of analytical frameworks to help members characterize end-use load profiles, extract insights from smart meter data and other customer databases.
  • Characterization of the grid impacts of customer interaction with emerging energy technologies and development of platforms for their integration as resources to enable an Integrated Power System.
  • Technical staff with expertise in heating, ventilating, and air conditioning (HVAC); lighting; water heating; motors; power electronics; data centers; building energy management systems and controls; smart end-use systems; and analytical frameworks for energy efficiency and demand response.

This program advances the efficient use of energy, helping to keep electric service affordable for customers and environmentally responsible for society through resource conservation and avoided emissions. It also facilitates the connected customer getting more value from their utility service.

Approach

The program uses the following approach to address the research gaps:

  • Validate the performance of emerging end-use technologies—for example, energy savings and peak demand reduction, reliability, and compatibility—to develop savings impacts to accelerate their adoption into programs and markets.
  • Update the Energy Efficiency Technology Readiness Guide, a compendium of technical, economic, and market readiness information for a comprehensive set of end-use technology categories, to serve as a convenient reference for utility energy-efficiency and demand response professionals.
  • Assess emerging energy efficiency and demand response technologies that could potentially support the Integrated Power System.
  • Conduct large-scale, multiyear field deployment of advanced energy-efficient technologies.
  • Produce in-depth technical reports and guidebooks and provide knowledge transfer through concise technical briefs, fact sheets, newsletters, and topical webinars throughout the year to members' staff and their end use customers.
  • Identify gaps and barriers to using AMI and other customer databases for development of analytics applications to derive utility and customer benefit. Showcase successful implementation of such applications.

Further, this program supports one of EPRI’s Research Imperatives to “Enable Integration of Customer Resources” by addressing the following research gaps:

  • Characterizing grid impacts of emerging energy efficiency and demand response technologies;
  • Integrating energy efficiency and demand response resources into grid operations.
Accomplishments

The research conducted through this program has helped members mitigate risk and avoid costs through:

  • Assessment, testing, demonstration, and field pilots of emerging energy-efficient and demand-responsive technologies and systems to determine efficacy prior to deployments in utility programs.
  • Synthesis of end-use load research results and techniques to provide predictive insights into electricity use forecasts.
  • AMI data analytics to provide valuable customer insights that can help improve customer satisfaction and utility operations.
  • Technology transfer through readiness guides, workshops, technical briefs and newsletters.

The program has also provided significant input towards the development of functional specifications for “demand-response-ready” (“DR-Ready”) end-use devices, including the definition of use cases and DR performance attributes. EPRI has facilitated a multidisciplinary dialogue on DR-Ready devices involving utilities, equipment manufacturers, public agencies and other industry stakeholders.

Finally, EPRI’s annual Technology Readiness Guides (2012, 2013, 2014 and 2015 editions) have benchmarked the maturity of technologies with respect to EPRI's energy efficiency technology development pipeline. They include comprehensive assessments of technologies, including detailed scoring criteria and estimates of energy savings potential.

Key Activities
  • Expand the scope and breadth of laboratory testing to keep pace with new and emerging technologies for energy efficiency and demand response and provide technical performance and operations data critical for utility business case evaluation and inclusion into customer programs.
  • Evaluate new energy efficiency and DR technologies for their grid impacts, and potential integration as resources to enable an Integrated Power System.
  • Assess utility applications that combine AMI data with other customer data sources (internal or external) to characterize benefits to customers and the utility, identify implementation barriers, and recommend solutions to overcome those barriers.
  • Consolidate summary profiles of end-use technology categories into an updated comprehensive Energy Efficiency Technology Readiness Guide for convenient reference. Provide assessment results for several technologies in technical briefs.
  • Issue strategic technology briefs, industry briefs, workshops, symposiums and other practical technology transfer and knowledge transfer tools for members.
Estimated 2017 Program Funding
$4.3M
Program Manager
Ammi Amarnath, 650-855-1007, aamarnath@epri.com

  • PS170A: Analytical Frameworks
    04-Jun-2016

    This project set develops and advances analytical frameworks, tools, and methodologies essential to utility application of customer resources and their impact on the integrated grid. Areas of interest include: energy efficiency and demand response, with particular focus on end?use load research and data analytics, the impact of and adoption of disruptive technologies and the integration of these impacts into grid planning, the load shape and economic evaluation of new customer technologies that may enhance grid operations and the realization of value from the large data sets available today through AMI, Smart Grid and other public/third party sources.  This project set characterizes end?use load profiles and advances techniques to extract insights from smart meter and other customer data. This project set can help utilities assign value to the impact of energy efficiency and demand response technologies and programs, disruptive technologies and grid integration. Participants will be well?positioned to create value from AMI and other customer data as well as to quantify the full benefits of their energy?efficiency and demand?response portfolios.

    Key research questions include:

    How can end?use load data be most cost?effectively and accurately acquired and analyzed to yield actionable insights for electric service providers?

    What are the key challenges faced and the types of methods/applications selected by utilities today in the process of implementing customer?oriented analytics?

    What are some of the advanced uses of customer?oriented analytics being used by the non?utility industries and how can we leverage them?

    How can we develop a generic framework that enables utilities to define the specific uses that meet their needs, determine the benefits and costs and support implementation?

    • P170.002: Impact of Energy Efficiency on Emissions of CO2 and Other Pollutants
      15-Jun-2016

      What are the environmental benefits from energy efficiency?

    • P170.005: End-Use Load Research
      15-Jun-2016

      How can end-use load data be most cost-effectively and accurately acquired and analyzed to yield actionable insights for electric service providers to maximize the value of customer resources and behavior into the integrated grid?

    • P170.024: Customer Data Analytics
      15-Jun-2016

      There is an industry need to integrate customer impacts into the applications of the grid operations and planning.  To meet this industry need, the following predictive customer analytics research questions need to be addressed:

      What are the current market products and their target applications that could benefit the utility and the utility customer?

      What are the key challenges faced and the types of methods/applications selected by utilities today in the process of implementing customer-oriented analytics?

      What are some of the advanced uses of customer-oriented analytics being used by the non-utility industries and how can it be leveraged?

      How is it possible to develop a generic framework that enables utilities to define the specific uses that meet their needs, determine the benefits and costs and support implementation?

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • PS170B: Demand Response Systems
    04-Jun-2016

    This project set takes a holistic look at demand response programs and technologies.  Some of the key research questions pertaining to demand response technologies addressed by this project set include:

    What are the capabilities required of mass market end use devices such as water heaters, thermostats, pool pumps and appliances for them to be “DR-Ready”, i.e., provide DR capabilities out of the box?  How can the utility requirements be harmonized with those of manufacturers to develop standards for DR-Ready devices?  How can thermal energy storage, both active and passive enable the grid to better align supply and demand on the grid?

    This project set also addresses demand response research at a more systematic level, addressing questions such as: What is the capability of building control systems to provide energy efficiency and demand response and what is the persistence of the measures?  What are the technology requirements to better enable the evolution of DR markets and enable utility participation in the markets?

    Further, this program supports one of EPRI’s Research Imperatives to “Enable Integration of Customer Resources”

    The work being done in this program is closely coordinated with and designed to complement the work undertaken in the Electric Transportation (P18), Energy Storage and Distributed Generation (P94), Information and Communication Technology (P161), Distribution Systems (P180), Integration of Distributed Energy Resources (P174), and Understanding Electric Utility Customers (P182) Programs.

     

    • P170.006: Enabling DR-Ready Devices and Programs
      15-Jun-2016

      Questions surround the capabilities required of mass market end-use devices such as water heaters, thermostats, pool pumps and appliances to be supportive of power system and market needs. To inform utility understanding of potential benefits and impacts of connected mass market end-use devices, the device capabilties need to be understood. Moreover, industry consensus is needed on what requirements for these devices could constitute being Demand Response-Ready (“DR-Ready”), with recognized capabilities supportive of the grid. Harmonization of utility requirements with physical product capabilities supported by manufacturers is also critical towards development of standards for DR-Ready devices.

    • P170.007: Peak Load Management of Thermal Loads
      15-Jun-2016

      Questions in thermal energy storage (TES) technologies revolve around assessing and valuing services offered by TES systems that extend above and beyond traditional peak load reduction. The value proposition of TES, particularly when aggregated and transformed into a dispatchable resource, is an important question, the answer to which will determine adoption of TES in utility portfolio. Quantifying cost of deploying such resources on customer side as compared to other storage technologies is also an area of research that will be addressed.

    • P170.009: Intelligent Buildings
      15-Jun-2016

      The hypothesis of this research is that residential building energy systems can be utilized as demand side resources such as energy efficiency (EE), demand response (DR) and PV power balancing. Drilling down the hypothesis yields three major research questions to be answered in the research:

      1. What services and support can residential buildings provide to grid operations?

      2. How can connected devices in smart homes (e.g., communicating thermostats, water heaters and plug load controllers) be leveraged in an aggregated fashion for PV balancing to mitigate dual daily peaks and excessive load ramping?

      3. What kind of portal can send the control signal to various home energy devices for aggregated response? 

    • P170.018: Demand Response Markets & Programs
      15-Jun-2016

      The evolution of wholesale markets and policies can impact implementation of utility demand response (DR) programs. How are market structures, rules, and policies evolving and how can utilities adjust DR program offerings in alignment with latest market developments? Who are the key players, what are their best practices, and where is the money and value being derived from DR? How can advancements in technologies, both at the end-use and aggregated system levels, expand the scope of customer-owned resources to support changing DR needs?

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • PS170C: Energy Efficient Technologies
    06-Jun-2016

    This project set assesses, tests, and demonstrates advanced energy-efficient technologies, such as space conditioning, water heating, lighting, appliances & plug loads, motors & drives, in diverse residential, commercial and industrial end-use applications. It addresses key issues, such as: What is the value of new end-use technology application for pursuing energy efficiency through program implementation? What data is required for each technology class and their respective applications, to provide benefit to members, customers and society? What new applications are made possible by changes and improvements to existing end-use technology classes?

    • P170.013: Space Conditioning
      15-Jun-2016

      What are the performance characteristics, costs, and applications for an advanced space conditioning technology? How can a specific space conditioning technology be applied as a resource for energy efficiency programs? What are market barriers for adoption of the technology?

    • P170.019: Motors and Drives
      15-Jun-2016

      Over 50% of energy used in the industrial sector is by motors driving pumps, compressors, fans and the like. Similarly, motor use in residential and commercial sectors is also large. What are the latest innovations in pumps and fans that could provide further energy and water efficiency measures that would benefit end-users through utility programs?

    • P170.020: High Performance Homes & Buildings
      15-Jun-2016

      What is the actual operating performance of Zero Net Energy residential construction?  How does the definition of ZNE affect load shape and create grid impacts?What combination of advanced technologies and subsystems can cost effectively enable zero or low energy buildings that are designed for optimal performance and market acceptance?  Does ZNE technology help to improve asset utilization?

    • P170.021: Appliances and Plug Loads
      15-Jun-2016

      Key questions in appliance and plug-load technologies are: What is the performance of innovative appliance, and electronic plug load technologies? What is their value to consumers and their potential as demand-side resources to support energy efficiency (EE) and demand response (DR) programs?  How is the rapid evolution of connectivity (the Internet of Things) providing new resources for energy efficiency?  What is the current and future potential value of connectivity?  Are there other revolutionary technologies that may significantly alter the energy & power characteristics of appliance loads.  Are there new classes of appliances or plug-loads set to come on line in the near future?

    • P170.025: Data Centers
      15-Jun-2016

      What technologies and strategies can improve the energy efficiency of small and medium sized data centers, which represent the largest category in the data center segment, without compromising customer productivity or uptime?  How can technologies and strategies be designed for inclusion into simpler utility program offerings?

    • P170.028: Water Heating
      15-Jun-2016

      Heat Pump Water Heaters are beginning to gain traction in the residential sector, and regulation is beginning to push their adoption. Commercial heat pump water heaters have been slower to catch on, and have seen market and technical barriers. There are key research questions in both spaces: in residential water heating, how can HPWHs become more cost-effective, more efficient and more grid-responsive? Will increasing market growth prompt new innovation within the sector?  For commercial water heating, how can systems become more cost-effective, such that they are more readily adopted into new construction? What can be done to make them easier to deploy in retrofits? Can pre-engineered packages be deployed for common buildings and applications?

    • P170.029: Process Technologies
      15-Jun-2016

      Disclaimer: This project under the Energy Efficient Technologies Project Set may or may not be part of the 2017 Research Portfolio. The Project Set Lead will evaluate the need and funding at the end of 2016 to determine whether there will be a product delivered under this project, or if the project will be put on hiatus until the following year. Thank you.

    • P170.030: Lighting Technologies
      15-Jun-2016

      Do networked lighting controls provide reliable energy savings in all applications? Are controls consistent in operation across installations and manufacturers? Evaluating lighting controls for their functionality and compatibility with various lighting sources will enhance EE and DR programs. EPRI lighting researchers are working with the industry to develop and test innovative approaches for lighting to be an integral part of load management programs. EPRI’s lighting research is exploring these questions in its base research and will continue to address these issues in 2017 and beyond.

    • P170.031: Refrigeration
      15-Jun-2016

      Key research questions in refrigerant and refrigeration system technologies are: Given the large installed base of high global warming potential (GWP) bearing refrigerant systems in heating, ventilation, air conditioning and refrigeration (HVAC&R) systems, what options are there for natural and/or low GWP synthetic refrigerants as future replacements? How can society continue to use refrigerants, but with reduced environmental impact? What are the short-term, medium-term and long-term solutions as legislation changes? How can utilities prepare themselves with options for customers faced with costly requirements to upgrade or change systems containing high GWP synthetic refrigerants?  Are there other potential benefits to moving toward natural and low GWP refrigerants that may help transform the market organically? What other opportunities for efficiency and demand reduction exist in the refrigeration sector?

    • P170.032: Passive Systems
      15-Jun-2016

      Disclaimer: This project under the Energy Efficient Technologies Project Set may or may not be part of the 2017 Research Portfolio. The Project Set Lead will evaluate the need and funding at the end of 2016 to determine whether there will be a product delivered under this project, or if the project will be put on hiatus until the following year. Thank you.

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • PS170D: Technology Transfer
    04-Jun-2016

    There are many emerging energy efficient and demand responsive technologies being introduced in the market every year. How do utilities identify the most promising technologies, and apply them in their programs? Furthermore, how do they value such technologies for their grid impacts, and potential integration as resources to enable an Integrated Power System? This Project Set focuses on answering these research questions by producing Technology Readiness Guides, and conducting Workshops, Symposia, Webcasts and other technology transfer products that could be applied by utilities in their energy efficiency and demand response programs.     

    • P170.026: Technology Briefs
      04-Jun-2016

      As utilities strive to meet increasing end-use energy efficiency and demand response requirements, they must make decisions about which technologies seem most promising in terms of availability for wide deployment and providing persistent energy savings and demand reduction, while also being cost-effective and likely to be adopted by customers. Utilities are also interested to understand the grid impacts of such technologies. To help utilities with these understandings, EPRI has developed, and continues to expand, this Technology Readiness Guide (TRG) to provide a readiness assessment of technologies in various stages of development as well as enabling comparison among these.

    • P170.027: Knowledge Transfer
      04-Jun-2016

      What new technologies, or changes to existing technologies have been introduced or have matured in the last year?  What is the potential of these new technologies in the energy efficiency and demand response space? How can they be used to support the Integrated Grid?

Program Name: Bulk Power System Integration of Variable Generation
text:
Overview

Program Description

Installed capacity of renewable energy have increased significantly over the last decade due to policy decisions such as state-mandated renewable energy standards and federal air and water standards, along with improved economic viability for these resources. Much of the existing and estimated development of renewables comprises variable resources such as wind generation and solar photovoltaics (PV), which when integrated with the grid, create new challenges for maintaining reliable system operation. Future projections are that a more significant build-out of these variable renewable resources is likely at both the transmission and distribution levels.

With these developments, power system planners and operators require new tools and resources to provide a reliable, sustainable, and cost-effective supply of electricity to consumers. Tools to aid in meeting these objectives include (1) improved and/or new sources of system flexibility to respond to and accommodate the increase in energy variability and uncertainty, (2) the development of additional transmission infrastructure to deliver energy from remote locations, and (3) planning and operational methods and software to effectively plan and operate the bulk system with these new resources, many of which may be at the distribution level. EPRI’s Bulk Power System Integration of Variable Generation (VG) research program addresses these needs and directly supports EPRI’s Research Imperatives #2 “Integration of Dynamic Customer Resources and Behavior” and #3 “Integrated Power System and Environmental Modeling Framework.”

Research Value

The Bulk Power System Variable Generation Integration research program provides variable generation integration analytics; development of planning and protection methods, tools, and models; and development of operator methods and tools to reliably and economically integrate wind and solar PV generation. This is accomplished through a collaborative process wherein EPRI works with its utility and independent system operator (ISO) members and other stakeholders to identify existing research gaps and associated project needs that would provide value to society and to EPRI members. Once identified, the EPRI Bulk Variable Generation Integration team of technical and project management experts works with members and the world’s foremost experts in related research areas to structure and conduct specific projects that delivers value in the near-term, mid-term, and long-term. Finally, this value is transferred to members through collaborative advisory and task force interactions, workshops and webcasts, and specific applications and demonstrations of the developed methods and tools.

Approach

EPRI's Bulk Power System Variable Generation Integration research program delivers value by using the shared experiences and understanding of EPRI's utility and ISO members in conjunction with the expertise of EPRI's staff and network of contractors. The program conducts research projects that lead to methods and tools used by system planners and operators responding to the challenges of high penetrations of VG. These prototype methods and tools are applied and validated by members before being transferred to commercial vendors that supply and support member applications.

EPRI also engages with external industry standards, regulatory, and research efforts to ensure that the EPRI research program is taking advantage of broader industry efforts and advancing the state of the art. For example, EPRI staff participates in North American Electric Reliability Corporation (NERC) Essential Reliability Services Working Group (ERSWG), Utility Variable Generation Integration Group (UVIG), and related IEEE and CIGRE working groups to inform the requirements that emerge from such efforts.

EPRI's research program strives to provide societal benefits by ensuring that utilities and ISOs can provide a reliable, economic, and sustainable electricity supply that ensure public safety and an promotes economic activity. The program supports member utility and ISO goals to deliver this electricity supply to the public by providing research results that address near-term, mid-term, and long-term gaps. For example, the 2017 Bulk System Variable Generation Integration research program will continue efforts to validate inverter-based short-circuit models for wind and PV facilities that are integrated into commercial tool for protection studies today. At the same time, we are conducting research to develop operator tools and techniques that will improve generation dispatch and reserve procurement based on the probabilistic nature of wind and solar, and developing operational flexibility assessment and resource evaluations tools for planning the investments needed to ensure sufficient ramping capability exists in the future.

This program is managed together with the Grid Operations (P39) and Grid Planning (P40) programs, and coordinates with related areas across EPRI, including Program 174 (Distributed Energy Resource Integration), Program 94 (Energy Storage) and Program 178 (Technology Assessment, Market Analysis and Integrated Portfolio Planning).   Where appropriate, we define and create joint deliverables that leverage the expertise and learnings from these other programs with the relevant Grid Ops & Planning research and experts to deliver R&D results that benefit both areas.

Accomplishments

The Bulk Power System Integration of Variable Generation program began in 2010, and has provided significant industry leadership and helped create valuable reports and tools in a number of areas:

  • Generic Models and Model Validation for Wind, Solar PV Generation, and Energy Storage (3002005731, 3002006525, 3002001002, 3002003351): These deliverables (reports, guidelines and a video) describe the recommended generic wind turbine, PV, and energy storage dynamic models developed through industry efforts with significant leadership from EPRI, as well as the related model validation efforts conducted by EPRI. This work has already resulted in the inclusion of improved generic models in existing commercial dynamic stability software packages.
  • Renewable Energy Model Validation (REMV) Tool Version 2.0 (3002003352): This software tool takes wind and solar PV plant disturbance response measurement data as an input and provides for automated validation of the associated dynamic model or provides optimized model parameter values to obtain a validated model.
  • Impact of Renewables on System Protection (3002005765, 3002002810): These reports describe electromagnetic transient type (EMT-type), time domain and associated frequency domain models of converter interfaced wind turbines and solar PV that can be used for short circuit studies to determine how they affect system protection. Additionally guidelines for conducting protection studies with high levels of inverter-based renewables are provided.
  • Voltage and Frequency Performance and Modeling of DER (3002007496, 3002005768, and 3002004697): These reports provide updates to a project focused on understanding potential impacts of high levels of VG on the bulk system voltage and frequency performance, including methodology development, case study results and recommendations on mitigating strategies. This project also examined the need for interconnection requirements and modeling approaches and recommendations for representing Active Distribution Systems in transmission models.
  • Operating Reserve Determination (3002006112, 3002002871): These reports provide updates to a project focused on understanding approaches for procuring operating reserve to manage the variability and uncertainty of variable generation. This includes the use of stochastic programming and multi-cycle modeling approaches to examine the benefits of new reserve procurement strategies compared to more advanced scheduling strategies. .
  • Power System Flexibility (3002005763, 3002005764, and 3002003581): These deliverables (reports and video) outline a framework to assist planners in assessing the system operational flexibility to meet increased ramping requirements associated with wind and PV. A set of metrics to calculate a system’s operational flexibility sufficiency were defined and demonstrated using case studies. Additionally, methods to determine the resource adequacy implications of variability and uncertainty were demonstrated. A video explains the concepts for general audience.
  • InFLEXion Flexibility Screening and Assessment Tool v 4 (3002005760) and v3.0 (3002004486): This software tool is designed to assist planners in assessing operational flexibility of systems. The multi-level approach takes data such as time series of wind and load and generator characteristics and performs a screening analysis of flexibility requirements and resources, while it can be used with detailed generation dispatch data to calculate flexibility adequacy metrics.
Key Activities

In 2017, EPRI's Bulk System Variable Generation Integration research program will offer its members a focused research portfolio with the following objectives:

  • Develop and validate wind and solar plant controller generic models for system planning studies, and evaluate and quantify limitations of positive sequence models for representing the behavior for unbalanced disturbances in weak portions of the grid.
  • Develop modeling approaches and recommendations for modeling Active Distribution Systems – systems with high penetrations of DER – and associated software to create models.
  • Develop and validate models that adequately represent the short-circuit response of wind and solar PV generators, including vendor engagement and case studies to demonstrate the models, and provision of guidelines for adjusting traditional protection schemes, devices, and associated relay settings for high levels of these resources.
  • Develop and demonstrate methods and tools to determine operating reserve requirements for high levels of variable generation, with consideration of all other system uncertainties, including location of resources and the use of probabilistic forecasting.
  • Develop methods, models, and tools that can adequately assess the frequency response of the system in real time and in that operational planning time-frame, and that consider the ability of variable generation to contribute to this response.
  • Demonstrate modeling approaches that consider the interaction of primary and secondary frequency control in systems with high penetrations of variable generation.
  • Develop methods and tools that consider operational flexibility needs in resource adequacy assessment and aid procurement of flexibility resources, including traditional central generation as well as demand side, storage and transmission solutions to flexibility constraints.
  • Provide general insights from on-going pilots aimed to evaluate beneficial and adverse impacts of using distributed resources for providing bulk system services, as well as providing information to members on ongoing developments related to renewable integration.
Estimated 2017 Program Funding
$3.2M

Last Updated
  • PS173A: System Planning Methods, Tools and Analytics
    13-Jun-2016

    This project set focuses on developing models, methods and tools for supporting transmission planning and system protection as systems start to accommodate high levels of renewable, inverter-based resources such as wind, solar PV, and battery energy storage, some of which are located on the distribution system. Transmission planners and protection engineers need validated models of these new technologies and system planning/protection guidelines for using these models to ensure the system is developed in a way that can be reliably operated with increasing penetrations of these resources. This project set includes research to provide these new models, tools, and methods.

     

    • P173.003: Model Development and Validation
      14-Jun-2016

      Computer simulation models of power systems are needed to facilitate an effective and reliable means of planning, designing, and operating the bulk power system.  Although the level of installed wind and photovoltaic (PV) generation is increasing substantially, validated, publicly available models that represent the behavior of many of these technologies are still trailing.  This project provides for the on-going research needed to ensure that the wind, PV, energy storage and other renewable related models for planning studies are developed, validated, and made available to commercial software vendors for inclusion in the tools used by member utilities and ISOs. This R&D work addresses modeling and validation of resources connected at the transmission/sub-transmission system as well as development and verification of methods to model distribution-connected resources in bulk system simulation models. 

    • P173.009: Impact of Renewables on System Protection
      14-Jun-2016

      The integration of renewable energy resources into power systems introduces several technical challenges. One major challenge is the impact on system protection, resulting from the complex fault response characteristics of these devices which are interfaced with the grid through power electronics-based converters and do not behave similar to conventional synchronous or asynchronous machines. There are two aspects related to this challenge that need to be investigated. First is the modeling of converter interfaced renewable resources in fault and protection system analysis tools used in protection studies. Traditional short-circuit modeling techniques are not adequate and there is an industry need for the development of short-circuit phasor-domain models of these devices that accurately represent their short circuit contribution to the system fault response and can be used for fault analysis and system protection studies. The second aspect is the performance of legacy protection schemes in systems with high levels of renewables, and potential mis-operations which will reduce the reliability of the grid. An understanding of the way these devices affect system protection is needed so that protection and planning engineers design the protection schemes appropriately without jeopardizing the security of the system.

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • PS173B: System Operations Methods, Tools and Analytics
    13-Jun-2016

    This project set focuses on developing methods and tools to improve efficiency and reliability of system operations in the presence of high levels of wind and solar. Two separate types of tools and methods are being investigated. The first area is operational planning tools being developed to allow operators efficiently manage the variability and associated with wind and PV. These tools are based on stochastic optimization and other advanced operational simulation techniques, and will allow operators to more reliably and efficiently schedule resources and understand the impact of various potential operational processes proposed to integrate wind and solar. This includes more optimal methods of procuring and deploying operating reserves as well as methods to utilize probabilistic forecasting and improve integration of forecasting in system operations.

    The second area in this set is related to the real-time operational reliability impacts of wind and PV on system voltage control and frequency response and control. As variable generation resources displace traditional resources that provide frequency response and control, there is a need for bulk system operators to understand frequency response of the system, including the primary frequency response and inertia, as well as the interaction between primary frequency response and secondary frequency control. It will become increasingly important to track operational metrics and have the capability to model different scenarios that may occur. This project set is ensuring that the impacts on operations are well understood and can be mitigated. The inverter-based resources can themselves support bulk system reactive power/voltage control and frequency response and this capability will also be evaluated, with results helping operators to understand the use of these stochastic resources in operations.

    • P173.005: Operational Support Tools to Manage Variability and Uncertainty
      14-Jun-2016

      The variability and uncertainty associated with variable renewable generation such as wind and solar photovoltaics (PV), energy efficiency measures, and new demand response resources can have a significant impact on system performance and operation as penetration levels increase. Specifically, variability and uncertainty intensify the challenge for system operators to forecast and schedule the most economical set of resources for meeting system energy demands while maintaining reliability. Consequently, new operational scheduling, forecasting, control methods, and analysis tools are needed to ensure the future system can be operated in a reliable and efficient manner.

      Traditional approaches for system operations manage the limited uncertainty associated with demand forecast error through offline analysis with periodic updates (e.g. on an annual basis). With a changing underlying demand, as well as a large and growing penetration of variable generators, a system operator’s risk exposure greatly increases. Following traditional approaches may no longer be feasible from a cost or reliability viewpoint. This project focuses on addressing the need to manage increasing uncertainty and variability in system operations at least cost, through leveraging new tools and scheduling methods to ensure that the changing generation and demand mix can be balanced at least cost while not impacting system reliability. 

    • P173.011: Voltage and Frequency Performance
      14-Sep-2016

      High penetration of renewable generation presents challenges in the planning and operations of power systems. Ensuring adequate frequency and voltage response are examples of such challenges as the generation mix changes with increase in penetration of inverter-based variable generation and planned retirements of fossil-fueled generation or as remaining conventional generation is displaced. Conversely, opportunities need to be explored to utilize emerging technologies such as inverter-based wind and photovoltaic (PV) resources, energy storage and demand response for contributing to voltage and frequency response. Thus, the industry needs to investigate the impact on system frequency and voltage performance as traditional resources that support these functions are displaced and investigate and demonstrated the ability of newer and less familiar resources to provide frequency and voltage support.  This investigation is complicated by the fact that some of the potential bulk system impacts may be driven by distribution-connected resources that are not readily modeled in bulk system simulation models.

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • PS173C: Strategic and Flexible Planning
    13-Jun-2016

    This project set provides methods and tools which consider the operational flexibility needs of systems with increased penetrations of variable generation. The variability and uncertainty related to wind and solar PV will require increased levels of operational flexibility to be accounted for in the planning time-frame. This will require metrics, methods and tools which can assess the increased requirements and identify needs. These metrics and tools will provide planners with the ability to determine whether a system is sufficiently flexible and will adequately consider and compare different resource types including conventional generation, demand response and energy storage. It will also provide methods to consider how the transmission system (both existing and new lines) can be included in the assessment of operational flexibility, and provide insights into how operational processes can be considered in the planning time-frame to ensure flexibility can be accessed. The resulting processes and tools can be used to ensure reliable, efficient integration of variable generation into the bulk system.

     

    • P173.012: Strategic and Flexible Planning
      14-Jun-2016

      With increased levels of variable generation (VG) and other potential changes to the system, such as coal retirement and increased reliance on natural gas, ensuring that systems have sufficient operational flexibility has become a strategic issue. In systems with high levels of production variability and uncertainty, flexible resources will be required to meet reliability targets by enabling the system to respond effectively to load or generation changes and to reduce the cost impacts of integrating large amounts of VG. Methods are required to assess whether sufficient resources exist to meet changes in net load (demand net of VG), and to ensure planning processes adequately consider flexibility. The need for flexibility must be balanced with the cost associated with increasing system flexibility.

      Prior research in this project developed a flexibility assessment framework including proposed new flexibility metrics, examined the impact transmission has on provision of flexibility, and proposed methods to consider flexibility in resource adequacy studies. A software tool, InFLEXion, was produced to demonstrate application of the methods.

      Work is also being done by tool vendors and utilities/ISOs to incorporate flexibility issues into their planning processes (for example significant work is being done in California). The metrics and methods developed here are designed to work in conjunction with these tools/methods, and in certain cases, build on existing work or improve those methods. In addition, the framework developed allows project participants to understand what these tools need to consider and helps to validate new techniques for considering flexibility in planning.

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • PS173D: Technology Transfer for Bulk System VG Integration
    13-Jun-2016

    Bulk system renewable integration technology transfer provides members with resources that convey the latest industry developments on integration issues, standards activities, and changes in technology, advancements, and challenges. They provide utility and ISO transmission planners, protection engineers, and operators with the insights as to the latest industry research related to renewables integration including integration study results, emerging standards, and new analysis/integration methods and tools. 

    Note that as this project set is designed to complement EPRI’s Integrated Grid efforts and other Project Sets in Program 173, and as such is not a full R&D project, members who join this but not one of the other Program 173 Project Sets will not have access to the related program-level task force, including webcasts and in-person meetings.

    • P173.013: Technology Transfer for Bulk System VG Integration
      15-Jun-2016

      This project provides and maintains mechanisms for technology transfer as well as industry coordination related to bulk system renewable integration.  The resources delivered from this project provides members with resources that convey the latest industry developments on integration issues, standards activities, and changes in technology, including insights from on-going pilots aimed to evaluate beneficial and adverse impacts of increased deployment of Distributed Energy Resources (DER).

Overview

Program Description

Increased amounts of distributed energy resources (DER) in the electric grid brings a number of challenges for the electric industry. Utilities may face large numbers of interconnection requests; distributed generation on some circuits will exceed the load; and many operating challenges involving feeder voltage regulation, hosting capacity limits, inverter grid support and grounding options are brought to bear. Furthermore, providing reliable service as DER penetrations increase and electricity sales diminish can also add economic challenges to the technical ones.

This Program addresses the aforementioned challenges with project sets that assess feeder impacts, inverter interface electronics, interconnection and communication standards, and integration analytics. The Program provides insights into utility interconnection practices and strategies related to future integration approaches. It also evaluates economic impacts and values of DER integration. Many of these activities support EPRI’s “The Integrated Grid” initiative.

Finally, the Program includes laboratory and field evaluations and demonstrations of improved DER power management and communications. A primary objective of the work in the field is to expand utility hands-on knowledge for managing distributed energy resources—without reducing safety, reliability, or asset utilization effectiveness.

Research Value

With the knowledge acquired through this research program, members will have access to information that supports:

  • Management of the interconnection queue and identification of effective screening methods;

  • Tools and methods to analyze of feeder operations with different levels and types of DER;

  • Functional requirements and standards development for DER interconnection, reliability and safety;

  • Deep understanding of smart inverter capabilities and performance;

  • Strategies for managing and integrating customer-sited DER;

  • Technical and economic assessment of different DER integration strategies with existing distribution assets;

  • New methods for integration of distributed resources into distribution planning tools; and

  • Preparation of existing and future distribution grids to support more effective integration.

Approach

This research program addresses four main areas of distributed energy resource integration:

  • Analytics to understand feeder impacts and benefits; integration of these analytics with distribution planning tools and methods;

  • Devices and controls for effective DER interconnections and coordination;

  • Practices that address the economics of DER integration; and

  • Industry coordination and technical transfer.

All projects build on and expand previous work related to DER integration. A range of products are identified for each project. Participants' input and prioritization will determine the final research investment and deliverable plan.

The work being done in this program is closely coordinated with and designed to complement the work undertaken in the Energy Storage and Distributed Generation (P94), Information and Communication Technology (P161), Energy Efficiency and Demand Response (P170), Technology Assessment, Market Analysis, and Generation Planning (P178), Distribution Systems (P180), Distribution Operations and Planning (P200) and Renewable Generation (P193) Programs.

Accomplishments

The Integration of DER program has delivered valuable information to members and industry. Results of the 2015 program are described in an annual summary (3002007299). Following are examples of program outcomes to date:

  • Updated and improved engineering guide. This guide is intended for utility engineers facing integration of distributed generation and storage. The guide is intended to serve as a reference for interconnection practices, provide criteria and approaches for screening installations, and suggest methods for planning with significant DSG. (3002005774)

  • Methodology for quantifying the impacts of PV on the distribution system and demonstrated examples of its application. This product provides examples of the Integrated Grid benefit-cost analysis framework, applied across an entire utility distribution system in the Southeast. Mitigation measures are analyzed for all distribution feeders, while six diverse feeders are evaluated in detail to analyze capacity deferral value and energy loss assessment. Subsequent results are then extrapolated to the entire set of distribution feeders to determine the economic implications of adding distributed PV to the distribution system. (3002005783).

  • Quarterly Solar PV Market Updates. The Updates, provide snapshots of PV market information, along with EPRI analyses, to inform utility members about economic-, policy-, and technology-related developments in the segment. The documents synthesize data on market outlooks, equipment cost and pricing trends, system design and efficiency advances, and changes in the incentive landscape, that are likely to impact utility solar PV investment and planning efforts. (3002005776, 3002005777, 3002005778, 3002005779).

  • Multi-year project evaluating the performance of multiple smart inverters operating in parallel. Smart inverters of different makes and models are being tested in the laboratory in a real world deployment scenarios. In 2015, research provided an update on a residential solar neighborhood test setup. Initial test results of two smart string inverters operating in parallel are included in the update. The impact of fixed power factor, low voltage ride thru (LVRT), volt-var, and volt-watt with volt-var functions were also investigated. (3002005784).

  • Technical support to IEEE P1547 full revision process. EPRI subject matter experts facilitated the voltage regulation and abnormal voltage and frequency condition subgroups. These subgroups developed new requirements for DER voltage regulation support and also low- and high voltage and frequency ride through requirements, which are expected to be included in the next version of the IEEE 1547 DER interconnection standard. Members were updated throughout the year through webcasts.

Key Activities

In 2017, this program expects to accomplish the following objectives:

  • Advance the development and application of utility screening tools, guidelines, feeder designs, and operating parameters to accommodate higher penetrations of distributed energy resources, while maintaining safety, reliability, operational efficiency, and power quality. 

  • Develop resources that enable utilities to more effectively apply new distribution system technologies, such as smart inverters, to support higher penetration levels of distributed generation.

  • Enhance utility understanding of the end-to-end integration needs and advanced grid support functions of grid interface technologies, such as smart inverters, to support the planning and implementation of DER integration systems. This work will be accomplished through laboratory testing and field demonstrations.

  • Assess the economic implications and practices for accommodating higher penetrations of DER.

  • Develop and maintain mechanisms for technology transfer to keep members up to date on integration issues, standards activities, and changes in technology, advancements, and challenges.

$4.0M

  • PS174A: Advanced Modeling and Simulation
    12-May-2016

    This project set provides the analytics needed to address both existing distribution issues and future options and concepts with higher penetration of distributed energy resources (DER).  It focuses on the readiness of the distribution system—both radial and network distribution—for incremental increases in distributed generation.  Several products will directly support work on “The Integrated Grid.”

    Most existing radial and network distribution systems are not designed for a significant penetration of distributed energy resources (DER).  Standards that address the interconnection of distributed generation (for example, IEEE 1547-2003) assume low penetration levels.  The industry recognizes that these requirements are changing with a more robust deployment of distributed photovoltaics (PV) in many utility systems. 

    Decisions on replacing or upgrading aging distribution systems will require considering the potential for higher levels of DER.  Utilities would also like to plan for and build in capability to support higher DER penetration levels while maintaining safety, protection, and reliability in a cost-effective manner.

    The work being done in this project set is closely coordinated with and designed to complement the work being done in the  Energy Storage and Distributed Generation (P94), Bulk Power System Integration of Variable Generation (P173), Distribution Operations and Planning (P200),and Distribution Systems (P180) Programs.

    • P174.001 Advanced Modeling and Simulation
      14-Jun-2016

      Most existing radial and network distribution systems are not designed for a significant penetration of distributed energy resources.  Standards that address the interconnection of distributed generation (for example, IEEE 1547a-2014) are evolving.  The industry recognizes that requirements and expectations need to change with a more robust deployment of DER.

      Decisions on replacing or upgrading aging distribution systems will require considering the potential for high levels of distributed renewable generation. Utilities would like to plan for and build in capability to support higher penetration levels of distributed renewable generation while maintaining safety, protection, and reliability.  A key issue this project will address is new distribution system technologies, such as smart inverters, that will allow greater penetration of DER. 

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • PS174B: Enabling and Assessing Grid Supportive DER
    12-May-2016

    With the proliferation of distribution-connected generation sources, especially renewables, it is a necessity that DER be capable of providing grid-supportive functions that minimize their disruptive impact and support distribution operations, ultimately enabling higher levels of renewable energy.   In prior years, this project set has oriented the utility industry toward this goal, but several challenges remain. The next steps are critical, including how DER aggregation is performed, which functions are active simultaneously, their response time and transient behaviors, and how many/multiple devices of differing types and brands interact to produce an overall grid impact. 

    These resources, which include photovoltaic (PV) generation and energy storage systems, have significant processing power and potentially fast response times, making both steady-state and dynamic grid benefits possible.  Utilities and manufacturers need accurate, unbiased information to guide their development and integration efforts.  Meanwhile, procedures are underway to revise DER interconnection standards that are the basis for grid codes everywhere, such as IEEE 1547 and UL 1741, and yet little is known about how aggregation will be performed and how required functions will actually be implemented in products.

    The work being done in this program is closely coordinated with and designed to complement the work undertaken in Energy Storage and Distributed Generation (P94), Information and Communication Technology (P161), Energy Efficiency and Demand Response (P170), Distribution Systems (P180), and Distribution Operations and Planning (P200).

    The functional requirements identified in this project are used by the EPRI Information and Communication Technology program (P161D) to guide the development of communication protocols, standards, and architectures that support the needs of smart inverters.

    • P174.003 Enabling and Assessing Grid Supportive DER
      14-Jun-2016

      With increasing deployment of these systems, many utilities are making investments in related communications technology.  With the introduction of many new grid interface systems, there is an increasing need to analyze and understand their operation and performance.  The next steps are critical, including how DER aggregation is performed, which functions are active simultaneously, their response time and transient behaviors, and how many/multiple devices of differing types and brands interact to produce an overall grid impact.  A better understanding of standards and safety practices is critical.

      This project set focuses on devices including inverters, controllers, and other related intertie technologies that provide the end-user-level distributed energy resource integration with the grid.  It focuses on evaluating grid functionalities for these devices, and it evaluates both the electrical power and communication interfaces for DER and advanced inverter functions.  The project set includes development of performance criteria, laboratory, and field testing.

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • PS174D: Utility Economics and Practices
    12-May-2016

    As utilities contemplate the integration and use of an expanding amount of distributed energy resources (DER) on the distribution system, they will be confronted by new system performance, reliability, and operating challenges. Accelerating adoption of solar PV specifically poses a range of business-related impacts that have economic implications. Increasing levels of DER generation have cost and benefit implications for customers and society, but are not yet well understood. Tracking DER market developments and integration activities, implementing informed management strategies, and forecasting DER adoption trajectories, will together be increasingly required to effectively guide utility strategic planning and business-related decision making. 

    This project set examines the economic implications of DER—primarily solar photovoltaics (PV)—and assesses leading practices for tactically accommodating higher penetrations of variable resources on distribution. In addition, it offers insight into the technical, economic, and market adoption potential of customer-sided PV to help inform utility planning activities. These activities are key components of “The Integrated Grid.”  Research coverage encompasses: PV integration approaches and associated cost-benefit analyses, utility solar business model design and mechanics, output variability forecasting and mitigation techniques, as well as end-use PV adoption estimation methods.

    The research in this project set is closely coordinated with and designed to complement the work undertaken in EPRI’s Energy Storage and Distributed Generation (P94), Technology Assessment, Market Analysis, and Generation Planning (P178), and Renewable Generation (P193) Programs.

    • P174.008 Utility Economics and Practices
      13-Jan-2017

      As utilities contemplate the integration and use of an expanding amount of distributed energy resources (DER) on the distribution system, they will be confronted by new system performance, reliability, and operating challenges. Tracking DER market developments and integration activities, implementing informed management strategies, and forecasting DER adoption trajectories, will together be increasingly required to effectively guide utility strategic planning and business decision making.

      The costs and benefits of increasing levels of DER on distribution are also not yet well understood. Accelerating adoption of DER is specifically posing a range of impacts that have economic implications.  The project will conduct research to determine the economic value of DER according to differing grid contexts and strategic deployment approaches. It will also explore the economic efficacy of differing grid management/mitigation approaches.
