Program Name: Technology Assessment, Market Analysis and Integrated Portfolio Planning
text:
Overview

Program Description

The electric sector today in the United States and around the world is undergoing a profound transformation that is driving unprecedented changes to company operations, corporate environmental compliance, resource planning, business strategy, and industry structure. This transformation results from the interplay of (i) dramatic changes in the technical performance and cost of power generation technologies, such as wind and solar; (ii) increased deployment of utility-scale wind and solar resources and distributed energy resources (DER); (iii) federal and state regulatory actions designed to increase deployment of renewables and distributed resources, and to dramatically reduce GHG emissions from new and existing power plants; and, (iv) sustained, low natural gas prices.

In recent years, the interplay of several of these factors caused dramatic changes to the dispatch of power plants in many U.S. regions. These changes in dispatch led to increased cycling and idling of base load coal plants along with an increasing number of coal plant retirements, and reduced dispatch and closure of some existing nuclear units. At the same time, natural gas fired power plants are being dispatched more than ever before, and many companies are considering investing in new natural gas-fired power plants to meet future capacity needs.   

Moreover, the traditional relationship between electric companies and their customers is undergoing a similar transformation. In recent years, companies have faced slow and uncertain load growth, and new distributed generation, storage, and grid technologies are creating new business paradigms and reducing demand for grid-delivered power.  The advent of two-way power flow and the development of the “integrated grid” is leading to greater interaction between electric companies and customers, and consumer behavior is changing in response to changing regulatory drivers, the availability of competitively priced distributed resources, and the deployment of new consumer technologies, such as “smart” phones, rooftop solar PV and electric cars.  

Sound data and information and new analysis methods and tools that can be used to incorporate these factors into long-range resource planning are critical for companies to continue to provide safe, affordable, reliable, and environmentally responsible electricity.  As this transformation of the electric sector continues to unfold, company resource planners and fuel managers will continue to be confronted with a variety of new planning challenges that require access to up-to-date information on the cost and performance of existing and new electric generation technologies and development and use of new analytic methods to effectively address emerging resource planning challenges. 

Internationally, electric companies also face a daunting array of resource planning challenges. Market liberalization policies adopted in some parts of the world are leading to the privatization and breakup of previously state-owned monopoly electric companies. Increasing industrialization and consumer expectations, particularly in the developing world, are dramatically increasing electric loads. International policies designed to reduce GHG emissions and increasing pressure to adopt “low-carbon” development pathways are leading electricity planners in many countries to reconsider investing in new fossil-fired generation, and many countries are increasingly turning towards renewable energy sources to try to meet their growing electric loads.

The Technology Assessment, Market Analysis and Integrated Portfolio Planning Program helps electric companies address these myriad interconnected issues by providing objective technical information and powerful analytic methodologies and software tools to explore familiar and emerging integrated resource planning issues. The program also provides a “meeting place” for company planners and fuel managers to discuss and assess technical challenges, possible solutions, and emerging information and analytical needs. This program also explores changing customer behavior related to the deployment of renewable energy and distributed resources, and how these kinds of resources are being incorporated into more traditional company generation resource planning efforts. This program has an extensive record of success providing technology cost and performance data, key information and tools to assist power companies in the electric resource planning process, and cost estimating and engineering design of new generation and retrofit projects. More specifically, the program provides the following:

  • Comprehensive, credible, and up-to-date data and analyses of technology costs and performance . The annual EPRI Technical Assessment Guide (TAG®) has set the standard in the industry for this kind of information. Combined with TAGWEB™, an Internet-based software package for creating customized technology cost estimates and performing screening-level financial analysis, and rapid-response support from the EPRI team, this information provides a sound basis for understanding and comparing technology cost estimates and validating results of more-detailed, engineering studies. The data included in the TAG® also provides key input data that companies need to conduct integrated generation portfolio planning.

  • Clear assessments of fuel and electricity market trends and interactions . Natural gas prices are a key driver of electricity prices in many markets, and fundamentally affect the economics of capital investments. At the same time, power industry demand for natural gas is an important agent of change in fuel prices and fuel market dynamics. EPRI research on industry trends and the near-term and long-term prospects for fuel markets provides key insights and understanding to complement projections from other sources.

  • Improved methods for conducting integrated resource planning.  Increasing deployment of utility-scale renewable resources and DER requires development of new analysis methods and tools to incorporate these resources effectively in company long-term electric company resource planning. In addition, dramatic changes in the resource mix resulting from imposition of new environmental regulations and dramatic changes in fuel prices are requiring company resource planners to develop new approaches to conducting integrated portfolio planning that encompasses electric generation, transmission, and distribution planning, and which includes potential impacts to long-term system reliability. 

  • Consistent analysis methodologies and powerful analytic tools :

    • TAGWEB™ provides up-to-date technology costs and performance data that can be adapted to specific locations and used for asset planning and other purposes;

    • EPRI’s Electric Generation Expansion Analysis System (EGEAS) is a powerful resource planning software tool that can be used by electric companies and regional transmission organizations to conduct Integrated Resources Planning, long-term generation planning, production cost modeling, and to evaluate the potential impacts of environmental policies on electric capacity and generation. EGEAS also can be used to evaluate future deployment of non-dispatchable renewable power generation technologies; energy efficiency and demand-side management programs, analyze system reliability and system economic and power costs.

In 2017, Program 178 will continue to deliver two project sets (PSET 178A and PSET 178B). Several interest and user groups also have been created to allow companies with narrower interests to participate in these elements of this program.  These include the Natural Gas Interest Group, the TAGWeb User’s Group, and the new Gas Turbine Combined Cycle (GTCC) Plant Development Interest Group. Program 178A supports the TAGWeb User’s Group Workshop where attendees focus on learning how to use the software and providing guidance on the generation and storage technology options that are included in software updates.  In conjunction with Program 79, Combined Cycle Turbomachinery, Program 178A also hosts the New GTCC Plant Development Interest Group, which is dedicated to leveraging staff expertise and EPRI members’ knowledge and plant development experience for mutual benefit by facilitating an open exchange among utility project development professionals and industry participants.  Program 178B provides partial support for the Natural Gas Interest Group (NGIG) and the EGEAS software platform, and P178B funders have full access to the NGIG discussions and associated research results, and a license to use the EGEAS software to conduct resource planning analyses.

In 2017, members of Program 178 or PSET 178A also will receive access to the following EPRI products:

  • One year TAGWEB™ license (5 per company);

  • Access to additional technical and economic studies developed throughout the year based on the interests of the members; and,

  • Membership to the New GTCC Plant Development Interest Group.

In 2017, members funding Program 178 or PSET 178B also will receive access to the following EPRI products:

  • License to EGEAS software version 11.0;

  • License to Utility Fuel Inventory Model (UFIM); and,

  • Membership to the Natural Gas Interest Group (NGIG)

Research Value

In this era of electric industry uncertainty, robust strategic planning decisions and risk management can save electric customers and companies hundreds of millions to billions of dollars. Program 178 has a long track record of success providing information and tools to help electric companies make more-informed, research-based, planning decisions that improve profitability, reduce corporate risk, and facilitate effective communication among diverse stakeholders.

This program also directly benefits the public by improving electric power sector integrated generation, transmission and distribution planning and fuels management so companies can continue to provide safe, reliable, environmentally-responsible electricity to consumers as cost-effectively as possible.

By combining technology assessment and market analysis with an array of resource planning tools and analyses, this research program provides a comprehensive, integrated solution to support electric company and regional transmission organization planning activities and decision making, including:

  • Comprehensive data, methodologies, and tools, provide a sound technical basis for technology planning, capital investment, and market strategies;

  • Insights into fuel market trends and uncertainties that drive electric sector economics and risks;

  • Tools and analyses to inform company strategy, decisions, and capital investment choices; and,

  • A practitioner community that can assist company staff with anticipating and exploring responses to emerging planning challenges.

This program conducts research and supports activities that contribute directly to addressing the challenges identified and described in EPRI research focused on developing an integrated power system and environmental modeling framework.  More specifically, this includes the technology cost and performance information developed in PSET 178A, and the integrated portfolio planning research and deliverables developed in PSET 178B.

Approach

Program staff works closely with program funders to identify and prioritize annual research topics, review results, and communicate key insights. Program members can access research results in a variety of ways, including:

  • Technical updates and reports provide industry-wide cost and market data, establish reference values, offer new and improved analysis methods, and provide insights into key fuel and electricity market trends.

  • Software tools provide customizable and flexible application of accepted methodologies to be used to analyze technology costs, integrated resource portfolio planning, market risk, and price/cost volatility. Flagship products include TAGWEB™, EGEAS, and UFIM.

  • Technical workshops, including the annual Program 178b Seminar on Fuels, Power Markets and Resource Planning, provide in-depth discussions of critical topics for resource planners, ground-breaking analyses and key results.

  • Frequent webinars provide opportunities for members to discuss ongoing analyses, research results and timely interaction with EPRI and outside experts without the need to travel.

This program coordinates its work closely with other EPRI research programs in the power delivery, generation and nuclear sectors to increase member value, leverage member funding, and ensure it does not duplicate other R&D efforts. The program collaborates with other EPRI research in a variety of ways, including: (i) developing shared deliverables as appropriate to avoid duplication and to share insights among a broader array of EPRI members; (ii) sharing information freely between program staff to ensure data, information, lessons learned, tools and methodologies are shared effectively across programs working on related issues; and, (iii) ensuring for consistent analyses across EPRI, and common understanding of shared challenges and potential solutions. For example, PSET 178b coordinates its project on Integrated Generation, Transmission and Distribution Planning closely with EPRI programs on Grid Operations (P39), Grid Planning (P40), Bulk Power System Integration of Variable Generation (P173), Distribution Planning (P200), and Integration of Distributed Energy Resources (P174D) in EPRI’s PDU division.

Interest and user groups examine more specific planning interests and narrower, model-focused issues, providing a place to share ideas, identify emerging issues, and to create focused research opportunities.

Accomplishments

  • TAG® is recognized as an authoritative source for up-to-date technology cost and performance information. It provides key data that can support long-range integrated portfolio planning, it is well accepted by regulators, and is sought after as a critical resource by domestic and international agencies and researchers.

  • EPRI’s fuel and industry markets research continues to expand understanding of the link between power plant project developments and domestic and global fuel markets, changing assessments of fuel supply and availability, and impacts of changes in infrastructures critical to the fuel supply chain.

  • For more than 30 years, PSET 178b has organized and hosted EPRI’s highly successful, invitation-only Annual Seminar on Fuels, Power Markets and Resource Planning.

  • EPRI’s United States Regional Greenhouse Gas and Energy Model (US-REGEN) continues to be used by the program to develop and analyze long-range planning scenarios of interest to program funders.

  • EGEAS is a state-of-the-art modular production costing and generation expansion software package widely used by power companies, regional transmission organizations, and regulators domestically and internationally to conduct long-range generation plans, to develop integrated resource plans, and to evaluate the potential reliability and economic impacts of environmental policies and regulations. EPRI released version 11.0 of this well-respected EPRI software product in 2015. A new and enhanced EGEAS version 12 is expected to be released and available to P178b members in Q4, 2017.

  • EPRI tools and methodologies, such as Utility Fuel Inventory Model (UFIM), and the Energy Book System (EBS), are well respected by companies and regulatory agencies and have helped companies make better-informed decisions, providing significant value to shareholders and customers.
Key Activities

Program R&D in 2017 will focus on updating existing data and methodologies and continuing to explore an array of critical planning issues including:

  • The annual TAG® technology report and associated program studies report will examine an array of technology issues identified by funders.

  • The TAGWEB™ software will be updated to reflect new technology-cost and performance information as well as updates to costing methodologies.

  • The annual EPRI Seminar on Fuels, Power Markets and Resource Planning will examine key fuel market and electricity industry trends in detail with leading experts.

  • The EGEAS software will continue to be improved to reflect interest in incorporating new features and enhancements.  

  • The program along with the Natural Gas Interest Group will continue to explore key issues related to the supply, demand, prices and environmental impacts of natural gas production and use.

  • The program will continue to inform members about the variety of commercially available generation planning tools and their core capabilities.

  • Development and analysis of multiple resource planning scenarios using EPRI’s proprietary US-REGEN Model.

  • Exploration of key issues associated with conducting integrated planning analyses that relates to the interaction of generation assets and transmission and distribution capabilities and infrastructure.

  • Exploration of key issues related to the deployment and integration of large-scale renewables and distributed generation resources into regional power grids and long-range generation planning.

  • Exploration of power market designs meant to facilitate the integration of DER and non-dispatchable renewable resources into wholesale power markets, including capacity auctions and ancillary services.

  • New, emerging issues identified by program members will be discussed and, if appropriate, initial analyses conducted. Candidate topics include: (i) Fuel availability and infrastructure limitations; (ii) Different approaches that may be used to project future technology costs and performance; (iii) Modeling future energy and environmental policy scenarios; and, (iv) methods and tools that can be used incorporate utility-scale renewable resources and distributed energy resources into company resource planning (v) costs of storage technologies (vi)valuation techniques/methodologies for storage (vii) future performance enhancements/upgrades for combustion turbines.  

In 2017, Program 178 again will consist of two project sets:

  • Project Set 178A, Engineering and Economic Guide for Power System Technologies (TAG) will focus on conventional and advanced technology cost and performance for new generation capacity screening, with supporting information on technology risks, cost escalation, and technology deep dives. Members suggest topics of interest and technologies where in-depth cost updates are needed. They are actively engaged in reviewing results.

  • Project Set 178B, Integrated Portfolio Planning and Market Analysis, will provide insights on evolving natural gas market dynamics, the interaction of fuel and power markets, and explore advances in integrated electric system generation, transmission and distribution planning analyses, and tools to help resource planners deal with emerging challenges.

Together these project sets provide a consistent set of information, analyses, and planning tools to inform and communicate company investment decisions.

Estimated 2017 Program Funding
$2.4 million

  • PS178A: Engineering and Economic Guide for Power System Technologies (TAG)
    08-Jun-2016

    Project Set 178A, Engineering and Economic Guide for Power Generation and Storage Technologies, develops critical technology, cost, and performance information for power generation and storage systems.  The research undertaken supports  project planning, whether longer term strategic planning or more near term project feasibility studies, by providing insight on the costs of power generation equipment, construction labor, and potential O&M expenses.  In addition to the data, access to the TAGWeb software enables direct comparison of technology options and comprehensive financial analysis, including levelized cost of electricity.  The software is pre-populated with key data based on certain design assumptions.  Members of the program are able to customize technology options to be reflective of local labor costs and specific financing options.   

    This project set provides a forum in which key electric company staff can discuss the challenges and potential solutions associated with developing integrated resource plans and project costs that are truly reflective of current and future market conditions.    

    • Annual TAGWeb User Access
      08-Jun-2016

      Power utility companies are actively considering what types of generation capacity to build and how to best meet future load demand in the least cost and most environmentally compliant fashion.  As the planning process for new capacity additions is fairly long and a diversified set of technologies has to be considered, power companies need credible and consistent information on the performance and cost of conventional and emerging power system technologies. Implementation of environmentally friendly and effective, capital-intensive, and long-asset-life technologies is more important than ever before. Developing and implementing strategic technology solutions require linking technology plans to business plans, which in turn requires critical information on the technologies. This information includes consistent, up-to-date data on the performance and cost of conventional and emerging electricity technologies and facilitates analysis of plant retrofits, retirements, major asset replacement/refurbishment, and new capacity additions.

    • Technology Assessment Guide (TAG)
      08-Jun-2016

      Power companies are considering large retrofit investments in existing coal generation to keep the units operating. Many are choosing to retire capacity, and with increases in the demand for power in the United States anticipated in the next few years and mandates in many states to increase the fraction of renewable capacity, companies are actively considering what types of generation capacity to build. As the planning process for new capacity additions is fairly long and a diversified set of technologies has to be considered, power companies need credible and consistent information on the performance and cost of conventional and emerging power system technologies. Implementation of environmentally friendly and effective, capital-intensive, and long-asset-life technologies is more important than ever before. Developing and implementing strategic technology solutions require linking technology plans to business plans, which in turn requires critical information on the technologies. This information includes consistent, up-to-date data on the performance and cost of conventional and emerging electricity technologies and facilitates analysis of plant retrofits, retirements, major asset replacement/refurbishment, and new capacity additions.

  • PS178B: Integrated Portfolio Planning and Market Analysis
    10-Jun-2016

    Electric company resource planning is evolving rapidly today in response to dramatic changes occurring in the electric sector in the United States and internationally. Today, company resource planners are being called on to develop more sophisticated integrated resource plans that span generation, transmission and distribution systems. Additionally, some jurisdictions are beginning to implement new distribution resource planning process to address growing deployment of distributed energy resources (DER), and there is growing interest among state PUCs and companies in conducting “integrated resources planning.”

    Resource planners today must contend with ongoing retirements of dispatchable baseload coal and nuclear units that traditionally have provided many of the services needed to maintain system reliability. They will also need to contend with growing deployment of utility-scale renewable resources and “behind-the-meter” distributed generation resources, such as rooftop solar photovoltaic (PV) systems; the advent of the “smart grid” and two-way power flow across electric sector transmission and distribution networks; public policies and changes in the market that incentivize deployment of energy efficiency (EE) and demand response (DR) programs; the emergence of new types of grid-connected and customer-sided electricity storage systems; and, uncertainty about future electricity loads and the evolution of the design of wholesale power markets.  

    In addition to these changes in the electric sector, the rapid increase in domestic natural gas production in recent years and the associated sustained decline of natural gas prices have dramatically changed the merit-order dispatch of electric power plants in many regions of the United States. These low prices have undercut the cost of operation of existing coal plants, and combined with increased penetration of large-scale renewable generation, low gas prices have contributed to reduced dispatch of nuclear units and even some recent nuclear plant retirements. The price of natural gas relative to coal and other fuels used to generate electricity is a critical variable in determining the market dispatch of power generation to meet customer load, and what types of new power generation technologies and facilities may be built in the future. 

    In addition, the ongoing deployment of large-scale, non-dispatchable renewable energy resources (i.e., wind and solar) can be expected to continue impact the market dispatch of power plants and lead to changes in the profitability of all of the power technologies used to meet customer load. The deployment of utility-scale renewable resources impacts the operation of existing baseload power plants, increases cycling and associated wear and tear, may lead to over-generation in some circumstances and reduced system reliability.

    The research undertaken by this project set is designed to help company resource planners and fuel managers to better understand the dynamics of the natural gas markets and prices, and the interactions between the fuels markets and the electric power markets.  In addition, this project is designed to assist members to develop future resource planning analyses that address key structural and operational changes occurring in the electric sector today, and to develop future resources plans that address electric generation, transmission and distribution in a more integrated way. 

    EPRI research program on Integrated Portfolio Planning and Market Analysis addresses needs and directly supports EPRI’s Research Imperatives #3 on “Integrated Power System and Environmental Modeling Framework.”

    This project set also provides a key forum for electric company staff to discuss the myriad challenges associated with conducting more integrated resource planning and forecasting future fuel prices, and to identify possible approaches, gain new insights, test existing tools and methods to assess how they address key issues, and develop new analytical methods and capabilities.  

    This project set coordinates its research efforts with EPRI programs on Grid Operations and Planning (Programs 39, 40 and 173), Distribution Planning (Program 200), and Integration of Distributed Energy Resources (Program 174) in EPRI’s PDU division.

    This project set coordinates its work directly with EPRI’s research programs on Grid Operations (P39), Grid Planning (P40), Bulk Power System Integration of Variable Generation (P173), Distribution Planning (P200), and Integration of Distributed Energy Resources (P174D) in EPRI’s PDU division.

    • Fuel and Power Market Analysis
      10-Jun-2016

      The price of natural gas relative to coal and other fuels used to generate electricity is a critical variable in determining the market dispatch of power plants to meet customer load, and what types of new power generation technologies may be deployed in the future.

      In recent years, the “shale revolution” has transformed the North American natural gas and electric power industries. The marriage of hydraulic fracturing technology and horizontal drilling of unconventional shale gas “plays,” has dramatically expanded natural gas production and led to lower natural gas prices. The sustained decline of natural gas prices in recent years has dramatically upended wholesale power markets, impacted the profitability of existing power plants, and altered future generation investment plans. 

      Low natural gas prices also have created new demands for natural gas in industry and transportation, a boom in infrastructure development, and a race to develop large liquefied natural gas (LNG) export terminals in the U.S. and Canada. In addition, implementation of the federal Clean Power Plan to reduce CO2 emissions from existing fossil-fired power plants is expected to boost demand for natural gas in the power sector in the coming years.

      As a consequence of these changes in the fuels and power markets, company fuel managers and resource planners are focused more than ever on understanding the drivers of changing natural gas supplies, demand and future natural gas prices. While low oil and natural gas prices have persisted for several years now, it is notoriously difficult to predict future natural gas prices, as some analysts expect abundant supplies and low prices to persist well into the future, while others believe the period of sustained low prices may come to an end more quickly.

      In addition to these key changes in fuels markets, the ongoing deployment of large-scale, non-dispatchable renewable energy resources, such as wind and solar, can be expected to continue to impact the market dispatch of power plants and lead to changes in the profitability of all of the power technologies used to meet customer load. The deployment of utility-scale renewable resources impacts the operation of existing baseload power plants, increases cycling and associated wear and tear, may lead to over-generation in some circumstances and reduced system reliability.

      To manage their existing power generation fleet effectively, and to plan strategically for the next round of capital investments in new facilities, it is critical for electric company fuel managers and planners to continuously improve their understanding of the dynamics of the natural gas markets and prices, and the interactions between fuels markets and the electric power markets.

    • Integrated Generation, Transmission and Distribution Planning
      02-Jun-2016

      Electric company resource planning is evolving rapidly today in response to dramatic changes occurring in the electric sector. These changes include increased deployment of distributed energy resources (DER) and utility-scale variable renewable resources, such as wind and solar; rapid changes in the cost and performance of power generation technologies; sustained low natural gas prices; the advent of the “smart grid” and two-way power flow across electric sector transmission and distribution networks; and, continually evolving environmental regulations, including implementation of the final Clean Power Plan to reduce CO2 emissions from fossil-fired power generation facilities. Increasingly, resource planners are being called on to develop more sophisticated integrated resource plans that span power generation, transmission and distribution systems. In addition, resource planners are trying to better understand and account for a variety of key issues associated with incorporating these challenges into resource planning.

      In recent years, load growth has slowed, and in some cases declined, across much of the United States as a result of slow economic growth, a transforming economy, increased reliance on demand response and distributed generation. The emergence of advanced distributed generation, storage, and grid technologies are changing some fundamental planning questions too. Increasing consumer choice, changing consumer behavior, and growing consumer demand for new ways to obtain electric power are beginning to impact electric company operations, planning and finance. These factors, combined with increased public scrutiny, media coverage of power industry decisions, and the large potential impacts of possible decisions, continue to fuel a high-stakes challenge for electric generation planners.

      This research project is focused on helping companies to meet these new resource planning challenges. We do this by helping members to better understand how resource planners around the country and regulators in different jurisdictions are addressing key areas that have long been part of “traditional” approaches to “generation planning,” as well as approaches for integrating transmission and distribution-level planning, and identify new innovations in resource planning that may help improve member planning activities to address current and future challenges.  This project also is designed help members to better understand analysis methods, tools and approaches that can be used to better incorporate deployment of distributed energy resources (DER) and utility-scale non-dispatchable renewable resources into integrated company resource planning.

Overview

Program Description

The traditional electric distribution system philosophy has been to design and maintain a system that provides the required level of reliability and resiliency in the most cost-effective manner —minimum cost for all customers. Today, distribution system owners need to continually improve the efficiency and reliability of the distribution system, accommodate a higher penetrations of distributed energy resources (DER), and maximize utilization of existing distribution assets without compromising safety and established operating constraints.

Significant changes to distribution design and operating practices are needed to accommodate these new requirements. At the same time, utilities will continue to grapple with the ongoing challenges of an aging infrastructure, increasing customer expectations, increasing competition for resources, and an aging workforce. Recent experience with major storm events has also revealed a need to re-examine practices for designing, maintaining, and operating the distribution system to improve its overall resiliency.

EPRI's Distribution Systems Program has been structured to provide members with research and application knowledge to support planning and management of the grid today and the transition to a modern integrated grid. The Program delivers a portfolio of tools and technologies to increase overall distribution reliability and resiliency; understand the expected performance for specific components throughout its life cycle; assess methods for evaluating the condition of system components; and develop and test new technologies. The program delivers a blend of short-term tools such reference guides and industry practices as well as longer-term research such as component-aging characteristics and the development of new inspection technologies.  Overall, the Program includes research that supports grid modernization and provides tools for planning, design, construction, maintenance, operation, and analysis of the distribution system.

Members of the Program gain access to a portfolio of projects that address the range of distribution issues, as well as the opportunity to collaborate with other members and EPRI technical experts to share ideas and solutions, improve knowledge transfer, and ultimately improve safety, reliability and operational performance.

Research Value

With the knowledge acquired through this research program, members will gain access to information that can help them accomplish the following:

  • Identify and apply new approaches and strategies for managing aging assets;

  • Apply advanced diagnostics, inspection and assessment methods, tools, and techniques;

  • Optimize component procurement specifications and equipment application guidelines to improve investment decisions;

  • Assess the costs and benefits of emerging technologies;

  • Integrate advanced distributed sensor technologies; and

  • Understand industry-leading practices in the management and operation of distribution systems.

Approach

EPRI's approach to providing value in the Distribution Systems Program involves multiple strategies:

  • Basic research: Research into new technologies, practices, and tools provide the foundation for ongoing advancements in the industry.

  • Testing: The work conducted in EPRI laboratories and in cooperation with other industry centers of excellence enables detailed assessments of design standards, equipment performance, application issues, and aging characteristics.

  • Solutions engineering: Developing, testing and demonstrating innovative solutions for new or existing distribution system challenges by taking advantage of research results from other sectors of the utility industry or other industries.

  • Application guidance: Basic research results are translated into application and assessment guidelines and approaches that members can use to plan, manage, and operate the distribution system of the future.

  • Industry knowledge databases: EPRI collaboration facilitates the collection of industry-wide information that can help Program members understand important trends and characteristics related to equipment and systems.

  • Technical information transfer and sharing: This strategy includes active participation in industry groups; a 24/7 hotline to address specific member issues; interest groups to coordinate information sharing on urgent topics; and workshops, conferences, and training in emerging research areas.

Accomplishments

EPRI's Distribution Systems Program has delivered valuable information that has helped its members and the industry in numerous ways: For example, the following products highlight recent results (3002007299) from this program:

EPRI tested and published findings on distribution components, which provide utilities with new, objective insights on criteria to consider when specifying future purchases of these components. In 2015, the following research was performed:

  • Material and design analysis of an underground switch which includes a visible break;

  • Laboratory evaluation of line recloser material and design characteristics;

  • Forensic review of failed capacitor switches; and

  • Method to identify cracked porcelain cutouts.

EPRI documented industry knowledge through the company immersions and industry surveys to provide knowledge transfer to the next generation of utility personnel responsible for the safe, reliable, affordable, and environmentally responsible distribution of electricity. In 2015, the following research was published:

  • Urban Underground Network Survey;

  • Underground Immersion at AEP;

  • Grounding and Personal Protection on Underground Systems; and

  • Distribution Hotline Calls.

EPRI continued to assess new technologies that are becoming an integral part of the distribution system infrastructure. The rigorous unbiased evaluation and assessment methodology used by EPRI includes laboratory-specified testing combined with practical field experience to produce fact-based results. In 2015, the following research was published:

  • Underground Distribution: Evaluation of Advanced Cable Diagnostics – Gas Detection of Melted Insulation;

  • Distribution Line Sensors;

  • Distribution Automation Controller Backup Power Supply Technologies; and

  • Development Plan for Downed Pole Sensor.

Key Activities

In 2017, this program expects to accomplish the following objectives:

  • Continue unbiased laboratory testing and evaluation of distribution components to provide objective insights on equipment performance, reliability, and aging to inform equipment specifications, acceptance tests, integration, as well as inspections and maintenance practices.

  • Through direct engagement (immersion) with member utilities, identify and document leading functional practices for maintaining and improving the reliability, resiliency, and safety of underground and overhead distribution systems.

  • Advance development and application of innovative new sensors to improve system reliability, safety, and asset management, as well as potentially reduce time for outage damage assessment and restoration.  The focus for 2016 will be downed pole and conductor sensors, which directly support EPRI Research Imperative 5 - Accelerate Adoption of Intelligent Sensor System Technologies for Improved Power System Operations, Maintenance, and Outage Restoration.

  • Provide mechanisms for technology transfer to support members with technical resources, training, and standards information as well as with key technical developments in the industry.

  • PS180B: Asset Inspection, Maintenance, and Planning
    16-May-2016

    Ongoing safe and reliable operation of the distribution system is in part attained through targeted inspection and maintenance of its components based on minimizing equipment life-cycle costs and risks. Many electric utilities are considering or already have moved toward implementing these asset management concepts.  However, the data and analytical tools required for equipment risk assessment and management are not well established.  Asset management decisions for maximizing performance and minimizing equipment life-cycle costs should be based upon risks associated with actual equipment condition and historical performance.

    This project set provides data to asset managers to better optimize equipment selection and inspection/maintenance cycles. This is accomplished through understanding the properties of distribution components and how existing, new, and emerging inspection techniques may be utilized to extend component service life.

    Information is gathered through a combination of literature reviews, field studies, interviews, equipment teardowns, and laboratory testing. Results are compiled into technical updates and guides which provide a better understanding of component reliability, equipment remaining life, and life-cycle cost. This project set helps utilities determine what information should be considered and how it should be prioritized to optimize cost, reliability, safety, and environmental impact.

    • P180.003 Asset Characterization, Degradation, and Failure
      14-Jun-2016

      Electric distribution systems are composed of immense asset fleets including poles, conductors, transformers, insulators, switchgear, and more. Many of these assets are approaching the end of or have exceeded their specified service lives. Asset managers must strategically allocate budget dollars to inspect/repair, replace, and/or defer maintenance. Optimized deployment of utility resources requires thorough understanding each component’s lifecycle: expected function and tolerances, costs of installation and upkeep, estimated service life, symptoms of degradation, and consequences of failure.

      In 2017, this project will investigate underground switches, beginning with material and design analysis of new units purchased through the project and aged/failed units donated by utilities. Findings from aged and failed units will be used, along with existing industry standards, to inform procurement specifications to reduce likelihood of failure.

    • P180.004 Inspection, Assessment, and Analytics
      14-Jun-2016

      Maximum asset service life is often accomplished through appropriate inspection and maintenance of components through its service life.  This can be costly and time consuming, so optimizing interval frequency and procedures are desirable. Additionally, decision support analytics and methodologies to support fleet asset management programs require new knowledge, tools and methodologies.  There are many inspection and maintenance options available, with new technologies and products emerging. Evaluation of devices and process efficacy can help utilities determine where to spend their money.

      Periodic inspection of distribution circuits provides insight regarding physical asset and overall system health. Identification of poorly performing components prior to failure avoids outages and potential safety hazards. Traditional inspection and maintenance practices identify some failing units, but miss some components near end-of-life, or are difficult to apply to the entire system in an appropriate amount of time at a reasonable price. Advanced inspection methods require significant investment in training and equipment, but can provide large returns if applied strategically and competently.

      This project investigates existing and novel methods to obtain, process and assess asset health information. Complementing project 180.003 which correlates asset health with potential inspection data sources, this project examines the approaches and tools necessary to enable the utility to obtain the data needed for condition assessment decisions. Additional sources of data from SCADA and emerging “Internet of Things” technology are also considered.

    16-May-2016

    This project set develops and evaluates approaches for designing distribution systems for reliability, and selecting the optimum methods for improving reliability as a function of distribution system characteristics. This project set will also identify and evaluate approaches for hardening the distribution system to improve resiliency during major weather events, including the identification of leading practices for improving storm response efficiency and effectiveness.

    Using an immersion process, this project set will identify and document leading practices for maintaining and improving distribution system reliability and resiliency. Because managing system performance is a key aspect of managing reliability and resiliency, this project set includes continued research to share leading industry strategies, programs and practices to optimize distribution system performance.

    This project set will also identify leading industry practices related to major event planning, preparedness and management; damage assessment, analysis and prediction; and communication of restoration progress with key stakeholders.

  • PS180E: Risk Mitigation Strategies
    16-May-2016

    This project set focuses on safety. Areas include new safety products, risk assessment methodologies, complying with standards, new training materials, and new practices. In area of risk mitigation, this project will identify and investigate new developments related to risk management for utility workers and the public. 

    This project set will also address the industry need for development of an effective and reliable approach for detecting high-impedance faults and downed conductors, to help improve public safety and reduce risk to utilities. Existing distribution relaying and controls are not able to detect these situations because the fault impedance is high. However new technologies and utility communications and automation infrastructure may allow for reliable detection of these high-impedance faults.

    • P180.009 High-Impedance Fault Detection
      14-Jun-2016

      Downed conductors and high-impedance faults remain a public safety issue for utilities, despite much research on this topic. Every year people are killed by contact to downed conductors. Existing relaying and controls on distribution systems are not able to detect these situations because the impedance of the faults is high, so utilities currently rely on phone calls from the public to identify these situations. New technologies and utility communications and automation infrastructure may allow for reliable detection of these high-impedance faults.

      New relays within the industry have optional algorithms for detection of high-impedance faults. These algorithms have not been extensively tested and documented in the field. Utilities are adding more distribution instrumentation for metering, automation, and for volt-var control. This communications and metering infrastructure might also be used to detect high-impedance faults. The key research question is: can these technologies reliably detect high-impedance faults without excessive false positives.

    • P180.010 Trends and Developments in Risk Management
      14-Jun-2016

      This project aims to identify and investigate new developments related to risk management for utility workers and the public. Areas include new safety products, risk assessment methodologies, complying with standards, new training materials, and new practices.

  • PS180G: Technology Assessment and Development
    09-Mar-2017

    Distribution automation technologies enable electric utilities to remotely monitor, coordinate, and operate intelligent distribution components in real time from remote locations. This project set evaluates and assesses distribution automation technologies such as sensors, switching devices, and other intelligent components that are being integrated into the system. The rigorous and unbiased evaluation and assessment methodology used in this project set includes laboratory-specified testing combined with practical field experience to produce fact-based results.

    This project set will provide members with new technological developments applicable to distribution systems. This will be done by researching available options and performing fundamental research to develop new distribution technologies, such as distribution sensors. These projects will be multi-year efforts to scope, design, prototype, test, validate, and commercialize new distribution technologies. The developed solutions can then be used to improve distribution system reliability, safety, and asset management.

    The work being done in this project set is closely coordinated with and designed to complement the sensor research being done in the Transmission and Substation area, and to the extent where communication technologies are involved, the Information and Communication Technology (P161) Program. The work is also closely coordinated with and designed to complement the work being done in the Asset Inspection, Maintenance, and Planning (P180B) Program.

    • P180.020 Overhead Practices
      14-Jun-2016

      This project will focus on identifying and collecting leading functional practices of overhead distribution systems. Participating members can expect to measure, compare, and validate their current practices and determine if any are in need of adjustment. By identifying better methods, and understanding the rationale used by peers to adopt alternate approaches, utilities can identify practices appropriate to them that improve efficiency, reliability, and safety.  

      In past years, this project has focused in line worker practices.  For 2017, the project will be focused on an area of particular industry need, the management of distribution automation devices.   These devices, used to remotely monitor, coordinate, and operate intelligent distribution devices and equipment in real time from remote locations, are prevalent and growing in number exponentially on distribution systems. Managing these devices (including activities such as designing, provisioning, installing and commissioning, testing, maintaining, operating and troubleshooting), is often challenging because it often involves coordination of resources with varied skill sets, and because of the rapid change in the technology.  Given these challenges and the criticality of these devices, there is a need to identify and document leading practices for managing these devices.  Ultimately, to move towards a “plug and play” environment, the industry needs to establish interoperability standards so that the various technologies necessary for these devices integrate properly.

Overview

Program Description

Customers are growing more and more sophisticated, with increasing expectations of value, speed, and reliability based on service interactions in multiple business sectors, such as home entertainment, business computing and communications, and the Internet of Things. These expectations are carrying over to the electricity sector. At the same time, customers are beginning to consider options related to electricity supply and use, with choices often coming from third parties, not their utility. Technology advances are giving customers more choice and control over when and how they use electricity, including smart appliances and thermostats, plug-in electric vehicles, and options for local generation, such as rooftop solar photovoltaics. The choices customers make are already having recognizable impacts on the electricity system, particularly on energy consumption and load shapes, and these impacts will continue to grow.

Customer choice and control can enhance the value of electricity service to the individual customer and to customers as a whole. Because utilities have established relationships with their customers, they can be very effective change agents toward offering customers choices that align with both customer and utility objectives. Utilities have opportunities to meet customer expectations and to dynamically integrate customers and their choices into the power system. However, with the increasing sophistication of customers, new and diverse strategies to integrate customers are needed going forward. For example, utilities can learn from competitive industries’ methods for understanding their customers. Businesses have developed detailed knowledge of their customers’ preferences and behaviors over decades of gathering information. They apply this knowledge of customer interests and values to devise products and services that meet diverse demands, and then they make appropriate offers to targeted customers. Similarly, utilities need strategies for creating and offering compelling choices for electricity service.

EPRI’s Understanding Electric Utility Customers research is focused on providing utilities with insights and tools to understand and to take action with their customers to offer choices that are aligned with customer preferences as well as utility and societal objectives of providing reliable, affordable, and environmentally-responsible power.

Research Value

This research provides results and tools utilities can use to develop customer programs that have a greater likelihood of success in terms of customer acceptance and of customer behavior change that benefits customers and society. The costs of implementing ineffective programs can be avoided by participating in and using the research. The research will also help utilities use the customer participation and impacts forecasts in utility planning and operations.  The collaborative approach provides opportunities to interact with diverse member organizations that have pioneered research approaches, have taken the risk to implement pilot programs, or have full customer programs in place. Collaboratively-developed tools are more cost effective and are designed based on larger and more diverse data sets, resulting in more robust tools that give higher value results than if developed by a single entity. Furthermore, such tools can be expanded with each new wave of research and the underlying foundations can be shared so that confidence in robust results among stakeholders is strong. Delving into existing programs and pilots provides a rich set of secondary research results that can often be used to estimate impacts on utility systems in place of spending the time and resources on primary research. With resources and results available, members have the opportunity to increase customer satisfaction by offering programs and services that customers prefer and targeting those customers that prefer them, while meeting corporate and societal goals.

This program provides insights, tools, and methods to help utilities understand and more meaningfully engage with their customers to empower them to make optimal choices with respect to their supply and use of electricity. These choices will enhance customer satisfaction while also aligning with the utility and societal objectives of keeping electricity service reliable, affordable, and environmentally responsible.

Further, this program supports one of EPRI’s Research Imperatives to “Enable Integration of Customer Resources” by providing critical information related to customer preferences for and adoption of customer resources.

Approach

This research program conducts research to forecast and understand the impacts of customer participation, performance, and persistence with respect to electricity service plans such as rate structures, coupled with enabling technologies and information and customer technologies such as plug-in electric vehicles and solar photovoltaic systems. The research also helps utilities create effective offerings based on what customer prefer and aligned with what will benefit society. This program will also develop strategies to incorporate customer impacts into system planning and operations.

The program focuses on the following:

  • Developing and demonstrating methods to characterize customer preferences.
  • Developing and testing new approaches for understanding customer diversity and developing robust, reliable methods for building actionable customer groupings and associations.
  • Synthesizing experience and knowledge of critical customer topics facing the industry that members can use for evaluating alternatives.
  • Capturing case studies to document examples of utility successes; for example, use of customer data to improve utility operations and customer satisfaction.
  • Identifying the process of developing and incorporating new customer programs, from conceptualization to estimating impacts on utility operations to integrating them into utility operations.
  • Designing effective electricity service plans employing rate structure designs that combine conceptual guidance from the disciplines of finance and economics with real-world experience about how customers respond to different rate structures.
  • Identifying strategies for integrating the impacts of behavioral programs fully into utility system planning and operations, so that utilities can effectively plan for expected changes in electricity use and load shape.
  • The work being done in this program is closely coordinated with and designed to complement the work undertaken in the Electric Transportation (P18), Energy Storage and Distributed Generation (P94), End-Use Energy Efficiency and Demand Response (P170), and Integration of Distributed Energy Resources (P174) Programs.
Accomplishments

In the three years this program has existed, EPRI has addressed the following research questions:

  • What are the foundational frameworks for understanding electricity customers?
  • What results can we use from the pricing and behavior pilots and programs conducted to date?
  • What are appropriate methods for understanding preferences for unfamiliar offerings?
  • What are methods for utilities to effectively develop and manage offerings to customers?
  • What are the customer-related linkages between wholesale (e.g., regional transmission organizations) and retail (e.g., distribution utilities) entities?

These questions are addressed below along with key research results.

What are the foundational frameworks for understanding electricity customers?

When embarking on this program, EPRI recognized that foundational frameworks would help enhance the value and understanding of research results by members, which have been represented by advisors from diverse backgrounds and responsibilities. This foundational work is available for all program members for various purposes, such as to help bring new staff members into the customer research area or to educate other parts of utility organizations on the value of understanding customers. For example,

  • EPRI developed the concept of electricity service plans to describe a broader vision of customer programs than simply rate structures. EPRI envisions electricity service plans as rate structures combined with behavioral inducements such as electricity usage information/feedback and enabling technologies to empower customers to change their electricity use and use patterns.
  • In the course of conducting secondary research, EPRI focused on what we call the 3 Ps: participation, performance, and persistence. These are the critical aspects of measuring the impacts of customer programs.
  • EPRI documented a number of frameworks that guide members in their customer pursuits, for example, Guidelines for Designing Effective Energy Information Feedback Pilots: Research Protocols (1020855), which specifies research protocols that are now widely referenced and used. Additional frameworks include:
  • Innovative Applications of Customer Data Analytics: A Case Study (3002005720)
  • Bring Your Own Device Program Models (3002006184)*
  • Obtaining Internal Support for Customer Choices (3002006185)*
  • Quantifying the Impacts of Time-Based Rates, Enabling Technology, and Other Treatments in Consumer Behavior Studies: Protocols and Guidelines ( 3002000282 ).
  • A Framework for Assessing the Net Benefits of Home Area Networks to Enable Demand Response ( 1021628 ).
  • A System for Understanding Retail Electric Rate Structures ( 1021962 ).
  • Price Elasticity of Demand for Electricity: A Primer and Synthesis ( 1016264 ).

What results can we use from the pricing and behavior pilots and programs conducted to date?

EPRI established a foundation for addressing the most critical gaps in its synthesis of research findings (EPRI 1023562: Understanding Electric Utility Customers) and has subsequently developed a significant library of secondary research in several reports and also in presentations delivered to members via Webcast, including:

  • The Demand for Residential Demand Charges (3002006183)*
  • Understanding Electric Utility Customers – 2014 Update: Review of Recent Studies (30020001268).
  • Opt-In vs. Opt-Out: Impact Implications for Full Service Territory: Evidence Review Webcast (3002004318).
  • What We Have Learned and How to Apply it to Your Utility: Evidence Review Webcast (3002003548).
  • Peak Time Rebate vs. Critical Peak Pricing: A Distinction without a Difference? Evidence Review Webcast (3002003547).

Transparency and research rigor are bolstered by EPRI making research findings available to a wider research audience—a practice not typically followed in the industry.

What are appropriate methods for understanding preferences for unfamiliar offerings?

EPRI researched methods for estimating preferences for residential customers, particularly for unfamiliar offerings, which is typical of utility pricing programs (EPRI 1024401: Methods for Characterizing Customer Preferences for Electric Service Plans). EPRI found that discrete choice experimentation, an approach used for product development in competitive markets, can also work in regulated markets for hypothetical or unfamiliar offerings.

EPRI tested discrete choice experimentation for time of use and fixed bill preferences for utility members in diverse regions with residential customers. The results show that between 20 and 30 percent of residential customers state that they would select a time of use rate. The project demonstrated how effective this approach is. EPRI is now working with utilities to document the findings and expand the types of electricity service plans the models can infer for the population.  In 2015, EPRI developed a software tool, Customer Preferences Estimator, to help utilities estimate the market share of various time-of-use rate and fixed bill designs, using the results from the supplemental project Characterizing Residential Customer Preferences for Electricity Service Plans.

IN 2016, EPRI embarked on a similar study on methods to estimate preferences for commercial customers.

Program 182 worked jointly with the Electric Transportation (Program 18) to characterize preferences for electric vehicles:

  • TVA Electric Vehicle Survey: Consumer Expectations for Electric Vehicles (1022729).
  • Characterizing Consumers' Interest in and Infrastructure Expectations for Electric Vehicles: Research Design and Survey Results (1021285).
  • Southern Company Electric Vehicle Survey: Consumer Expectations for Electric Vehicles 1022728.
  • TVA Electric Vehicle Survey: Consumer Expectations for Electric Vehicles ( 1022729).
  • Texas Plugs In: Houston and San Antonio Residents' Expectations of and Purchase Intentions for Plug-In Electric Vehicles (1025825).

What are methods for utilities to effectively develop and manage offerings to customers?

EPRI developed and demonstrated a method for developing electricity service plan offerings that align with utility strategic goals, which was demonstrated with utility members. This work pulls together secondary and primary research on customer preferences with the understanding of the financial impacts of customer participation in electricity service plans. EPRI’s detailed pricing model estimates the changes in revenues resulting from electricity service plan participation.

In addition, EPRI developed an electricity service plan portfolio management system that can help a utility manage a portfolio of electricity service plans that together meet utility strategic goals.

  • Electric Service Plan Portfolio Management: Approaches and Potential Applications.
  • Specifications For and Design of an Electric Service Plan Portfolio Management System (3002001266).

What are the customer-related linkages between wholesale (e.g., regional transmission organizations) and retail (e.g., distribution utilities) entities?

EPRI developed a conceptual framework for understanding the role and value of demand response in determining what level of service reliability to provide customers. It will help program designers understand the underlying market mechanisms that determine why and to what extent consumers are willing to participate in load curtailment programs designed to reduce capacity costs, and how their participation affects capacity costs.

  • A Framework for Valuing Demand and Price Response (3002001271).
  • A Framework for Valuing Demand Response as a Capacity Adequacy Resource (1017876).

Complementary customer behavioral research is conducted by, or jointly with, Program 170 (End-Use Energy Efficiency and Demand Response), Program 18 (Electric Transportation) (listed above), and the EPRI Smart Grid Demonstration Initiative. This body of work includes:

  • Workshop Summary: Synthesizing Utility Experiences in Educating and Engaging Customers in Smart Meter/Smart Grid Deployments (Joint report with Smart Grid Demonstration Project) (1026432).
  • The Effect on Electricity Consumption of the Commonwealth Edison Customer Applications Program: Phase 2 Final Analysis (1023644).
  • The Effect on Electricity Consumption of the Commonwealth Edison Customer Application Program Pilot: Phase 1 (joint report with Smart Grid Demonstration Project) (1022703).
  • Social Media in Support of Outage Management: Workshop Summary (3002002280).
  • Systems to Support Intelligent Building Management and Behavioral Programs: The State of the Market (Joint report with P170: EE/DR Tech) (3002001265).
Key Activities

The 2016 program continues to tap into the body of research and results to conduct practical and critical reviews of current challenges, trends, and opportunities. Members select the topics and receive the results in webcast form for easy sharing among colleagues and stakeholders. Study of data analytics to benefit customers continues with the development of functional requirements for data analytics capability within a utility. Commercial customers are the focus of the preferences research in 2016.  Selecting appropriate research methods for estimating preferences for commercial customers is the first step.  Following that step, a field study to determine preferences will be launched.  Finally, we delve into working across the utility to help the planning and operations teams incorporate customer participation and impacts estimates into their work. This will open up lines of communications and help to improve the planning and raise awareness of customer choices and their impacts on electricity use.

  • P182.002: Behavioral Program Evidence Review
    15-Jun-2016

    In the quickly changing utility environment, there is more opportunity than ever to deliver new products and services that help utilities  both engage with their customers more productively, as well as employ them as grid resources.  But what do customers want?  And how can utilities rely on customer program impacts for planning purposes? 

    These questions represent very broad research areas, and this project seeks to contribute to their resolution by carving out specific topical research questions that P182 members ask us to investigate. 

    Past research topics have included:

    • Utility procedures for bringing new offerings to customers
    • Residential demand/partial usage charges: rate structures to accommodate distributed generation
    • Bring your own device programs: what are they, what do they mean for customers, and how do demand impacts differ compared to traditional utility programs?

    Potential topics for 2017 include:

    • On talking to people: communications experts on educating customers about complicated utility concepts
    • Behavioral programs and opportunities for low income customers: prepay, bill alerts, and beyond
    • Residential demand charges II: experiences from recent pilots and implementations
    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P182.010: Customer Data Analytics
    15-Jun-2016

    As utilities continue AMI and other smart grid investments, and as customer interest in connected devices grows, so do the myriad of data streams that these technologies make available. Other industries claim that using advanced customer data analytics of “Big Data” has led to a better understanding of customer needs, more efficient processes, and new and more targeted service offerings. The utility industry is now in the early stages of learning how to make use of its customer data to obtain similar ends, and in ways that show tangible value. At the same time, the proliferation of data analytics platforms on the market, and the value they may deliver, is difficult to get a handle on.

    This project seeks to address the primary research question of “How can utilities make use of their customer data, in conjunction with other data sources, to maximum its value for both customers and the utility?” by focusing on two specific objectives:

    • Look within the utility industry for novel data analytics applications.
    • Look to other industries that make use of advanced customer analytics to understand their applications, how they use findings to maximize value, the systems and personnel they have in place, and how they justified those investments initially.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P182.011: Forecasting Commercial Customer Participation and Impacts
    15-Jun-2016

    Commercial (business) customers, those with loads under 500 kW, typically have few alternatives to a standard, one-size-fits-all electric service. Business use electricity in a variety of spatially and temporally different ways that provide opportunities for them to benefit from service diversification. A wide range of pricing plans, more aligned with marginal electricity supply costs can leverage those opportunities and provide benefits to all customers, not just those that subscribe to them.

    Utilities and other service providers must be able to predict participation in prospective services to determine if offing them is worthwhile, and if so in what manner. The market potential may be limited and specific to certain customers, so effective implementation requires further differentiation: who are the likely subscribers? Specific to the utility industry, effective system planning and operation depends on a solid understanding of how customer's preferences for prospective services will impact system resources.  Until market research methods that meet these needs are devised and proven, commercial customer will be underserved to the detriment of all consumers of electricity and electric system operation. Additionally, offering choices (a portfolio) requires that those serve are internally consistent (the reflect real differences on costs) and externally viable (they produce sufficient revenues to over those costs).

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • P182.012: Integrating Customer Resources into Utility Planning and Operations
    15-Jun-2016

    Utilities must anticipate and be responsive to the expanding choices available to consumers in how they purchase electricity. Those choices include diverse forms of price response, ranging from paying prices that are posted a day ahead, or even a few minutes ahead, to purchasing fully hedged service for several years, to being paid occasionally to forego electricity usage. They also include a variety of ways to become a producer of some of their electric requirements: directly by installing distributed generation, effectively through on-site storage devices, or virtually through cooperative agreements that include either or both. Offering classes of customers a single way to buy electricity is neither sustainable nor desirable for utilities.

    Consumer choices produce fundamental changes in electric demand. These need to be recognized, characterized, and quantified because they have profound consequences for how utilities plan and operate their electric system. This involves more than increasingly sophisticated load forecasts. It requires developing planning protocols that take into account how changes in electricity demand effect the requirements to deliver diverse services reliably. It requires extending those learnings to system operations so that the benefits of diversified demand are realized, and adverse outcomes are anticipated and averted. In other words, it requires utilities to evolve from operating as a collection of separate functional units to a cohesive enterprise which shares information and focuses on customers.  

    To continue to provide reliable, safe and affordable power, the utility of the future must incorporate customer behavior into utility strategic, tactical, and operational activities. This involves both functional realignment and cultural adjustments. To make these necessary changes, the utility must coordinate customer research with enterprise planning and operations so that they share a common goal, develop ways to collaborate on research initiatives, define common data needs, and take joint responsibility for achievement of goals. This can happen organically in a collaborative technical and business environment that is focused on customers’ wants and needs, and fulfilling them responsibly and effectively. Therefore, integrating enterprise activity around a customer focus makes the requisite cultural changes inevitable.
