Overview

Program Description

Cyber and physical security have become critical priorities for electric utilities. The evolving electricity sector is increasingly dependent on information technology and telecommunication infrastructure to ensure the reliability and security of the electric grid. Specifically, measures to ensure cyber security must be designed and implemented to protect the electric grid from attacks by terrorists and hackers, and to strengthen grid resilience against natural disasters and inadvertent threats such as equipment failures and user errors.

The Cyber Security and Privacy Program of the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) focuses on addressing the emerging threats to an interconnected electric sector through multidisciplinary, collaborative research on cyber security technologies, standards, and business processes.

Research Value

The rapid pace of change in the electric sector creates a challenging environment for asset owners and operators to monitor the cyber security activities of industry groups, develop an understanding of how new technologies affect security, and maintain the right internal resources for assessing those technologies. EPRI employs a team of experts with comprehensive backgrounds in cyber security who address these challenges by providing insight and analysis of various security tools, architectures, guidelines, and results of testing to program participants.

Participation in EPRI’s Cyber Security and Privacy Program can provide the following benefits:

  • A better awareness of industry and government collaborative efforts, where members can "plug in" to current activities;
  • Guidance on developing cyber security strategies and requirements for selecting effective technologies;
  • Guidance on security metrics;
  • Techniques for assessing and monitoring risk;
  • Practical approaches to mitigating the risk of operating legacy systems;
  • Early identification of security gaps through laboratory assessments of security technologies; and
  • Technologies which support the management of cyber incidents and increase the cyber security and resiliency of the grid.
Approach

The Cyber Security and Privacy Program focuses on developing security requirements, creating new security technologies, and performing laboratory assessments of existing, relevant technologies. Members may use the products to enhance their current cyber security posture and increase the security of systems that are deployed in the future.

Key deliverables in this program include:

  • Newsletters and whitepapers to address high-impact issues;
  • Guidance on security metrics;
  • Guidance on assessing and monitoring risk;
  • Tools to manage networks and devices for power delivery systems;
  • Tools to support improved incident and threat management; and
  • Tools and techniques for assessing grid security, resiliency, and cyber security posture.
Accomplishments

The portfolio of projects in the Cyber Security and Privacy Program has delivered several key accomplishments that have helped its members specifically and the industry as a whole.

National Electric Sector Cybersecurity Organization Resource (NESCOR): National Electric Sector Cybersecurity Organization Resource (NESCOR): The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) awarded EPRI a contract to provide research and development resources for DOE’s public-private partnership, NESCOR. EPRI led the working groups that focus on identifying vulnerabilities and threats, assessing cyber security standards, and testing and validating technologies. The results of this work have been used to develop improved threat models, cyber security requirements, and security technologies. NESCOR delivered the following documents:  

  • Electric Sector Failure Scenarios and Impact Analyses : This document includes cyber security failure scenarios and impact analyses for the electric sector. A cyber security failure scenario is a realistic event in which the failure to maintain confidentiality, integrity, and/or availability of sector cyber assets creates a negative impact on the generation, transmission, and/or delivery of power.
  • Analysis of Selected Electric Sector High Risk Failure Scenarios : The failure scenarios in this document provide detailed analyses for a subset of the failure scenarios identified in the document listed above, which were prioritized for inclusion in this document, based upon the level of risk for the failure scenario and the priorities of NESCOR utility members.
  • Attack Trees for Selected Electric Sector High Risk Failure Scenarios : This briefing includes the modified attack tree diagrams from the detailed analysis documents.
  • Guide to Penetration Testing for Electric Utilities : This security test plan provides guidance to electric utilities on how to perform penetration tests in the smart grid domains of advanced metering infrastructure (AMI), demand response (DR), distributed energy resources (DER), distribution grid management (DGM), electric transportation (ET), and wide-area monitoring, protection, and control (WAMPAC). Penetration testing is one of the many different types of assessments that utilities can perform to evaluate their overall security posture.
  • Guidelines for Leveraging NESCOR Failure Scenarios in Cyber Security Tabletop Exercises: This document provides exercise facilitators with guidance concerning procedures and responsibilities for exercise development, facilitation, simulation, and support. It also includes a NESCOR failure scenario and explains how to expand this scenario for use in a cyber security tabletop exercise. 

Incident and Threat Management: Within the Security Technologies Project Set, EPRI is addressing the challenge of managing cyber and physical threats to substation and field devices.  In 2016, EPRI:

  • Developed and tested use cases for real world situations correlating aggregated data from substation sources in the Cyber Security Research Lab (CSRL);
  • Identified incident detection architectures for the Integrated Security Operations Center (ISOC) field devices and developed a corresponding test bed in the CSRL; and
  • Specified the requirements and tasks necessary to integrate the incident detections systems with SIEM tools.

Assessing and Monitoring Risk: Within the Information Assurance Project Set, EPRI focuses on security challenges that affect multiple operations domains, such as designing security into products, creating security metrics for the electric sector, and developing technical solutions for meeting security compliance requirements.  In 2016, EPRI:

  • Built on the 2015 Cyber Security Architecture Methodology report (3002005942) to include applicable device classes, security tools, and NESCOR failure scenarios for testing.
  • Revised the 2015 Creating Security Metrics for the Electric Sector report (3002005947) to include more in-depth parameters for creating a metrics program as well as risk-based security metrics.
  • Updated the Security, Cyber, Risk Assessment Methodology (SCRAM) database (3002005943).   
Key Activities

In 2017, this program expects to accomplish the following objectives:

  • Industry Collaboration: Track industry and government activities and provide technical contributions to key working groups;
  • Situational Awareness: Develop tools and technology for improved situational awareness for transmission and distribution systems;
  • Event and Incident Response: Improve the electric sector’s ability to detect, respond, and recover from cyber incidents.  The program will also continue technical development of the Integrated Security Operations Center (ISOC);
  • Threat and Vulnerability Management: Develop guidelines for advanced threat management for power delivery systems;
  • Cyber Security Program Management: Extend the security architecture methodology to include DER systems and address the technical challenges of cyber security compliance;
  • Asset, Change, and Configuration Management: Develop guidelines for effective configuration management;
  • Risk Management: Provide a methodology and metrics to establish a framework to evaluate the effectiveness of implemented security controls within power-delivery systems and operational environments; and
  • Supply Chain and External Dependencies: Examine various measures to reduce supply chain risk.

    • P183.001: Industry Collaboration
      14-Jan-2017

      The landscape of cyber security activities in the electricity sector involves numerous industry, government, and regulatory groups. Although tracking these groups can be a daunting effort, it is critical for utilities to be up-to-date on key industry activities. This project set provides members with an up-to-date view of industry activities and supports technical contribution to these groups.  It also supports white papers and working groups on key cyber security topics. 

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • PS183B: Security Technologies
    04-May-2016

    The Security Technologies project set addresses several security challenges facing power-delivery and control systems, including threat and vulnerability management, incident response, identity and access management, and situational awareness. The technology addressed within these focus areas can increase the security of next-generation power-delivery systems through a combination of new security tools and procedures to provide end-to-end security and support defense-in-depth strategies. Additionally, this project set will explore technology that helps organizations remain resilient to cyber security threats and continue to perform critical operations while under duress and during the recovery process.

    • P183.004: Security and System Monitoring
      14-Jun-2016

      Situational awareness involves developing near real-time knowledge of a dynamic operating environment. In part, this is accomplished through the logging and monitoring of IT, OT, physical security systems, and communication infrastructure assets essential for the delivery of the function. It is equally important to maintain knowledge of relevant, current cybersecurity events external to the enterprise. 

    • P183.005: Incident Response
      14-Jun-2016

      Incident response includes detecting cyber security events, establishing criteria for event prioritization, and correlating multiple cyber security events. Utilities need to establish and maintain plans, procedures, and technologies to detect, analyze, and respond to cybersecurity events and to sustain operations throughout a cybersecurity event. These criteria should align with the organization’s cyber security risk management strategy and ensure consistent assessment of events.

      This project covers four primary areas of incident response: 

      1. Detect cyber security events

      2. Escalate cyber security events and declare incidents

      3. Respond to incidents and escalated cyber security events

      4. Plan for recovery and continuity

    • P183.006 Threat Management
      15-Jun-2016

      The objective of threat management is to establish and maintain plans, procedures, and technologies to detect, identify, analyze, manage, and respond to cyber security threats, commensurate with the risk to the organization’s infrastructure (e.g., critical, IT, operational) and organizational objectives.

      A cyber security threat is defined as any circumstance or event with the potential to adversely impact organizational operations (including mission, functions, image, or reputation), resources, and other organizations through IT, OT, or communications infrastructure via unauthorized access, destruction, disclosure, modification of information, and/or denial of service.

    • P183.007 Identity and Access Management
      15-Jun-2016

      Controlling access includes determining access requirements, granting access to systems and networks based on those requirements, and revoking access when it is no longer required. Secure communication tools should include capabilities to manage user and device credentials, avoid unauthorized access, and ensure the integrity of communications. 

      Identity and access management tools should:

      • Provide access to assets based on cyber security risk to the system

      • Monitor anomalous access attempts as indicators of cyber security events

      • Provide user and device-to-device authorization of activities and source of data/commands

    Print Project List | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • PS183D: Information Assurance
    04-May-2016

    This project set focuses on security challenges that affect multiple operations domains, such as designing security into products, creating security metrics for the electric sector, and developing technical solutions for meeting security compliance requirements.

    • P183.012: Cyber Security Architecture
      14-Jun-2016

      For grid modernization, increased interconnection in electric sector devices is required and this will result in a larger attack surface that may be exploited by potential adversaries such as nation-states, terrorist organizations, malicious contractors, and disgruntled employees. A security architecture methodology that is used for attack vector analysis needs to be developed to support cyber security risk management in this new environment.

      The objective is to provide a common methodology that may be used by utilities of all sizes – from large investor owned utilities (IOUs) to smaller cooperatives and municipalities. EPRI is collaborating with other research efforts that are defining enterprise architecture methodologies to ensure that the security architecture methodology does not conflict with these other efforts.

      This research project is mapped to the following C2M2 domains: Risk Management (RM), Cybersecurity Program Management (CPM), and Threat and Vulnerability Management (TVM).

    • P183.013 Cyber Security Compliance
      20-Oct-2016

      Cyber security standards, guidance, and regulations have been developed as a result of continual threats to business and process control networks. In recent years, electric utilities that are part of the North American bulk electric system (BES) have established cyber security programs to ensure compliance with the critical infrastructure protection (CIP) standards of the North American Electric Reliability Corporation (NERC). New cyber security requirements for critical infrastructure are being introduced in other regions as well, such as the Network and Information Security (NIS) Directive of the European Commission. In addition, some states are developing cyber security requirements for the distribution sector of the grid.

      Compliance with cyber security regulations and cyber security requirements is non-trivial and requires IT staff and control system engineers to work together to implement and maintain a cyber security program for control systems.

      This research project is mapped to the following C2 M2 domains: Risk Management (RM), Asset, Change and Configuration Management (ACM), Identity and Access Management (IAM), Threat and Vulnerability Management (TVM), and Cyber Security Program Management (CPM). Note: compliance is referenced in all of the C2M2 domains, but this project focuses on the ones listed above.

    • P183.014 Cyber Security Metrics
      15-Jun-2016

      Over the past decade, the electric sector has produced both mandatory and voluntary standards and guidelines to address cyber security. Each of these attempts to enhance the security posture of a utility, despite the fact that each utility has unique environments, ownership structures, and functions for the overall reliability of the nation’s power grid. These standards and guidelines were developed in similar ways to the sector’s creation of documents in other fields—balancing of load and generation, management of reliability events, and other functions required for reliable operations. The science and engineering behind power systems dates back to the late 1800s, with thousands of studies and measurement behind each model used for planning and operations. Unfortunately, cyber security is not as mature—as a field, the science involved in protecting digital systems has only existed for a fraction of the history shared with power systems engineering. Over the past two decades, research has continued to evolve in the field of cyber security measurement. These advancements make it possible to implement a cyber security metrics program within any utility, regardless of size, organization, or ownership structure.

       

      There are several challenges with cyber security metrics. While there are many business and regulatory pressures driving utilities to improve process efficiency, there is also a lack of data sharing required to have a dialogue regarding “what metrics matter” in cyber security. As a result, security metrics routinely focus on standards development or other frameworks that may not be entirely appropriate for measurement.

      This research project is mapped to the following C2M2 domain: Risk Management (RM). (Note: metrics is not specifically referenced in the C2M2, but is used as part of risk management.)

    • P183.015 Security Supply Chain
      15-Jun-2016

      Commercially available information and communications technology (ICT) solutions present significant benefits including low cost, interoperability, and choice among competing vendors. These commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) solutions can be proprietary or open source and can meet the needs of a global base of customers. However, the same globalization and other factors that allow for such benefits also increase the risk of a threat event which can impact the ICT supply chain. These ICT supply chain risks may include insertion of malicious software and hardware.

      The project is mapped to the following C2M2 domains: Risk Management (RM), Threat and Vulnerability Management (TVM), and Supply Chain and External Dependencies Management (EDM).

Overview

Program Description

Demands to supply water to a growing population are increasing worldwide and having profound impacts on the use of limited water resources. The electric power industry requires large water quantities and is frequently subject to water shortages. It also discharges water that is no longer usable within the power plant, and needs to be able to comply with the steam electric power generating industry standards and regulations. Nations and regions worldwide are adopting regulations on discharge limits and improving water utilization for electricity generation. The adoption of new water-conserving technologies for power production can help alleviate pressures to reduce water withdrawals, consumption and discharges, while maintaining power plants’ abilities to meet demand for electricity.

The Electric Power Research Institute's (EPRI's) Water Management Technology program (Program 185) identifies, evaluates, and demonstrates cost-effective and reliable treatment technologies that support limiting pollutants discharged from a power plant. The program also evaluates the performance, operability, reliability, and cost of advanced cooling technologies designed to reduce water withdrawal and consumption while minimizing the impact on plant thermal efficiency. These technologies are applicable worldwide and equally to Rankine steam boiler and gas-fired combined-cycle units. To reduce water consumption, the program evaluates processes to recover moisture from the flue gas (Rankine or combined-cycle) and to enable re-use of wastewater streams within the power plant by removing species that cause scaling and/or corrosion.

Research Value

Program research helps facility owners develop effective water treatment compliance and water conservation strategies. As water discharge limits are becoming more stringent for selenium, mercury, arsenic, other trace metals and nutrients (nitrates/nitrites) tighten, power companies require independent performance and economic data on cost-effective, reliable treatment options. Where such technologies are not available or cost-effective, the program seeks and evaluates new processes that could meet the target discharge concentrations.

Program research also provides power companies with performance, thermal penalty, and cost data on cooling options that reduce or avoid the withdrawal and/or consumption of water. In-depth evaluations of currently-available approaches enable power companies to evaluate their near-term options with greater confidence. Identification, development, and evaluation of novel technologies (mostly found under EPRI’s Technology Innovation Program and transferred to this program after feasibility has been shown) can help power generators reduce their water withdrawal/consumption with less impact on plant thermal efficiency. Complementary work to demonstrate the benefits of water balance modeling, and the capabilities of water treatment technologies to render wastewater streams usable in plant processes, can enable power plant operators to reduce demand for fresh water.

Approach

EPRI seeks new wastewater treatment and conservation technologies that can support reduced pollutant discharge concentrations or reduce water consumption. Program 185 guides further development of technologies and provides independent performance, thermal efficiency, and cost evaluations. For wastewater treatment processes, the program generally uses the following approach:

  • Search for appropriate technologies (existing or emerging)
  • Screen promising processes via laboratory bench tests (e.g., “jar tests”)
  • Demonstrate proof-of-concept in pilot units treating actual wastewaters

The program follows a similar approach for water conservation and advanced cooling technologies. The program also utilizes the Water Research Center, located at Georgia Power’s Plant Bowen, to support proof-of-concept pilot tests and, possibly, near-commercial-scale system studies.

Program results are communicated through updates to members, reports, and educational briefings for policy makers and regulators. This program delivers:

  • Independent evaluations of wastewater treatment systems, including overall treatment performance and capital as well as operation and maintenance costs. Systems include physical/chemical, biological, and zero liquid discharge (ZLD).
  • Evaluations of cooling technologies that can reduce water withdrawal/consumption (especially fresh water) significantly, with much less degradation of plant thermal performance and fewer operations/maintenance issues than currently available options, such as air-cooled condensers. Many of these technologies can be used worldwide and on either boiler-based Rankine or gas-fired combined-cycle units.
  • Assessments of the ability to re-use wastewaters within the power plant, after appropriate treatment, and associated performance and cost projections.
  • Experiences in using a variety of water balance modeling tools to minimize overall fresh water consumption and pollutant discharge.
  • A database of emerging water treatment or conservation/reuse technologies of potential applicability to the power industry worldwide, to be used by EPRI for R&D planning and informing the industry of improved treatment options.
Accomplishments

Since this program’s inception in 2013, critical research has addressed plant water balance models, advanced cooling technology evaluations, and water treatment developments. Focus on hybrid cooling has resulted in two demonstration projects at the Water Research Center. In the area of water treatment, besides several technology developments centered on flue gas desulfurization (FGD), additional projects involving membrane techniques and innovative thermal evaporation have shown promise in highly concentrated wastewater streams, which indicates they could be applied to many potentially difficult-to-treat chemistry applications.

Many of the research activities in Program 185 will enhance the core deliverables of treatment guidelines and a five-year rotating plan of open and closed cooling water chemistry guidelines, followed by guidelines for physical chemical FGD wastewater optimization, biological treatment processes, and thermal evaporation and other ZLD approaches.

Key Activities

Program R&D for 2017 will address the treatment of selenium, mercury, arsenic, and nutrients in FGD blowdown as well as other constituents of interest such as boron and bromide. The program also will address methods of managing cooling tower water chemistry to reduce water consumption through increased cycles of concentration; options for biofouling control in cooling systems; moisture recovery from flue gas; and treatment systems to enable use of degraded waters for plant cooling. Specifically, the research will:

  • Seek novel water management technologies that improve pollutant removal and/or water conservation.
  • Develop biological treatment guidelines and physical/chemical wet FGD wastewater treatment guidelines for optimized performance.
  • Find, assess, and test promising technologies that cost-effectively remove trace metals including selenium, mercury, and arsenic; nutrients, and soluble species (e.g., boron and bromine) from power plant wastewaters. The emphasis will include both innovative physical/chemical and biological treatment processes and concerns with scaling and fouling of associated membrane filtration devices.
  • Discover and determine the effectiveness of scaling and deposition monitoring techniques that allow corrective action to be taken before a problem occurs. This will be supplemented with a software tool for identifying and mitigating formation of deposits.
  • Develop cooling water treatment guidelines that address challenges of biofouling while preserving environmental compliance with current and potential future regulations.
  • Prepare treatment and design consideration guidelines for the use of degraded water supplies, such as municipal wastewater or high salinity/brackish water that could be alternative water sources for freshwater power plant make-up.
  • Identify potential processes to recover water from evaporative plant losses or water vapor content in flue gas streams and test their effectiveness and durability.
  • Conduct evaluations of wastewater byproduct encapsulation applications, including at power plants where coal combustion byproducts are combined with water/wastewater and other materials for landfill application.
  • Identify and determine the feasibility of innovative approaches to remove scaling and corrosive compounds from wastewaters to allow their reuse in the power plant.

  • Economic and Performance Assessment of Membrane and Thermal Water Treatment Combinations for Desalination and Wastewater Applications
    14-Jun-2016

    As water scarcity increases around the world it is critical that electric utilities find new ways to consume less fresh water from local sources. This can be accomplished more immediately by water optimization within the plant, wastewater treatment including increasing reuse and technological innovation to reduce fresh water consumption. A concurrent path would also be to pursue desalination to provide water for use within the plant and/or to supplement fresh water to the local community. Power plants are a natural partner for desalination, which is a very energy intensive process, and cogeneration of fresh water and power at utilities in water scarce regions has been successfully demonstrated internationally.  The many water treatment systems existing in this scenario are usually evaluated as stand-alone technologies of either thermal evaporation or membrane treatment processes, depending on water chemistry and volume.  Combinations of these technologies can reduce the size of costly thermal systems by reducing feed volume with less costly membrane systems prior to subsequent thermal evaporation.  This project will address the advantages and disadvantages of potential combinations of desalination and wastewater treatment practices providing a selection guide to when and how a combination treatment strategy would be beneficial.

Overview

Program Description

Renewable energy is fundamentally changing the electricity industry's strategic landscape. Active industry engagement in development and deployment of renewable energy for power generation has increased significantly, and continued engagement is more critical than ever before. Renewable portfolio standards, financial incentives, concerns over energy security, desire for a diversified generation portfolio, continually declining capital costs, and efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will continue to drive renewable energy deployment.

Over the long term, renewable energy development will depend on renewables operating cost-effectively without mandates or subsidies. Research and development can improve the efficiency of various technologies in converting renewable energy resources to electricity. Improved operations and maintenance practices and technologies can reduce costs associated with utility-scale operations of renewable power plants. Up-to-date information is critical to explore new opportunities for deployment, operation, and maintenance of renewable generation. Finally, targeted research is necessary to reduce the cost of renewable generation, improve overall reliability, and facilitate widespread deployment.

The Electric Power Research Institute’s Renewable Generation program (Program 193) provides a portfolio of research and development opportunities that:

  • Assesses the status, performance, and cost of renewable generating technologies, including wind, solar, hydro, biomass, and geothermal;
  • Conducts targeted research and development to address critical issues relative to the technical assessment, operation, maintenance, and overall reliability of renewable generation resources;
  • Evaluates the technical and economic impacts of emerging renewable energy technology and O&M trends; and
  • Provides opportunities for members to engage in general-interest renewable generation activities, including workshops, tours, and other events.

Research Value

Renewable energy resources and their application in generating electricity most often are considered collectively when addressing key drivers in renewable energy deployment, including renewable portfolio standards, energy security, greenhouse gas emission reductions, and other issues. However, wind, solar photovoltaic, solar thermal, biomass, geothermal energy and hydropower options largely are unrelated technologically; each has its own developmental status, readiness timeline, industry drivers, and economic and technology challenges. EPRI's Renewable Generation program conducts targeted research to improve the performance, availability, and cost-effectiveness of existing renewable technologies and to develop new renewable technologies and applications. The program also provides objective cost and performance information for renewable technologies, helping participants:

  • Capitalize on market opportunities for renewable compliance and power purchases, resulting in improved decision-making;
  • Identify the appropriate role of diverse renewable resources in expanding new and sustainable generation capacity; and
  • Apply results from modeling, simulation, and future energy scenario analyses that will help guide decisions on renewable energy assets.

Through collaboration with key industry stakeholders, EPRI members guide development and demonstration of technologies that will optimize operating efficiency, reduce overall costs, and improve reliability of large-scale renewable generation.

In the face of increasing renewable generation penetration, EPRI’s Renewables Program provides current information on key renewable generation technologies, including technical performance and system costs.  The work undertaken enables power producers to most effectivity integrate renewables into their generation fleet and tackle the unique issues associated with renewable asset management.    

Approach

Value is delivered to members of Program 193 in a variety of ways: 

  • EPRI keeps members informed about global technical developments through advisory meetings, webcasts, and networking to share experiences and capitalize on the lessons learned by others.
  • Participants are able to identify and prioritize research needs and engage in technology-specific research and development projects that focus on specific areas of interest. Participants benefit from the collaborative development of solutions to common technology challenges that they could not afford to solve individually.
  • Through collaboration with technical experts across EPRI (e.g., operations and maintenance, nondestructive evaluation, renewable integration, energy storage, and energy and environmental analysis activities), Program 193 helps members learn about the latest technologies to improve energy recovery from renewable resources, understand the role of these energy resources, and helps develop and implement a robust research portfolio to address identified critical technology issues.
  • Transfer of technology to participants is achieved through technical reports and guidelines, participation in technology development activities, pilot-scale demonstrations and testing programs, technology applications at participant asset locations, technology interest groups and topical workshops, and engagement with key industry stakeholders and the general public.
Accomplishments
  • Modeling, data mining of cost information from completed projects, and financial analyses efforts have provided insights on renewable generation costs (capital and production) and technology trends that directly support integrated resource planning activities and future generation scenario analyses. Products include economic and energy scenario analyses, topical reports on renewable technology issues, and webcasts/meetings of strategic interest to members and key stakeholders. Recent topical analyses included conduit hydro technologies, biomass combined heat and power, and community solar.
  • EPRI activities at the Solar Technology Acceleration Center (SolarTAC) have expanded EPRI’s research capabilities to include reliability and performance testing in a real-world environment. Results address issues around site requirements, installation, commissioning, performance, reliability, and O&M for multiple solar technologies.
  • EPRI activities at the Southeastern Solar Research Center are providing valuable insights into solar photovoltaic performance in a variety of installation configurations in a humid environment, including short-term solar forecasting and long-term performance and reliability through accelerated aging.
  • Program 193 R&D has led to development of best practices and guidelines for wind turbine maintenance and performance optimization, including cost-effective nondestructive examination of wind turbine blades while in operation, best practices for managing wind farm end-of-warranty concerns, and maintenance guidelines.
  • EPRI activities in hydropower led to development and demonstration of a robotic inspection technology to cost-effectively inspect the surface and near-surface (i.e., subsurface) regions of hydro civil structures. This work is now being expanded to improve underwater inspection capabilities and enhance penstock integrity assessment.
  • General-interest activities in renewable generation technologies, including industry meetings, technical tours, and technology summits/workshops, provide valuable overviews of critical technology issues and identify future research needs.
Key Activities

Technology-specific opportunities for collaborative R&D will continue in 2017, enabling participants to engage in targeted R&D in individual renewable technologies of interest. Program 193 will continue to deliver cost and performance information to allow comparisons and better define the role of renewable generation among all generation options. The 2017 plan will focus on asset management and investigating strategies that optimize energy production cost effectively.  In addition, program activities include technical forums, conferences, site visits, and workshops on topics of common interest, allowing participants to pool their R&D funding to develop solutions to common technology challenges. Through collaboration with technical experts across EPRI (e.g., operations and maintenance, renewable integration, energy storage, nondestructive evaluation, component integrity, and energy/environmental analysis activities), members can learn about the latest technologies to improve energy recovery from renewable resources, understand the role of these energy resources, and help develop and implement a robust research portfolio to address identified critical technology issues.

Last Updated
  • PS193A: Renewables Technology Status, Cost and Performance
    15-Jun-2016

    Renewable generation is fundamentally changing the electricity industry's strategic landscape. Active industry engagement in development and deployment of renewable energy for power generation has increased significantly, and continued engagement is more critical than ever before. Renewable portfolio standards, financial incentives, concerns over energy security, consistent reductions in capital and operating costs, improvements in performance measures, and efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will continue to drive renewable energy deployment.  Information is critical to exploring new opportunities for deployment, operation, and maintenance of renewable generation. Effective resource planning and new generation development requires accurate cost and performance information for commercial renewable technologies.  It is equally important that utility staff understand the renewable generation market and how technology, costs and performances of renewable generation will trend over time. 

    Project Set 193A is the comprehensive, integrative program responsible for providing members with current and projected costs – capital, O&M, and levelized cost of electricity and technology advancements for renewable generation sources.  The program is considered a particular helpful resource that supports generation planning and project development.  The research in this project set is driven by utilities' needs to:

    • Assess the status, performance, and cost of renewable generating technologies
    • Address critical issues relative to the economics of renewable generation resources
    • Assist and guide investments in renewable energy and support long-term generation planning efforts

    Each renewable-resource specific technical report provides an overview of generation options including technology descriptions, performance characteristics, and near-term, emerging technology advancements that have the potential to positively impact the costs.  In addition, detailed capital and O&M costs are developed based on current market conditions and projected trends.  Costs are benchmarked against other sources with a great degree of effort on transparency in explaining variances.  LCOE estimates are estimated, along with probabilistic modeling to provide a comprehensive financial analysis.  

    • Solar Technology Status, Cost and Performance
      15-Jun-2016

      All utilities face the question of exactly where renewable generation will fit in the future of low-carbon electricity generation. According to U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA) data from March 2016, non-hydro renewables generated more than 10% of the U.S. electricity for the first time. There is a significant level of business and technical uncertainty as to which emerging renewable technologies will be most cost-effective, reliable, and durable in the long run. Utilities need a clear understanding of the opportunities and risks associated with renewable generation technologies. 

      While wind energy continues to hold a larger share of power generation, solar energy is experiencing record-setting growth. The installed cumulative solar capacity at the end of 2015 was 247 GW, a growth of approximately 30% over the installed solar capacity in 2015. Double-digit expansion is expected to continue in the near term, primarily with solar photovoltaics (PV). However, concentrating solar power (CSP) installations are expected to increase, particularly in international markets. As utility planners and others involved in generation portfolio decisions consider making new or expanded investments in solar power, they need accurate technical information to support their choices.

    • Waterpower Technology Status, Cost and Performance
      14-Jun-2016

      All utilities face the question of exactly where renewable generation will fit in their future low-carbon and diversified choices for electricity generation. There is a significant level of business and technical uncertainty as to which emerging renewable technologies will be most cost-effective, reliable, and durable in the long run. Utilities need a clearer understanding of the opportunities and risks of relying on renewable generation and how this likely will affect the bottom line. It is increasingly important for energy providers and the public to have the best available information about cost and performance of renewable generation options for use in corporate planning and strategy.

      As renewable energy penetration grows, storage technologies are increasingly becoming more important for grid stability and reducing capacity variability.  While much of the attention around storage has focused on batteries, specifically Li-ion batteries, there is a growing interest in pumped storage hydropower.  This technology is commercial; however, it has been limited due to either a lack of appropriate sites, capital intensity of projects or environmental concerns.  Closed-loop pumped storage, hydropower projects that are not continuously connected to naturally flowing water feature, have the potential of being an alternative that can be implemented with little impact to the environment and potentially less expensive than traditional open-looped pumped storage projects. 

    • Wind Power Technology Status, Cost and Performance
      15-Jun-2016

      All utilities face the question of exactly where renewable generation will fit in the future of low-carbon electricity generation. There is a significant level of business and technical uncertainty as to which emerging renewable technologies will be most cost-effective, reliable, and durable in the long run. Utilities need a clear understanding of the opportunities and risks associated with renewable generation technologies. 

      Of the growth in renewables, energy from wind continues to be a significant contributor.  The installed cumulative wind capacity at the end of 2015 was 423 GW, a growth of about 17% over the installed wind capacity in 2014. Double-digit growth is expected to continue in the near term.  As utility planners and others involved in generation portfolio decisions consider making new or expanded investments in wind power, they need accurate technical information to support their choices.

  • PS193B: Wind
    25-Jan-2017

    Renewable energy is changing the electricity industry's strategic landscape. Even though wind power technologies have advanced significantly in recent years, obstacles continue to stand in the way of widespread deployment, effective integration within the electricity grid, and sustainable long-term performance. 

    Access to up-to-date information on wind technology innovations, targeted research, and large-scale demonstrations, are necessary to reduce capital and operating costs, minimize environmental impacts, and increase reliability.  All of those will ultimately help improve the attractiveness of future wind energy deployment on-shore and off-shore.

    The key to the Wind Area of the Renewables program is to provide:

    • Analyses on the degree of maturity for wind turbine components
    • Evaluate, assess, and develop advanced technologies that support wind turbine operation and NDE inspections
    • Demonstrate technologies and their integration in the existing fleet and future deployments
    • Advanced asset management tools
    • Maintenance guides for critical components including life extension strategies and performance monitoring to optimize reliability and reduce O&M cost 
    • P193B Wind Power Technology and Asset Management Optimization
      10-Mar-2017

      Access to up-to-date information on technology innovation and potential, as well as targeted research and large-scale demonstrations, are necessary to reduce capital and operating costs, minimize environmental impacts, and increase reliability, improving the attractiveness of future wind energy deployment. Objective assessments are needed of the status, the technical and economic feasibility, and the requirements for further development and demonstration of new wind turbines and components of emerging technologies. The needed R&D scope includes blades, rotors, drive trains, gearboxes, generators and power electronics, sensor controls, towers, foundations, and other components for both land-based and offshore wind projects.

      At the end of 2016, the rated capacity of worldwide wind power generation reached 481 gigawatts (GW) and U.S. capacity reached 83 GW. Effective management of the growing fleet of wind turbines requires asset management tools to monitor, operate, and maintain these machines to maximize reliability and power generation and optimize O&M total cost.

    • Wind Farms End of Life Decommissioning Options
      15-Jun-2016

      Wind farm decommissioning (including dismantling of turbines and towers and site remediation) options and costs may have a significant economic impact at the end of life (EOL) or when purchasing a wind farm from a previous owner.  Salvage value of material and equipment typically only contribute to a small fraction of the EOL expenses.  There are many practical lessons that can be learned from European and Canadian countries that have regulations that require wind farm owners to set aside funding for decommissioning activities. 

      There are a limited number of studies that have analyzed the EOL options and provided cost estimations for the work needed to properly remediate a wind farm site.  This work will provide insight and guidance on the necessary activities and costs to properly decommission a wind farm site.  That information can then be used to help secure those funds during the operational life of the asset.   

    • Wind Turbines Advanced Control Strategies Technology Review
      15-Jun-2016

      Large wind turbines require sustainable control solutions to increase energy capture, reduce structural loads and guarantee safety, reliability and availability.  With the proper controls strategy, hardware redundancy can also be minimized.  A technology review of these key issues for the wind industry could potentially support the goal of reducing the levelized cost of electricity (LCOE) through increased energy production and reduced capital and O&M costs.

  • PS193C: Solar
    15-Jun-2016

    At the end of 2015, approximately 250 GWdc of solar power was installed on a global cumulative basis. Half of this capacity is utility-scale/central station PV plants. This subset of solar PV installations is the primary focus of the Solar project set (PS193C). Utility-scale installations have helped reduce solar PV's cost of electricity through reductions in capital expenses (e.g., progress along manufacturing learning curves), operating expenses (e.g., continuous improvement processes and scale economies in O&M), and technology innovations (e.g., PV module power increases). Continued advances along these themes are likely to bring solar PV's cost of electricity closer to unsubsidized, cost-competitiveness, further increasing its deployment.

    Existing solar PV deployments are serving as informational feedback loops to drive future learning. Record capacity installations are expected to continue globally, with 66 GWdc predicted in 2016 and 68 GWdc in 2017.  It is anticipated that cost reductions will happen incrementally through deepening understanding of existing technologies and processes, with the possibility of breakthrough innovations accelerating reductions. Greater understanding of plant performance is needed to better predict and optimize lifetime costs against lifetime energy production. As capital expenses continue to decrease,  operating expenses become a more important driver of solar’s cost of electricity, both in terms of its expense and maintaining energy output at desired or contractually-bound levels. Accurate and predictive knowledge of technology performance and reliability will reduce project risk and/or increase returns on investment. At the system level, it is equally important to have a holistic understanding of a solar plant’s life cycle—from its design through to its decommissioning—in order to optimize its lifetime costs against its lifetime energy. Increased industry learning and collaboration is needed to move away from a near-term $/W focus to a longer-term lifetime energy versus lifetime costs focus (i.e., levelized cost of electricity).

    Work in Project Set 193C is divided into 3 research themes to provide practical understanding and guidance to key industry needs, including:

    • Research and in-depth analysis to better predict, validate, and understand lifetime energy production of solar technologies
    • Gather industry best practices, standards, and costs associated with solar plants, from design to decommissioning
    • Provide objective, unbiased analysis on rapidly changing market, costs, and technology to help inform utility decision making

    These efforts are closely coordinated with and designed to complement work undertaken in other sectors and programs within EPRI, such as Energy Storage and Distributed Generation program (P94), Bulk Power System Integration of Variable Generation (P173), Integration of Distributed Energy Resources program (P174), Technology Assessment, Market Analysis, and Generation Planning program (P178), Distribution Systems program (P180), and other project sets within the Renewable Generation (P193) Program.

    • Analysisd of PV Plant Energy Losses
      15-Jun-2016

      The energy produced by new utility-scale PV plants has increased as better plant design, technology, and lessons learned are incorporated. Part of this increase has come from minimizing plant losses. This report will help readers better understand loss factors within a plant, aid design of future plants, and/or inform benchmarking of existing plants.

    • Comprehensive Plant Performance Comparison & Analysis
      15-Jun-2016

      There are many complex factors, techniques, standards, and measurements to be considered and understood. This report intends to provide a comprehensive, pragmatic, and applicable guide for understanding utility-scale PV plant performance. Furthermore, this report provides a knowledge repository and foundation to develop more targeted, concise findings for members.

    • Considerations for Due Diligence and Acquisition of Mid-life PV Plants
      15-Jun-2016

      It is anticipated that the first-time owner of many PV plants will not be its only owner. In the U.S., the Investment Tax Credit and accelerated depreciation schedule have a five year time window to fully extract their benefit (and not be subject to recapture). After five years, it may be financially preferable for the original owners to sell the plant and extract cash for other investments. Short-term thinking in upfront $/W terms may create long-term technical and financial ramifications for the second-owner (and beyond).

    • Correlating O&M to Lifetime Energy Production: Methods and Case Studies
      15-Jun-2016

      The PV industry lacks a clear understanding of how operations and maintenance (O&M) activities affect lifetime energy. It is not apparent how often or which maintenance activities should be done to achieve contractual or internal targets over the life of a plant.

    • Quantifying the Impact of Quality along the PV Supply Chain – Equipment, Plant, and Workmanship
      15-Jun-2016

      It is widely expected that PV plant capital expenses (e.g., overnight $/W) will continue to decline in the coming years. Module prices continue their downward pricing trajectory and some Engineering, Procurement, and Construction (EPC) firms are reducing margins to gain market share as PV installations continue to grow year-on-year globally. Meeting these cost reduction targets can come at the sake of quality, which is often overlooked when projects are judged by $/W instead of LCOE. There is a need to better quantify the impact of quality along the PV supply chain.

    • Solar adn Distributed Energy Resources Hotline
      15-Jun-2016

      When timely answers to pressing solar questions are needed, a hotline into industry experts is beneficial. The industry moves rapidly and, furthermore, it is not feasible to explore all corner cases in EPRI reports.

    • Solar Industry Updates
      15-Jun-2016

      The solar industry’s rapid pace of innovation, evolution, and maturation can make it difficult to keep up with trends or make coherent sense of the constant barrage of industry headlines. This series of newsletters will provide analysis of front line PV market topics that reside at the intersection of the policy/regulatory, technology, and economic areas.

    • Solar Power Fact Book
      15-Jun-2016

      Compared to other generation options, solar has many unique aspects including its technology, performance, economics, and environmental impacts. Minimizing the solar learning curve is important for quickly and efficiently utilizing internal staff and resources. Furthermore, having a technically accessible and convenient compendium of these topics can assist briefings at any technical skill level and/or rank within the organization.

    • Technical and Cost Considerations for the Decommissioning and Disposal of PV Plants
      15-Jun-2016

      Globally, 80% of utility-scale PV plants have been built in the past 5 years. These plants are expected to last at least 25 years, meaning the industry has largely ignored end-of-life considerations (particularly in the U.S.). It is unknown what financial and technical issues will be encountered during the decommissioning and disposal of a PV plant. In fact, some older plants are already needing to find disposal solutions as modules break and plants are reconfigured or decommissioned.

    • The Changing Marginal Value of PV as Deployment Increases
      15-Jun-2016

      Globally, the electricity supply mix is rapidly changing for a variety of market and policy-based reasons, often favoring increased deployment of renewable energy. From an aggregate perspective, increasing supply more than demand will decrease electricity prices. This report explores the issues and nuances of marginal value changes for non-dispatchable generation assets as their penetration increases, with a focus on PV. The effect of plant size (e.g., residential vs. utility-scale) on marginal value is also explored.

Overview

Program Description

Rising operating costs, increased competition from other generating sources, and regulatory pressures have increased the need to improve plant heat rates. Heat rate improvements bear a direct relationship to tonnage releases of all air emissions, including CO2.  The integration of heat rate assessment capability into retrofits of operating plants and new plant designs is critical to ensuring the optimal efficiency in plant operations.

The focus of the Electric Power Research Institute’s (EPRI’s) Heat Rate Improvement program (Program 194) is to improve operating plant heat rate, independent of the fuel fired. The program will advance the state of the art, benefitting all power generating companies -- including those now starting performance improvement programs and those with vast experience and mature programs.

The efforts behind improving heat rate require a broad understanding of power plant design, operation, maintenance, ambient conditions, thermal sciences, combustion, and the type of fuel fired. To be successful, a holistic view must be taken to ensure results are both cost-effective and do not create problems elsewhere in the plant. The Heat Rate Improvement program activities include research on thermodynamics, auxiliary power consumption, heat transfer, plant processes, controls, new hardware, fluid dynamics, measurement, and software, in addition to issues related to fuel quality and the combustion process.

Research Value

The Heat Rate Improvement program focuses on a holistic approach to cost-effectively enhance power plant efficiency without creating side effects. Heat rate improvements:

  • Yield significant savings in fuel costs and are by far the lowest-cost and a proven and commercially available method for reducing CO2 emissions. 
  • Improve overall combined-cycle plant performance, permitting those sites to reduce fuel costs per MW as their capacity factors increase.
  • Can enable program members to achieve substantial cost savings through improved boiler performance, regained capacity, and increased flexibility in fuel sourcing.
  • Can reveal reliability related problems in the quest to identify performance or thermal efficiency problems, permitting timely maintenance and a reduction of generation costs.
  • Enhance operational flexibility by improving plant performance at part and low load.
Approach

For more than three decades, EPRI has led the power industry in developing, advancing, and demonstrating cost-effective heat rate improvements via new technologies, hardware, software, and best operating/programmatic practices for bettering efficiency at minimal cost and maximum reliability. More recently, EPRI has led the industry in identifying and quantifying cost-effective solutions to operability and performance issues associated with baseload and flexible operations, heat rate, and fuel quality impacts. 

Accomplishments
  • Site evaluations for production optimization, auxiliary power consumption, combined-cycle plant performance, and boiler air in-leakage reduction, which provide participating companies with the framework to apply these methods to improve plant performance.
  • Analyzing the effects of flexible operations on plant performance and providing methods to mitigate the adverse components.
  • Identifying and evaluating new monitoring methods for plant components, systems, and fleets.
  • Evaluating coal flow rate measurements methods, determining methods to balance coal pipe flow rates, and analyzing the effects of those improvements.
  • Development of sets of routine performance test guidelines, permitting plants and power companies to conduct tests more frequently and with fewer resources.
  • Sponsorship of workshops, conferences, and webcasts in which funders and other key industry participants can share ideas and best practices, and outline needed solutions.
Key Activities

The program R&D for 2017 will continue to focus on a holistic approach to improve the power plant heat rate independent of the fuel fired. Specific efforts may include:

  • Condenser performance advances: This project follows the recent work done on measurements of very low pressures and evaluation of the application of coatings and potential modifications and/or physical changes to enhance heat transfer to improve the condenser’s performance.
  • Evaluation of CEMS as a measure of heat rate: Following the recent work done by EPRI in this field, this project will conduct additional field evaluations to determine the current accuracies and assess potential modifications to improve the application of technologies.
  • Evaluation of automated methods to identify sources of boiler air in-leakage: This R&D evaluates the installation of acoustical sensors to detect changes in boiler air in-leakage on a more real-time basis, including air in-leakage in areas with limited access.
  • Modifications and actions to improve combined-cycle plant heat rate: This project evaluates the potential of successful heat rate improvement activities in coal-fired plants for application in combined-cycle units.
  • Sustainability of heat rate improvements: This R&D estimates the sustainability of common heat rate improvements, determines the degradation rates for those heat rate improvement actions and modifications, and determines costs to maintain the improvement or slow the degradation rate.
  • Improving startups to reduce costs and optimize heat rate: This multi-year project will identify potential improvements to unit startup activities to optimize heat rate without increasing maintenance costs. Both hardware modifications and new operational techniques will be evaluated. 
  • Improved fluid flow measurements: Methods to measure key flow rates (e.g., attemperation) will be evaluated in an attempt to both improve plant efficiency and minimize the deleterious effects of excessive flow rates.

Last Updated
  • Evaluate Condenser Hydrophobic Nano-Coating
    04-May-2016

    Steam condenser performance has a large, and often detrimental, effect on power plant heat rate.  The steam power cycle, prevalent in all steam power plants, is based on the rejection of low temperature waste heat and the condensing of the steam exhausted from the low pressure turbines.  Condensers provide that function by passing a large volume of cooling water through thousands of tubes which are placed directly below the steam turbine’s exhaust.   Power plant operators and designers have sought to improve the heat transfer in the condenser to minimize the adverse effects on plant performance.  Their methods have included periodic cleaning of the raw water side of condenser tubes, minimizing the tube wall thickness, and using materials more conducive to heat transfer for the tube walls. 

    But very little attention has been paid to the steam side of condenser tubes until recently.  Placing a very thin coating on the exterior of the tubes to enhance condensation and heat transfer may be an option to improve condenser performance and that of the entire power plant.  Recently nano-coatings have been developed to potentially make the tube surfaces more hydrophobic, which could improve heat transfer.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Evaluate Reductions of HRSG Pressure Drop
    13-Jun-2016

    Increases in the gas side pressure drop in HRSGs readily translate into performance penalties.  The degradation of heat transfer reduces steam production and temperatures, while excessive pressure drops limit gas turbine performance.  HRSG internals due to their geometry and material of construction combined with impurities in the turbine exhaust gases have experienced increasing pressure drops.  Methods to reduce the pressure drop across the HRSG can be explored to improve combined cycle plant performance.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Evaluation of Automated Methods to Identify Sources of Boiler Air In-leakage
    04-May-2016

    Boiler air inleakage degrades power plant performance. When occurring upstream of a steam generator’s O2 probes, it can drive the furnace into a super-substoichiometric condition, potentially increasing the damage to internal components, increasing unburned carbon, affecting ash sales, limiting NOx reduction levels, and decimating boiler performance. Independent of its location, the unplanned-for increase in flow through the backpass of the unit will push the limits of induced draft fan capabilities and, under some circumstances, may eventually cause a unit derate. The excess flow passing through particulate collection devices, such as electrostatic precipitators and baghouses, sharply reduces their collection efficiencies and may increase SO3 levels.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Evaluation of Cooling Tower Performance Improvements
    04-May-2016

    Cooling Towers are in use at over 200 major electric generating plants in the United States, representing approximately 800 units and a total of over 210,000 MW. Most new power plants are required to use cooling towers instead of once-through cooling systems. Cooling towers and associated systems cause significant loss of availability and heat rate penalties in both nuclear and fossil-fired power plants.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Evaluation of Potential Combined Cycle Plant Heat Rate Improvements
    04-May-2016

    Combined cycle power plants are now operating with higher capacity factors, making heat rate improvements a priority to reduce fuel costs and emissions.  EPRI has been on the forefront in identifying different actions and modifications to improve combined cycle plant heat rate.  Actions to improve heat rate will only occur if cost justified.  That justification requires a precise value for the potential heat rate improvement instead of a range or estimate.  Hence the industry needs a methodology to determine the heat rate improvement value and gains through its demonstration and ultimate application.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Improved Fluid Flow Measurements
    04-May-2016

    A reliable measurement of key power plant flow rates is essential for optimal control, performance monitoring, and performance improvements.  Many of the devices used for continuous flow measurement have typically been in service for the life of the plant and their actual condition may not be well understood.  Several avenues of potential degradation exist, which can affect the accuracy of the flow rate measurement.  The nuclear power industry has struggled for decades with feedwater flow measurement challenges, specifically the phenomena of Venturi fouling.  Higher levels of plant performance and flexible operations are now expected for the existing coal and gas-fired fleets, which will require reliable data.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Improving Unit Startups to Reduce Costs and Optimize Heat Rate
    04-May-2016

    Caught between the requirements of environmental regulations, low gas prices permitting higher capacity factors of combined cycle units, and the variations due to renewable generation, the operating environment for formerly base-loaded coal plants has become more challenging.   All types of fossil-fired units are experiencing more startups.  In addition to the increased wear and tear on the plant components, those startups come with a substantial cost for fuel, aux power, labor, and other materials.  Through the evaluation of startup processes, and potential procedural and hardware improvements, unit startups may be optimized leading to the realization of heat rate improvements and cost savings.

    Print Project | View Full Project Overviews in Member Center
  • Sustainability of Heat Rate Improvements
    04-May-2016

    In the recent push to improve heat rate many options have been identified.  Power plant owners and operators in their quest to balance the competing needs for scarce budget funds must decide which heat rate improvements to pursue and have little guidance on the lifetime or sustainability of those heat rate improvement actions.  If a company invests millions of dollars into a physical modification, how much or little of the resulting improvement still exist in 2, 5, or even 10 years?  And can actions be taken to reduce the rate of degradation?
